heading: Double jeopardy
HeadNote.description:
Double jeopardy - Offence of criminal intention for glorification of sati under S.5 - Is not the same as criminal intention to violate or defy prohibitory order - Hence, Art.20(2) is not attracted.

Article 20(2) of the Constitution provides that no person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offence more than once. To attract applicability of Article 20(2) there must be a second prosecution and punishment for the same offence for which the accused has been prosecuted and punished previously. A subsequent trial or a prosecution and punishment are not barred if the ingredients of the two offences are distinct.  [Para 8]

The rule against double jeopardy is stated in the maxim nemo debet bis vexari pro una et eadem causa. It is a significant basic rule of Criminal Law that no man shall be put in jeopardy twice for one and the same offence. The rule provides foundation for the pleas of autrefois acquit and autrefois convict. The manifestation of this rule is to be found contained in S.26 of the General Clauses Act, 1897, S.300 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and S.71 of the Indian Penal Code.		 [Para 9]

The gist of the offence under S.5 is the commission of an act, which amounts to glorification of Sati. It is the Commission of act by itself, which is made punishable on account of the same having been declared and defined as an offence by S.5 of the Ordinance/Act. The gist of the offence under S.6 of the Ordinance/Act is the contravention of the prohibitory order issued by the Collector and District Magistrate. Section 5 punishes the glorification of Sati. Section 6 punishes the contravention of prohibitory order issued by the Collector and District Magistrate, which is a punishment for the defiance of the lawful authority of the State to enforce law and order in the society. What is punished under Section 5 is the criminal intention for glorification of sati; what is punishable under Section 6 is the criminal intention to violate or defy the prohibitory order issued by the lawful authority. It cannot be said that the ingredients of the offences contemplated by S.5 and S.6(3) are the same or that they necessarily and in all cases overlap or that prosecution and punishment for the offences under Ss.5 and 6(3) - both are violative of Article 20(2) of the Constitution or of the rule against double jeopardy.  [Para 13]

heading: Departmental enquiry
Right of representation
Reversed.	 [Para 10,11]
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Art.14 - Departmental enquiry - Right of representation - Rules giving restricted right by providing that the friend cannot address Inquiry Officer or cross-examine witnesses - Not invalid or unconstitutional.

There is no vested or absolute right in any charge-sheeted employee to representation either through a counsel or through any other person unless the statute or rules/standing orders provide for such a right. Moreover, the right to representation through some one, even if granted by the rules, can be granted as a restricted or controlled right. Refusal to grant representation through an agent does not violate the principles of natural justice.   [Para 10]

Rule 153(8) only provides for assistance to a charge-sheeted employee by an agent. Thus, a restricted right of representation has been granted by Rule 153(8). Even if no right of assistance had been granted by the rules, there would be no illegality or unconstitutionality. How then can it be said that when a restricted right is granted, the said restricted right is unconstitutional ?  2001(5) Andh L.T. 543 (FB) - Reversed.	 [Para 10,11]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Acquisition of land under MRTP Act
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land under MRTP Act - Provisions of S.24 of new Land Acquisition Act, 2013 not applicable on such acquisition - Objects of MRTP Act and Act of 2013 are wholly dissimilar - They operate in two different fields - That apart, MRTP Act continues to make reference to repealed Land Acquisition Act, 1894 and not to the Act of 2013 - Even though there is some incidental overlapping in matters of acquisition, provisions of S.24 of 2013 Act clearly not applicable which is applicable only to acquisitions "initiated" under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

	After considering the provisions of the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning Act, 1966 [MRTP Act, for short] and the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013 [RFCTLARR Act, for short] and the true intent and object of enacting the same, it appears that both the enactments are self-contained codes and the provisions of Section 24 of the RFCTLARR Act would not be applicable to the acquisitions under the provisions of the MRTP Act for varied reasons.

	The MRTP Act is a self-contained code. The State Legislation has enacted the MRTP Act in exercise of its powers under Entries 5 and 18 of List II of Schedule VII, whereas the RFCTLARR Act is enacted by the Parliament in exercise of its legislative powers under Entry 42 of List III of the VIIth Schedule. A complete scheme has been provided under the MRTP Act for attaining the object of planned development. The paramount object of MRTP Act is planning and acquisition of land is incidental, that too for a very limited purpose. A reference to the provisions of Land Acquisition Act, 1894 in some of the provisions of the MRTP Act is made only for determining the compensation and completing the process of acquisition. The MRTP Act and RFCTLARR Act are wholly dissimilar and have different objects.

	The reference to the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 in the MRTP Act, having been held to be a reference by incorporation, the provisions of Section 24 of RFCTLARR Act, which is enacted after the repeal of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 cannot be read into the provisions of MRTP Act, specially when the MRTP Act is not yet amended and its provisions do not make a reference to the RFCTLARR Act.

	Even assuming that the other provisions of the RFCTLARR Act were to apply to the acquisitions under the MRTP Act, it could be gathered from the clear and unambiguous provisions of Section 24 of the RFCTLARR Act, by applying the salutary principles of interpretation that the provisions of Section 24 of the RFCTLARR Act would apply only to the acquisitions 'initiated' under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894. The word 'initiated' has been defined in the Oxford English Dictionary to mean 'cause, process or action to begin'. The proceedings for acquisition under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 commence or begin with the issuance of the Section 4 notification. A reference is also made to the Section 4 notification in the proviso to Section 24 (2) which goes to show that the provisions of Section 24 of the RFCTLARR Act would be applicable only to the acquisitions under the Land Acquisition Act. The heading of the Section which is one of the internal aids of interpretation also shows that the provisions of Section 24 of the RFCTLARR Act would apply only to the proceedings 'initiated' under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

	Although the provisions of RFCTLARR Act would not per se apply to the MRTP Act specially when the MRTP Act is not yet amended and continues to make a reference to the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 by incorporation, the provisions of RFCTLARR Act insofar as they relate to determination of compensation will have to be read into the MRTP Act, so as to save some of the provisions of the MRTP Act from the vice of discrimination.

(1973) 1 SCC 500, 2011 ALL SCR 176 Ref. to. 		 [Para 10,11,12]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Provisions of MRTP Act and Land Acquisition Act, 2013 whether overlapping - By applying doctrine of "pith and substance" it can be seen that true intent of both Acts is different - There is only fractional overlapping but that is saved by doctrine of "incidental overlapping" - Both the Acts are within legislative competence of State and Centre - They can co-exist and operate with compatibility.

	By applying the doctrine of 'pith and substance', it could be seen that the true intent of both the enactments is different. The MRTP Act deals with planning and development, the acquisition of land being incidental for achieving the object of the Act, whereas the Land Acquisition Act and the RFCTLARR Act [i.e. the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013] are enacted with an object of acquiring the land for public purposes and companies, for determination of the compensation and for the rehabilitation and resettlement of the affected. Both the Laws i.e. the MRTP Act and the RFCTLARR Act are wholly dissimilar, they operate in different fields and have different objects.

	The State Legislature has enacted the MRTP Act in exercise of its powers under Entries 5 and 18 of List II of Schedule VII, whereas the RFCTLARR Act is enacted by the Parliament in exercise of its legislative powers under Entry 42 of List III of the VIIth Schedule. A complete scheme has been provided under the MRTP Act for attaining the object of planned development. The paramount object of MRTP Act is planning and acquisition of land is incidental, that too for a very limited purpose. A reference to the provisions of Land Acquisition Act, 1894 in some of the provisions of the MRTP Act is made only for determining the compensation and completing the process of acquisition. The MRTP Act and RFCTLARR Act are wholly dissimilar and have different objects.

	After considering the scheme of the two enactments, even if a fractional overlapping is accepted between the two Statutes i.e. the MRTP Act and the RFCTLARR Act, the same is saved by the doctrine of 'incidental overlapping', specially when the Centre and the State have enacted the Laws i.e. the RFCTLARR Act and the MRTP Act respectively, within the legislative competence and both the Acts can coexist and operate with compatibility.

AIR 1970 SC 1771, 2011 ALL SCR 176 Ref. to. 		 [Para 10]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Deemed lapse of acquisition proceedings - Conditions to be satisfied.

Any determination under S.24 (2) must proceed sequentially. First, the factum of an Award under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, must be clearly established. The said Award must predate the commencement of the Act, i.e., 01.01.2014., by at least five years (or more), i.e., the Award must have been passed on or before 01.01.2009. This having been established, if possession is found to have not been taken, or compensation not paid, then the proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed. Thereafter, the appropriate Government, if it so chooses, may reinitiate acquisition proceedings in respect of the same land, but under the 2013 Act's regime. Each and every deeming operation under Section 24(2) requires unambiguously and unvaryingly that a factual conclusion be drawn about the passing of the Award under Section 11, of the 1894 Act, on or before 01.01.2009; further, the absence of compensation having been paid or the absence of possession having been taken by the acquirer, either of these, must be a proven point of fact, as a threshold requirement attracting the lapse.   [Para 2]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Expression "compensation has not been paid" in S.24(2) of 2013 Act
HeadNote.description:
Expression "compensation has not been paid" in S.24(2) of 2013 Act - Meaning and effect on subject acquisition - Land acquisition more than five years prior to commencement of 2013 Act - Persons interested not consenting to receive compensation - Compensation money deposited in government treasury - Cannot be treated as equivalent to compensation paid to land owners / persons interested - Held, in such a case land acquisition proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed under S.24(2) of the 2013 Act. 

For the purposes of Section 24(2), the compensation shall be regarded as "paid" if the compensation has been offered to the person interested and such compensation has been deposited in the court where reference under Section 18 can be made on happening of any of the contingencies contemplated under Section 31(2) of the 1894 Act. In other words, the compensation may be said to have been "paid" within the meaning of Section 24(2) when the Collector (or for that matter Land Acquisition Officer) has discharged his obligation and deposited the amount of compensation in court and made that amount available to the interested person to be dealt with as provided in Sections 32 and 33. 1894 Act being an expropriatory legislation has to be strictly followed. The procedure, mode and manner for payment of compensation are prescribed in Part V (Sections 31-34) of the 1894 Act. The Collector, with regard to the payment of compensation, can only act in the manner so provided. It is settled proposition of law that where a power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all. Other methods of performance are necessarily forbidden.

The deposit of compensation amount in the government treasury is of no avail and cannot be held to be equivalent to compensation paid to the landowners/persons interested. The subject land acquisition proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed under Section 24(2) of the 2013 Act.  [Para 17,18,20]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Lapsing of acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Lapsing of acquisition - Possession not taken and compensation, too, not paid - Is sufficient to grant protection u/S.24(2) of the Act of 2013.

Any determination under Section 24(2) of the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act, 2013, must proceed sequentially. First, the factum of an Award under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, must be clearly established. The said Award must predate the commencement of the Act, i.e., 01.01.2014., by at least five years (or more), ie., the Award must have been passed on or before 01.01.2009. This having been established, if possession is found to not have been taken, or compensation not paid, then the proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed. Thereafter, the appropriate Government, if it so chooses, may reinitiate acquisition proceedings in respect of the same land, but under the 2013 Act's regime.           [Para 1,5]

HeadNote.description:
Declaration of deemed lapse of acquisition - Procedure. 

Any determination under provision of S.24(2) must proceed sequentially. First, the factum of an Award under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, must be clearly established. The said Award must predate the commencement of the Act, i.e., 01.01.2014., by at least five years (or more), ie., the Award must have been passed on or before 01.01.2009. This having been established, if possession is found to not have been taken, or compensation not paid, then the proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed. Thereafter, the appropriate Government, if it so chooses, may reinitiate acquisition proceedings in respect of the same land, but under regime of the 2013Act.

Each and every deeming operation under Section 24(2) requires unambiguously and unvaryingly that a factual conclusion be drawn about the passing of the Award under Section 11, of the 1894 Act, on or before 01.01.2009; further, the absence of compensation having been paid or the absence of possession having been taken by the acquirer, either of these, must be a proven point of fact, as a threshold requirement attracting the lapse.

2014(2) ALL MR 923 (S.C.),  2014(6) ALL MR 451 (S.C.), 2015(2) ALL MR 940 (S.C.) Rel.on. 			          [Para 1,2,5]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Period of five years
HeadNote.description:
Period of five years - Period during which land acquisition proceedings remained stayed on account of stay or injunction granted by any court cannot be excluded.

From a plain reading of Section 24 of the 2013 Act it is clear that Section 24(2) of the 2013 Act does not exclude any period during which the land acquisition proceeding might have remained stayed on account of stay or injunction granted by any court. In the same Act, proviso to Section 19(7) in the context of limitation for publication of declaration under Section 19(1) and the Explanation to Section 69(2) for working out the market value of the land in the context of delay between preliminary notification under Section 11 and the date of the award, specifically provide that the period or periods during which the acquisition proceedings were held up on account of any stay or injunction by the order of any court be excluded in computing the relevant period. In that view of the matter it can be safely concluded that the Legislature has consciously omitted to extend the period of five years indicated in Section 24(2) even if the proceedings had been delayed on account of an order of stay or injunction granted by a court of law or for any reason.

Clearly the Legislature has, in its wisdom, made the period of five years under Section 24(2) of the 2013 Act absolute and unaffected by any delay in the proceedings on account of any order of stay by a court. The plain wordings used by the Legislature are clear and do not create any ambiguity or conflict. In such a situation, the court is not required to depart from the literal rule of interpretation.

(2002) 3 SCC 53 Rel.on. [Para 9,10]

There is nothing in the language of the proviso to restrict the meaning of the words used in Section 24(2) mandating that the proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed if the award is five years or more than five years' old but the physical possession of the land has not been taken over or the compensation has not been paid. The law is trite that when the main enactment is clear and unambiguous, a proviso can have no effect so as to exclude from the main enactment by implication what clearly falls within its express terms.

AIR 1959 SC 713 Rel. on.

(2014) 6 SCC 564 Ref. to.      [Para 11]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Compensation for land owners
HeadNote.description:
Compensation for land owners - Land in rural area - Cl.2 of First Schedule giving discretion to appropriate Govt. to provide for multiplier factor ranging from 1 to 2 based on actual distance of project from urban area - Govt. Notification dt.13/8/2014 pegging maximum multiplier factor only to 1.10 for all land in rural area which are more than 25 kms. away from urban area - Held, arbitrary discriminatory to land owners whose lands are situated at a very long distance i.e. more than 100 kms. from urban area - Notification quashed.

It is required to be kept in mind that the notifications or rules which are examples of delegated legislation, cannot override the statutory mandate. The subordinate legislation has to supplement and not to supplant the statute. The benefit granted by the statute cannot be nullified by the rules framed thereunder.  Viewed from this angle, perusal of Clause 2 of the First Schedule to the Act of 2013 makes it clear that the same prescribes discretion regarding determination of different slabs of multiplier factors for multiplying the market value of land in rural areas depending upon its distance from urban areas. Neither any discretion nor corresponding guideline is provided for limiting the multiplier factor to a figure below 2 and, as such, the decision of the appropriate Government reflected in the notifications dt.19/3/2014 and dt.13/8/2014 cannot be upheld. The same is bad in law and deserves to be quashed and set aside.

A subordinate legislation which is not backed up by any statutory guideline under the substantive law and opposed to the enforcement of a legal right would not be valid. In this context, if it is accepted that discretion to limit the multiplier factor to any figure between 1 and 2 is delegated to the appropriate Government by the Act of 2013, then such delegation would be arbitrary as well as violative of provisions of Article 14 of the Constitution as there is no corresponding criteria or standard so as to enable the appropriate Government to act within the framework of the statute. There is no guiding principle or policy provided to guide the exercise of such discretion in limiting the multiplier factor in rural area to any figure between 1 and 2. As against this, the guiding principle, as seen from the First Schedule to the Act of 2013, seems to be fixing the schedule or slabs of distances of projects from urban areas wherein different multiplier factors ranging from 1 to 2 can be determined, the minimum being 1 and the maximum being 2. If absolute discretion is held to be conferred on the appropriate Government in fixing the factor, as contended by the State, then the delegation of such power will have to be construed as excessive in nature and ultra vires the provisions of Article 14 of the Constitution because of absence of guiding principle or policy provided in the statute for limiting the multiplier factor below 2.

This notification dated 13.8.2014 appears to be merely an attempt to show compliance of statutory mandate under the First Schedule which requires the appropriate Government to determine the factor of multiplier in rural areas between 1 to 2 based only on the distance from urban area. Financial implications and financial constraints can not be said to be relevant factor for determining the multiplier factor by which the market value of the land in rural area is required to be multiplied. Thus, extraneous consideration of inadequacy of funds and inviable increase in budgetary cost vitiates the exercise of discretion conferred upon the appropriate Government under the First Schedule to the Act of 2013 and, therefore, the impugned notifications are bad in law as they are product of extraneous considerations.    [Para 39,40,45]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Compensation under new Act
HeadNote.description:
Compensation under new Act - In respect of certain land notified under old Act - Provisions of sub-section (2) of S.24 carve out an exception - Condition precedent for seeking compensation under new Act is making of Award 5 yrs or more prior to the commencement of new Act. 

Provisions of Section 24 (2), to which the Proviso is appended, would apply only to the Awards that are made five years of more, prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013. The Award was made on 09.07.2009 and the Act of 2013 came into force on 01.01.2014. The Award was not made five years or more, prior to the commencement of the Act on 01.01.2014. Since, the Proviso appears to have been appended to sub-section (2) of Section 24 of the Act of 2013, the petitioners would not be entitled to seek compensation under the provisions of the new Act.

Also, it is clear from the provisions of Section 24(1)(b) that where the Award is made under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, then such proceedings shall continue under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 as if the Act was not repealed. The provisions of sub-section 2 of Section 24 carve out an exception to the provisions of Section 24(1)(b) of the Act of 2013 and create a class of acquisitions in respect of the Awards, which have been made five years or more, prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013 under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, but where the physical possession of the land is not taken or the compensation has not been paid, for the purpose of lapsing. The Proviso, being applicable to the provisions of sub-section 2 of Section 24, the condition precedent for seeking compensation under the Act of 2013 would be the making of the Award five years or more prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013.        [Para 6]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Benefit of S. 24
HeadNote.description:
Benefit of S. 24 - Claim for by purchaser of land after issuance of notification u/S. 4 of Act of 1894 - Sale effected after issuance of notification u/S. 4 is void - Such purchaser cannot invoke provisions of S. 24 and is not entitled to benefit of S. 24. 
	S. 24 (2) provides that in case the award has been passed five years or more prior to the commencement of the Act, but the physical possession of the land has not been taken, or the compensation has not been paid, the said proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed. It is not the case set up that compensation had not been paid to purchasers/owners. The only case set up is that physical possession has not been taken and proceedings of taking over possession have been questioned to take advantage of provisions under S. 24(2) of the Act of 2013. Whereas, averment in the writ petition itself indicates that possession had been taken over in the year 2000 and that unauthorized colonies have come up in the area. Thus, it is clear that possession, if any, is illegal, and in fact, the actual physical possession had been taken, and re-entering in possession in an unauthorized manner can confer no right. There is nothing to doubt that actual physical possession had been taken in 2000. Thus, S. 24(2) is not attracted in the case. 
	Even otherwise, proviso to S. 24(2) does not recognize a purchaser after S. 4 notification inasmuch as it provides that where an award has been made, and the compensation in respect of a majority of land holdings has not been deposited in the account of the beneficiaries, then, all beneficiaries specified in the notification for acquisition issued under the Act of 1894, shall be entitled to compensation under the provisions of the Act of 2013. The proviso makes it clear that in case of compensation concerning the majority of landholding has not been deposited, then recorded owner(s) at the time of issuance of notification under S. 4 of the Act of 1894 shall have the right to receive the compensation. Purchasers after S. 4 notification have not been given the right to receive the higher compensation under the provisions contained in the act of 2013. Such a person who has purchased after S. 4 notification, as sale deed is void under the Act of 1894, cannot claim rehabilitation and resettlement as per policy envisaged under the Act of 2013, as his land has not been acquired, but he has purchased a property which has already been acquired by the State Government, he cannot claim even higher compensation, as per proviso to S. 24(2) under the Act of 2013. The transaction of sale, effected after S. 4 notification, is void, is ineffective to transfer the land, such incumbents cannot invoke the provisions of S. 24. It would be unfair and profoundly unjust and against the policy of the law to permit such a person to claim resettlement or claim the land back as envisaged under the Act of 2013. When he has not been deprived of his livelihood but is a purchaser under a void transaction. (2017) 6 SCC 751 Overruled, (1975) 2 SCC 232; (1988) 2 SCC 602 Foll. (Paras 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21)

headline: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013), S. 24 – Land Acquisition Act (1894), S. 4 – Purchaser of land after issuance of notification u/S. 4 of Act of 1894 cannot invoke provisions of S. 24 of Act of 2013 and is not entitled to benefit of S. 24.

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Lapse of acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Lapse of acquisition - Acquisition proceedings initiated in terms of Ss.125 to 127 of MRTP Act - S.24(2) of new LA Act not applicable to such proceedings.

Town Planning achieves various social and economic objectives. Town planning is aimed at fulfilling social and economic objectives which go beyond the physical form and arrangement of buildings, streets, parks, utilities and other parts of the urban environment. Town planning is thus essential for efficiency, well-being of all and leads to increase in wealth in the long run. [Para 59]

While carrying out the planned development, a balance has to be achieved between the individual rights and larger good of the society. The MRTP Act has its own scheme for achieving such a balance. The MRTP Act has an elaborate methodology of identification and finalization of the need for public amenities and to initiate the process for acquisition of the land for fulfilling the need so determined. The MRTP Act has its checks and balances such as Section 127, which mandates that a private land cannot be placed under reservation indefinitely depriving the owner to put it to full use. An embargo has been placed on the powers of the State by providing a time limit under Section 127 within which lands so identified needs to be acquired. If the acquisition proceedings would lapse in this manner, it would frustrate the rights of the State as contemplated under Section 126 as well as 127 of the Act. Such cause of action will disturb the equilibrium of MRTP Act and cause legal and practical impediments. 	 [Para 60]

Thus, the position of law in its simplest sense is that schemes of town planning laws such as the MRTP Act, which are complete codes in themselves, cannot be disrupted by adopting different time frames and on default consequences of lapsing of acquisition. Such outside concepts will produce imbalances in the functioning of these enactments.	 [Para 61]

Apart from the scheme of the MRTP Act, there is an intrinsic indication in the Section 24(2) of new Act 2013 itself as to why it cannot be made applicable. Section 24(2) is reproduced earlier. This section will apply if the acquisition proceedings are initiated under the Land Acquisition Act. The crucial phrase used in Section 24(2) is "initiated under the Land Acquisition Act". The word "initiated" has not been defined under the new Act 2013. The phrase "initiated of Land Acquisition Act" was not used in the L.A. Act. This phrase has been employed in the new Act 2013 in Section 24. The legislature has deliberately chosen the phrase "initiated". Initiation is not mere presentation but consciously putting the process in motion. The dictionary meaning of the word initiation is "originating", "to start". When the new Act 2013 was enacted, the decision of the Constitution Bench in respect of an enactments dealing with planned development which are complete codes, was holding the field and hold the field even today. The Petitioners sought to advance various arguments as to whether Section 4 could be initiation of proceedings or Section 6 of the Act. The dicta of the Constitution Bench is clear. The Constitution Bench in the Girnar (3)[2011(3) SCC 1.] at more than three places in the report has reiterated that the proceedings under the L.A. Act commence under Section 4 and under the MRTP Act. For the MRTP Act, there is no notification under Section 4 and an application under Section 126(2) is to be in the format laid down under Section 6 of the L.A. Act. Keeping this dicta in mind, the phrase "initiated under the land acquisition Act" will have to be construed. Emphasis in Section 24(2) is on which authority under which Act has initiated the proceedings. Therefore, when the legislature used the phrase "initiated under Land Acquisition Act" it will not cover acquisition proceedings which originate and are consciously put in motion for acquisition for a planned development under the MRTP Act pursuant to an application under Section 126(2). 	 [Para 73]

Thus since Section 24(2) of the new Act 2013 provides different time frame and lapsing of acquisition on default, it cannot be applied to the acquisition initiated under Section 125 to 127 of the MRTP Act. The MRTP Act has not undergone any change from its character as a complete code. Section 24(2) of the new Act 2013 will apply only if the acquisition proceedings are "initiated" under the Land Acquisition Act, and cannot apply if they are initiated under Section 125 to 127 of the MRTP Act. 2011 ALL SCR 176 Rel. on. 	 [Para 76]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Land Acquisition award
Period of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Land Acquisition award - Period of limitation - S.25 of LA Act, 2013 applies to awards made u/S.24(1)(a) and period of limitation of 12 months would commence from 1st January, 2014. 
	In present case issue is whether two-year period specified under S. 11A of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 will apply even after the repeal of the 1894 Act, or the twelve-month period specified in S.25 of the Act of 2013 will apply for the awards made u/S.24(1)(a) of the 2013 Act?
	Considering object and purpose behind Ss.24 and 26 to 30 of Act of 2013, practical absurdities and anomalies may arise if two-year period for making of an award in terms of S.11A of 1894 Act commencing from date of issue of the declaration is applied to the awards to be made under S.24(1)(a) of the 2013 Act. This would mitigate against underlying legislative intent behind prescription of time for making of an award in respect of saved acquisition proceedings initiated under the repealed 1894 Act, which is two-fold: (i) to give sufficient time to the authorities to determine compensation payable under the 2013 Act; and (ii) to ensure early and expedited payment to the landowners by reducing the period from two years under S.11A of the 1894 Act to twelve months under S.25 of the 2013 Act. In case of declarations issued in January 2012, on application of S. 11A of the 1894 Act, the time to determine compensation under the 2013 Act would vary from a day to a month, and while in cases where the declarations were issued within twelve months of the repeal of the 1894 Act, the landowners would be at a disadvantage as an award beyond the twelve-month period specified in S.25 of the 2013 Act would be valid. In the first set of cases, given the onerous factual and legal exercise involved in determination of compensation and the need to issue notification under S.26(2) of the 2013 Act, publication of the awards would be impractical. Hasty and incorrect awards would be deleterious for the landowners. If the awards are not pronounced, the acquisition proceedings would lapse defeating the legislative intent behind S.24(1)(a) of the 2013 Act to save such proceedings. 
	A rational approach so as to further the object and purpose of S.24 and 26 to 30 of the 2013 Act is required. It was held that in cases covered by clause (a) to S.24(1) of the 2013 Act, the limitation period for passing/making of an award under S.25 of the 2013 Act would commence from 1st January 2014, that is, the date when the 2013 Act came into force. Awards passed under clause (a) to S.24(1) would be valid if made within twelve months from 1st January 2014. Contention of the land owners, relying upon R.19 of the Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Settlement (Maharashtra) Rules, 2014 for giving a restrictive meaning and excluding S.25 of 2013 Act is misplaced. This Rule states that the formula provided in S.26 to 30 of the 2013 Act would apply where a notification under S.4(i) of the 1894 Act was issued before 31st December 2013, and an award has not been made before the 31st December 2013. The Rule refers to the formula for computation of compensation to be applied under S.24(1)(a) of the 2013 Act, but it does not follow that S.25 which prescribes the limitation for making of an award will not apply. For the reasons stated above, we hold that S.25 of the 2013 Act applies to awards made under S.24(1)(a) of the 2013 Act and the period of limitation of twelve months would commence from 1st January 2014.	(Paras 19, 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Applicability of the 2013 Act
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of the 2013 Act - Scheme of S.24 of the Act, explained.

The provisions of the 1894 Act are repealed by the 2013 Act with effect from 1-1-2014 and, therefore, it was necessary to take care of the land acquisition proceedings initiated under the 1894 Act, which were pending at different stages. Section 24 is enacted to take care of all such situations with an intention to balance the conflicting interest of the land holders and the State and it has been given overriding effect over all the provisions of the 2013 Act. Section 24 divides all such proceedings in three categories - (A) the proceedings to which all the provisions relating to the determination of compensation under the 2013 Act shall apply, covered by clause (a) of sub-section (1), (B) where the provisions of the 1894 Act relating to the determination of compensation shall apply, as contemplated under clause (b) of sub-section (1), and (C) where the land acquisition proceedings initiated under the 1894 Act shall lapse in entirety in terms of sub-section (2) of Section 24. Categories (A) and (B) are covered by sub-section (1), whereas category (C) is covered by sub-section (2). The provisions of sub-sections (1) and (2) operate in different fields. Sub-section (1) relates to applicability of the provisions of the 2013 Act for determination of compensation, whereas sub-section (2) deals with lapsing of land acquisition proceedings initiated under the 1894 Act. 	 [Para 8]

The provision of clause (b) of sub-section (1) of Section 24 of the 2013 Act covers the cases where an award under Section 11 of the 1894 Act was made within a period of five years prior to the commencement of the 2013 Act. The object of giving an overriding effect to the provision of sub-section (2) is to exclude the cases where an award under Section 11 of 1894 Act was made within a period of five years prior to the date of commencement of the 2013 Act from lapsing of acquisition. The period of five years or more prior to the commencement of the 2013 Act, specified under sub-section (2) of Section 24 of the 2013 Act, cannot, therefore, be imported or read in clause (b) of sub-section (1). The effect of such reading would be three-fold, viz. (A) lapsing of the entire acquisition proceedings initiated under the 1894 Act upon establishing that the compensation in respect of a majority of land holdings has not been deposited in the account of beneficiaries, (B) the latter part of the proviso making the beneficiaries entitled to the compensation as per the 2013 Act shall become redundant, and (C) the protection provided to save lapsing of acquisition in its entirety shall be lost. 	 [Para 9]

The proviso below sub-section (2) deals with the subject of applicability of the provisions of the 2013 Act relating to the determination of compensation covered by clause (b) of sub-section (1) of Section 24 therein, subject to the satisfaction of condition that the compensation in respect of a majority of land holdings has not been deposited in the account of the beneficiaries. The proviso has to be read as an exception to the provision of clause (b) in sub-section (1) of Section 24 of the 2013 Act so as to advance the intention of the Legislature to strike the balance of conflicting interest between the land holders and the State, and to award a fair compensation. 	 [Para 10]

HeadNote.act_name: Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013)
heading: Proviso to S.24(2)
Interpretation of
HeadNote.description:
Proviso to S.24(2) - Interpretation of - Proviso to S.24(2) operates in different situations and contingencies, and in fact does not subtract or accept anything from S.24(2).

Sub-section (2) of Section 24 explains conditions prerequisite for deemed lapsing of the proceedings of acquisition. In the event of declaration of an award under Section 11 of Act of 1894, five years or more prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013, subject to the conditions that physical possession of the land has not been taken or compensation has not been paid. Whereas, proviso to sub-section (2) deals with holding the claimants entitled to compensation in accordance with the provisions of Act of 2013 in the event of failure of the State or the acquiring body in making payment of compensation to the majority of land holders. The consequences specified in the proviso as well as sub-section (2) are different, whereas, contingencies specified for lapsing under sub-section (2) are also different. In a way, proviso to sub-section (2) deals with a totally different situation which is not contemplated under sub-section (2). Under sub-section (2) of Section 24, even if a single claimant satisfies the requirement i.e. declaring of an award under Section 11 of the Act of 1894, five years or more prior to the commencement of Act of 2013 together with fulfillment of requirement of failure of the acquiring body or the State to take possession of the land or payment of compensation, consequence of lapsing of acquisition shall follow. Whereas, proviso to sub-section (2) deals with cases not of a single individual but cases where majority of the land holders have not been paid compensation or the amount has not been deposited in the account of the beneficiaries and consequences thereof would be entitlement of those claimants to receive compensation in accordance with provisions of the Act of 2013.

The proviso to sub-section (2) operates in different situations and contingencies and in fact does not subtract or except anything from sub-section (2) of Section 24. It is true that normal function of the proviso is to provide for an exception of something that is outside the ambit of the usual intention of the enactment, or to qualify something enacted therein, which, but for the proviso would be within the purview of such enactment.
(1985)1 SCC 591, 2013 ALL SCR 34, 1980 AIR (SC) 482 Foll.   [Para 22,24]

heading: Circular issued dt.5-5-17
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Circular issued dt.5-5-17 - Validity - Resolution of "Stressed" assets - Circular is applicable to banking and non-banking institutions alike - Such non-banking financial institutions are inseparable from banking institutions in so far as application of circular is concerned - Non banking financial institutions cannot be segregated from banks so as to make the circular applicable to them even if it is ultra vires insofar as banks are concerned - Therefore, said circular can be declared as ultra vires as a whole.

	There is nothing to show that the provisions of Section 45L(3) have been satisfied in issuing the impugned circular. The impugned circular nowhere says that the RBI has had due regard to the conditions in which and the objects for which such institutions have been established, their statutory responsibilities, and the effect the business of such financial institutions is likely to have on trends in the money and capital markets. Further, it is clear that the impugned circular applies to banking and non-banking institutions alike, as banking and non-banking institutions are often in a joint lenders' forum which jointly lend sums of money to debtors. Such non-banking financial institutions are, therefore, inseparable from banking institutions insofar as the application of the impugned circular is concerned. It is very difficult to segregate the non-banking financial institutions from banks so as to make the circular applicable to them even if it is ultra vires insofar as banks are concerned. For these reasons also, the impugned circular will have to be declared as ultra vires as a whole, and be declared to be of no effect in law. Consequently, all actions taken under the said circular, including actions by which the Insolvency Code has been triggered must fall along with the said circular. As a result, all cases in which debtors have been proceeded against by financial creditors under Section 7 of the Insolvency Code, only because of the operation of the impugned circular will be proceedings which, being faulted at the very inception, are declared to be non-est.	 [Para 45,46]

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.45QA (Inserted in 1997), Chapter III B (Inserted in 1964)
heading: Provisions of RBI Act would prevail over Companies Act
HeadNote.description:
Provisions of RBI Act would prevail over Companies Act - Scheme under S.391 cannot be entertained unless it is in conformity with S.45QA of the RBI Act.

Sections 45 Q A of the RBI Act states in categoric terms that provisions of Chapter IIIB shall have effect notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law. The overriding effect extends not only to any other law for the time being in force but also to any instrument having effect by virtue of having such law. The reasons for giving such categoric overriding effect are evident from the objects and reasons given in the Amendment Act. The magnitude of the exploitation of the poor sections of the society, leading to utter destruction of innumerable families was the underlying impetus to bring the NBFCs under strict control. Chapter IIIB of the RBI Act is a complete code in itself. The Companies Act is a prior enactment as the same was enacted in the year 1956, whereas, Chapter IIIB was inserted in the RBI Act (55 of 1963) w.e.f. 1964. Section 45QA was inserted by the Act No. 23 of 1997 w.e.f. 9th January, 1997. Thus, provisions of the RBI Act would prevail over the Companies Act, it being a later enactment. It is a settled proposition of law that a later enactment will override the earlier enactment. Chapter IIIB has been given an overriding effect over all other laws including Companies Act by incorporating Section 45Q with a clear intention to ensure that in a case of NBFC, a scheme under Section 391 of the Companies Act cannot be entertained unless it is in conformity with the provisions of Section 45QA of the RBI Act.           [Para 47,48]

heading: Requisitioning of premises
HeadNote.description: Requisitioning of premises - Cannot be for an indefinite period - Premises requisitioned in 1955 and occupied by Govt. servants till 1961 - Owner getting possession after their vacating premises and inducting tenant - Govt. not paying any rent to owner - It could be held that derequisition had taken place in 1961 - Issue of notice to tenant in 1980 to vacate premises on ground that premises are under requisition is illegal - In any case requisition could not continue beyond 30 years and thus it could not continue after 1985. (Para 3)

heading: Applied.	(Paras 11, 12)
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for construction of camp for military operation - Solatiam and interest on amount of compensation cannot be awarded. Contempt Case (Civil) No.815 of 2007, Dt.2-4-2009 (Jhar) - Reversed. 2003(3) ALL MR 766 (S.C.) - Applied.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Award of arbitrator
HeadNote.description: Award of arbitrator - Over and above amount of compensation Arbitrator awarding solatium @ 30% p.a. and interest @ 6% p.a. - Award was virtually ignored by authorities as neither it was challenged nor payment was made to claimants - Held this was not a fit case to exercise discretionary power under Art.136 of the Constitution in favour of appellant authorities - Constitution of India, Art.136. 1995 Supp(4) SCC 22, 1995 Supp (4) SCC 223, (2005)11 SCC 291 Rel. on.			(Paras 25, 26)

HeadNote.act_name: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act (1952)
heading: Requisition of property
HeadNote.description: Requisition of property - Property requisitioned during war time for army purposes in 1945 - Property cannot be requisitioned permanently - Property cannot also be transferred to any other person - Government transferring property to a private Women's College and rent payable by College was received by the owner for years together - Maximum period of requisition was 17 and ought to have ended in 1987 but it continued for 22 years thereafter - Creation of so-called tenancy for purpose alien to requisition was unlawful and Competent Authority was under an obligation to return it to its owner - For the Munsif and High Court to say that appellant owner must seek remedy in Civil Court is adding insult to injury.			(Paras 8, 9, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act (1952)
heading: Claim for
HeadNote.description: Quashing of acquisition notification - Claim for - On ground that land acquired for public purpose is utilized for private commercial purpose which amounts to fraud - Land acquired in 1953 for purpose of airport - Airport was constructed and functioning and operator of airport have been given permission for exploiting unutilized land forming part of project for ancillary uses - Such user cannot be termed as fraudulent so as to vitiate original acquisition of land - No provision in law, enabling owner of land acquired by State for public purpose under the Act, to reclaim same in future on ground of its subsequent change of user - Once land vests in State u/S.7, State cannot be divested of its title for non-user of land for purpose for which it was acquired - Acquisition notification cannot be quashed. 	(Paras 5, 6, 8, 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act (1952)
heading: Property requisioned for 15 years
HeadNote.description:
Property requisioned for 15 years - It has to be surrendered or delivered to owner after expiry of such period - Exception is made in Section 7 - Possession need not be given if such property is acquired under S.7.

The provisions of Section 6(1A) are mandatory.  Under Section 6(1A) the Central Government has to release from requisition any property requisitioned under the said Act after the commencement of the Amending Act of 1970, on or before the expiry of the period mentioned therein from the date on which possession of the said property was surrendered or delivered to, or taken by the Competent Authority under Section 4.  The only exception is if such property is acquired under Section 7 within the period specified therein.  Admittedly in the instant case the said property was not acquired under Section 7.  Therefore, the authorities cannot continue in possession of the premises.  [Para 9,12]

HeadNote.act_name: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act (1952)
heading: Compensation payable on account of requisition
HeadNote.description:
Compensation payable on account of requisition - Whether compensation is not fixed by an agreement between the parties is a matter which has got to be determined by the arbitrator to be appointed under S.8(1)(c) and in the manner prescribed under S.8(2) of the Act - The Civil Court will, therefore, have no jurisdiction to determine the same.

Compensation payable on account of requisition, when it is not fixed by an agreement between the parties is a matter which has got to be determined by the arbitrator to be appointed under Section 8(1)(c) and in the manner prescribed under Section 8(2) of the Act of 1952. The Civil Court will therefore have no jurisdiction to determine the same. That the plaintiff has sought compensation on the basis of a different method other than the method the arbitrator is required to follow, is not sufficient to confer jurisdiction on the civil court. Determination of compensation is in the exclusive domain of the arbitrator. AIR 1990 P.&H. 53 - Ref. to.	 [Para 17,18]

HeadNote.act_name: Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act (1952)
heading: Exclusion of
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Exclusion of - Exclusion of jurisdiction of a civil court is not to be readily inferred and such exclusion must be either explicitly expressed or clearly implied.	(Para 20)

HeadNote.description: Framing of charge - Setting aside of - Challenge - FIR lodged against accused persons u/S.304 RPC - While framing charges Trial Court formed opinion that investigation prima facie establishes offence u/S.302 and framed charge u/S.302 - High Court however applied the test which is to be seen at final stage to find out as to whether accused is guilty of charge or not and set aside order framing charges - Extraneous factor taken into consideration by High Court while setting aside order framing charge - Not sustainable - Impugned order set aside. 	(Para 7)

heading: Conviction under
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Conviction under - Appeal - Accused appellant charged under S.302 r.w. S.34 - Trial Court convicting him under Ss.306 and 498-A - High Court upholding conviction - Appellant contending that ingredients of Ss.306, 498-A were absent and no question was put to him under S.313, Cr.P.C. relating to these offences - Held, as no question about demand of dowry and abetment of suicide was put up in S.313 examination conviction is liable to be set aside - No useful purpose would be served by remanding matter since more than 20 years had lapsed and appellant has already served part of custodial sentence.	(Para 11)

heading: Murder
Appeal against conviction
HeadNote.description: Murder - Appeal against conviction - Prosecution case that accused fired gun shot at deceased resulting into his death - Evidence of eye-witnesses who were family members of deceased are consistent and fully corroborated with each other - Their evidence also supported by other independent witnesses - Motive behind killing was refusal by deceased to give his daughter in marriage to accused - Accused guilty of charges of murder - His conviction under S.302 is proper.  (Paras 15 to 20)

heading: Sentence
HeadNote.description: Sentence - Abduction and murder of former MLA - Accused tried along with 17 others - Eleven accused discharged and two co-accused acquitted - Trial went on for almost 20 years and accused had already undergone 11-½ years in jail - Accused had made a remorseful confession - He was only involved with abduction part and nothing to do with murder - During period 1-½ years bail his conduct and behaviour was exemplary - Held his sentence may be reduced from 14 years to that already undergone.	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Rape on divorced wife
HeadNote.description: Rape on divorced wife - Accused had concealed fact of execution of Talaq-nama (divorce deed) from his wife and had been co-habiting with her for 7/8 years - She filing maintenance application when she was turned out of the house - Accused taking a plea of divorce though Talaq-nama was not communicated or pronounced to wife - He had also executed a power of attorney in her favour describing her as his wedded wife and empowering her to sell his land to third party - Held, divorce deed was only a paper writing which was not given legal effect and co-habitation of accused would not amount to commissioner of offence of rape - Accused acquitted.			(Paras 18, 19, 22)

heading: Murder or culpable homicide
HeadNote.description: Murder or culpable homicide - Accused-Jawan posted in J & K, shot his superior dead with his service rifle while on guard duty at about 9:30 pm - Deceased allegedly humiliated accused and attempted commission of unnatural offence upon accused on same day in noon time - Evidence proves that after said incident accused was seen crying and depressed - However, no evidence to prove that accused had continued to suffer a prolonged spell of grave provocation - In fact, accused and his colleagues had planned to beat deceased in the evening - That apart, accused also attended to his normal duty during day time and after dinner went to perform his guard duty at 9 pm - Circumstances do not betray any sign of grave and sudden provocation to have continued haunting accused and depriving him of self control - Moreover, there was seven hours time gap between the incidents, sufficient for accused to cool down - Offence not falling under Exception 1 of S.300 - Conviction and sentence u/s.302 of Ranbir Penal Code held, proper. 			(Paras 13, 16)

heading: Death sentence
Murder case
HeadNote.description: Death sentence - Murder case - First incident involving death of four persons while second incident involved death of one person - Accused convicted in respect of first incident with aid of S.34 since role attributed to him is participation in offence by standing outside door of house - However, evidence of eye-witnesses clearly implicating him in second incident stating that it is accused who had fired shot on deceased resulting into his death - Ends of justice would meet if death penalty is commuted to life imprisonment. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Murder
HeadNote.description: Murder - Appellant, army personnel allegedly shot dead his senior on account of some altercation - Incident took place in their barrack itself - Other officers came to the spot on hearing sound of fire - They deposed to have seen appellant with rifle in his hand pointing towards the body lying on ground - Medical and FSL reports established that deceased died of gunshot injury and firing was done from service rifle of appellant - That apart, appellant himself confessed his guilt before other officers and offered explanation that he committed a mistake - Conviction u/S.302 proper. 			(Paras 5, 6, 7, 8)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Murder or culpable homicide - Determination - Plea of sudden fight not raised before courts below - That apart, evidence shows that deceased was unarmed whereas appellant was carrying his service weapon - Evidence also shows that appellant fired two shots as the first did not hit the deceased - Second shot had hit the neck of deceased, leading to his instantaneous death on spot - Thus, vital part of body chosen for infliction of injury, number of shots fired and circumstances in which incident took place, leaves no manner of doubt that appellant had intended to kill deceased - Case would fall u/S.302 and not u/S.304. 			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Murder
Appreciation of evidence
HeadNote.description: Murder - Appreciation of evidence - Accused allegedly hit deceased on his head with iron bar causing his death - Father of deceased was present on scene of offence - Motive stated to be prior scuffle on account of some financial transaction wherein accused stood as guarantor for payment to deceased - After incident, deceased himself went to police station - In view of severe injuries, his failure to disclose entire incident in FIR, would not be fatal - Alleged motive proved from statement of witnesses who had seen prior scuffle wherein accused had also threatened deceased - These witnesses also witnessed recovery of weapon i.e. iron bar at instance of accused - Medical evidence that head injury was cause of death, fully corroborate evidence of father of deceased - Father of deceased had narrated manner of attack, his evidence is trustworthy - He is a natural witness, cannot be rejected as being interested witness - Submissions regarding details of financial transaction, not entertainable - Concern of Court is to see overt acts committed by accused - Oral and medical evidence prove guilt of accused - Conviction upheld. 	(Paras 15, 17, 18, 19, 22, 23, 27, 28, 33)

HeadNote.act_name: Railways (Extent of Monetary Liability and Prescription of Percentage) Rules (1990)
heading: Loss of luggage
Non-delivery of luggage
HeadNote.description:
Loss of luggage - Non-delivery of luggage - It is obvious that luggage was lost in transit - Liability of luggage would be covered by S.100 and not by S.103 - Railway administration is liable to pay the value of the goods.

In the instant case, there was non-delivery of the luggage to the appellant and, therefore, it is obvious that the luggage was lost in transit.  Therefore, the burden was on the railway administration to prove that how it is lost and it was not on account of negligence or misconduct on the part of the railway administration.  In such circumstances, the contention of the learned counsel for the railway administration that Section 103 of the Act read with Rule (3) of the Rules would be applicable appears to be misconceived and the Court is of the considered view that the liability of the railway administration would be governed by the provisions of Section 100 of the Act so far as the loss of luggage is concerned and Rule (3) of the Rules would be inapplicable to the goods which are booked as luggage and not as consignment.

In the present case though other conditions are printed on the reverse of the ticket that the monetary liability of Railway administration will be determined by the Rules 1990 and the liability of Railway administration for loss, damage, destruction, deterioration or non-delivery shall not exceed Rs.100/- per Kg. for booked luggage unless the value of the consignment has been declared and percentage charge on excess value has been paid, it cannot be said that the appellant would not be entitled to value of the goods which were lost in transit on account of negligence on the part of the servants of the Railway administration. The appellant had produced the bills and those bills showed that the total value of the luggage was Rs.90,061/- only.  The railway administration did not examine any witness to disprove those bills and, therefore, there is no reason for this Court to hold that the value of the goods has not been proved.  Moreover, non-examination of witness by the Railway administration would lead to adverse inference against it under Section 114(g) of the Indian Evidence Act.  Since the railway administration did not examine any witness nor has cross-examined the appellant, it is obvious that the luggage has been lost in transit due to the negligence on the part of servants of the Railway administration.  Held, the appellant is entitled for the value of the goods, i.e. Rs.90,061/- and the Railway administration is liable to pay the same to the appellant.  1988 Mh.L.J. 434 - Rel.on.  [Para 13,15,16]

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.9 R.13 - Appeal - Against ex-parte order issuing recovery certificate - Ground of defective service of notice - Borrower-company objecting that notice was deliberately not sent on its correct address to obtain ex-parte order - Address of borrower- company is Block No.714-725 - Whereas address mentioned in notice was 712-725 which includes Block No.714-725 - Notice of recovery proceedings returned with remark 'not claimed' - In terms of Regulation 19(6), when notice is returned with such remark, it can be presumed that there was proper service of notice - Receipt of notice, not disputed by Director of borrower company - It shows they have knowledge of recovery proceedings - Applying the principles under O.9 R.13, merely on account of defect in service, ex-parte decree cannot be set aside - Appeal dismissed.	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Benefit under Probation of Offenders Act
HeadNote.description: Benefit under Probation of Offenders Act - Conviction u/s.160(2) of Railways Act - Applicant-convict, in revision not challenging his conviction but only seeking benefit of 1958 Act - Applicant after his conviction met with two accidents leading to permanent disability - That apart, he had no criminal record - Applicant given benefit of 1958 Act and released on certain conditions. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Dacoity
Conviction
Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Arms Act (1959), Ss.3, 25 - Dacoity - Conviction - Sustainability - Allegedly mangalsutra of victim was snatched by accused by inserting his hand through window of bogie - Statement of victim was recorded after 4 months of incident - Medical witness who gave treatment to victim lady, did not prove anything incriminating against accused - Neither the person who registered FIR nor investigating officer deposed that whose mangalsutra was snatched - No Identification parade was conducted - No incriminating material found from spot - Conviction is based on mere suspicion, hence, cannot be sustained. 			(Paras 11, 14, 18, 19, 21, 23)

heading: Theft of luggage
HeadNote.description: Theft of luggage - Allegations of deficiency of service by Indian Railway - Theft is inferred and not established - Reliance is placed on S. 100 of Railway Act - However complainant has failed in establishing negligence on part of Indian Railways - Complaint is liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Complaint against Railway
HeadNote.description: Complaint against Railway - Railway contended that they are not responsible for loss/theft of luggage of passengers - Held, provision of S.100 of Railway Act applicable to railway department as a carrier of luggage - Also that articles stolen were not luggage - Contention of Railway not sustainable. 			(Para 7)

heading: Workman
HeadNote.description: Workman - Evidence not showing any contract of employment with deceased - Held, the deceased was, therefore, not a workman as contemplated u/s.2(1)(n)(i) of Workmen's Compensation Act r/w. S.2(34) of the Railways Act.	(Para 8)

heading: Railway claim
Condonation of delay
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Railway claim - Condonation of delay - Delay of 4 and ½ years in filing application - Condonation sought on ground of illiteracy, poverty, lack of communication between claimants and their advocate and that claimants faced lots of difficulties in collecting police papers and getting them translated for purpose of filing petition - Adverse inference drawn for reason that claimants did not provide particulars as which police station they had visited for getting documents and that who was advocate who kept pending file with him for 2 years - Not justified - Delay caused was not deliberate or intentional - Claimants were not going to be benefitted by such delay - Materials on record prima facie show that deceased was bona fide passenger and that he suffered death in untoward incident - Delay in such cases has to be liberally condoned. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

headline: Duty of Railway to disprove claim of the claimant by adducing cogent & proper evidence to prove exception u/S 124A under Railways Act (1989).

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Liability of railway to pay compensation - Claimant claiming that deceased travelling as bona fide passenger fell down from running train due to sudden jerk of train and died - Defence of Railways that deceased committed suicide by jumping from train - Railways examined guard in support of their defence - Guard stated that he was informed by some passenger that deceased jumped from train, therefore, it is suicide - Guard has not stated name of passenger who has given him information - Said passenger cannot be examined - Evidence of guard was hearsay, not admissible in evidence - Railways failed to discharge burden that deceased not died in untoward incident - Further, spot panchnama and inquest panchnama prepared by Railway police showing that deceased died due to falling from train - It proves that deceased died due to untoward incident - Railway liable to pay compensation. 	(Paras 16, 20)

heading: Compensation
Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Untoward incident - Deceased run over by goods train and not by passenger train - Though deceased was bona fide passenger it was not case of untoward incident as he did not die by falling from passenger train but after passenger train had passed he was run over by goods train - Held, claimant would not be entitled to compensation.	(Paras 4, 5)

headline: Railways Act (1989), S. 124-A – Compensation – Untoward incident – Deceased having valid ticket even if died due to his own negligence, Railway cannot deny it’s liability to pay compensation.

heading: Compensation
Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Untoward incident - Deceased fell down from running train due to push of door and died - Respondent claiming that deceased died due to his own negligence - Record showing that deceased was having valid ticket - Deceased even if died due to his own negligence, Railway cannot deny it’s liability to pay compensation - Claimants entitled to compensation of Rs. 8,00,000/-. 2010 ACJ 2453; AIR 2018 SC 2362 Rel. on. (Paras 6, 10, 12, 13)

heading: Claim petition- Death due to explosion of bomb in train
HeadNote.description: Claim petition- Death due to explosion of bomb in train - Evidence on record show that deceased was a bonafide purchaser - Railway failed to prove its case that there was an announcement for passengers not to board in train - Negligence on the part of Railway, proved - Compensation of Rs. 2 Lacs with interest of 6% p.a. awarded. 			(Paras 12, 13, 15)

heading: Interest on Compensation
HeadNote.description: Interest on Compensation - Is payable right from date of application and not from date of award - While awarding interest, tribunal can consider the bank rate - Award of interest at 6% p.a. from date of registration of case upheld. AIR 2005 Bom. 409 - Dissented from.	(Paras 2, 3)

heading: Compensation
Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Entitlement - Death of person in railway accident - Burden to prove that the person who died in the accident was not a bona fide passenger lies on the Railway Administration. 1993 ACJ 846 - Rel. on.			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Compensation
Jurisdiction
Untoward incident
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Jurisdiction - Untoward incident - Passengers thrown out of train by anti social elements - Death caused due to this - District Forum under Consumer Protection Act not empowered to decide claim of compensation - Such claim is to be decided by Railway Tribunal and none else.

In view of the definition of 'untoward incident' provided under section 123(c) of the Act of 1989, it is beyond doubt that the compensation on account of untoward incident can be decided by the Railway Tribunal and none else.  Therefore, the District Forum under the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 could not decide the dispute raised by the respondents. [Para 8]

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Compensation - Liability of Railway Administration - Oral and documentary evidence show accidental fall of bonafide passenger from running train - It is liability of Railway Administration to compensate claimants.

2010(5) ALL MR 986 (S.C.), 2010(4) ALL MR 472 (S.C.), 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.), 2001 ACJ 721 Rel.on.	 [Para 9]

heading: Bonafide passenger
Presumption of law
Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Bonafide passenger - Presumption of law - Untoward incident - Passenger fell off crowded train and died - Fact that ticket not found on body of passenger, held, not enough to absolve Railway from its liability - There is possibility of ticket getting misplaced in overcrowded compartment - Presumption always in favour of law abiding nature of citizen - Without any plea and proof as to exception, Railway cannot escape from its statutory liability to pay compensation - Award of compensation, upheld. 			(Paras 3, 5)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Liability of Railway Administration to pay compensation - Deceased bona fide passenger met his death due to fall from running train - With effect from 1.8.1994 u/S.124A, Railway Administration has also become liable to pay compensation for loss of life or injury to bona fide passenger, who become victim of untoward incident - No escape route for railway - Railway held liable to pay compensation. 			(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Nuisance and trespass
Conviction for
HeadNote.description: Nuisance and trespass - Conviction for - In the charge sheet no reference to any nuisance or act of indecency leveled for committing an offence punishable u/s.145(b) - Order of conviction does not specify what sentence given for which offence, which shows non-application of mind on the part of Magistrate - No copy of charge sheet furnished to accused before conviction - Charge-sheet not disclosed the ingredient of alleged offences - Plea of guilty would not be valid - Applicant already undergone imprisonment - Would be entitled to acquittal. (Paras 17, 18)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Demand of additional freight charges - Legality - Petitioners transported Gram Husks from Nagpur to Malkapur on 13.04.2005 - At relevant time Gram Husk was treated as fodder and therefore, petitioners paid freight charges at Nagpur accordingly - When it reached to Malkapur on 16.04.2005, respondents asked petitioners to pay additional freight charges - Respondents contended that as per ARN No.83 of 2005 which came into force on 13.04.2005 itself, Gram Husks fall under category of food grain and pulses - However, date of A.R.N. No.83 of 2005 mentioned in Cl.2 of A.R.N.No.96 of 2005 was 20.04.2005 - Whereas date mentioned on A.R.N. No.83 of 2005 was 29.04.2005 - Therefore, A.R.N.No.83 of 2005 warranting re-classification of Gram Husk could not have been enforced on 13.04.2005 retrospectively - Demand of additional freight duty from petitioners, unsustainable. 	(Paras 18, 19, 20, 21)

heading: Liability of railways
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Liability of railways - Compensation on death of passenger in accident - Determination of - Amount of compensation payable on date of accident with reasonable rate of interest shall first be calculated - If amount calculated is less than amount prescribed in Schedule of 1990 Rules on date of award, claimant would be entitled to higher of those two amounts - Court erred in awarding interest on amended amount of Rs.8,00,000/- as accident has occurred prior to amendment - Interest should have been calculated on Rs.4,00,000/- i.e. amount prior to amendment - However, claimant entitled to compensation of Rs.8,00,000/-.  2018 ALL SCR 1750 Rel. on. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Railway accident
Untoward incident
Liability of Railway
HeadNote.description: Railway Manual 231, Appendix IV - Railway Accidents and Untoward Incidents (Compensation) Rules (1990) - Railway accident - Untoward incident - Liability of Railway - Deceased fell from train and met with untoward accident - Evidence as spot and inquest panchanama, post-mortem notes proves case of deceased - Deceased had valid pass for train travelling - Deceased though over travelled beyond his authorised distance cannot be labelled as mala fide passenger - In such case Railway could have recovered excess charges - Passenger can also be allowed to return to station of his destination - Railway liable to pay compensation of Rs.4,00,000/- with 6% p.a. from date of application. 2009(2) Mh.L.J. 160, 2008 ACJ 1895, 2006 ACJ 253 (A.P. High Court), AIR 2007 Raj. 38, III(2005) ACC 232, AIR 2005 AP 444 - Rel. on. IV(2005) ACC 736, 2008(4) Mh.L.J. 679 - Ref. to.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Transport of goods
Damage
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Transport of goods - Damage - Compensation - Appellant-plaintiff purchasing 300 bags of groundnut seeds - Consignment reaching Amalner station - Some bags found in torn condition - Packing, counting, loading and unloading was not supervised by railway staff - Seals of wagon found intact at destination - Sender at whose risk goods were loaded in wagon was not examined - Specifications of packing conditions not fulfilled - Railway administration cannot be held responsible for loss.	(Paras 1, 6, 7)

heading: Compensation on account of untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Compensation on account of untoward incident - Liability to pay interest - Can be claimed only from date of determination of compensation - Not from date of filing application before Tribunal.	(Paras 19, 22)

heading: Claim for compensation
Railway accident
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Claim for compensation - Railway accident - Maintainability - Rejection of earlier claim petition relating to same accident by Railway Tribunal - Writ petition in respect thereof dismissed and attained finality - Subsequent petition filed differently worded without producing fresh evidence on same cause of action - Moreover, petition filed without consent or authority of injured - Amounts to abuse of process of court and hit by principles of constructive res judicata - Liable to be dismissed.	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Untoward incident
Meaning and construction
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Meaning and construction - Word 'untoward incident' should not be given narrow and restricted meaning - Though S.123(2)(c) talks about accidental falling of a passenger from train, actual falling need not necessarily be outside the train.

Though the wording of S.123(2)(c) talks about accidental falling of any passenger from a train carrying passengers, the actual falling need not be outside the train.  There can be cases where the passenger can be accidentally hit say by a stone pelted by a miscreant from outside, who falls within the train.  The wording of S.123(2)(c) does not require that he should necessarily fall outside the train.  Emphasis of the said definition is on an untoward incident caused in an accident and once the accident has occurred not much importance can be given as to whether body of passenger falls inside or outside train. 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) - Rel. on.   [Para 10]

heading: Delay in delivery
Suit for damages
Commission Agent
HeadNote.description: Delay in delivery - Suit for damages - Commission Agent - Agent having interest in the goods can sue the railway administration for damages on account of delay in delivery. AIR 1976 Delhi 236 - Rel.on.	(Para 11)

heading: Railways Claims Tribunal Act (1987), Ss.13(2), 24
HeadNote.description:
Railways Claims Tribunal Act (1987), Ss.13(2), 24 - Transfer of pending cases - Notice u/s.80 of Civil P.C. - Pending suit which is transferred to the Claims Tribunal u/s.24 - Has to be treated and tried by the Claims Tribunal as an application and not as a Civil Suit - Provisions of Railways Act, 1989 and Rules made thereunder are applicable for inquiring into or determining the claims by the Claims Tribunal under the Act, 1987, in view of S.13(2) of the Act - Compliance of provisions of S.80 of Civil P.C. is not necessary before filing an application under S.16 of the Railway Claims Tribunal Act.

A pending suit which is transferred to the Claims Tribunal under Section 24 has to be treated and tried by the Claims Tribunal as an application and not as a civil suit.  It is further clear that the provisions of the Railways Act, 1989 and the Rules made thereunder are applicable for inquiring into or determining the claims by the Claims Tribunal under the Act of 1987, in view of Section 13(2) of the Act.  Similarly, sub-section (1) of Section 18 makes it amply clear that the Railway Claims Tribunal would not be bound by the procedure laid down by the Code of Civil Procedure but shall be guided by the principles of natural justice and shall have powers to regulate its own procedure.
