Though sub-section (3) of Section 18 stipulates that the Claims Tribunal may have the same powers as are vested in a Civil Court under the provisions of Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 for the purpose of discharging its function, it cannot be said that the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure would strictly apply to the proceedings pending before the Railway Claims Tribunal.  If a transferred suit is to be treated as an application under Section 24 of the Act of 1987, it would not be possible to hold that the provisions of Section 80 could be made applicable while deciding the application pending before the Railway Claims Tribunal. Though the provisions of Section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure are held to be mandatory and though the same could have been attracted to the facts of the instant case had the special civil suit which was filed by the appellant been decided by the Civil Court, it could not be said that they would still apply after the suit was transferred to the Railway Claims Tribunal.  Compliance of provisions of Section 80 of C.P.C. is not necessary before filing an application under Section 16 of the said Railway Claims Tribunal Act.  Though compliance with the provisions of Section 78-B of the Indian Railways Act, 1890, corresponding to Section 106 of the Railways Act, 1989 is mandatory and notice to the Railways would be necessary before institution of a claim before the Claims Tribunal under Section 16 of the Act of 1987, it cannot be said that notice under Section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure is also necessary in such a case.  In the instant case, there was compliance with the provisions of Section 78-B of the Railways Act before institution of the proceedings before the Civil Court or Railway Claims Tribunal.  Though it could be said that the compliance of provisions of Section 80 was necessary for instituting a civil suit against the Railways in an ordinary Civil Court, it cannot be said, especially after perusal of the provisions of sections 13(1), 18 and 24 of the Act of 1987, that a notice under Section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure was mandatory and non-compliance with the provisions of Section 80(1) dealing with the notice period, should result into dismissal or rejection of the claim.  The aforesaid conclusion is further fortified by the express provisions of Section 24(2)(b) which stipulate that it would be in the discretion of the Claims Tribunal to proceed with the transferred case from any stage or even de novo as it may deem fit.  When the Claims Tribunal has powers under Section 24(2)(b) to enquire in respect of a claim, afresh or de novo after its transfer, it cannot be said that the Claims Tribunal is deciding the civil suit and not as a claim petition filed under Section 16 of the Railway Claims Tribunal Act, 1987.  Thus, looking at the controversy from any angle, it could be said that the Claims Tribunal was not justified in rejecting the claim preferred by the appellant solely on the ground that there was non-compliance with the provisions of Section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure.  The Tribunal should not have rejected the claim application as the provisions of Section 80 of the Code of Civil Procedure were not applicable to the proceedings transferred to the Claims Tribunal and necessary notice under Section 78-B of the Railways Act, 1890 had already been served on the respondents. AIR 1984 SC 1043 - Referred to.  [Para 12,13]

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Railway passenger holding valid ticket fell from train and died - Negligence of passenger who was standing at open door of train compartment cannot be termed as 'criminal act' - Award of compensation of Rs.2 lakhs by Tribunal upheld.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Railways Circular No.95/2006
Penalty
Imposition of
HeadNote.description: Railways Circular No.95/2006 - Board's letter no.2008/TT-III/73/8, dt.1.7.08 - Penalty - Imposition of - Import of Manganese ore - Cargo handled by shipping line to port - Containers transported by container corporation to depot by rail-commodity declared as 'chips' and not manganese ore, restricted commodity - In Bill of loading commodity mentioned as manganese ore - Shipping service accepting mistake of description in communication with container corporation - Committing same error in second batch sent after 7 days - Importer-consigner not privy to wrong description - Container corporation recovered penalty earlier from shipping services - Importer not jointly and severally liable to pay penalty with shipping line. (Paras. 21, 23)

heading: Railway accident
HeadNote.description: Railway accident - Deceased was thrown out from running train due to crowd and sudden jerk - Importance cannot be given to fact that ticket was not recovered from victim's dead body as it may be thrown out or lost - Furthermore Railway Administration do have employees to check ticketless travelers and prosecute them immediately - There was no evidence adduced that it was not untoward incident - Railway administration is responsible for death of passenger irrespective of wrongful act, neglect or default on its part - Order of Tribunal to pay compensation, upheld. 			(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation for
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Compensation for - Claimant fell down between gap of platform and train and sustained amputation of two fingers - Compensation has to be awarded as per Rule 1997 - It was awarded in sum of Rs. 1,20,000/- by Tribunal as per said Rule - Award of compensation, proper. (Paras 2, 3)

heading: Delay
HeadNote.description:
Delay - Application for condonation of, rejected by Tribunal - Simultaneously findings on merits were recorded that claim is not tenable as there was no compliance of S.106 - Held, if application for condonation of delay is rejected, matter cannot be decided on merits - Order liable to be set aside - Matter liable to be remanded back.

2001(3) ALL MR 400, AIR 1995 SC 1111 Disting.

2009(2) ALL MR 429 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			 [Para 5]

heading: Claim as to
HeadNote.description: Short delivery of consignment - Claim as to - Burden to prove weight of consignment at time of loading - Remarks on railway receipt read as "said to contain" and "loading not supervised by staff" - That means railway administration did not accept correctness of quantity mentioned by consignor - Consignor did not insist railway staff to check quantity nor did he accept receipt under protest - Consignor bore the risk involved in handing over consignment - Finding that consignor failed to prove short delivery of consignment - Not erroneous. 	(Paras 7, 8, 11)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Passenger fell off crowded train due to sudden jerk - Suffered amputation of right hand and two fingers of left hand - Produced railway ticket, police papers as well as medical papers - Booking clerk of Railway admitted issuance of ticket - Under these circumstances, held, accidental falling of claimant covered within definition of "untoward incident" u/s.123 - If Railway intended to take shelter of exception u/s.124-A, it must have taken such plea in reply to claim petition and led specific evidence - Having failed to plead and prove exception, Railway cannot escape liability - No infirmity in order granting compensation. 	(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Compensation
Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Untoward incident - Claimant fell down due to sudden jerk and his left palm came under wheel of train - Evidence on record shows that claimant suffered 65% disability in untoward incident - On behalf of railway administration by an interested witness they just denied incident - When victim suffers in untoward incident, his evidence before Tribunal alongwith documentary evidence in support thereof ought to be kept on high pedestal than mere denial of incident by an interested witness on behalf of railway administration - Also claimant receives compensation on account of untoward incident, unless conduct of such claimant is blameworthy on account of exceptional facts which must be pleaded and established by railway administration - Claimant ought to succeed to receive compensation on evidence which appears reasonably acceptable upon preponderance of probabilities - No such exceptional facts pleaded and established by railway administration - Claimant entitled to receive compensation. 	(Para 4)

heading: Accidental death
HeadNote.description: Accidental death - Death of passenger by accidental falling from train - Deceased found between "S" and "P" stations - Ticket recovered from his person was also for travelling between "S" and "P" - Held though body was cut into two pieces there was sufficient evidence to show that it was accidental death and not death while crossing railway line.  (Paras 4, 5)

heading: Claim for compensation
Non-delivery of goods
HeadNote.description: Claim for compensation - Non-delivery of goods - No enquiry made or information was sought from railway administration under any written endorsement regarding alleged non-delivery of goods in writing within six months - Notice served after expiry of six months from date of booking - Notice invalid. 	(Paras 2, 5)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - What is.

In the instant case whether it was in claimant's anxiety to alight the reserved compartment in order to board the general compartment or whether it was due to push given by TTE that the injured passanger fell down, in either case, injured came within the expression "accidental falling of a passenger from a train carrying passengers" which is an 'untoward incident' as defined in section 123 (c) of the Railways Act, 1989.

2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Foll.	       [Para 8]

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Compensation - Liability of Railway to pay - Deceased by purchasing general class ticket boarded in wrong train and died due to fall from train - Deceased came to Nanded Railway Station and desired to go purna, was established - No contrary evidence was produced by Railway - In such circumstances Railway could not avoid its liability to compensate victim - Order granting compensation of Rs.4,00,000/- was proper.

2013 ACT 635, 2010(5) ALL MR 986 (S.C.), 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			 [Para 6,7,9]

heading: Untoward incident
Challenge
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Dismissal of claim petition - Ground that deceased was not a bonafide passenger - Challenge - Tribunal did not record evidence in accordance with law - Important documents were produced but no endorsement was taken from Advocate for other side as to whether documents admitted or denied - Affidavit of claimant was allowed but proceedings did not indicate as to whether cross-examination was conducted by Railway Administration - Tribunal dismissed claim even though there was no record of legal evidence - Not proper - Direction given to Tribunal to allow parties to lead evidence in accordance with law and then decide claim. 	(Para 3)

heading: Liability of Railway
HeadNote.description: Compensation for untoward incident - Liability of Railway - Contention that deceased was not bonafide passenger - Burden to prove this is on Railway - Submission by Railway that no ticket, pass or identity card found on body of deceased - No evidence produced to support its submission by Railway - Evidence of widow, employer, witnesses state that deceased had gone to attend office - Spot, inquest panchanama, post-mortem report show that body was lying near platform having injury on vital organs - Documentary evidence shows that deceased met with untoward incident - Judgment that Railway to pay compensation is not liable to be interfered with. 2004(1) ALT 100 - Ref. to. 2005(4) ALL MR 189 - Rel. on.	(Para 4)

heading: Findings recorded by Railway Claims Tribunal
HeadNote.description: Findings recorded by Railway Claims Tribunal - Findings based on proper appreciation of legal and equitable principles - It would not be proper to reverse the findings recorded by Tribunal - Held, Railway Administration cannot be made an exception to the principle of equity - It cannot charge more than what was just and reasonable and unduly enrich itself. Contract Act (1872), S.72.	(Para 4)

heading: Untoward incident
Liability of Railway
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Liability of Railway - Claimant fell down from train due to forceful push of heavy crowd in compartment - He lost both his legs - Railway denied its liability on ground that claimant himself was negligent in standing near the door - Held, claimant cannot be blamed for standing near the door if there was crowd - Railway could not show that there was no crowd - Unless Railway prevents crowd from entering into compartment at starting station itself, it cannot escape its liability - Mishap comes within meaning of "untoward incident" - No exception u/s.124-A pleaded or proved - Railway liable to pay compensation. 		 	(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Loss or damage to consignment
HeadNote.description:
Loss or damage to consignment - Compensation on basis of weight of consignment - Weight of goods to be considered without taking into account the weight of packing or preservatives.

In Section 2(9) of the Railways Act, 1989 the term "consignment" has been defined to mean 'goods entrusted to a railway administration for carriage'. The expression 'goods entrusted for carriage' can only be understood as what is actually intended to be carried by the Railways, and not any items of packing or those required for preserving the goods intended to be carried. In the instant case, it were the fish that was intended to be carried by the Railways and not the ice or the packing in which the fish was kept for its proper carriage. Needless to say, no item used for packing or preserving an article under transport, could be, by any logic meant to be sent or carried by the consignor just for the sake of it. Therefore, the weight of the consignment would have to be taken as the weight of the goods entrusted to the Railway Administration and intended by the consignor to be transported by it. In other words, it is the net weight of the consignment and not the gross weight of the consignment, which is required to be considered for the purposes of Rule 3(iii) of the Rules, 1990.  [Para 8]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Death of passenger in an untoward incident - Deceased falling down from running local train after his head banged on railway post - Deceased having railway season ticket and stood near door of compartment - Incident taken place during evening rush hours - Held, judicial notice has to be taken of the fact that in the City of Mumbai suburban local trains are always overcrowded - Passengers have no option but to stand near doors of compartment as it becomes impossible to force entry inside compartment during rush hours - No case of his negligence made by Railway Authority - This being a case of accidental fall, the claimant would be entitled to compensation.

In the present case, the deceased was travelling by a suburban local train in the city of Mumbai. The incident occurred at about 18.35 in the evening. A judicial notice has to be taken of the fact that in the city of Mumbai the suburban local trains are always overcrowded. In the present case, the incident has taken place during evening rush hours. It is a fact of life in the city of Mumbai that it is very difficult even to enter the 2nd class compartments of suburban local railway trains at any hour during the course of the day. Especially in morning and evening rush hours the situation is worst and forcing one's entry in a train becomes a daunting task. The situation is not different even on a public holiday. The passengers who normally travel by suburban trains in the city have no choice but to undertake travelling by over-crowded suburban trains only with the object of reaching their respective places of work for earning livelihood. To keep up with the speed with which the city of Mumbai moves, the passengers have no option but to stand near the doors of the compartment as it is impossible to force entry inside the compartments. No purpose is served by waiting for the next train as the situation continues to be the same. There are poles/posts erected by railways near the railway tracks for carrying electric and other cables. A person who stands at the door on the foot board has to survive the enormous pressure exerted by the passengers who are standing inside. There is every possibility that a passenger who is standing at the door may loose his balance due to the pressure of heavy rush. In such a case there is every likelihood that he will be hit by a pole/post standing by the side of Railway track and suffer the inevitable.  However, there may be cases where a passenger is adventurous and though it may be possible to enter the compartment he may choose to hang outside the door on the foot board. When such a person suffers the fate as the deceased in this case has suffered, it is possible to say that he had suffered a self-inflicted injury. But that is not even the case made out by the railway administration in the present case before the Tribunal. No such specific case is made out in written statement. This is a case where the deceased alongwith his wife were travelling by a suburban train to meet their relative at Bhandup. There is more than sufficient evidence on record to show that it was a case of accidental fall from the railway. By no stretch of imagination any negligence can be attributed to the deceased. It does not lie in the mouth of the railway administration to say that as the deceased passenger was standing on the foot board near the door of the compartment, he was negligent. It is an accepted fact in the city of Mumbai that the passengers are forced to stand near the door due to perpetual overcrowding of the suburban trains. There is no option left with the passengers but to do so if they have to reach the place of work in time. 	Therefore, present case will not fall in the category of exception carved out by clause (b) of section 124-A. Court cannot shut eyes to the ground realities of the life in the city of Mumbai.  [Para 10,13]

heading: Parcel Leasing Policy
HeadNote.description: Parcel Leasing Policy - Railway leased out luggage rakes of trains by auction process so as to avoid loss of revenue caused due to underutilized luggage capacity - Railway held entitled or empowered to auction the space for particular period - Provided auction contractor adheres to prescribed tariff - Direction issued to Railway to fix outer or upper limit of rates chargeable by contractor for different trains, held proper.  (Para 16)

heading: Claim petition
HeadNote.description: Claim petition - Damages arising out of non-delivery of goods - Valuation given in forwarding note does not bind the claimant - Valuation is a matter of evidence and proof - Consignor can prove that actual value was much more than the value he had voluntarily declared - Railway Administration not applying its mind to documents and evidence produced and relying only on railway receipt and forwarding note - Matter remanded.        (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Untoward incident
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Evidence and proof - Claim that deceased accidentally fell down from train and died - Claimant widow produced a railway ticket on record, stating that same was recovered by police from dead body - However, list of items prepared by police makes no mention of any such ticket - Besides, two inconsistent statements given by widow on question of date on which deceased left his native place - No eye witness to alleged incident - Even Station Supdt. on duty stated to have received no report of any such incident - Nothing to show that deceased boarded train on relevant date - Question of deceased falling from train, also does not arise - Untoward incident not proved - Claim petition validly dismissed. 			(Paras 6, 9, 10)

heading: Untoward incident
Evidence and proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Evidence and proof - Claim that deceased fell down from a train and died thereafter - However, train not identified - Neither passenger ticket nor anything else recovered from possession of deceased to show that deceased was a bonafide passenger - Claim petition is also delayed by more than five years - It is therefore impossible for Railway Administration to conduct proper enquiry - There being no valid evidence, stale and unreasonable petition liable to be dismissed. 	(Para 3)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Deceased, while travelling by train, fell down and came under wheels of train and died on spot - Railway ticket was not recovered from dead body - However, brother of deceased stated that he himself had purchased railway ticket from Umri to Nanded for deceased - Said statement is corroborated by police papers which show the location of incident - Presumption is that deceased was a bonafide passenger - No evidence adduced by railway to contrary - Compensation granted.	(Para 6)

heading: Bar of jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Bar of jurisdiction - Complaint that Central Railway was charging Ist Class fare for A.C. Chair Car - Proper forum to file the complaint is Railway Rates Tribunal - Complaint filed in Consumers Disputes Redressal Commission - Commission directing the Central Railway to charge actual fare from the passenger and further directed to pay the complainant Rs.2,372/- as cost of the Complaint - Jurisdiction of the commission being barred, the order of the commission quashed and set aside.	(Para 4)

heading: Claim against Railways
HeadNote.description: Railway Claims Tribunal (Procedure) Rules (1989), R.44 - Railways (Manner of Delivery of Consignments and Sale Proceeds in the Absence of Railway Receipt) Rules (1990), R.3(1), (2) - Claim against Railways - What the Tribunal is required to determine is claim against Railway administration and not inter se disputes between the claimant and third parties. 	(Para 18)

heading: Railway claim
Dependent
HeadNote.description: Railway claim - Dependent - Claimant-elder brother of deceased is not a dependent as defined u/S.123(b) of Act - Thus, claimant is not entitled for compensation in respect of death of his younger brother. (Para 8)

heading: Untoward incident
Claim for compensation
Rejection
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Claim for compensation - Rejection - Ground that application filed by claimants with regard to deceased aged 75 years, whereas dead body recovered was of unidentified male of 45 years who was run over by train - Assessment made by doctor regarding age of deceased is not acceptable without radiological report as head was completely smashed and body was full of scratches - Claimants have identified dead body from clothes and it was handed over to them by Railways - No evidence to show that some other persons also came to claim dead body - Considering evidence of witnesses coupled with injury found on deceased as well as residential address of deceased establishes that deceased was victim of untoward incident as defined u/S.123(c)(2) of Railways Act - No contrary evidence brought on record by Railway by fixing any Video Camera at every pole of Railway to establish that it is run over by a Rail and not an untoward incident as defined u/S.123(c)(2) of Act - Claimants entitled to compensation of Rs.4,00,000/- with interest at 7.5% p.a.
2018 ALL SCR 1750, 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Rel. on. 
(Paras 17, 18, 19, 22)

headline: No evidence brought on record by Railway to establish that deceased has not died in untoward incident as defined u/S.123(c)(2) of Railways Act – Claimants entitled to compensation.

heading: Damages
Compensation
Open delivery granted
HeadNote.description: Damages - Compensation - Consignment loaded properly arrived at destination in broken condition - Open delivery granted - Shortages of goods detected - Railway authority and consignee putting their signatures on report of open delivery - Not open for railways to turn Nelson's eye to shortage certificate and loss or damage ascertained there under - Compensation awarded by Tribunal being just and proper affirmed. 2005(2) TAC 671 (AP), 2005(1) TAC 164 (AP), AIR 1987 Ori 149 Disting and AIR 2000 Ori 27 Disting. 	(Para 8)

heading: Accidental falling from train
HeadNote.description: Accidental falling from train - Sudden jerk in running train - Deceased colliding against Home Signal but was not allowed to fall down by his brothers who pulled him back - Words "falling from train" must receive liberal interpretation - Deceased received injuries due to forceful jerk and case was covered by definition of "untoward incident" and railway administration cannot refuse to pay compensation.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Death of deceased as a result of falling down from train - Burden of proof - Burden is always on the railway to prove that deceased was not bonafide passenger.

Since the burden is always on the railway, and since that burden has not been discharged by the railway, it has to be held that the deceased was bonafide passenger. Secondly, what has come in the evidence of Vikram Singh is that the handle which deceased Prasad was holding in the train broke down. If this is so, then it is clear that the entire responsibility for the death of Prasad is of the railway, because maintenance of railway carriers by which the passengers are carried is the responsibility of the railway. If defective handles and broken handles are not replaced and, the passengers suffer on that count, then railway cannot escape from its liability. 2002 CLT (SC) 176, 1994(1) T.A.C. 67 and 1993 ACJ 846 - Referred to.	 [Para 13,14]

heading: Railway accident
Claim for compensation
HeadNote.description: Railway accident - Death due to untoward incident - Claim for compensation - Deceased bonafide passenger fell down while traveling in local train and succumbed to the injuries - Question of deceased being a bonafide passenger is an admitted fact - Definition of untoward incident perused - Railways failed to prove that case falls within exceptions - Therefore Tribunal bound to give findings based on principles of law - Claimant held, entitled to compensation. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Railway property not taxable
HeadNote.description: Railway property not taxable - Malliable Iron Casting (MIC) parts - The term railways 'material' or any other loose description as to Railway's interest in goods or alleged admission by Railway that MIC parts are purchased by Railway in itself, held, does not prove that the ownership of goods on the day of detention was that of Railway. (Para 46)

heading: Publication of declaration
HeadNote.description: Publication of declaration - Is complete when it is published in official gazette - Even if it is published in any newspaper, it will only be for general information and will not serve any purpose under the Act - What is relevant for purpose of reckoning period of one year is the date of declaration under S.20-E(1) in official gazette and nothing else.		(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Lapsing of acquisition
HeadNote.description: Lapsing of acquisition - Delay in making award - Competent Authority proceeding on basis that when public notice is published in newspapers date of publication in newspapers would be date of publication of declaration and award made within one year from such date would be proper publication - Delay was result of such assumption - Hence acquisition did not lapse but land owners would be entitled to additional compensation for delay in making award at a rate not less than 5% of the value of award for each month of delay.			(Para 11)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Compensation - Deceased died due to fall from running local train - Second class railway journey ticket was recovered from body of deceased - Wife of deceased was material eye witness - No fact pleaded to show that victim was rash and negligent in any manner so as to endanger his own safety or he was indulged into a criminal act u/Ss.134 and 136 of Railways Act - Thus, accident was covered within meaning of untoward incident - Claimant entitled to compensation of Rs.4,00,000/- along with interest. 			(Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Compensation - Liability of Railway Administration, stated.

Dependents of any bonafide Passenger of the train or even holder of valid platform ticket, upon entering into Railway premises if such bonafide user becomes victim of an untoward fatal incident must be compensated, even assuming for the sake of argument that such user was knocked down by the train. In such cases the liability of the Railway administration is strict, irrespective of proof of any wrongful act, neglect or default on the part of the Railway administration. 						       [Para 7]

heading: Offence under
Ingredients
Accused obstructing
HeadNote.description: Offence under - Ingredients - Charge that accused obstructed Assistant Engineer in discharge of duties - Incident not taking place either in railway carriage or upon any part of railway - Assistant Engineer visiting some Railway station and after completing work intending to return home - Accused obstructing - Assistant Engineer while latter was occupying front seat - Accused also threatening Assistant Engineer - Held, that the Assistant Engineer had completed his duties and had come to jeep to return home and as such complainant could not be said to be on duty - Ss.145 and 146 could not be attracted and conviction there under could not be sustained.	(Para 4)

heading: Railway
Claim for compensation
Entitlement
Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Railway - Death due to untoward incident - Claim for compensation - Entitlement - Deceased fell on railway track while getting into moving train and run over by train - Tribunal rejected claim holding witness as interested and that happening was not an 'untoward incident' - High Court allowed the claim - Appeal - Supreme Court upheld High Court views and dismissed appeal.

There was no good reason to disbelieve witness because there is nothing to show that he had any motive to give false evidence, or that he was an interested witness. Further, his evidence could not have been discarded merely because he did not go to the spot and help in removing the dead body from the railway track.  Moreover, merely because police did not record his statement does not mean that he was not present or gave false evidence.  It is common knowledge that in our country often there is a large crowd on railway platforms, and it is simply impossible for the police to record statement of everyone there.  However, evidence of the Station Master corroborated the evidence of PW-2 who has been disbelieved.  Deceased had attempted to board the train and fell down from the running train.  It will not make any difference whether the deceased was actually inside the train when she fell down or whether she was only trying to get into the train when she fell down.  In either case it amounts an 'accidental falling of a passenger from a train carrying passenger. 'Hence, it is an 'untoward incident' within the expression in S.123(c) of the Railways Act, 1989 and claimants are entitled to compensation.  Appeal dismissed.  					      [Para 7,10]

heading: Railway
Accident
Compensation
Entitlement
Interpretation of expressions
HeadNote.description:
Railway - Accident - Compensation - Entitlement - Interpretation of expressions - The expression 'accidental falling of a passenger from a train carrying passengers' includes accidents when a bona fide passenger i. e. a passenger travelling with a valid ticket or pass is trying to enter into a railway train and falls down during the process.

No doubt, it is possible that two interpretations can be given to the expression 'accidental falling of a passenger from a train carrying passengers,' the first being that it only applies when a person has actually got inside the train and thereafter falls down from the train, while the second being that it includes a situation where a person is trying to board the train and falls down while trying to do so.  Since the provision for compensation in the Railways Act is a beneficial piece of legislation, it should receive a liberal and wider interpretation and not a narrow and technical one.  The latter of the above mentioned two interpretations i.e. the one which advances the object of the statute and serves its purpose should be preferred.  					 [Para 11,12]

If we adopt a restrictive meaning to the expression 'accidental falling of a passenger from a train carrying passengers' in Section123(c) of the Railways Act, we will be depriving a large number of railway passenger victims of train accidents from getting compensation in railway accidents.  The expression 'accidental falling of a passenger from a train carrying passengers' includes accidents when a bona fide passenger i.e. a passenger travelling with a valid ticket or pass is trying to enter into a railway train and falls down during the process.   [Para 14]

heading: Railway
Accident
Compensation
Entitlement
Interpretation of provisions
HeadNote.description:
Railway - Accident - Compensation - Entitlement - Interpretation of provisions - Provision for compensation in the Railways Act being a beneficial piece of legislation should be given liberal and not literal or strict interpretation.

It is well settled that if the words used in a beneficial or welfare statute are capable of two constructions, the one which is more in consonance with the object of the Act and for the benefit of the person for whom the Act was made should be preferred.  In other words, beneficial or welfare statutes should be given a liberal and not literal or strict interpretation.  						 [Para 12]

heading: Railway-Accident
Compensation
Entitlement
HeadNote.description:
Railway-Accident - Compensation - Entitlement - Deceased fell on railway track while getting into moving train and run over by train - Accident in which deceased died is not clearly covered by Proviso to S.124-A - Accident did not occur because of any of the reasons mentioned in clauses (a) to (e) of the Proviso - Case is clearly covered by the main body of S.124, and not its Proviso - If a case comes within the purview of S.124-A it is wholly irrelevant as to who was at fault - Doctrine of strict liability discussed. Constitution of India, Art.38(1).

In this case, the Supreme Court has narrated the evolution of the doctrine of strict liability (also known as no fault liability), it has surveyed its status across the jurisdictions in the world and has explained how it has been an exception to the general principles of the law of torts that there is no liability without fault.  Thus in cases where principle of strict liability applies, the defendant has to pay damages for injury caused to the plaintiff, even though the defendant may not have been at any fault.  Court has explained how the doctrine is a method for imposing losses on superior risk bearers, by referring to various authorities on the subject of strict liability Court has noted how the principles laid down in Rylands Vs. Fletcher, 1866 LRI Ex 265 have been diluted over the period of time and what has been the recent trend in application of the doctrine of strict liability and it witnessed swing in favour of this principle by referring to Bhopal Gas Tragedy and its decision in M. C. Mehta's case -AIR 1987 SC 1086- and that strict liability is not subject to any exceptions to the rule in Rylands Vs. Fletcher.  The idea that public bodies act not for its own profit but for the benefit of the community and it should not be liable to strict liability is based on misconception.  Strict liability has no element of moral censure.  It is because such public bodies benefit the community that it is unfair to leave the result of a non-negligent accident to lie fortuitously on a particular individual rather than to spread it among the community generally.  In various social welfare statutes in India the principle of strict liability has been provided to give insurance to people against death and injuries, irrespective of fault.  Court re-emphasised need of developing new principles for fixing liability in cases like the present one and the law of strict liability de hors statutory provisions in view of M. C. Mehta's decision.  Law of torts is not stagnant but is growing.  Submission of appellant that there was no fault on the part of railways, or that there was contributory negligence, is based on a total misconception and hence has to be rejected.  Appeal dismissed.  				 [Para 16,17,18,56]

heading: Compensation for
Notice is mandatory
HeadNote.description: Short supply of goods - Compensation for - Notice under S.106 to railway administration - Notice is mandatory - Provisions of Ss.106, 107, not being retrospective in operation, are not applicable to suits or claims filed before Act of 1989 was brought into force.		(Paras 21 to 23)

heading: Strict liability of Railway
HeadNote.description:
Strict liability of Railway - Railway administration undertakes hazardous activities - Strictly liable for certain accidents despite the fact that there may not be any wrongful act, negligence or default on its part - Exceptions to such strict liability are mentioned in S.124A.

The claimants in accident claim cases are often dependents on the deceased and may not have personal knowledge about the untoward incident. The claim is based upon knowledge which the claimants may get from the Railways itself in respect of untoward incident occurring within the premises of Railways. The Railway Administration which undertakes hazardous activity of running passenger trains using rail tracks have strict liability towards passengers travelling by train. In a given case, the train may suddenly stop with a jerk and the passengers from the crowded compartments may, as a result of falling down, may fall prey to an untoward incident. In such cases, the Railways cannot be allowed to plead ignorance about occurrence. Liability of Railway Administration for death of passenger due to accident is covered under Chapter XIII of the Railway Acts, 1939. Section 123(c)(2) relates to untoward incident which includes the accidental falling of any passenger from a train carrying passengers. Section 124 lays down principle of strict liability notwithstanding anything contained in any other law. Railway Administration is strictly liable for certain accidents to train or any part of the train carrying passengers despite the fact that there may not be any wrongful act, neglect or default on the part of the Railway Administration. 						      [Para 6]

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Challenge to the findings that deceased was a bona fide passenger and died while getting down from the train - Appellant Railway seeking remand of matter to Tribunal for producing fresh evidence - Held, it was obligation of appellant to lead evidence that the deceased was not bona fide passenger holding railway ticket and was not getting down from compartment of the train - Appellant did not lead evidence to bring the case within exception listed u/s. 124A - No fault can be found with the Tribunal when it decided to award compensation on the basis of the available evidence before it which was not contradicted by appellants - Appeal dismissed.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Untoward accident
HeadNote.description: Untoward accident - Railway alleged that deceased committed suicide in front of train - Train ticket recovered from dead body - Initial report that a person on uptrack, came between compartment - Person who reported this was not examined - Valid railway ticket gives inference that deceased was bonafide passenger. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Rule of strict liability
HeadNote.description:
Rule of strict liability - Cases where Rule of strict liability applies, Railway administration has to pay compensation - Even though it may not have any fault.
2007 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 147 Rel. on. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Railway accident
HeadNote.description:
Railway accident - Deceased was standing at open door of railway compartment and fell down - Standing at open door of compartment may be negligent act - However it is not criminal act with element of malicious intent of mens rea - It comes within expression of 'untoward incident' - Compensation granted, to be upheld.

2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.), 2010(4) ALL MR 472 (S.C.), 2010(5) ALL MR 986 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	 [Para 9,10]

heading: Interest
Railway accident
HeadNote.description: Interest - Railway accident - Deceased was standing at open door of railway compartment and fell down - Compensation of Rs. 4,00,000/- granted with reasonable interest of 7% p.a. - Appeal liable to be dismissed. 	(Para 10)

heading: Consignment
HeadNote.description: Consignment - Goods not delivered at all - Consignor certainly has a right to claim the damages for loss caused to the goods.			(Para 7)

heading: Consignment
Damage to goods
Suit for damages
HeadNote.description: Consignment - Damage to goods - Suit for damages - Suit can be instituted against only one Railway.	(Para 7)

heading: Consignment
Non-delivery of
HeadNote.description:
Consignment - Non-delivery of - Damage to consignment is the result of delay in transit - This is certainly a case of non-delivery - Held, Railway is liable to make good the loss.

The negligence on the part of the Railways in this case in handling the consignment is writ large. Hence, no blame can be put at the door of the consignee in not taking the delivery. The consignment was booked on 26th May, 1984, and it reached destination on 29th June, 1984. Obviously, it reached the destination after more than a month. It ought to reach the destination at the most in week's time. The Railway did not tender any evidence about normal time of delivery and also in respect of handling of consignment. It must, therefore, be said that it was Railway administration, who was negligent in handling the consignment. If the goods reached the destination after more than one month they are bound to be damaged in transit being perishable. There is nothing on record to suggest that the consignor was informed of arrival of consignment. The consignee is not supposed to make an enquiry about consignment for weeks together particularly, when the goods are perishable. Therefore, if, after 15 days the consignee did not make enquiry about delivery the blame cannot be put at his door. He is not expected to visit the Office of the Railway for months together to find out if the consignment has arrived. The pleadings show that almost entire consignment was in damaged condition. The damage to the consignment is the result of delay in transit. This is certainly a case of non-delivery. The Railway is squarely liable to make good the loss.  [Para 8]

heading: Railway accident
HeadNote.description:
Railway accident - Defence that deceased was leaning outside, dash against pole, fell down - Evidence clearly show that death of deceased was due to accidental falling from train - It is untoward incident under S.123 - Defence liable to be rejected. 
2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) - Rel. on.  (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Railway accident
Authorised passenger
HeadNote.description:
Railway accident - Authorised passenger - Defendant did not produce valid ticket - Deceased was not detected as passenger travelling without ticket - Unless contrary is proved it has to be presumed that deceased was authorised passenger - Appeal against award of compensation liable to be dismissed.  
2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) - Rel. on.  (Paras 13, 14)

heading: Untoward incident
Bonafide passenger
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Bonafide passenger - Respondent held season pass for travelling between Parbhani and Nanded and it was not valid for superfast trains - But respondent produced season ticket that was valid between 19-11-2007 till 18-12-2007 when incident took place on 22-11-2007 - No contrary evidence produced by railways - Held respondent was bonafide passenger. (Para 7)

heading: Untoward incident
Proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Proof - Respondent suffered injury to his eye due to pelting of stones while travelling - Unexplained delay of 9 months in filing FIR from date of incident - Respondent though claimed that he was taken to railway police chowki and from there he was sent to medical examination - None of police personnel examined by him nor he brought any record from police chowki to corroborate incident - Also discharge card issued by hospital does not show as to how patient has received injury, there was no mention about any incident taken place in Railways - Tribunal having not considered aforesaid facts nor dealt with issue of untoward incident in a satisfactory manner and granted compensation - Award of tribunal set aside - Matter remanded back for fresh consideration. (Paras 8, 9)

heading: Fall of deceased
HeadNote.description: Compensation on account of untoward incident - Fall of deceased - Fall, a result of untoward incident - The claimants, held, would be entitled for compensation amount.		(Para 18)

heading: Fall
HeadNote.description: Compensation on account of "untoward incident" - Fall - When a person accidentally falls from the train because of some jerk etc., held, it would not amount to "self-inflicted injury" but an "untoward incident" - Claimants entitled to compensation under S.124-A of the Act.	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Railway accident
Liability
HeadNote.description: Railway accident - Liability - Allegations that deceased boarded train by off side - Accidental falling of any passenger from train is untoward incident - Person who has purchased valid ticket, who becomes victim of untoward incident is covered within meaning of term 'untoward incident' - Deceased had railway ticket is not disputed - Dependents of victim are entitled to claim compensation. 	(Para 6)

heading: Railway accident
HeadNote.description: Railway accident - Report of Inspector, RPF prima facie appears unbelievable - Passengers on platform would not shout in chorus that one man is laying under running train - Further Railway Administration ought to have examined Inquiry Officer as to why he did not record statement of any such person, who could have deposed relevant facts before Tribunal - In absence of evidence order of Tribunal granting compensation, upheld. 	(Para 7)

heading: Untoward incident
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Limited amount of compensation upto Rs.4,00,000/- towards "no fault liability" - No restriction on claimant to seek compensation beyond said amount if he is able to establish any wrongful act, neglect or default on part of railway administration - Tribunal refusing such opportunity to claimants - Not justified - Matter required to be remitted back to Tribunal. 	(Para 10)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Accident occurred while passenger boarding train fell down when train had started to roll down on track - Would be covered as "untoward incident". 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Para 10)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Whether, covered by exception to S.124A - Appellant was bonafide passenger holding valid ticket-cum-reservation - Accident occurred while he tried to get back in train when it had started moving - He had alienated from train only to buy toothbrush and in that process, he had to move here and there and when he was away from bogie, train started rolling - No act done by appellant which endangered safety of other passengers nor he persisted to travel on roof, step or engine of train or any other part of train not intended for use of passengers in spite of warning by railway servant - Negligence could be attributed not to appellant but to railway administration for not making available requisite store for passengers travelling on long distance trains - Hence, accident not covered by any exception to S.124A. 	(Para 13)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Compensation - Accident occurred while passenger boarding train fell down when train had started to roll down on track - As result, passenger has suffered amputation of his left thigh - Such accident is covered by entry no.19 of Notification dated 22nd December 2016 - Therefore, passenger is entitled to receive compensation of Rs.4,80,000/- under this entry.			(Para 14)

heading: Untoward incident
Payability of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Payability of compensation - From date of accident and not from date of award - However, interest from date of accident till payment will be at such rate as may be considered just and fair by Tribunal, on same pattern as in accident claim cases - If amount so calculated is less than amount prescribed as on date of award, claimant will be entitled to higher of two amounts. 

(2001) 3 SCC 714, (1976) 1 SCC 289 Ref. to. 	(Para 15.4)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Exemption from liability on ground of 'self- inflicted injury' - Negligence of a passenger while boarding or de-boarding train, does not fall within concept of 'self-inflicted injury' - It would require an intentional act and not mere negligence - Concept of contributory negligence is alien to liability based on 'no fault theory'.

2018 ALL SCR 1254 Ref. to. 

AIR 2014 Kerala (12), (2017) III ACC 799 (Bom), (2018) ACJ 702 Held Not Good Law in view of 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) & 2010(5) ALL MR 986 (S.C.) 	(Para 16.6)

heading: Bona fide passenger
Presumption as to
HeadNote.description:
Bona fide passenger - Presumption as to - Mere presence of a body on Railway premises will not be conclusive to hold that injured or deceased was a bona fide passenger - However, mere absence of ticket will also not suffice to reject claim regarding bona fide of passenger - Initial burden will be on claimant which can be discharged by filing affidavit of relevant facts and burden will then shift on Railways - Issue can be decided on case to case basis. 

(2015) ACJ 171, 2013 ACJ 1061 Approved.

(1993) ACJ 846 Held Not Good Law. 

AIR 2017 SC 1436 Ref. to. 	(Para 17.4)

heading: Untoward incident
Claim for compensation
Rate of interest
Not warranted
HeadNote.description:
Untoward incident - Claim for compensation - Rate of interest - Two different rates from date of application till date of award and from date of award till realization - Not warranted - In absence of any specific statutory provision, interest can be awarded without making any difference in two stages - Legal position in this regard is at par with cases of accident claims under Motor Vehicles Act, 1988. 

2010(4) ALL MR 472 (S.C.), (2011) ACJ 2356 Ref. to. 	(Para 18)

heading: Untoward incident
Justifiability
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Dismissal of claim on ground that deceased was not bona fide passenger - Justifiability - No ticket recovered by Railway Police from deceased - Yet, inquest report clearly showing that deceased while travelling in train had dashed against electric post, sustained grievous injuries and died on spot and that there were no other reasons for his death - Tribunal however dismissed claim merely on ground that passenger was not bona fide - Tribunal failed to consider benefit of doubt that deceased could have been a bona fide passenger, should be given to claimant while dealing with a beneficial piece of legislation - Hence, impugned order held not sustainable - Claimant held entitled to compensation. 2012 (3) CTC 741 Rel.on.	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: Untoward incident
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Victim whether a bona fide passenger - Burden of proof - Normal presumption is that a passenger in a train holds a valid ticket - Therefore, onus is on Railway Administration to prove that victim was not bona fide passenger. 	(Para 15)

heading: Untoward incident
Dismissal of claim
Legality
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Dismissal of claim - On ground that there is no evidence of bonafide passenger - Legality - Accident summary report and statement of co-passenger show that deceased was travelling in general compartment of train - He was standing at the door of compartment and fell down as the train started - Negligence cannot be attributed to deceased as general compartments are normally crowded - Further, in view of S.124-A, presumption is that deceased was bonafide passenger - Claimants are entitled to compensation. (Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Untoward incident
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Strict liability of Railway - In case where deceased died due to accidental fall from train, Railway Administration is strictly liable to pay compensation unless evidence is adduced to establish that deceased was not bonafide passenger. 2010(5) ALL MR 986 (S.C.) Foll. (Para 3)

heading: Untoward incident
Proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Proof - Dead body of deceased found lying on railway track between Bodwad and Bhusawal - Inquest panchnama showing that Railway ticket purchased at 12.17 pm on date of incident, recovered from pocket of pant worn by deceased - Merely because seizure of same was not mentioned in spot panchnama, would not render the same suspicious - Infact spot panchnama recorded that body of deceased was already sent to Hospital and there was nothing worth seizure found at place of incident - Time mentioned on ticket clearly showing that deceased was travelling between Bodwad and Bhusawal at time of incident - Tribunal however held that since there is no eyewitness to show that deceased had indeed purchased said ticket and recovery of other articles apart from ticket not mentioned in spot panchnama, said ticket is manipulated - Approach of tribunal is hyper technical, hence not sustainable - Material on record sufficient to prove that death occurred while travelling in train - Claimants entitled to claim compensation. 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Railway claim
Quantum of compensation
HeadNote.description: Railway claim - Quantum of compensation - Fact that deceased died in untoward incident while travelling in train, proved - Claimants held entitled to Rs.8,00,000/- as per latest amended Rules brought into force by Gazette Notification dt.22/12/2016. 	(Para 17)

heading: Untoward incident
Claim for compensation
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Claim for compensation - Applicant had valid journey ticket to travel from Saundad to Barabhati - Alleged incident occurred in middle of journey - As per applicant, due to rush and jerk of train, he fell down from running train near platform - As result, his left leg had to be cut above knee - Whereas, eye witness-ticket seller stated that applicant fell from train as he was trying to alight from running train - Not acceptable, as his office is located at distance of about 200 meters from place of incident - No other eye witnesses to incident - Applicant being bonafide passenger, had no reason to alight from running train - No case of either self-inflicted injury or criminal act on part of applicant - Claimant entitled to compensation.	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 15)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Compensation - Applicant's left leg was cut above knee, due to his falling down from train - As per amended Rules of 2016, compensation payable in respect of such injury is Rs.6,40,000/- - Submission that said Rules came into force on 22.12.2016, would not apply as alleged incident occurred on 24.02.2016 - As per judgment in Rathi Menon's case [2001 ACJ 721], if any benefit is conferred on victim and said benefit is available on date when case is finally adjudicated, said benefit should be extended to such victim - Hence, compensation of Rs.6,40,000/- granted. 2001 ACJ 721 Rel. on. 	(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Untoward incident
Proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Accidental fall from train - Proof - Claimants examined only mother of deceased who is not an eye-witness - She admitted in cross-examination that she does not know how her son fell down from train - Claimants produced documents like spot panchnama, inquest panchnama, postmortem report, etc. but did not examine any person who prepared those documents - Further, panch witnesses to inquest panchnama were not eye-witnesses - There was no evidence to prove that deceased fell down from running train - It cannot be said that deceased died as result of untoward incident - Claimants not entitled to compensation. (Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Untoward incident
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Burden of proof - In absence of evidence to show that death was result of an untoward incident, burden of proof to establish that deceased was passenger without ticket, does not shift on railways. (Para 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
Payment of compensation
Meaning and scope
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Payment of compensation - Not dependent upon handing over of possession of land - Use of word "shall" in S.20H(1) and (2) in contradistinction to use of word "may" in S.20 I (1) - Meaning and scope - In view of facts, calling upon petitioner-land owner to evict encroachers on acquired land and to handover vacant possession of land to respondent, corporation public sector undertaking, as condition precedent to payment of compensation - Illegal and impossible because by virtue of legal fiction in S.20E(2), land in question already vested absolutely in Central Govt. free from encumbrances - And petitioner would have no authority to carry out eviction on land in question.

S.20-H and 20-I shows that payment of compensation to the person(s) entitled to is not dependent upon handing over of possession of the land. There is no negative statutory mandate in this regard. As it is, section 20-I which deals with taking over of possession follows section 20-H which deals with deposit of the awarded compensation by the central government with the competent authority and immediate payment of the same by the competent authority to the person(s) entitled thereto. The draftsman has consciously placed the provision dealing with taking over of possession after the provision dealing with deposit and payment of the awarded compensation amount. This is made further clear by the language employed in subsections (1) and (2) of section 20- H on the one hand and the language employed in subsection (1) of section 20-I on the other hand. In the case of the former, after the award is passed, the central government shall deposit the compensation amount with the competent authority before taking possession of the land (emphasis ours) and as soon as the amount is deposited, the competent authority shall pay the same to the person or persons entitled thereto. While no time limit is prescribed what is unmissable is that before taking over possession of the land the central government has to deposit the compensation amount with the competent authority and as soon as the deposit is made, competent authority shall make the payment to the person(s) entitled, clearly indicating an element of urgency. On the other hand a period of sixty days is prescribed for surrender or delivery of possession under sub-section (1) of section 20-I. This is clearly indicative of the fact that payment of compensation is not contingent upon handing over of possession. Besides, use of the word ‘shall’ while dealing with deposit and payment of the awarded compensation amount under sub-sections (1) and (2) of section 20-H in contra-distinction to the use of the word ‘may’ while dealing with taking over of possession in terms of sub-section (1) of section 20-I is also indicative of the legislative intent that payment of compensation is independent of taking over possession. (Para 47)

Therefore calling upon the petitioner- land owner to evict the encroachers and to hand over possession of the land in vacant condition thereafter to corporation public sector undertaking for whose benefit land was acquired as a condition precedent to payment of compensation besides being legally unsustainable is also practically not possible because by virtue of the legal fiction under sub-section (2) of section 20-E, the land in question is already vested absolutely in the central government free from all encumbrances and, therefore, petitioner will have no legal authority to carry out eviction on the land in question. Therefore the stand taken by the respondent corporation would not at all be justified being beyond the statutory framework. (Paras 48, 49)

In the circumstances since the competent authority has failed to discharge his statutory duty / obligation as per mandate of sections 20-H and 20-I of the Act which has caused prejudice to the petitioner-land owner and there has been an inordinate delay in payment of compensation since 06.05.2017 when the award was made and the petitioner is unable to utilize the land in question in any manner after publication of the notification under section 20-E(1) of the Act in view of sub-section (2) thereof as the land stood vested absolutely in the central government free from all encumbrances. Therefore, the petitioner would also be entitled to interest for the delay. (Para 51)

heading: Untoward incident
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Burden of proof - Case that deceased fell down from running train due to sudden jerk and died - He was holding valid journey ticket - Railway authority brought him to hospital - Body of deceased was not cut into pieces which would have been in case railway engine had given dash - Spot panchanama and inquest panchanama show that deceased fell down from running train and died in ‘untoward incident’ - No report given by railway, intimating about any accidental dash being given by passing train to deceased - Facts and circumstances are sufficient to presume that deceased died in untoward incident - Claimants have discharged its burden while railway failed to rebut it - Compensation granted.  2009(3) Mh.L.J. 539, 2005(2) T.A.C. 11, 2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 19, 21, 22, 23)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claimed, in view of notification dated 22nd Dec., 2016, which has enhanced compensation from Rs.4,00,000/- to Rs.8,00,000/- - Ordered accordingly. 2017 ACJ 2447 Ref. to. 	(Para 30)

heading: Date of applicability of Act is date on which offence by accused child took place and not the date of the trial.	(Para 28)
HeadNote.description: Date of applicability of Act is date on which offence by accused child took place and not the date of the trial.	(Para 28)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Claim for dismissal of - On ground that there is non-disclosure of cause of action for seeking declaration as to voidness of election - Petitioner-claiming that there is non-compliance with provisions of Constitution of India and provisions of Act of 1951 and Rules framed thereunder while conducting elections - Except stating that there was mismatch in number of votes polled and number of votes counted, there were no averments to show how election of returned candidate affected due to non-compliance of various statutory provisions - There was also no averments showing specific breach or violation of provisions of Act of 1951 or Rules framed thereunder - Election petition is based on incomplete cause of action - Election petition liable to be dismissed. AIR 2010 SC 1227 Foll. (Paras 7, 8, 13, 14, 15)

headline: Civil P.C. (1908), O. 7, R. 11(a) – Representation of People Act (1951), Ss. 83, 80, 100(1) – Election petition – Claim for dismissal of – Petitioner-claiming that there is non-compliance with provisions of Constitution of India and provisions of Act of 1951 and Rules framed thereunder while conducting elections – There were no averments to show how election of returned candidate affected due to non-compliance of various statutory provisions – There was also no averments showing specific breach or violation of provisions of Act of 1951 or Rules framed thereunder – Election petition is based on incomplete cause of action – Election petition liable to be dismissed.

heading: Election petition
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Setting aside of election of returned candidate on ground of improper acceptance of nomination - Challenge - No efforts made by High Court to find out whether improper acceptance of the nomination had materially affected result of election - Held, High Court having failed to determine said issue, not empowered to declare the election as void - Order of High Court, held not proper.

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Petitioner seeking declaration as to election of returned candidate is void - Petitioner states that returned candidate is a voter of another constituency but he had omitted to enclose electoral roll or a certified copy thereof along with his nomination papers - No objection that returned candidate was not qualified to contest election as he was not a voter of any constituency of the State - Nor any objection raised that he was not eligible to participate in the election on account of non-submission of electoral roll - No case made out for declaration that result of election in favour of returned candidate was void - Petition liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Exclusion of period of appeal
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of period of appeal - Railway Tribunal declaring revision of railway freight as unreasonable - Special leave petition against decision of Tribunal granted - S.46-A of Railways Act though grants finality to decision of Tribunal cannot exclude jurisdiction of Supreme Court to hear appeal by special leave - Once leave to appeal is granted correctness of Tribunal's decision is wide open - Hence limitation for filing suit to claim refund of excess amount of freight illegally realised would run from date of order in SLP.	(Paras 13 to 17)

heading: Damage to goods in transit
HeadNote.description: Damage to goods in transit - Fire in wagon damaging consignment - Initial onus is on railways to prove extenuating circumstances - Failure to discharge the onus of proving that it had used reasonable foresight and care in the carriage of goods and still the fire took place - Held railway cannot escape from liability to pay damages to goods. 			(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Scope
Railway employee
Died in accident
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Railway employee - Travelling by train for attending his duties - Died in accident - Having Railway pass which had expired two days before and not renewed - He is a bona fide passenger and not trespasser - His defendants entitled to compensation of Rs. One lac.

Railway Accidents and Untoward Incidents (Compensation) Rules (1990), R.6.

The dependants of a person who is travelling as a 'bonafide passenger' in railway train is entitled to receive compensation of Rs.1 lac as per Rule 6 of the Railway Accidents (Compensation) Rules, 1950 and the burden would be on the Railway Administration to establish that the deceased was not travelling as a "passenger" in the railway train on the date of the accident and that he was not a bonafide passenger.  [Para 10]

In instant case the deceased was a railway employee (Khalasi). He met with railway accident and died while he was travelling by train for attending his duties.  He had a railway pass to travel but the period of that pass had expired just two days prior to the date of accident.

Held that since the deceased was already having pass issued in his favour which expired just two days before the day of accident it did not follow that he was not a bonafide passenger in the train.  Once the conclusion is drawn that he was a passenger in the train but with a pass which had expired or remained to be renewed, that does not mean that the dependants of the deceased cannot be held to be entitled to receive the compensation.  It could not be said that he was a trespasser in the train and not a bona fide passenger.  The words, "bonafide passenger" and "trespasser" are entirely distinct from each other and cannot be assigned the same meaning and therefore, it is obvious that the deceased was not at all a trespasser in the railway train but he was travelling as an employee of the railway administration for attending his duty and the only fault on his part was that he did not get the pass renewed after its expiry and unfortunately the accident occurred just two days after the expiry of the period of the pass.					 [Para 11,12,14]

Thus the dependants of the deceased are entitled to compensation of Rs.one lac under R.6 of the Railway Accidents (Compensation) Rules (1950).	 [Para 15]

heading: Compensation
Interest
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Interest - Railway Tribunal awarding compensation of Rs.4 lacs with 7% interest from date of order till realisation - Appeal filed claiming 12% interest - Order modified with direction to pay 6% simple interest from date of application till date of award and thereafter at 9% till date of actual payment. 2009 ACJ 2444 - Foll.	(Para 4)

heading: Loss of consignment
Wooden case
HeadNote.description:
Loss of consignment - Wooden case - Is a package or parcel within the meaning of S.77-B of the Act - It is necessary to disclose value of consignment to railway administration - Otherwise railway administration is not responsible for the loss of consignment.

An article must be 'packed' in some way, either by putting in a case or a wrapping of some form before it can be described as a 'package' or a 'parcel'.  Obviously in the present case, 11 rolls of terrycotton cloth were packed in a wooden case.  This wooden case certainly constitutes a package or parcel within the meaning of section 77-B of the Indian Railways Act and therefore, it was necessary for the petitioners to establish that the value of the goods were disclosed to the Railways on the package. One of the obvious purpose of enacting section 77-B is to ensure that the railways are made conscious of the fact that they are carrying a parcel or package of a substantive value so that they exercise a high degree of care.  This is not to say that the railways are entitled to be negligent where the package is of a lesser value.  AIR 1957 Patna 231 - Referred to.	 [Para 9]

heading: Verification of claim
HeadNote.description: Verification of claim - Notice under S.78-B of Railways Act - Notice served on Chief Claims Officer - Chief Claims Officer, an authority entrusted with job of verification of claims - Such Officer has jurisdiction in relation to claims for compensation and enquiries on traffic - Held, notice forwarded by respondent to Chief Claims Officer is in accordance with the provisions of S.78-B of Railways Act. AIR 1965 SC 1954 and 2007(4) ALL MR 548 - Ref. to.			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Claimants injured in railway accident on 4.7.1988 i.e. before Railway Accidents and Untoward Incidents (Compensation) Amendment Rules, 1997, came in force
HeadNote.description: Claimants injured in railway accident on 4.7.1988 i.e. before Railway Accidents and Untoward Incidents (Compensation) Amendment Rules, 1997, came in force - Claimants receiving 3 to 4 injuries resulting in pain and suffering - Rs.10,000/- awarded as lumpsum compensation plus interest at the rate of 7.5% from date of application.		(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Delay in delivery of perishable goods
HeadNote.description:
Delay in delivery of perishable goods - Delay on account of misconduct or negligence on part of railway administration - Absence of proof as to how goods were handled during transit - Railway administration not absolved from liability to pay damages by virtue of S.74(A) of the Act.

The burden is on the railway administration to prove that there was no negligence or misconduct on the part of the railway administration or its servant if the goods are deteriorated, damaged destructed or not delivered on reaching its destination within a reasonable time.  In the present case the railway administration did not adduce any evidence to show as to how the goods were handled in transit.  There is no evidence to show that the goods when tendered for its carriage, they were suffering from any inherent vice or there was any inherent defect in the goods.  On the contrary, the clusters plantains were certainly perishable articles and therefore it was necessary on the part of railway administration to carry the goods to the destination within a reasonable time.  It is admitted position in the present case that there was a delay of two days in reaching the goods to the destination so far as three consignments are concerned and there was a delay of about four days in reaching the goods to the destination so far as one consignment is concerned, and therefore considering the delay, goods are bound to get deteriorated during transit and hence in absence of the proof as to how the goods were handled during transit, it is not possible to accept the contention of learned counsel for the railway administration that the delivery of the goods was accepted under protest and hence the railway administration is absolved from liability to pay damages by virtue of Section 74(A) of the Railways Act. 1992 Mh.L.J. 1193, AIR 1969 Bom. 401 and AIR 1969 Bom. 7 - Rel. on.   [Para 15,16]

heading: Limitation under
Preferring of claim
HeadNote.description:
Limitation under - Preferring of claim - It must reach Railway administration within six months - Mere despatching by post within that period not sufficient.

A claim has to be preferred in writing to the Railway administration within six months from the date of delivery of goods to the Railway. The claim can be said to be preferred to the Railway administration only if it reaches the said authorities within the prescribed period. Merely addressing a claim to the Railway administration and posting it through a registered post within the prescribed period is not enough.  [Para 4]

heading: Non-delivery of goods
HeadNote.description: Non-delivery of goods - No loss caused to claimant - Issue of notice under S.78-B is necessary. (Para 5)

heading: Property of railways detained by a railway servant
Meaning of
HeadNote.description: Expression "If a railway servant is discharged...." - Meaning of - Discharge would mean cessation of relationship of employer and employee, may be by retirement, resignation, dismissal or removal. (Para 11)

heading: Delivery of property detained by railway servant
HeadNote.description: Delivery of property detained by railway servant - Railway employee allotted premises refusing to leave after retirement - He is entitled to be evicted under S.138 - He is estopped from challenging title of railway administration over premises in question - Whether railway administration is owner, mortgagee, lessee or licensee is not required to be decided in such proceedings at the instance of sub-lessee or licensee of railway administration.		 (Paras 13, 16)

heading: Procedures for delivery of property wrongfully detained by railway servant
HeadNote.description: Procedures for delivery of property wrongfully detained by railway servant - Railway servant wrongfully refusing to vacate premises allotted to him after his retirement - Question of mesne profit cannot be decided in S.138 proceedings.	(Para 17)

heading: Claim for compensation
HeadNote.description: Accident by collision between passenger and goods train - Passenger, a teenager, studying in Std.8th sustaining injury to his one hand and finger of another hand - Claim for compensation - Claimant claiming for loss of his hand, for pain and suffering, loss of amenities and enjoyment, loss of earning capacity - Loss of chances to get good life partner-lady - Besides claimant claiming special damages - Claim for special damages not described and substantiated - Court holding that claim for special damages was covered under other heads already claimed - Grant of compensation by trial Court on other heads but refusing to grant special damages - Action of Court is just and proper.		(Para 8)

heading: Compensation
Notice
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Notice - Short supply of goods - Claimant can give notice to zonal railway administration to which goods were delivered to be carried by railway - Notice may be given to that zonal railway administration on whose railway destination station lies, or loss, destruction, damage occurred.

A notice to the concerned railway administration is necessary for the railway administration to know and enquire and investigate as to whether the loss, destruction etc. occurred due to whose fault and to determine the compensation to be paid to the claimant.  If the railway administration does not pay the compensation as contemplated by Section 78-B or if pay less compensation it may be open for the complainant to institute a suit as provided for under Section 80 of the Act of 1890 either for compensation or for enhancement of the compensation awarded by the railway administration, as the case may be.  Keeping the purport of both these provisions in view the submission will have to be examined whether a suit can be instituted against a particular railway administration even if the notice contemplated under Section 78-B is given to other railway administration.	 [Para 12]

heading: Compensation
Interest
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Interest - Amount of compensation awarded for short supply of goods - Held, Tribunal should maintain uniformity in awarding interest on claim amount. AIR 1952 Bom. 365 - Ref. to.			(Para 24)

heading: Compensation for non-delivery of goods
HeadNote.description: Compensation for non-delivery of goods - Theft of consignment during railway transit - Claim of appellant that 1 bag of cardamom not delivered by respondents though retrieved from thief - Declaration as to value of goods though not given, same is not necessary in case of non-delivery - To decide if case is of non-delivery or of illegal detention of bag - Matter is liable to be remanded. AIR 1979 Gujarat 176 and 1988 Mh.L.J. 435 - Followed. (Paras 11, 15, 16)

heading: Cheating and criminal conspiracy
HeadNote.description: Cheating and criminal conspiracy - Alleged involvement of petitioners Sub-Registrar  registering document - Registration of documents do not in any manner validate contents of document - Registration of sale deeds by petitioners in discharge of their duties - Fact that seller does not have title - Would not confer title on purchaser under said sale deeds - Thus, registration of such document by petitioners cannot be construed as act in commission of offence to cheat Govt. Authority which had title in said land - It does not show even prima facie involvement of petitioners in alleged conspiracy. (2009) 8 SCC 757 Foll.	(Paras 16, 19, 25)

heading: Lis pendens
Applicability
