HeadNote.description: Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.52 - Lis pendens - Applicability - Appellant in possession of suit land as mortgagee since 1970 - Respondent No.1 agreed to sell land to appellant by agreement dt.25-5-71 - Subsequently Respondent No.1 executed sale deed of same land on 2-8-1971 in favour of Respondent Nos.2 to 6 disclosing in sale-deed that appellant was in possession since 1970 - Held respondent Nos.2 to 6 could not be held to be bona fide purchasers without notice of original contract and as sale stood completed only on date of registration i.e. 3-9-71, registration would relate back to date of execution and as sale stood completed during pendency of suit, doctrine of lis pendens was applicable and they could not take benefit of S.19(b).	(Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Partition decree
HeadNote.description:
Partition decree - New rights inter se parties to partition created - Registration of decree is compulsory.

The partition as well as the decree, in the instant case, not only relate to pre-existing rights, but it does create new rights interse parties to the partition since some persons have relinquished their right in the property, as a result of which, the pre-existing rights have changed. The decree is required to be registered under S. 17(2) of the Registration Act.  [Para 8]

heading: Composite document
Will and gift
HeadNote.description:
Composite document - Will and gift - Fact of registration of a "will" will not render the document a settlement.

In a composite document, which has the characteristics of a Will as well as a gift, it may be necessary to have that document registered otherwise that part of the document which has the effect of a gift cannot be given effect to. Therefore, it is not unusual to register a composite document which has the characteristics of a gift as well as a Will. Consequently, the mere registration of document cannot have any determining effect in arriving at a conclusion that it is not a Will. The document which may serve as evidence of the gift, falls within the sweep of Section 17 of the Registration Act.  [Para 17]

heading: Suit for specific performance
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - In respect of unregistered 'agreement of Re-conveyance' - Maintainable, in view of S.49 of Registration Act. 	(Para 15)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Partition suit dismissed on finding that there was earlier partition evidenced by unregistered partition deed - That dead was acted upon and taxes were paid separately and khatas were also recorded separately - High Court setting aside dismissal of suit only on ground that unregistered partition deed cannot be relied upon - Other findings not reversed or disturbed with - Held approach of High Court could not be sustained and hence decree passed by High Court was liable to be set aside.	(Paras 11, 14)

heading: Second appeal
Interference
Scope
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Interference - Scope - Suit for declaration and possession - Plaintiff claimed his title over suit house on the strength of Will executed by his adoptive mother - Defendant however denied the same on ground that document of Will is not registered - Contention also raised that suit house is built on nazul land which has been given on patta to defendant by Nazul Authorities therefore he is the owner of suit house - Held U/ss.17, 18 of Registration Act, document of Will is not compulsorily registerable - Execution of Will has also made it immaterial for plaintiff to prove the fact of his adoption - Contention that nazul land is given to defendant on 'patta' is also not acceptable in view of concurrent findings of Courts below that defendant was a licencee on suit house - Defendant has no title over suit house. AIR 2002 AP 75; AIR 2002 Rajasthan 66 - Distinguished. 			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Secondary evidence
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Stamp Act (1958), S.34 - Secondary evidence - Of document which in original is not admissible - Permissibility - Plaintiff in suit for declaration and perpetual injunction seeking permission to lead photostate copy of sale deed on basis of which he sought declaration as to title - Said sale deed is not registered and not properly stamped - As per provisions of Registration Act and Maharashtra Stamp Act, unregistered and non-stamped document is not admissible in evidence - When document itself is not admissible, plaintiff cannot lead secondary evidence to prove said document. (Paras 13, 20, 22)

heading: Admissibility as evidence
HeadNote.description: Family arrangements as to partition - Admissibility as evidence - No provision of law requiring family settlements to be reduced to writing and registered - However, if it is reduced to form of writing with purpose that terms should be evidence by it, it required registration - Without registration it is inadmissible - But, same can be used as corroborative piece of evidence for showing or explaining conduct of parties. 	(Para 17)

heading: Unregistered partnership deed
HeadNote.description: Unregistered partnership deed - Can be used for collateral purpose in view of S.49 of Registration Act - However, partnership deed is required to be executed on stamp duty - Unregistered partnership deed not properly stamped, cannot be used in evidence. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Eviction of licensee
HeadNote.description: Eviction of licensee - On expiry of license period - Challenge on ground that license agreement was not registered - Petitioner also claiming that as per S.55(2) of Rent Control Act in absence of registration, claim of petitioner that he was tenant and not licensee will prevail - Respondent-landlord has produced license agreement before registering authority, however petitioner failed to remain present before authority - Respondent discharged responsibility of getting agreement registered in terms of S.55(2) - Presumption u/S.55(2) is rebuttable - Respondent has proved that agreement in question was leave and license agreement and does not create relationship of landlord and tenant - Also, unregistered agreement of leave and license is admissible in evidence in view of S.24(b) - Claim of petitioner that agreement in question is tenancy agreement and not leave and license agreement, cannot be accepted - Eviction of licensee, proper. 			(Paras 13, 15, 16, 18, 21)

heading: Necessity of registration
HeadNote.description: Tenancy agreement of period less than 1 year - Necessity of registration - As per S.55 of MRC Act, every agreement between landlord and tenant after commencement of aforesaid Act shall be in writing and must be registered under Registration Act - Registration of tenancy agreement for period less than 1 year is mandatory and not optional. (Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - On ground of bonafide need of landlord - Landlord claiming that he entered into tenancy agreement with tenant and rented one shop for period of 11 months - Tenant also alleged to be in arrears of rent and in illegal possession of suit shop after expiry of agreement - Tenant submitted that he was rented two shops by landlord for period of 10 years - Agreement was not registered by landlord, therefore same cannot be relied on and possession of tenant cannot be said to be illegal after expiry of 11 months - Submission of tenant regarding terms of tenancy is to be accepted - Landlord in cross-examination admitted that tenant was admitted in two shops and was paying rent regularly - It discredited whole case of landlord - Also no evidence produced on record by landlord to show his bona fide need - Suit liable to be dismissed. (Paras 15, 16, 19, 20, 21, 24)

heading: Unregistered document
HeadNote.description:
Unregistered document - Suit for specific performance on its basis - Plaintiff seeking possession on basis of unregistered agreement of sale - Under S.4 of MOFA unregistered agreement of sale is void document and suit cannot be filed on its basis - S.4A of Act introduced by amendment does not make unregistered document non est - There is no specific requirement of registration of agreement of sale of immovable property - Suit for specific performance of contract can be instituted on its basis.

Proviso 1 of S.4 (2) is in respect of unregistered agreement which has taken place before commencement of MOFA Act and how that unregistered document can be registered. Proviso 2 lays down procedure how unregistered agreement of sale can be registered by presenting it before office of Registrar by following procedure under proviso and under Registration Act.

Proviso added to S.49 of Registration Act enabled party to file suit for specific performance under Specific Relief Act based on unregistered agreement of immovable property demanding other party to come forward and execute and register agreement. Thus it removed hurdle in respect of admissibility of such unregistered document of immovable property. S.4A being enabling section sings same tune.

1981 BLR 339, 2005 ALL MR (Cri) 2403, AIR 1998 SC 554, 2010 (3) ALL MR 477 (S.C.), 2012 (5) ALL MR 462, 1924 Allahabad 938, AIR 1999 SC 2958, AIR 1937 Nagpur 132, AIR 1937 Nagpur Bombay 46 (V 51 C 7), AIR 1964 Bom 49 Ref. to. 	          [Para 10,11]

heading: Unregistered agreement
HeadNote.description:
Unregistered agreement - Suit for specific performance on basis of unregistered agreement of sale - After insertion of S.4A suit under MOFA is maintainable - However suit must be filed only as per provisions of S.4A of MOFA - Unregistered agreement of sale is not invalid and can be used in evidence - Specific performance on basis of said document can be demanded within purport of S.4A - Contention that S.4A has overriding effect over S.4 is correct and to be upheld.

2005 ALL MR (Cri) 2403, AIR 1998 SC 554 Ref. to.   	 [Para 13]

heading: Unregistered agreement
HeadNote.description:
Unregistered agreement - Suit for specific performance on basis of unregistered document - Plaintiff went to Registrar office for registration of agreement to sell in his favour - Document could not be registered as defendant developer did not turn up - Presentation of instrument for registration itself is to be construed that party has asked other person to execute document - It is duty of registering officer to verify whether other party is present or not - If other party is not present then presentation itself is sufficient for registering officer to proceed and take step of sending notice to other party.

In view of deeming provision under S.4(2) proviso 2 of MOFA registering officer to issue summons when document is presented and other party remained absent. Registering officer should not wait for written application of other party. Registrar cannot remain passive while performing his duty which is contemplated under proviso.						         [Para 18,19]

heading: Specific performance
HeadNote.description: Specific performance - On basis of registered agreement of sale possession can be demanded for conveyance by co-operative society - However many times it is tripartite agreement - Land owner if is 3rd person who subsequently comes into picture at time of conveyance, possession is always handed over on basis of registered agreement of sale - Therefore in unregistered agreement of sale prayers demanding registration of document and possession are maintainable.	(Para 20)

heading: Anticipatory bail
Registration of sale-deed
Powers of Registrar
Title of transferor
HeadNote.description: Anticipatory bail - Registration of sale-deed - Powers of Registrar - Title of transferor - S.34 of the Act does not require nor does it empower the Sub-Registrar to enquire into the tile and to satisfy himself about the title of the transferor - Held, if all other requirements of registration prescribed by the Act and the Rules are complied with, the Sub-Registrar cannot refuse the registration of a document only on the ground that the title of the transferor, in his opinion, is defective, or that the name of transferor is not shown as owner in the revenue records. AIR 1923 PC 114 - Ref. to.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Relinquishment deed
Admissibility in evidence
Document not registered
HeadNote.description:
Relinquishment deed - Admissibility in evidence - Document not registered - Document for "Relinquishment of right in immovable property" for a disclosed consideration of Rs.50,000/- - Document on impressed stamp paper of Rs.50/- which is admittedly insufficient - Not admissible in evidence.

In the present case, the document of Relinquishment Deed was rendered inadmissible in the following admitted premises:-

[a]	Suit is for partition and possession.

[b]	Defendant's possession is admitted.

[c]	Nothing is to be shown or proved for collateral purpose or issue from this document.

[d]	Document is admittedly for "Relinquishment of right in immovable property" for a disclosed consideration of Rs.50,000/-.

[e]	Document is on impressed stamp paper of Rs.50/- which is admittedly insufficient.

[f]	Document is not referred for compliance under Section 37 of the Bombay Stamps Act, 1958.

[g]	Under Section 34, it is not admissible due to failure to comply with proviso to Section 34.

[h]	Admittedly, it needs stamp chargeable as per law.

[i]	This document is not registered.

In these premises of facts and law, namely statutory bar on Court falling from Section 17, read with Section 49[c] of the Registration Act, 1908, and Section 34 read with Section 37 of the Bombay Stamps Act, 1958, only conclusion, which emerges, is that application [Exh.72] objecting admissibility is liable to be allowed, and the Court that the Relinquishment-Deed dated 21st December, 1996 was not admissible in evidence.  2005(3) ALL MR 430, 2004(2) ALL MR 191 and AIR 1988 SC 881 - Ref. to. 	 [Para 10,11]

heading: "Lease"
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.105 - "Lease" - Definition of lease under various Acts are different - Definition under Bombay Stamp Act includes even making of an application to grant lease and order accepting such application - An agreement to let is also included within the ambit of Art.36.

The definition of the lease under Indian Registration Act, 1908 and under Transfer of Property Act, 1882 and that in Bombay Stamp Act, 1958 are different. It is also true that the definition under Bombay Stamp Act, 1958 even includes the making of an application to grant lease and order accepting such application.

It is also true that an Agreement To Let is also included within the ambit of Article 36.

In so far as effect of deletion of the explanation III by amending Article 36 by Maharashtra Act 16 of 1995 is concerned, it must be held that the deletion of the explanation is of no consequence. Careful perusal of the explanation indicated that explanation merely stated the legal position as always existed. In a given case, if the parties entered in to an Agreement To Let and there are sufficient indications either from the recitals of the agreement or other surrounding circumstances that there was immediate and present demise made under the agreement, irrespective of the explanation, the instrument would be chargeable with stamp duty. On the other hand, in a given case if the nomenclature of the agreement is 'Agreement To Let' or 'Agreement To Lease' or 'agreement for lease' but there is no present demise, the document will not be chargeable with stamp duty.
1995(2) BCR 31(SC) Ref. to.          [Para 35,36]

heading: Award
Registration of
HeadNote.description:
Award - Registration of - Award issued directions for execution of documents - No right created in immovable properties by Award itself - Award not compulsorily registrable.

Registration Act (1908), S.17

AIR 1974 SC 1912 - Rel.on. (Para 6)

heading: Arbitration agreement contained in unregistered but compulsorily registrable instrument
HeadNote.description:
Arbitration agreement contained in unregistered but compulsorily registrable instrument - Is valid and enforceable.

An arbitration agreement does not require registration under the Registration Act. Even if it is found as one of the clauses in a contract or instrument, it is an independent agreement to refer the disputes to arbitration, which is independent of the main contract or instrument. Therefore having regard to the proviso to section 49 of Registration Act read with section 16(1)(a) of the Act, an arbitration agreement in an unregistered but compulsorily registrable document can be acted upon and enforced for the purpose of dispute resolution by arbitration.  [Para 9]

heading: Unregistered lease deed of tea estate
HeadNote.description: Unregistered lease deed of tea estate - Prior to that there was agreement of sale - Appellant had agreed to purchase - Appellant invested huge amount for improving tea estate - Respondent abruptly evicted appellant - Appellant invoked arbitration clause in lease deed - Held in absence of arbitration agreement with reference to agreement of sale appellant could not seek arbitration and unregistered lease deed being not enforceable - Arbitration also cannot entertain any claim for enforcement of lease or a claim for damages or for recovery of amounts spent. 		(Paras 16 to 19)

heading: Agreement of sale
Registration of
HeadNote.description:
Mortgage by conditional sale - Agreement of sale - Registration of - Where transaction is not one of mortgage, the second document would not need registration, even if it is a part of the same transaction of sale - Held, in this case also the transaction was a mortgage by conditional sale and having regard to provisions of S.17 of Registration Act, the agreement of sale was not compulsorily registerable.

Proviso appended to Section 58(c) is clear and unambiguous.  A legal fiction is created thereby that the transaction shall not be held to be a mortgage by conditional sale, unless a condition is embodied in the document which effects or purports to effect the sale.  Where two documents are executed, the transaction in question would not amount to a mortgage by way of conditional sale.  In a case of this nature, ordinarily the same would be considered to be a deed of sale coupled with an agreement of reconveyance.

In the instant case, no relationship of debtor or creditor came into being.  No security was created and in fact conveyance of the title of the property by the respondent to the appellant was final and absolute.

If the transaction is really one of mortgage then the second deed would be inadmissible for want of registration; but where the transaction is not one of mortgage, the second document would not need registration, even if it is a part of the same transaction of sale.

In this case also the transaction is a mortgage by conditional sale and having regard to the provisions of Section 18 of the Indian Registration Act, the agreement of sale was not compulsorily registerable.  AIR 1926 Bom. 497, 2007 ALL SCR 39 and (2006)4 SCC 432 - Ref. to.  [Para 12,17,18]

heading: Lis-pendens
HeadNote.description: Lis-pendens - Challenge to order registering lis pendens notice - Proceedings under S.138 of NI Act are subjudice - Held, proceeding u/s.138 of NI Act is not where right to immovable property is directly and specifically in question - Therefore, S.52 of TP Act is not applicable - No question arises of registering authority invoking S.18(ee) of Registration Act - Registration of notice is without jurisdiction and authority - Hence, not sustainable. (Paras 8, 9, 11, 12)

heading: Gift of some amount in cash
HeadNote.description: Gift of some amount in cash - Does not require registration - Statutory requirements under Ss.122, 123 are not attracted.	(Para 24)

heading: Sale
"Kararnama" not registered
HeadNote.description:
Bombay Stamp Act (1958), S.34 - Sale - "Kararnama" not registered - Same cannot be admitted in evidence even for collateral purpose as per S.49 of Registration Act.

Sale is defined under Section 54 of Transfer of Property Act, 1882 which contemplates that "sale" is a transfer of ownership in exchange for a price paid or promised or part-paid and part-promised. Sale how made - such transfer, in the case of tangible immoveable property of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards, or in the case of a reversion or other intangible thing, can be made only by a registered instrument.  In the case of tangible immoveable property of a value less than one hundred rupees, such transfer may be made either by a registered instrument or by delivery of the property.  Delivery of tangible immoveable property takes place when the seller places the buyer, or such person as he directs, in possession of the property.  Contract for sale - A contract for the sale of immoveable property is contract that a sale of such property shall take place on terms settled between the parties.  It does not, of itself, create any interest in or charge on such property. It is thus obvious that sale can be made only by a registered instrument.  The Article A Kararnama was not registered and, therefore,the same cannot be admitted in evidence even for collateral purpose, as per Section 49 of the Registration Act. Therefore, the appellant Court has obviously committed an apparent error of law by observing that this document can be admitted in evidence for collateral purposes.		 [Para 14,15]

heading: Protection of possession
HeadNote.description: Protection of possession - Two documents, one agreement to sell and another possession receipt - No explanation as to why two documents executed - Agreement to sell was not on sufficiently stamped paper and possession receipt not duly registered with appropriate authority - Defendant failed to show his readiness and willingness to perform his part of contract - Thus, defendant, held not entitled to invoke S.53A for benefit of protection of his possession in absence of compulsory registration of documents. (Paras 15, 16, 18)

heading: Not registered
HeadNote.description:
Lease agreement for period exceeding one year - Not registered - Can be looked into for collateral purposes of determining relationship of landlord and tenant and agreed rate of rent, in view of settled possession of tenant and regular payment of rent.

The lease agreement for 5 years was not registered.  However, in view of the settled possession and/or permissible possession by the tenant, apart from regular payment of rent towards the use of said premises as a tenant was in itself sufficient to create relationship of landlord and tenant for the purpose of C.P. & Berar Rent Control Order.  The bar of Section 49 and/or Section 17 of the Registration Act did not affect or take away the legal rights created in favour of such occupant/tenant.  The lease agreement even though not registered, still could be looked for the purpose of determination of the relationship of landlord and tenant, and also of agreed rate of rent.  Such lease agreement has evidential value for the purpose of deciding relationship of landlord and tenant, as well as, agreed rent between the parties.				 [Para 7]

heading: Leave to defend
Rejected.	(Paras 8, 9)
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.42 - Leave to defend - Application filed by landlord under S.42 seeking eviction of non-applicants from suit property - Plea of Oral gift deed of immovable suit property - Fact that no gift deed was executed and registered - Thus ground taken by non-applicants that they had become owner of suit property in view of oral gift - Cannot be allowed to be raised in view of S.123 of Transfer of Property Act and S.17 of Registration Act - Non-applicants having not raised any ground or defence which would disentitle petitioner from getting order for eviction - Application seeking leave to defend - Rejected.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Termination of lease
Legality
Lease by conduct
HeadNote.description:
Termination of lease - Legality - Lease by conduct - No written lease deed executed between parties - Defendant, by way of a letter written in 1985 accepted the proposal of lease for 10 years - Thereafter, through another letter written in July 1995 defendant informed the plaintiff that it would pay rent with 20% enhancement for another 5 years and forwarded a cheque towards arrears of rent - Plaintiff merely encashed the cheque with no acceptance letter - Subsequently sent a notice of termination w.e.f. 31.10.1995 - In the circumstances, held, encashment of cheque by plaintiff would not mean lease agreement between parties stood renewed for next five years - In absence of any written and registered deed, it would be a month to month lease - Plaintiff landlord can terminate the lease at the expiry of any month with necessary notice and without any explanation - Hence, termination of lease cannot be said to be illegal.

(2000) 6 SCC 394, (1977) 2 SCC 646 Ref. to.	 [Para 36,37]

heading: Protection under S.53A
HeadNote.description: Protection under S.53A - Defendant is in possession of property by virtue of document of lease from previous owner - Property was given on lease for 10 years on unregistered document - Instrument is invalid in view of S.107 of T.P. Act - Therefore, there cannot be any transfer of any interest under document to defendant - Protection under S.53A not available.(Para 29)

heading: Protection under S.53A
HeadNote.description: Protection under S.53A - Oral and documentary evidence show that from 1987 itself defendant stopped paying rent - Defendant was asked to pay rent even after sale of property to plaintiff by original owner - Defendant failed to pay rent - Defendant disputed title of plaintiff - Defendant claiming possession under agreement to sell with previous owner - However, defendant could not prove agreement - Defendant failed to prove that it was ready, willing to perform its part of contract - Defendant not entitled to protection under S.53A. (Para 33)

heading: Termination of tenancy
HeadNote.description:
Termination of tenancy - Defendant is tenant in property of society - Defendant claiming that Liquidator of Society entered into agreement of sale with him - No record shows that there was approval to so called proposal given by Liquidator - No enforceable agreement had come into existence - Further, when property belongs to society it is always desirable that property is sold by public auction - Refusal to relief of specific performance held proper.
AIR 1963 SC 1685 Disting. (Para 38)

heading: Documents requiring registration
HeadNote.description: Documents requiring registration - S.45 of Trade Marks Act grants discretion to Court to receive a document in evidence even though in respect thereof no entry was made in the Register. (Paras 15 to 18)

heading: Non-registration of gift-deed
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Gift of immovable property - Non-registration of gift-deed - Effect - Unregistered document shall not have the effect of transfer of title.

In the instant case, defendant has claimed his title over suit property on the strength of an unregistered gift deed executed by plaintiff community court observed the following :-

By virtue of S.17 of Registration Act, unregistered instrument executed in favour of defendant by the plaintiff community will not vest any title in him and, furthermore, the document being not in consonance with S.123 of Transfer of Property Act, cannot be construed as evidence entitling defendant to claim the property.  Unregistered instrument of gift shall have no effect of transfer of title.  Thus it can be concluded that no title has been passed in favour of defendant by virtue of unregistered instrument of gift which is in conflict with the provisions of S.17 of Registration Act and S.123 of Transfer of Property Act.  [Para 8]

heading: Lease deed
Non-registration
HeadNote.description:
Lease deed - Non-registration - Does not prevent Court from looking into it to ascertain what has happened between parties in respect of property - And in absence of registration a monthly lease has to be deemed to have created between parties.

 2016 ALL SCR 2080 Rel. on. 	(Para 14)

headline: Registration Act (1908), Ss.17(2)(vi), 17(1)(b) – Compromise decree – Registration, whether compulsory – Conjoint reading of S.17(1)(b) & S.17(2)(vi) indicates that a compromise decree comprising immovable property other than which is subject matter of the suit/proceeding requires registration - u/S.17(2)(vi), any decree/order of Court exempted from registration - Compromise decree pertaining to immovable property, which had been subject matter of suit – Registration not required

heading: Compromise decree
Registration, whether compulsory
HeadNote.description:
Compromise decree - Registration, whether compulsory - Compromise decree pertained to immovable property which had been subject matter of suit - Registration not required.

A compromise decree passed by a Court would ordinarily be covered by Section 17(1)(b) but subsection (2) of Section 17 provides for an exception for any decree or order of a Court except a decree or order expressed to be made on a compromise and comprising immovable property other than that which is the subject-matter of the suit or proceeding. Thus, by virtue of sub-section(2)(vi) of Section 17 any decree or order of a Court does not require registration. In sub-clause (vi) of sub-section (2), one category is excepted from sub-clause(vi), i.e., a decree or order expressed to be made on a compromise and comprising immovable property other than that which is the subject-matter of the suit or proceeding. Thus, by conjointly reading Section 17(1)(b) and Section 17(2)(vi), it is clear that a compromise decree comprising immovable property other than which is the subject matter of the suit or proceeding requires registration, although any decree or order of a Court is exempted from registration by virtue of Section 17(2)(vi). A copy of the decree passed in instant case indicates that decree dated 04.10.1985 was passed by the Court for the property, which was subject matter of the suit. Thus, the exclusionary clause in Section 17(2)(vi) is not applicable and the compromise decree dated 04.10.1985 was not required to be registered on plain reading of Section 17(2)(vi).

(1995) 5 SCC 709 Disting.

(2019) 8 SCC 729, (2006) 10 SCC 788 Ref. to.

heading: Registration of decree
Necessity of
HeadNote.description: Registration of decree - Necessity of - When legislature has specifically excluded applicability of clause (b) & (c) with regard to any decree or order of court, applicability of S. 17(1)(b) cannot be imported in S. 17(2)(v) by any indirect method - Decree and order did not require registration. (Para 17)

heading: Agreement to create a mortgage by depositing title deeds does not require registration as a contract of mortgage
HeadNote.description:
Agreement to create a mortgage by depositing title deeds does not require registration as a contract of mortgage - Letter recording fact of deposit of title deeds already made, also does not require registration - Test laid down.

Document whereby the borrower agreed to deposit with the bank all deeds writings and documents of title of his property described therein, with intention to create an equitable mortgage and also agreed to execute a deed of mortgage in favour of the bank does not require registration. A letter recording face of deposit of title deed also does not require registration. If a document on the fact of it and properly interpreted in the light of the circumstances does not disclose the creation of a mortgage or even the document is not an operative instrument and is merely evidential it does not require registration. The document must contain all essentials of the transaction and the essentials are debt, date of repayment, sum secured, nature of the mortgage and subject matter of mortgage.

A.I.R. 1970 S.C.  659 relied on.  [Para 6]

heading: Registration of document
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - Delay in presenting sale deed - Can be condoned only upto a period of four months - Sale deed presented for registration after a delay of more than eight months - Registration will not convey or transfer title to suit land in favour of purchaser.	(Paras 11, 14)

heading: Registration of document
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - It is only if there is a transfer or relinquishment of right, title or interest in the property that it would require registration.	(Para 11)

heading: Development agreement/permission
Withholding of registration
Challenge as to
HeadNote.description: Development agreement/permission - Withholding of registration - Challenge as to - Circular dt.19th May, 2007 issued by Collector directing Registering Authority to insist upon an NOC from Collector before registration of any document - Since Collector has no appellate, supervisory, or revisional powers over Registering Officer under Act - Circular/letter issued by Collector dt.19/5/2007 - Illegal and without authority of law. AIR 2007 Mad. 159 - Rel. on.	(Paras 26, 28)

heading: Registration fee
HeadNote.description:
Registration fee - Registration fee on graduated scale on basis of value of subject-matter of instrument - Fee received could not be said to be much in excess of overall expenditure incurred in maintaining the department - Fee cannot be struck down as invalid. AIR 1964 Punjab 492, AIR 1978 SC 1181, AIR 1971 Allahabad 390 Overruled.

There is no generic difference between a tax and a fee which are both compulsory exaction of money by public authorities. The corelationship between the levy and the services rendered should be one of general character and not of mathematical exactitude. Further, the broad and general corelationship between the totality of the fee on the one hand and the totality of the expenses of the services on the other, will be sufficient to justify the levy. The levy will not fail only on the ground that the measure of its distribution on the persons or incidence is disproportionate to the actual services rendered by them. The true test being the comprehensive level of the value of the totality of the services set off against the totality of the receipts. The character of the fee is thus established. The vagaries in its distribution amongst the class do not detract from the concept of a fee as such.  [Para 15]

Notification issued by State Govt. prescribing registration fee on graduated form on basis of value of subject-matter of instrument is in accordance with the spirit of S.78 of the Registration Act and is valid in law, particularly when there was no material on record to show that the overall amount received by the Govt. by way of fee from the Registration Department far exceeds the overall expenditure incurred in maintaining the said department.  The notification issued by the State Govt. could not be struck down merely by taking into consideration the registration fee paid by the plaintiffs and quantification of the value of services rendered to them.		 [Para 12]

heading: Mohammedan Law
HeadNote.description: Mohammedan Law - Levy of stamp duty - On oral gift made by a Mohammedan - Merely because same was reduced in writing on stamp paper and mutated, stamp duty cannot be imposed - No provision in Registration Act for levying stamp duty on such gift - S.129 of T.P. Act not applicable to Mohammedan. 2011(3) ALL MR 981 (S.C.), 2014(6) ALL MR 900 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Para 4)

heading: Registered document
HeadNote.description:
Registered document - Effective date.

In view of the provisions of S. 47 of the Registration Act, 1908 it is well settled that a document on subsequent registration will take effect from the time when it was, executed and not from the time of its registration. Where two documents are executed on the same day, the time of their execution would determine the priority irrespective of the time of their registration. The one which is executed earlier in time will prevail over the other executed subsequently.					 [Para 3]

heading: Unregistered partition deed
Inadmissible in evidence
But
Exh. 3
HeadNote.description:
Unregistered partition deed - Inadmissible in evidence - But - court is not precluded from considering other evidence adduced by party in support - Of the extent of his holding.

The position of law regarding admissibility of the deed of partition - Exh. 3 - as held by the High Court, in our view, is unassailable. The document did not require registration and having not been registered, was rightly held to be inadmissible. But that is not the end of the matter. The question whether the other evidence available on record on the point is to be considered, arises for consideration. As noted earlier, the High Court brushed aside such evidence holding that the transaction having been reduced to writing it is the only document which can be looked into and if for any legal impediment it cannot be looked into, other evidence for the said purpose also cannot be looked into. In that respect, the contents of the document have to be looked into to see whether by the document the transfer of shares of the parties is effected or the document is only a memorandum of previous partition which is now reduced to writing as evidence of the same. Therefore, though the document was not available to be looked into for want of registration, if the parties have adduced other evidence to prove the extent of their holding, evidence on record was to be considered. In this regard, it is to be kept in mind that the suit is not based on the document- Exh. 3 or for enforcement of any right or claim arising under the document. On a plain reading of the judgment of the lower appellate Court it is clear that the Courts below had not only placed reliance on Exh. 3 but had also taken into consideration the other materials on record in support of the plaintiff's case that his land-holding was less than 5 acres. The High Court was not entitled to disturb the finding of fact recorded by the lower appellate Court on the basis discussed earlier without considering the other relevant evidence available on record.		 [Para 9]

heading: Registration of document
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - Time for presenting document - Documents presented in office of Sub-Registrar within 4 months of their execution - However, office of Sub-Registrar took its own time for adjudication of stamp duty which went beyond time limit mentioned in S.23 - Held, petitioner cannot be made to face consequence of delay caused by authorities - Refusal of registration, not justified - Sub-Registrar directed to register documents. 	(Para 6)

heading: Award distributing residue assets of a partnership firm among partners on dissolution of partnership firm
HeadNote.description:
Award distributing residue assets of a partnership firm among partners on dissolution of partnership firm - Does not require registration under S.17.

By the award the arbitrators distributed the assets of the dissolved firm between the partners in accordance with their respective shares in the partnership. The real question for consideration is whether such an award amounts to creation of or transfer of any fresh rights in movable or immovable properties so as to bring it within the ambit of Section 17 of the Registration Act? A perusal of the award shows that it is simply a case of distribution of assets of the dissolved firm amongst the partners themselves. A partnership firm is not an independent legal entity, the partners are the real owners of the assets of the partnership firm. Actually the firm name is only a compendious name given to the partnership for sake of convenience. The assets of the partnership belong to and are owned by the partners of the firm. So long as partnership continues each partner is interested in all the assets of the partnership firm as each partner is owner of the assets to the extent of his share in the partnership. On dissolution of the partnership firm, accounts are settled amongst the partners and the assets of the partnership are distributed amongst the partners as per their respective shares in the partnership firm. Thus, on dissolution of a partnership firm, the allotment of assets to individual partner is not a case of transfer of any assets of the firm. The assets which hereinbefore belonged to each partner, will after dissolution of the firm stand allotted to the partners individually. There is no transfer or assignment of ownership in any of the assets. This is the legal consequence of distribution of assets on dissolution of a partnership firm. The distribution of assets may be done either by way of an arbitration award or by mutual settlement between the partners themselves. The document which records the settlement in this case is an award which does not require registration under Section 17 of the Registration Act since the document does not transfer or assign interest in any asset. (1993)1 SCC 589 Rel on. (1974)1 SCC 671 Disting.  [Para 3]

heading: Unregistered partition deed
Admissibility in evidence
HeadNote.description: Hindu Succession Act (1956), S.14(1) - Unregistered partition deed - Admissibility in evidence - By said partition deed Hindu woman creating right of her two sons in property given to her in lieu of maintenance - Said property was her absolute property by virtue of S.14(1) of Hindu Succession Act - Hindu woman being absolute owner of property, cannot execute partition deed in respect of said property - As for partition other party should also have title or share in that property - She can create right or transfer title either by sale deed, or by gift deed, mortgage deed etc. - Further, value of property was more than Rs.100/- therefore in view of S.17 of Registration Act it was compulsorily registrable document irrespective of nomenclature - Unregistered partition deed cannot be used even for collateral purpose - Unregistered partition deed not admissible in evidence. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Gift
Registration of
HeadNote.description:
Gift - Registration of - Relinquishment of flat in question without receiving any consideration therefor - That relinquishment acted upon by the society - It comes within the purview of Gift within meaning under S.122 of Transfer of Property Act - Such gift has to be registered so that in law transfer will take effect.

In the present case, it is seen that the Judgment Debtor No.3 submitted an application to the society expressing that they were relinquishing their right in the said flat in favour of applicant without receiving any consideration therefor. On the basis of this application, Society has acted upon and then recorded change in the share certificate which now mentions only the name of the applicant. The applicant has accepted that position. The act of relinquishment was in relation to the interest in the immovable property though that occurs due to the transfer of shares. In other words, the applicant has accepted the transfer of interest in the immovable property effected by way of relinquishment by the co-owners. If it is so, it would fall within the definition of Gift of immovable property within the section 122 of Transfer of Property Act. Indeed, expression relinquishment is not defined in the Transfer of Property Act but dictionary meaning thereof is abandonment of right or abatement of right. The concomitant of abandonment or relinquishment of right of one devolves that corresponding right in favour of the other which has the effect of transfer by way of gift within the expansive definition under section 122 of the Transfer of Property Act. Such gift has to be registered so that in law transfer will take effect. (1998)9 SCC 194 and 1990(3) Bom.C.R. 389 - Referred to.  [Para 5]

heading: Compromise decree
Decrees passed accordingly
HeadNote.description: Compromise decree - Compromise demarcating each other's properties entered - Decrees passed accordingly - Plaintiff subsequently claiming title to passage on basis of compromise decree - Passage was not subject matter of injunction suit - Claim of plaintiff that he was given exclusive right to passage in lieu of portion of his land - Even if the passage was not subject matter of suit, indisputably, in terms of CPC Amendment Act, 1976, compromise decree was permissible - Hence transaction amounted to transfer of property not subject matter of suit and as such registration thereof was imperative.	(Paras 18, 19, 21, 29)

heading: Scale of fines
HeadNote.description:
Delay in presentation of documents - Scale of fines - Words "not exceeding ten times the amount of proper registration" - It is not the mandate of law that in every case a fine of ten times the registration fee should be imposed - Ten time is the upper limit and within that limit a judicial discretion has been vested in the Registrar to determine what if any fine should be levied.

Where the delay in presentation does not exceed four months, it is open to the Registrar to accept a document for registration on the payment of a fine not exceeding ten times the amount of the proper registration fee. The words 'not exceeding' are important because it is not the mandate of the law that in every case a fine of ten times the registration fee should be imposed. Ten times is the upper limit and within that limit a judicial discretion has been vested in the Registrar to determine what if any fine should be levied. Similarly, each of the clauses of Rule 27 empower the imposition of a fine not exceeding a particular ceiling. Under clause (2) thereto which is applicable in the present case where the delay exceeds one month but does not exceed two months, the fine is not to exceed five times the proper registration fee. In a case such as the present, where the Petitioner had submitted that it was due to an illness he was unable to remain present for admitting the execution of the document before the registering officer, it was not incumbent as a matter of course to impose a fine of five times the registration fee.							 [Para 5]

heading: Unregistered sale deed
Rel.on.		(Paras 12, 15)
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Unregistered sale deed - Can be admitted in evidence as evidence of a contract. 2008(8) SCC 564, (1999)7 SCC 114 - Rel.on.		(Paras 12, 15)

heading: Registration of document
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - Document of sale deed of one mango tree - Whether it requires registration - Sale deed did not say about tree being cut or allowed to remain standing on land - It is standing for appreciably long time and it has to be regarded as tree and not timber - Mango tree was purchased with intention of maintaining it, allowing it to grow and using its fruits in future - Document of sale deed of one mango tree requires compulsory registration. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Suit in respect of property 'A'
HeadNote.description: Suit in respect of property 'A' - Decree in respect of immovable property 'B' which was not subject matter of suit at all - Necessity of registration in respect of property 'B' - Inconsistent views in 2008 ALL SCR 1826 and 1995(5) SCC 709 - Matter to be referred to larger Bench.			(Para 15)

heading: Registration of document
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - Agreement of relinquishment of share - Is required to be compulsorily registered and proper stamp duty is required to be paid thereon.			(Para 6)

heading: Whether requires registration
HeadNote.description: Deed of relinquishment without consideration - Whether requires registration - Deed clearly show that right, title and interest vesting or extinguishment was all done in past years - Mention thereof, is only found in present documents by way of acknowledgment of past event of partition which was acted upon - Deed does not itself inherently divest, vest, extinguish any right, title or interest in any of parties - Deed does not require registration. 	(Para 4)

heading: Deed of conveyance
Registration of
HeadNote.description: Deed of conveyance - Registration of - Delay in lodging for adjudication - Delay was purely attributable to Collector of Stamps in passing final adjudication order - It cannot be attributed to any intentional or deliberate act or negligence on part of petitioner - Delay liable to be condoned. AIR 1987 SC 2195 Foll.	(Paras 8 to 11)

heading: Registration of conveyance
Denial
HeadNote.description:
Registration of conveyance - Denial - Ground that title of vendor was not shown - Held, it is only Civil Court which would consider the title - Order denying registration on said ground, not tenable.

In the instant case the Registering Authority has persisted in refusing to register the document of conveyance on the ground that the title of the vendor has not been shown. It is only the Civil Court which would consider the title. There is nothing in the Registration Act or the Registration Manual to empower the Registrar in seeing or satisfying himself about the title of the vendor. Hence registration entails nothing more than the factum that the executants or their agents attended before the Registrar and admitted the execution of the document.

There are many instances where the parties without any title seek to transfer such purported title which they do not have and legitimize the illegal act by the process of registration. The Registering Authority, being conscious of such a fact, may consider himself obliged to prevent transfers by such illegal acts. However the jurisprudential rule that none can transfer a better title than what he has is indeed as elementary as it is basic. The Registering Authority, therefore, need not be take open itself the duty of a Civil Court which alone would go into question of title upon it being challenged. The law in that behalf is clear.

AIR 1983 Bombay 1, 2003 ALL MR (Cri) 1970 Ref. to. 			           [Para 9,10]

heading: Consent decree
Registration of
HeadNote.description: Consent decree - Registration of - Time for filing appeal against consent decree was over on 20/10/2011 - Since no appeal was filed decree can be said to have become final on that day - Decree which was presented on 27/12/2011 for registration was within time - Document should be accepted for registration within 4 months of its execution as per S.23 - Period of 7 months taken by authority to adjudicate stamp duty and penalty payable - Said period of 7 months cannot be taken into consideration while computing period of 4 months - Similarly period spent while prosecuting this petition cannot be considered - Consent decree was presented for registration within time. 			(Para 9)

heading: Development agreement
HeadNote.description: Development agreement - Document creating substantial rights in favour of petitioner - After constructing flats petitioner also entitled to sell flats row houses etc. - S.17 comes into play as soon as any right is created and hence document was registrable. (Para 7)

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Document showing relinquishment of right in respect of immovable property - Document is compulsorily registerable - If not registered, cannot be relied upon for proving factum of partition - Cannot be relied upon even for collateral purpose, until the same is impounded. 	(Para 17,18)

heading: Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Circular of Corporation, dt. 11.9.2012 - Unregistered power of attorney - Seeking sanction for development - Rejection of - Validity - S.17 provides that an irrecoverable power of attorney relating to transfer of immovable property executed on or after commencement of amended Act - On 1.4.2013, is liable to be registered - Petitioner sought permission for development after coming into force amended provision of S.17 - Petitioners power of attorney, therefore required to be registered - Rejection of unregistered power of attorney, proper. 	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Registration of document
Requirement as to
HeadNote.description: Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.54 - Registration of document - Requirement as to - Agreement granting easementary rights - Said agreement only granting right of way to plaintiff to take his bullock cart from land of defendant - Ownership of defendant over said portion of land was not transferred in favour of plaintiff - Agreement granting easement need not require registration.	(Paras 9, 10, 12)

heading: Refusal
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Registration of sale deed - Refusal - On ground that property in question is not within sanctioned plan - Not justified - Enquiry by Registrar u/S.34(3) is limited to factum of execution of document, identity and authority of persons appearing before him - Executive direction issued by Collector directing Registrar to decline registration on grounds other than mentioned in statute, not permissible. 2003 ALL MR (Cri) 1970, 2010(5) ALL MR 692, 2013(2) ALL MR 565, 2010 ALL MR (Cri) 2569 Rel. on. 	(Paras 4, 5, 6)

heading: Unregistered partition deed
HeadNote.description: Unregistered partition deed - Use for collateral purpose - Scribe of deed deposing that it was scribed as per directions of only one brother - Plaintiff-brother was minor at time of partition - Deed not showing that it was signed by any one as guardian of plaintiff - Deed in question also included property which was already acquired by Govt. - Evidence showing that much after alleged partition deed application for succession certificate came to be filed by mother of plaintiff on behalf of all brothers and sisters of plaintiff - Held, theory of partition put up by plaintiff in circumstances cannot be believed. 	(Paras 8, 10)

heading: Registration of document
Necessity of
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - Necessity of - Document transferring interest in immovable property worth more than Rs.100/- in favour of plaintiff - Record showing that document in question is nothing but memorandum of family arrangement - It is not required to be registered. 			(Paras 16, 18, 19)

heading: Unregistered document
Admissibility
HeadNote.description: Unregistered document - Admissibility - S.49(1)(a) of Registration Act prevents unregistered document being used as 'evidence of transaction', which affects immovable property - Document is registered family settlement 'Khararunama' - Words used therein intending to refer to arrangements which parties allegedly made in past - Document does not purport to by itself create, declare, assign, extinguish or limit right in properties - Thus, Khararunama may not attract S.49(1)(a) - Said document though relating to immovable property, there would be no breach of S.49(1)(c), it being not used as evidence of transaction affecting such property - However, being let in evidence, being different from being used as evidence of transaction is pertinent - Transaction or past transactions cannot be proved by using Khararunama as evidence of transaction - Merely admitting Khararunama cannot be understood to mean that if those past transactions require registration, then, mere admission, in evidence of Khararunama and receipt would produce any legal effect on immovable properties in question - Further, Khararunama being record of alleged transactions, it may not require to be stamped - Moreover appellants and respondents, admittedly, partitioned their joint family properties those became their separate properties. (Paras 33, 34, 35, 36)

heading: Cancellation by Registrar
Not permissible
HeadNote.description: Registration of sale deed - Cancellation by Registrar - On ground of fraud or impersonation - Not permissible - Such power not available to Registrar who is only an administrative authority - Cancellation can be ordered only by Civil Court. 2018 (127) ALR 466, (2016) 10 SCC 761, AIR 2007 (AP) 57 Rel. on. 			(Paras 7, 8, 14)

heading: Family settlement
HeadNote.description:
Family settlement - Registration of, need for and question of admissibility in evidence - Deed of settlement would not become liable to registration, unless it confers rights upon individual, vis-à-vis an item of immovable property, which, he is not otherwise entitled to, under relevant law of succession - A settlement not creating any right in 'praesenti' cannot be treated as inadmissible, on ground that it is not registered. Stamp Act (1899), Ss.2(24), 3, 35.

Though, the object underlying the settlement is to bring about harmony among the parties to it, the legal implications arising out of settlements are not uniform. In some cases, the settlement may bring about transfer or conferment of rights instantly, upon the parties to it, vis-à-vis movable or immovable properties. If the settlement confers rights upon the individual, vis-à-vis on items of immovable property, which, he is not otherwise entitled to, under the relevant law of Succession, a transfer comes into existence, and thereby the deed of settlement becomes liable to be registered.  				 [Para 23]

It is not uncommon that settlements provide for arrangements, which would materialize at a future date. In such cases, the manner in which the rights are to be conferred on various parties is defined, and the actual transfer of rights would take place at a future date. The situation is comparable broadly, to the one under a preliminary decree. The rights of the parties vis-à-vis identified items of property are indicated and actual transfer is to take place at a later point of time i.e., as and when a final decree is passed; to put it in strict legal terms, no interest 'in praesenti' is created in favour of any party, under settlement of such category.  			 [Para 24]

From the principles laid in AIR 1966 SC 1836, AIR 1969 AP 417, AIR 1966 SC 292, it becomes clear that a settlement, which does not create any right 'in praesenti' cannot be treated as inadmissible, on the ground that it is not registered.  AIR 1966 SC 1836, AIR 1969 AP 417, AIR 1966 SC 292 - Rel. on.  [Para 29]

heading: Words "executed and authenticated in the manner hereinafter mentioned"
HeadNote.description:
Words "executed and authenticated in the manner hereinafter mentioned" - Would mean as per procedure specified in S.33.

The words "executed and authenticated in manner hereinafter mentioned" in Section 32 (c) would mean the procedure specified in Section 33. This is clear from the opening words of Section 33 which reads "for the purposes of Section 32, the following power-of-attorney shall alone be recognised". Section 32 refers to documents presented for registration by a holder of "power-of-attorney" in Clause (c) and it therefore follows that the procedure specified under Section 33 would be attracted where a document is presented by a person holding a "powers-of-attorney" of the persons mentioned in Clause (a) of Section 32.

heading: Expression "person executing"
HeadNote.description: Expression "person executing" - Can only refer to person who actually signs or marks the document in token of execution, whether for himself or on behalf of some other person - Hence a power of attorney holder who executes a document in terms of power of attorney can present it for registration and get it registered. AIR 1960 Punj 226, AIR 1950 Bom. 326-Rel. on. AIR 1958 AP 107, AIR 1961 Cal. 540-Overruled.		(Paras 23, 25)

heading: Object of registration
HeadNote.description: Object of registration - Is to guard against fraud by obtaining a contemporaneous publication and unimpeachable record of each document - If no fraud is alleged, Registrar on being satisfied that document is executed by the person by whom it is purported to have been signed, has to proceed with the registration of the same.	(Para 27)

heading: Who can present document of registration
HeadNote.description: Who can present document of registration - Power of attorney holder executing document of sale on behalf of principal and then presenting it for registration - It is not necessary that he should hold a power of attorney authenticated before Sub-Registrar.			(Para 30)

heading: Interpretation of
HeadNote.description: Document of relinquishment of right - Interpretation of - Held, nomenclature of the document is not important - The document in its entirety has to be considered - Document, held, needs registration u/s.17 of the Act. AIR 1987 PATNA 102 (F.B.) and 2003 AIR SCW 6923 - Ref. to.			(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Purpose of registration
HeadNote.description:
Purpose of registration - Registration of a document gives notice to the world that such a document has been executed.

The Registration Act, 1908, was enacted with the intention of providing orderliness, discipline and public notice in regard to transactions relating to immovable property and protection from fraud and forgery of documents of transfer. This is achieved by requiring compulsory registration of certain types of documents and providing for consequences of non-registration. Section 17 of the Registration Act clearly provides that any document (other than testamentary instruments) which purports or operates to create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish whether in present or in future "any right, title or interest" whether vested or contingent of the value of Rs.100 and upwards to or in immovable property. Section 49 of the said Act provides that no document required by section 17 to be registered shall, affect any immovable property comprised therein or received as evidence of any transaction affected such property, unless it has been registered. Registration of a document gives notice to the world that such a document has been executed. Registration provides safety and security to transactions relating to immovable property, even if the document is lost or destroyed. It gives publicity and public exposure to documents thereby preventing forgeries and frauds in regard to transactions and execution of documents. Registration provides information to people who may deal with a property, as to the nature and extent of the rights which persons may have, affecting that property. In other words, it enables people to find out whether any particular property with which they are concerned, has been subjected to any legal obligation or liability and who is or are the person/s presently having right, title, and interest in the property. It gives solemnity of form and perpetuate documents which are of legal importance or relevance by recording them, where people may see the record and enquire and ascertain what the particulars are and as far as land is concerned what obligations exist with regard to them. It ensures that every person dealing with immovable property can rely with confidence upon the statements contained in the registers (maintained under the said Act) as a full and complete account of all transactions by which the title to the property may be affected and secure extracts/copies duly certified.  [Para 8]

heading: Compulsory registration
HeadNote.description: Registration of immovable property - Compulsory registration - Held, any process which interfers with regular transfers under deeds of conveyance properly stamped, registered and recorded in the registers of Registration Department, is to be discouraged and deprecated.	(Para 11)

heading: Scope
Instrument requiring registration
Not registered
HeadNote.description: Scope - Instrument requiring registration - Not registered - Can be used for collateral purpose - Cannot be used to prove creation or extinguishment of right to immovable property - It can be used to prove nature and character of possession.	(Para 6)

heading: Family settlements
Consent decree
Required no registration
HeadNote.description:
Family settlements - Consent decree - Exempt from requirement of registration - Agreements recording family settlements - Merger of, in decree of Court - Required no registration - Clause in agreement clarifying a previous deal in respect of property not forming part of suit properties but not affecting any change to any legal rights in property and merely reciting what existing rights were - Said clause would not serve to take consent decree outside scope of exception in Section 17(2)(vi) of Act.

Section 17(1) of the Registration Act, 1908 insofar as it is relevant, requires under clause (b) thereof, registration of "non-testamentary instruments which purport or operate to create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish, whether in present or in future, any right, title or interest, whether vested or contingent, of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards, to or in immovable property". Sub-section (2) of Section 17 creates exceptions to the mandatory requirements of Section 17(1)(b) and (c).  One of the exceptions made in Section 17(2) of the Registration Act 1908,  is  clause (i).  This exception pertains to "any composition deed."  In other words all composition deeds are exempt from the requirement to be registered under that Act.  The Composition Deed in this case was a transaction between the members of the  same family for the mutual benefit of such members.  It is not the appellants' case that the agreements required registration under any other Act.  Furthermore, in this  case the agreements had merged in the  decree of the Court which is also excepted under sub-section 2(vi) of Section 17 of the Registration Act, 1908.	 [Para 31]

The only property which did not form part of the suit properties were the forty four acres of land at Raisen belonging to AA's son.  Clause (e) in the second agreement did not seek to either create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish either in present or in future, any right title or interest in the property within the meaning of Section 17(l)(b) of the Registration Act.  All that clause (e) of the second agreement expressly did was to clarify a previous deal.  It did not affect any change to any legal rights in the property and merely recited what the existing rights were.  This clause would not therefore serve to take the consent decree dated 25th August, 1993 outside the scope of the exception in Section 17(2)(vi) of the Registration Act, 1908.	 [Para 32]

The appellants made much of the fact that no leave was obtained from the Courts under Order 22 Rule 10 of the Code to bring VMS on record as an assignee of their rights.  This was an argument which has been raised for the first time before us. The Rule gives an assignee of a party's interest during the pendency of the suit the option to apply for leave to continue the suit and is resorted to by an assignee when the assignee is of the opinion that his interest would be better preserved thereby.  There is no obligation on the assignee to come on record.  Indeed, in Dhurandhar Prasad Singh Vs. Jai Prakash University, (2001)6 SCC 534, this Court has held that the prayer for leave could be made not only to by the assignee but also by the assignor.  The appellants, who were the assignors in this case, were aware that they had assigned their rights and liabilities in the suit properties to VMS.  They did not choose to bring the fact of such assignment on record in the pending suits.  Furthermore, the suits were not being "continued" but were being brought to an end as far as the appellants were concerned.  For both these reasons, VMS' choice not to apply for  leave under Order 22 Rule 10 cannot be construed as having been made with any ulterior motive to defraud the appellants.						 [Para 34]

The pleadings of fraud in both the applications of the appellants were in any event grossly inadequate.  Both the Trial Court and the Division Bench have correctly held so.  In fact the basic cause for which the appellants initially came to the Court was a non-payment of amounts as specified under the agreements by VMS.  We concur with the finding of the learned Single Judge that the appellants could execute the decree for the monies due under compromise decree dated 25th August, 1993.  Mere non-payment was certainly not supportive of a ground for setting aside the decree on the basis of an allegation of fraud.	 [Para 35]

heading: Registration
Necessity
HeadNote.description: Registration - Necessity - Determination as to whether document in question is a partition deed or mere family arrangement - Properties of family divided by it - Plea of plaintiff that arrangement was agreed between parties in 1970 but he raised certain objections regarding unequitable distribution - Held, it is a family arrangement and not partition deed - No need of registration. (Para 4)

heading: Under consent decree defendant agreeing to give their flat as security if they failed to pay decretal amount
HeadNote.description:
Under consent decree defendant agreeing to give their flat as security if they failed to pay decretal amount - Flat mentioned only as security and decree not creating any right, title or interest in favour of plaintiff in the said flat - Held consent decree did not require registration under S.17.

In the present case flat belonging to defendant was mentioned only as a part of the security for the suit claim and the decree did not create any right, title or interest in favour of the plaintiff in the said flat.  The right, title and interest of the defendants are not adversely affected in the consent terms and if they honour the decree, the flat would be untouched.  Therefore, the consent decree did not require registration under Section 17 of the Registration Act.  The result would have been otherwise, if in the consent decree the flat was offered to the plaintiff in lieu of the decretal amount in full and final settlement of the suit claim.  In such circumstances, such a decree would surely have required registration before it could be put for execution.  If the parties by consent indicate or mention some immovable properties as security for the decretal amount, such a decree, would not require registration under Section 17 of the Act.

AIR 1977 Orissa 198 and AIR 1971 Mad 182 Rel.on.  [Para 6]

heading: Licence agreement
HeadNote.description: Licence agreement - Security Deposit agreement not registered - Licensee cannot claim lien under such Deposit Agreement - Lien, if any, is contractual and not statutory.

heading: Unregistered partition deed
HeadNote.description: Unregistered partition deed - Whether admissible in evidence - Document of family settlement/ family arrangement can be used as corroborative evidence as explaining arrangement made thereunder and conduct of the parties. 	(Para 9)

heading: Rectification deed
HeadNote.description: Rectification deed - Signed by plaintiff and stating that description given in original sale deed of the land sold is 4 acres and 15 gunthas was a mistaken description and he had in fact sold entire area of 8 acres 30 gunthas - Document requires registration. AIR 1971 SC 751 Rel.on. AIR 1962 Mad 360 Distinguished.	(Para 20)

heading: Unregistered award
HeadNote.description: Unregistered award - Award in respect of property of more than Rs.100/- and not subject-matter of dispute or reference to arbitration - Award is compulsorily registrable - It could neither be admitted in evidence nor can decree be passed in terms of the same. AIR 1974 SC 1066, 1989 (3) SCC 99 Rel. on.	(Para 39)

heading: Unregistered relinquishment deed
HeadNote.description: Unregistered relinquishment deed - Admissibility of, in evidence, scope of, when it is not recording a past transaction whereunder party had already relinquished her rights - Under the document in question, petitioner-plaintiff stated to have relinquished her rights over joint family properties movable and immovable - Document sought to be marked on behalf of respondent-defendants, since a relinquishment deed, the same being not properly stamped and unregistered, held inadmissible in evidence - Trial Court, held erred in receiving the same and marking it as Ex.B-1.	(Para 18)

heading: Purport and effect of
HeadNote.description:
Purport and effect of - Non-registration of documents required by Section 17 or by any provision of Transfer of Property Act to be registered, consequences of.

The Registration Act, 1908 was enacted with the intention of providing orderliness, discipline and public notice in regard to transactions relating to immovable property and protection from fraud and forgery of documents of transfer. This is achieved by providing for consequences of non-registration. Section 17 clearly provides that any document (other than testamentary instrument) which purports or operates to create declare, assign, limit or extinguish whether in present or in future any right, title or interest whether vested or contingent of the value of Rs.100/- and upwards to in immovable property.-Section 49 provides that no document required by Section 17 to be registered shall affect any immovable property comprised therein or received as evidence of any transaction affecting such property, unless it has been registered. Registration of a document gives notice to the public that such a document has been executed.   [Para 11]

It is provided under Section 49 that no document required by Section 17 or by any provision of the Transfer of Property Act to be registered shall affect any immovable property comprised therein or be received as evidence of any transaction affecting such property unless it is registered. As per the provision made in the proviso to that section such a document may be received as evidence of any collateral transaction not required to be effected by registered instrument. It has consistently been held by Courts of law that an unregistered document of transfer which is required to be registered and not registered is admissible in evidence to prove the date of entering into the fact of possession of the transferee and to show the character of his possession. Though an unregistered document required to be registered under law is not admissible in evidence to claim any right under it, it would be admissible in evidence for a collateral purpose i.e., for a purpose other than that for which the document was created. It has always been held that a vendee under an unregistered sale deed, who comes into possession under it, though the document is inadmissible in evidence to prove title or any rights under it, it will be admissible in evidence to show the character of possession of the vendee viz., whether it is in his own right or whether it is with permission like that of a lessee or licensee and if he continues in such possession for over the statutory period he acquires title to the property not on account of the unregistered sale deed, but on account of the fact of his having been in possession for over the statutory period in his own right adversely to the real owner. Similarly, if a lessee comes into possession of immovable property under an unregistered lease deed which requires to be registered under law, certainly, it would be admissible in evidence to show the character of his possession, viz., that his possession is that of a lessee and therefore permissive in nature, since a lessor, who parts with physical possession to a lessee, under law is always considered to be in constructive possession through the lessee. Therefore, so long as the possession of the lessee is permissive, he cannot prescribe any title hostile to his lessor. [Para 12]

It is also well settled that if an unregistered document is sought to be relied on for collateral purpose under proviso to Section 49, the party has to pay the stamp duty and penalty.   [Para 13]

HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Right, title or interest in immovable property - Mere entries in Municipal Property Tax register does not clothe a person with any title or interest in suit property - If any rights were to be conferred, there ought to have been either sale deed or lease deed duly executed between the parties - If any right, title or interest in immovable property was transferred to a person, the same could have been done only by written documents duly registered under the provisions of S.17 of Registration Act. HeadNote.description: Compulsory registration of document - Necessity - Question whether document in question is partition deed or is document in nature of compromise/settlement between parties possessing/cultivating suit land - Evidence showing that all coparceners were not included in said deed - Therefore document not a partition deed but family arrangement between quarelling coparceners over possession of suit land - Moreover intention of parties being to inform Court/Revenue authorities for effecting entries in revenue records - Document cannot be construed as partition deed by which right is created, extinguished, declared so as to render it compulsorily registrable under S.17(1)(b).
