heading: Unregistered document
HeadNote.description:
Unregistered document - Can be admitted in evidence for a collateral fact/collateral purpose - Meaning and proof of collateral purpose.

From the principles laid down in the various decisions of Apex Court and the High Courts, it is evident that :-

1.	A document required to be registered is not admissible into evidence under Section 49 of the Registration Act.

2.	Such unregistered document can however be used as an evidence of collateral purpose as provided in the Proviso to Section 49 of the Registration Act.

3.	A collateral transaction must be independent of, or divisible from, the transaction to effect which the law required registration.

4.	A collateral transaction must be a transaction not itself required to be effected by a registered document, that is, a transaction creating, etc. any right, title or interest in immoveable property of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards.

5.	If a document is inadmissible in evidence for want of registration, none of its terms can be admitted in evidence and that to use a document for the purpose of proving an important clause would not be using it as a collateral purpose. [Para 21]

In this case, it was the case of the appellant that the suit premises was let out only for the particular named officer of the respondent and accordingly, after the same was vacated by the said officer, the respondent was not entitled to allot it to any other employee and was therefore, liable to be evicted which, was an important term forming part of the lease agreement. Therefore, such a Clause, of the Lease Agreement in this case, cannot be looked into even for collateral purposes to come to a conclusion that the respondent was liable to be evicted because of violation of said Clause of the Lease Agreement.   [Para 22]

heading: Unregistered lease
Admissibility
HeadNote.description: Unregistered lease - Admissibility - Clause in lease deed that premises were let out to a particular named officer of the Company and cannot be allotted to any other officer - It is an important clause in lease deed and cannot be looked into even for collateral purposes.	(Paras 24, 28)

heading: Renewal of licence
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Registration Manual Part I and II - Constitution of India, Art.19(1)(g) - Circular dated 21.06.2001 issued by Inspector - General and Stamp Controller, Maharashtra State - Licence of document/bond writers - Renewal of licence - Circular by State Government - Circular prescribing condition that no licence shall be granted or renewed in favour of petition/document/bond writer who has crossed his age of 60 years or that licence of such person should be cancelled - S.69 nowhere provides for any such authorisation in favour of the State - Held, direction issued in the impugned challenged is not within the scope of the provisions - Circular debarring or dequalifying person above age of sixty years from practising as a document/Bond writer is illegal and violative of Art.19(1)(g) of the Constitution - Offending part of the circular quashed and set aside holding it to be bad and illegal.	(Paras 19 & 20)

HeadNote.description: Award of Arbitrator recording finding on basis of pre-existing facts viz gift deed in favour of daughters revocation of gift and partition of property between his sons subsequent to revocation of gift deed - Award neither creating any right nor extinguishing any right in praesenti or in future - Award requires no registration. Sanctity
HeadNote.description: Registered document - Sanctity - Registered document has lot of sanctity attached to it - Held, sanctity cannot be allowed to be lost without following proper procedure.	(Para 39)

HeadNote.description: Registered power of attorney - Mere filing of criminal complaint against power of attorney-holder held, not sufficient to revoke power of attorney.			(Para 39)

Registration of
HeadNote.description: Partition deed - Registration of - Document has to be read in totality, not in piecemeal - Document cannot be said as partition deed for one purpose which requires registration - Memorandum of partition deed for other purpose which does not require registration - No provision shows registration of part of document - Document which is partition deed requires registration - Unregistered document is not admissible in evidence.(Para 11)

heading: Partition deed
HeadNote.description:
Partition deed - Admissibility of unregistered deed in evidence - Submission that even if it is found that document is inadmissible in evidence it has to be exhibited - Its admissibility has to be decided after evidence of parties is recorded, at hearing of suit - Submission liable to be rejected. 

No provision is pointed out which casts obligation on Trial Court  to admit all documents even if they are inadmissible in evidence and reserve decision about admissibility of documents until final judgment of case. As per 2008 (6) Mh.L.J. 912 Trial Court has to work out its own modality depending upon facts of each case. If it is possible for Trial Court to come to conclusion that document is inadmissible in evidence, then it will be exercise in futility to require Trial Court to admit document and reserve its decision on question of its admissibility until hearing of case.    [Para 12,13,14]

heading: Partition deed
Unregistered document
Admissibility in evidence
HeadNote.description: Partition deed - Unregistered document - Admissibility in evidence - Petitioners want to rely on document only to substantiate their case of partition - Petitioners are not able to find out any collateral purposes - Therefore submission made by petitioners relying upon proviso below S.49(c) cannot be accepted.(Para 15)

heading: Registration of lease deed
HeadNote.description:
Registration of lease deed - After expiry of period of lease - Relates back to date of execution.
2010 ALL SCR 2441 Rel. on. (Para 54)

heading: Gift under Muslim Law
HeadNote.description: Gift under Muslim Law - Solely because it is written instrument, does not require registration.(Para 19)

heading: Agreement entered into between FCI and plaintiff for plaintiff constructing plinths and leasing them out to FCI initially for three years on agreed rent
HeadNote.description:
Agreement entered into between FCI and plaintiff for plaintiff constructing plinths and leasing them out to FCI initially for three years on agreed rent - FCI's objection that agreement was not registered - Held, it was not an agreement creating right in immovable property and hence, not compulsorily required to be registered.

If the agreement is such which may amount to a present demise even though the document may be contemplated to be executed later on it may be a document or agreement creating the rights.  There must be demise of the property in praesenti.  But an agreement for securing another agreement or deed in future would not be such an agreement or document which may require registration.  Clause 8 of agreement did not create any right in praesenti nor there was any immediate demise of the property.  It was only an executory agreement.  The construction of the plinth it seems had yet to start with other facilities and amenities.  On completion, such a certificate was to be obtained from the defendant.  It was thereafter that the possession was to be handed over under the lease agreement which was to be executed between the parties.  The construction was to be strictly in accordance with the directions and specifications of the defendant.  Condition No.9 also contemplated that if the structure was found defective or workmenship was faulty the defendant could refuse to take possession of the premises and the earnest money was liable to be forfeited.  Hence it is evident that no possession, right or title had passed on in praesenti at the time of execution of the agreement, and there were many prior conditions attached thereto.  Such an agreement, has been rightly  held to be only an executory agreement and not an agreement creating rights in the immovable property, hence not compulsorily required to be registered.  It was a mere agreement between the parties which was not registered but was admissible in evidence.	 [Para 11]

heading: Unregistered document
HeadNote.description:
Specific Relief Act (1963), S.6 - Unregistered document - Admissibility in evidence in a suit for specific performance - Held, in a suit for specific performance even an unregistered document affecting immovable property and which is otherwise required to be registered, could be admitted as evidence of contract.

	Section 17 of the Registration Act indicates the document in respect of which registration thereof is compulsory and Clause (e) takes within its sweep the non-testamentary instruments transferring or assigning any decree or order of a Court or any award when such decree or order or award purports or operates to create, declare, assign, limit or extinguish, whether in present or in future, any right, title or interest, whether vested or contingent, of the value of one hundred rupees and upwards, to or in the immovable property. In the instant case trial Court had referred to this provision to conclude that as the document in question related to the creation of a right in the immovable property, it could not be looked into for want of registration as required in terms of Section 17 (e) of the Registration Act. Section 49 deals with the effect of non-registration of the documents required to be registered and reads as : "no document required by Section 17 or by any provision of the Transfer of the Property Act, 1882 to be registered shall - (a) affect any immovable property comprised therein, or (b) confer any power to adopt, or (c) be received as evidence of any transaction affecting such property or conferring such power, unless it has been registered".

	The proviso thereto, however, circumscribes the effect of Section 49 and reads: "provided that an unregistered document affecting immovable property and required by this Act of Transfer of the Property Act, 1882 to be registered may be received as evidence of a contract in a suit for specific performance under Chapter II of the Specific Relief Act, 1877 or as evidence of any collateral transaction not required to be effected by registered instrument". Therefore, a reading of Section 17 with the proviso to Section 49 of the Registration Act, 1908 would support the case of the appellants that in a suit for specific performance under the Specific Relief Act, 1963 even an unregistered document affecting the immovable property and otherwise required to be registered under the Registration Act or Transfer of Property Act may be received as evidence of a contract or as evidence of any collateral transaction not required to be effected by a registered instrument. The appellants as the original plaintiffs had filed a suit not only for declaration and permanent injunction but also for the specific performance, compensation and consequential reliefs and therefore in a suit of this nature, the appellants would be entitled to rely on the unregistered document by invoking Section 17 read with the proviso to Section 49 of the Registration Act, 1908. 

2010(3) ALL MR 477 (S.C.) Ref.to.				 [Para 10,11]

heading: Partition deed
Being unregistered one
HeadNote.description: Partition deed - Being unregistered one - Cannot be admitted in evidence. (Para 11)

heading: Competency of person referred to in R.44(1)(c)
HeadNote.description:
Competency of person referred to in R.44(1)(c) - Cannot be related to any factor other than which is specified in S.32.

A document is to be presented for registration primarily by its executant himself or by a person duly authorised in terms of the provisions of law relating to delegation of such power.  The competency of a person referred in Rule 4(1) (c) of the said Rules is essentially the one spoken in Section 32 of the said Act. It cannot relate to the title of the person to the property which is subject matter of such document. The conclusion in this regard is inevitable considering the provisions of Part III & Part VI of the said Act. As it is clear from the provisions of law contained in Section 32 of the said Act, which speaks about the competency of the person to present a document for registration, obviously the Rules framed under the said Act cannot travel beyond the scope of the Statute, under which, they are framed.  Apart from being executant himself or a person duly authorised by him or claiming under the same, no other restrictions have been imposed in relation to the entitlement of a person to present a document for registration.  Being so the competency of the person referred to it Rule 44 (1) (c) of the said Rules cannot be related to any factor other than which is specified in Section 32 of the said Act.  The competent person does not mean to be the title holder of the property which is the subject matter of the document presented for registration.   [Para 11]

heading: Powers of registering authority
HeadNote.description:
Powers of registering authority - Registering authority has no powers to verify or ascertain as to whether the executant of the document has title to the property which is sought to be dealt with under the document presented for registration.

The registering authority has no powers to verify or ascertain as to whether the executant of the document has title to the property which is sought to be dealt with under the document presented for registration.  Any enquiry by the Registering Authority in the matter of title of the property which is the subject matter of the document presented for registration would be beyond the jurisdiction and powers of such authority.  The executant of the document is, in no way, answerable to the Registering Authority relating to the title of the property which is the subject matter of the document presented by him for registration.  Any refusal for registration of the document by the Registering authority on the ground of absence of title to such property to the executant or on account of any defect in his title to such property would be per se illegal act on the part of Registering authority. [Para 11]

heading: Registration of document
Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Registration of document - Agreement of sale - Agreement cannot be treated as conveyance for purpose of Registration Act - Agreement of sale, not compulsorily registrable.	(Para 17)

HeadNote.description: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.20 - Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.53A - Unregistered agreement to sale - Admissibility of, as evidence - Plaintiff sought to produce unregistered sale agreements to prove his claim for specific performance of contract - Unregistered sale agreements can be received as evidence of contract in suit for specific performance of contract as per proviso to S.49 of Registration Act - However, same cannot be admitted as evidence for purpose of protection of possession u/S.53A of TP Act. HeadNote.description: Deed of family settlement - Relinquishment of property was to take effect in future - Deed of family settlement, held, was not required to be compulsorily registered. (Para 10)

HeadNote.description: Registration of conveyance deed - Time limit of eight months - Computation of - Deed of conveyance was executed on 31st December 2009 and presented for registration on 25 July 2014 - Delay of more than four years caused - However, period of 3 years, 10 months and 25 days were consumed by statutory authority for adjudicating stamp duty, which has to be excluded - After exclusion, time taken for presentation of documents was 7 months and 28 days, is within limitation period of 8 months - Since document has not been presented before 4 months, petitioner is directed to pay fine for such delay. 			(Paras 5, 6, 8)

Determination

HeadNote.description: Registration of consent decree - Decree was with regard to property which was subject matter of suit - Hence, not required to be registered u/S.17(2)(vi) of Registration Act being covered by exclusionary clause. (Para 20)

heading: Admissibility in evidence
HeadNote.description: Unregistered family settlement deed - Admissibility in evidence - If document of family settlement is unregistered and unstamped, its use can be restricted for collateral purpose for proving possession - Family settlement deed in question was not only unregistered but also not properly stamped - Appellate court not at fault in not admitting family settlement deed. heading: Sale certificate
Refusal to register
HeadNote.description: Security Interest (Enforcement) Rules (2002), R.1 - Sale certificate - Issued to auction purchaser - Refusal to register - No statutory prohibition shown which enables Registering Officer to refuse registration of sale certificate - Registering Officer has no right to decide whether person who presented document for registration has marketable title or not - It is duty of Registering Officer to register sale certificate issued in favour of auction purchaser by Authorized Officer of Secured Creditor under provisions of Security Interest (Enforcement) Rules, 2002 - Registering Officer directed to register sale certificate on payment of stamp duty etc. - In view of facts registration of sale certificate shall not be refused on basis of encumbrance of State Govt. (Paras 15, 19, 22)

heading: Immovable property
HeadNote.description: Immovable property - Transfer of Development Rights (TDR) - TDR a benefit arising out of an immovable property - Since TDR is to be used and utilised into an immovable property, held, it would certainly be an immovable property itself - All the incidents of immovable properties would be attached to such an agreement. 2007(2) B.C.R. 587 - Rel. on.	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Registration of agreement
HeadNote.description: Registration of agreement - Agreement of Transfer of Development Rights (TDR) - TDR being an immovable property itself - Held, none of the parties including the plaintiff, therefore, can base its claim in an action in law upon the unregistered agreement to transfer TDR which is a benefit arising from an immovable property and consequently immovable property itself.	(Para 26)

HeadNote.description: Registration of sale deed/agreement - Name of Govt. Authority (MSRDC) entered into 7/12 Extracts of lands in question - But later said entry deleted - Giving impression to owners/power of attorney holders that said land being deleted from acquisition, no more required by MSRDC - Search report of Advocate also showing that owners of lands had marketable title and lands not encumbered - In facts Registering officers-petitioners could not be required to go into title in said lands - Could not have refused registration of said documents - Further, no material on record about petitioners receiving gratification from any accused - They merely carried out their duties in registering said documents - Charge against them under PC Act - Not sustainable. heading: Breach of the order of First Appellate Authority
HeadNote.description:
Breach of the order of First Appellate Authority - First Appellate Authority under S.19 of Right to Information Act is not a "Court" within meaning of S.2(b) - Contempt petition is not maintainable.

The vesting of the power to decide whether the information should be provided or not as per the request made under Section 6 of the said Act would not make the Appellate Authority a Court within the meaning of the said Act of 1971. The Appellate Authority under the said Act cannot be said to have a power to give a judgment which has finality and authoritativeness. It is not possible to accept that the Appellate Authorities under the said Act are charged with a duty to decide the disputes in a judicial manner and to declare the rights of the parties by a judgment. Even if the Appellate Authority under the said Act may act judicially, it does not become a Court. The Appellate Authority under the said Act cannot be said to have been entrusted with the judicial functions of a Court. The Appellate Authority does not have power to give a definitive judgment after considering the evidence having regard to the facts of the case and by application of law.  [Para 7]

heading: Consumer complaint
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Consumer complaint - Maintainability - Complaint filed against an Information Officer for not supplying information sought by complainant - Held, RTI Act provides complete answers to all grievances of complainant - Hence, complaint held not maintainable. 	(Para 7)

heading: Consumer complaint
HeadNote.description: Consumer complaint - Relating to deficiency in service by Information Officer by not providing information under RTI Act - Maintainable.		(Para 11)

heading: Detention order
Grounds of
Non-disclosure of
HeadNote.description: Detention order - Grounds of - Non-disclosure of - In terms of Section 8(1)(h), it is not obligatory on the authority to disclose the detention order and the grounds in support thereof before the arrest of the proposed detenu - Thus documents, such as proposed detention order and the Grounds of Detention, which are intended to be served on the detenu at the time of his arrest - Cannot be made available under the provisions of the Right to Information Act - Even assuming that the documents would be covered by the definition of 'information' predicated in Section 2(f) - It would be exempted from disclosure within the meaning of Section 8(1)(h) of the Act.		(Paras 46, 47)

heading: Scheme of revaluation
HeadNote.description:
Circular No.239 of 2013, Annexure A, cls.1(iv), 3(iii), 3(xiii) - Scheme of revaluation - Complaint to State Chief Information Commissioner (SCIC) that clauses 1(iv), 3 (iii) of circular No.239/2013 issued by Vice Chancellor, University of Pune were in conflict with provisions of RTI Act - Circular issued in exercise of powers under S.14(8) of Universities Act, dealing with scheme of revaluation - SCIC, issuing direction for deletion/correction thereof, illegal.

The provisions contained in Circular No.239 of 2013 and Annexure-A thereto concern with the scheme of revaluation of answer papers. If a candidate is desirous of seeking re-evaluation,then it is obligatory for him to apply for photocopies of evaluated or re-evaluated answer books within ten days from declaration of results of the examination concerned. Thereafter, within ten days from the date of receipt of such photocopies, such applicant has to submit application for revaluation. There are time limits imposed upon the examiners as well as the university in the matters of revaluation. This is necessary considering the magnitude of the requests for re evaluation as also the necessity to complete the revaluation process with utmost dispatch. If the time limit set out in clause 1(iv) is disturbed or varied, it is possible that an applicant seeks for copies even on the 89th day after the declaration of results and further within ten days from the receipt thereof insists that his answer papers are re-evaluated. This would, possibly, lead to the collapse of the entire scheme of revaluation. In any case, these are policy matters, which are within competence of academic authorities. The scope of even judicial review by a Constitutional Court in such matters, is very limited.  [Para 8,9]

Circular No. 239 of 2013 and Annexure-A thereto do not infringe upon the right of candidate, or for that matter any person to inspect or obtain photocopies of assessed, evaluated or re-evaluated answer-books within a period of three months from the date of declaration of result. However, if a candidate seeks to avail re evaluation of his answer-books, then such candidate is required to comply with the procedure and time schedules set out in Circular No.239 of 2013 and Annexure-A thereto. Consequently, the directions to 'Correct' clause 1(iv) in Annexure-A to Circular No.239 of 2013, was not warranted. even though the University of Pune may not be in a position to effectively enforce the provisions of transfer contained in clause 3(iii) with regard to photocopies of answer-books obtained under RTI Act, there was no reason to issue any direction for deletion of the said clause by the SCIC in exercise of powers conferred by Section 18 of the RTI Act. The same is position with regard to clause 3(xiii) which provides that University shall not be liable for failure and delay in supplying photocopies of evaluated/re-evaluated answer-books due to any reason beyond the control of the University. The complaint made by respondent No.2 cannot be said to be a complaint which falls within any of the predicates of Section 18 of the RTI Act. If, however, the ominibus clause contained in Section 18(1)(f) of the RTI Act is stretched and the complaint is regarded as one under Section 18 (1) of the RTI Act, there is still no power to be found in Section 18 of the RTI Act, under which the directions for 'deletion/correction' of Circular No.239 of 2013 issued by the Vice Chancellor in exercise of powers conferred upon him by Section 18(8) of the M.U. Act can be issued. The directions issued also cannot relate to the provisions contained in Section 19(8) of the RTI Act, which incidentally concerns the appellate jurisdiction of the SCIC, which it was admittedly not exercising whilst entertaining the complaint made by respondent No.2. Section 19(8) of the RTI Act, in any case empowers the SCIC to require public authority to take any such steps as may be necessary to secure compliance with the provisions of RTI Act, including by making necessary changes to its practices in relation to maintenance, management and destruction of records. Annexure-A to Circular No.239 of 2013 deals with scheme of re-evaluation of answer-books and in that sense has no nexus with the rights of any person to obtain photocopies of answer-books simplicitor by resort to the provisions of RTI Act. Even a constitutional Court after record of conclusion as to unconstitutionality of a legislative or a quasi legislative exercise, would normally strike down the same, but refrain from directing 'deletion/correction'.In such circumstances, the directions issued for 'deletion/correction' are clearly in excess of jurisdiction. (1984) 4 SCC 27 Rel. on. 2011 ALL SCR 2239 Disting.  [Para 12,13,18,19,21]

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Agricultural Produce Market Committee - Is established and constituted statutorily as local authority and as such provisions of Right to Information Act apply to it. Maharashtra Agricultural Produce Marketing (Development and Regulation) Act (1963), Ss.2(j), 11, 12, 13.

The Market committee is brought into existence not by virtue of an act of any person to register a Market Committee like a Society and then bring it into existence, but a Market Committee comes into existence by virtue of operation of the provisions of the APMC Act, which is the law made by State Legislature. Not only that, Section 12(2) clearly provides that every Market Committee shall for all purposes be deemed to be a local Authority.  By virtue of Section 12(2) of the APMC Act, the Agricultural Produce Market Committee will fall within the meaning of 'local authority' and consequently, under Section 2(h) of the RTI Act, 2005.  Decision in 2009(4) ALL MR 873 Disting.					  [Para 11,12]

heading: Order of penalty
Interference with
HeadNote.description: Order of penalty - Interference with - Finding based on evidence and after affording the petitioner a reasonable opportunity of being heard as contemplated by law - Held, the impugned order does not call for any interference. (Paras 4, 5)

heading: Public Authority
HeadNote.description: Public Authority - Whether Co-operative Housing Society is Public Authority - Society neither owned, controlled or financed by the government - Solely on basis of supervision and control by Registrar of societies and definition of "public servant" in Co-operative Societies Act and in Karnataka Lokayukta Act a Society cannot be termed a "Public Authority" - It should fulfill conditions stipulated in S.2(h)(d) of the RTI Act. AIR 2005 SC 2677, AIR 1988 Kerala 75 (F.B.) - Foll.	(Para 7)

heading: Information relating to third party
HeadNote.description:
Information relating to third party - Cannot be supplied without hearing that party and without joining it as party respondent.

If the information is pertaining to third party is ordered to be supplied without hearing third party, third party is loosing his right to prefer First Appeal under Section 19 of the Act, 2005 and third party is also loosing a right to prefer Second Appeal under Section 19(4) of the Act, 2005 and, therefore, third party ought to be joined as party respondent, which has not been joined by present respondent No.2 in his First Appeal as well as in his Second Appeal and, therefore also, the order passed by Second Appellate Authority deserves to be quashed and set aside.  AIR 2007 Guj 203 and 2007(3) G.L.H. 352 - Rel.on.   [Para 12]

heading: Appointment of Central and State Information Commissioners
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Central and State Information Commissioners - Power of writ court to interfere with - Writ petitioner praying that an impartial Sub-committee be formed to assist the selection committee under RTI Act - Held, such an act would mean enactment of law by the court which is not permissible - It is the Legislature's task to enact law - Courts interpret the law and do not enact the law.

A close look at Sections 12 and 15 would show that the Committee that makes recommendations to the President or the Governor (as the case may be) is the High Power Committee. Before the said Committee makes recommendations to the President, the Committee takes into consideration that such person has eminence in public life with wide knowledge and experience in the subject as set out in the Act.  That the recommendee meets the criterion can be assumed from the fact that the recommendation is made by such High Power Committee unless malafides are alleged and found to have some merit.  The appointment of the Central Chief Commissioner and Information Commissioners and the State Chief Information Commissioner and the State Information Commissioners cannot be assailed on the ground that they are not in the opinion of the petitioners or the Court, the persons having eminence in public life with wide knowledge and experience.

The comparison, without knowing the intricacies of the system and set up, of the appointment of Secretaries in USA with the appointment of Chief Information Commissioner, Information Commissioners, State Chief Information Commissioner and State Information Commissioners under RTI, 2005, is odious.  The writ petition is founded on assumptions, presumptions, preconceived notions and comparisons.  The prayer made by the petitioners that the Chief information Commissioner and the Information Commissioners appointed by the respondents under the RTI Act may be declared ad-hoc or temporary appointees is wholly misconceived.  The prayer made by the petitioners to the effect that an impartial sub-committee be formed to assist the selection committee under the RTI Act, 2005 would mean enactment of law by the court which is not permissible.  It is the Legislature's task to enact law.  The Courts interpret the law and do not enact the law.	 [Para 5,7]

heading: Kerla Anti-Social Activities (Prevention) Act (2007), S.3
HeadNote.description:
Kerla Anti-Social Activities (Prevention) Act (2007), S.3 - Petition under RTI Act - Documents, necessary to challenge order of preventive detention at pre-execution stage, sought for - As per Subhash Popatlal Dave's case person sought to be arrested in execution of an order of detention would not be entitled to invoke provisions of S.3 of RTI Act - Held, same principle would apply in respect of order of detention and documents in support of ground of detention - Hence, petition dismissed. 

In Subhash Popatlal Dave's case, the Supreme Court emphasized that the legislature has made an exception to the disclosure of information which could be contrary to the interests of the nation, after referring to clause (a) of Sub Section (1) of Section 8 of the Right to Information Act. Sub Clause (b) of Clause 3 of Article 22 of the Constitution makes it clear that clause (1) of Article 22 shall not apply to any person who is arrested or detained under any law providing for preventive detention. Clause (1) of Article 22 of the Constitution of India mandates that no person who is arrested shall be detained in custody without being informed, as soon as may be, of the grounds for such arrest. Even in respect of an arrest other than an arrest under the law providing for preventive detention, the constitutional mandate is only with respect to being informed of the grounds of arrest, only after the arrest. Even that right would not be available to a person who has been preventively detained under an order of preventive detention. Therefore, the rights under the Right to Information Act would not affect Sub Section (1) of Section 7 of the Kerla Anti-Social Activities (Prevention) Act since it is in tune with the constitutional guarantee under Article 22 of the Constitution of India. On the same grounds on which the Supreme Court held in Subhash Popatlal Dave's case that the person sought to be arrested in execution of an order of detention would not be entitled to invoke the provisions of Section 3 of the Right to Information Act in respect of the grounds of detention, the same principles would apply in respect of the order of detention and the documents in support of the grounds of detention.

2012 (7) SCC 533 Rel. on.      [Para 12]

heading: Delay in furnishing information
HeadNote.description: Delay in furnishing information - Show cause notice to the erring officer - Proceedings dropped after the officer tendering unqualified apology for delay - Provision u/S.20 RTI Act stipulates imposition of Rs.250/- for each day during delay - In view of decision of HP High Court either the penalty has to be imposed at the rate fixed or no penalty has to be imposed - Matter remanded back to be decided again strictly in terms of S.20. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Information as to salary details
HeadNote.description: Information as to salary details - Sought by wife of respondent/public servant - Being wife, applicant is entitled to know what remuneration her husband is getting - Information not exempted under S.8(1)(j). 2012(6) ALL MR 442 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Disclosure of information
Exemption from
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - Exemption from - Information relating to salary and posting etc. of petitioner working in a Govt. School - Not private in nature - Hence, not covered under any of exemptions given u/S.8 RTI Act. 			(Paras 4, 6, 7)

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Question as to whether respondent society-a registered charitable institution is a public authority - Society running a hospital on a leased land given by Govt. - It has also got exemption under Income Tax Act - Held, merely because leased land given by Govt., would not mean that society is controlled and financed to such an extent that state would have a substantial control over the same - Grant of exemption under IT Act would also not mean that Govt. would have such control over hospital - Therefore, respondent held not a public authority hence not liable to provide information under RTI Act. 2014(1) ALL MR 451 (S.C.) Ref. to.			(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Non-compliance by respondent
HeadNote.description: Complaint to State Commission - Scope of exercise of power - Order of appellate authority to furnish information to petitioner - Non-compliance by respondent - Direction by Information Commission to respondent to show cause as to why action u/S.20 of RTI Act should not be ordered on account of non-compliance of earlier direction - Non-compliance with that order also - Petitioner filed fresh complaint u/S.18(1)(e) - State commission held that respondent was liable to furnish requisite information - Thereby in fact set aside order which was in favour of petitioner, without same being challenged by respondent - Thus, exercised power of review - Whereas it was required to adjudicate as to whether petitioner was supplied incomplete, misleading or false information under RTI Act - Power of review not being inherent and having not been conferred under provisions of the Act, exercise of same is beyond jurisdiction - Hence, order of State Commission, set aside.	(Paras 3, 6)

heading: Public authority
Word "substantially financed"
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Word "substantially financed" - Educational Institution in question indirectly receiving funds from Government - Would be covered by definition of "public authority".

The institution in question was engaged in providing education to the society. For appointment of teachers, the courses to be taught in institution and all other affairs were fully covered by the statutory provisions. The institution was receiving grant-in-aid for payment of salary to entire teaching staff, non teaching staff, and Class-IV employees. Apart from payment of salary, the institution also received maintenance grant from time to time from the Government. Instant is the case where institution was receiving funds directly from Government for payment of salary and for maintenance. The word "substantially financed" clearly indicates that the institution has not to be 100% financed by the State. The word "substantial" has been used only to indicate that even if entire finance and expenditure of institution in not borne by Government still institution will be covered by definition of public authority. The object of the Act is to secure access to information under control of public authorities. The institution, which is being run in accordance with the statutory provisions and receiving finance by State Government substantially is duty bound to divulge the information, as sought, accordance with the provisions of Act, 2005.   [Para 7,8]

heading: Independence of judiciary and right to free speech and expression
HeadNote.description: Independence of judiciary and right to free speech and expression - Respondent seeking information about appointment of certain Judges from the office of Supreme Court - Question whether information sought for amount to interference in the functioning of the judiciary and whether information sought for can be withheld from the Respondent and whether it is exempt under S.8(1)(j) of the Act - Questions raise great and fundamental issues and require to be placed before a larger Bench.(Paras 15-17)

heading: Information relating to judicial decisions
HeadNote.description:
Information relating to judicial decisions - Application to know why and for what reasons judge had come to a particular conclusion against petitioner - Further information was sought as to why the judge omitted to examine certain documents and why he did not take note of certain arguments - Held answers sought by the petitioner could not have been with administrative authority nor could he have had access to this information and judge was not obliged to give any reasons as to why he had taken such decision in the matter which was before him.

An applicant under Section 6 of the RTI Act can get any information which is already in existence and accessible to the public authority under law. Of course, under the RTI Act an applicant is entitled to get copy of the opinions, advices, circulars, orders, etc., but he cannot ask for any information as to why such opinions, advices, circulars, orders, etc. have been passed, especially in matters pertaining to judicial decisions. A judge speaks through his judgments or orders passed by him. If any party feels aggrieved by the order/judgment passed by a judge, the remedy available to such a party is either to challenge the same by way of appeal or by revision or any other legally permissible mode. No litigant can be allowed to seek information as to why and for what reasons the judge had come to a particular decision or conclusion. A judge is not bound to explain later on for what reasons he had come to such a conclusion.   [Para 6]

A judicial officer is entitled to get protection and the object of the same is not to protect malicious or corrupt judges, but to protect the public from the dangers to which the administration of justice would be exposed if the concerned judicial officers were subject to inquiry as to malice, or to litigation with those whom their decisions might offend. If anything is done contrary to this, it would certainly affect the independence of the judiciary. A judge should be free to make independent decisions. [Para 7]

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Institution recognised under the State Act and receiving grant-in-aid from State Government - Would be covered under S.2(h) of the Act.(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - Imposition of, no scope for, when information sought for by petitioner already supplied and intention of petitioner appears to harass respondents, than to seek information - Having put machinery into motion, petitioner chose not to appear before Chief Information Commissioner/R1 on stipulated date - Such misadventure on part of petitioner needs to be contained by award of costs - Further, nature of information sought for by him is such that, instead of being of any help to individual beneficiaries, it is prone to be used as a handle, to derive undue benefits - Requiring Information Officer and appellate authority to attend such queries would have its own impact upon their regular functions.	(Para )

heading: Right to information
HeadNote.description: Right to information - Applicant had applied for a clerical post in a bank - She was intimated that her application reached Bank after the deadline fixed for receiving the applications and hence not considered - Without challenging this communication she cannot seek details under the provisions of the Act, about how recruitment to the post was made.		(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Appeal
Exercise of jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Exercise of jurisdiction - Appellate authority ordered appointment of PIO in private aided college and sub-subsequently initiated contempt proceeding for non-compliance - At the date of impugned orders, petitioner college was not notified u/s.2(h) as public authority - Brought within purview of RTI Act subsequently - Held, orders passed by appellate authority without jurisdiction - Liable to be quashed and set aside. 			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Application for information
HeadNote.description: Application for information - Applicant need not give any reason or show any nexus as to why the information is required - Order requiring such reasons, liable to be quashed and set aside - Matter remanded to appellate authority for reconsideration.		(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Public authority
Definition of
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Definition of - Whenever there is even an iota of nexus regarding control and finance of public authority over the activity of a private body or institution or an organization etc. the same would fall under the provisions of Section 2(h) of the Act - Non-government educational institution recognized under U.P. High School and Intermediate Education Act and receiving grant-in-aid - Falls within definition of "public authority".		(Paras 13, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - S.20 does not provide for imposition of any penalty upon the appellate authority.	(Para 6)

heading: Third party information
HeadNote.description: Third party information - Certified copy of service book and personal record of government servant - Sought on ground that government servant had allegedly taken benefit of two advance increments in lieu of sterilization - Held, information has no relationship to any public activity and if parted with will lead to invasion of privacy of a government servant and as such cannot be supplied.	(Paras 16-18)

heading: Disclosure of Information
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of Information - When chief Information Officer seeks to disclose information belonging to third party, such information cannot be disclosed without complying with mandatory requirement of S.11 - Third party must have an opportunity of being heard and this could be done only in the event such a party is made a party in the proceedings before the Authority.			(Paras 6 & 8)

heading: "Public Authority"
HeadNote.description: "Public Authority" - Electricity supply company engaged in distribution and supply of energy - Company a subsidiary of wholly owned Government Company - As such State having deep and pervasive and not merely regulatory control over its activities - It is "Public Authority" within meaning of S.2(h).	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: In appeal
Scope u/s. 19(8)
HeadNote.description: Powers of State Information Commissioner - In appeal - Scope u/s. 19(8) - Ex-employee approached school tribunal in an appeal - Claimed various documents from Trust - Directions given to public authority i.e. Education officer (Secondary) to procure information from the trust - State Information Commissioner empowered the public authority to take any steps as may be necessary to secure compliance with the provisions - Provisions of RTI applicable to Trust therefore cannot be viewed as excessive - Ex-employee not pointed out that there was any other notice for hearing - Impugned order of State Commissioner to the extent indicated above passed without hearing petitioner would be unsustainable - Information or documents available can be looked into only after extending an opportunity of hearing - Order of State Information Commissioner would be liable to be quashed. 	(Paras 8, 11, 13)

heading: Application under RTI Act
HeadNote.description:
Application under RTI Act - Information relating to corruption sought to be furnished - Denial on ground that vide G.O. Ms. 158, dt.26.8.2008, provisions of S.24(4) of RTI Act shall not apply to Tamil Nadu State Vigilance Commission and Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-corruption Organization - Held, department cannot claim exemption from furnishing particulars relating to corruption - Govt. order has no application to the facts of the case.

In terms of Section 24(4), the State Government is empowered to notify in the Official Gazette that nothing contained in the Right to Information Act shall apply to such intelligence and security organization being organizations established by the State Government. Nevertheless, in the light of the first proviso, such power being conferred on the State Government to notify exempting such intelligence and security organizations, it cannot notify in respect of the information pertaining to the allegations of corruption and human rights violations. As a necessary corollary, the power to exempt from the provisions of the Act is not available to the State Government even in case of intelligence and security organizations in respect of the information pertaining to the allegations of corruption and human rights violations. The application of the notification depends upon the nature of information required.

In this context, in the instant case the first respondent in W.A.No.321 of 2010 has sought for the particulars relating to the number of investigations completed and the number of persons convicted for the years from 2003-2004 to 2007-2008 with the details as to the names of such convicted persons, the post held by them when the act of corruption was done, the charges framed and the recommendations given to the Vigilance Commissioner after investigation. Likewise the first respondent in W.A.No.320 of 2010 has sought for the particulars relating to the number of police stations/wings/branches within the Chennai city were raided by the DVAC officials during the last five years i.e., from January, 2003, how many police officials were caught during the raids, the list of names, the designation and the address of such officials who were caught and the amount recovered from each official, details of departmental actions taken against such official including the copy of enquiry report, the details of prosecution launched against such officials, the status of prosecution against each official, how many have been re-inducted into active service including the date of rejoining the service and their present place/station of service, the details of action taken by the Department to prevent corruption at police stations/branches/wings especially in Chennai city and the grievance redressal machinery for the public to make a complaint against such corrupt official demanding bribe/favour to do the duty. As all these particulars would certainly relate to corruption, the Government Order has no application to the facts of case.   [Para 16,17]

heading: Personal information
HeadNote.description: Personal information - Petitioner seeking information about personal matters pertaining to service career and details about Income Tax Returns and about his assets and liabilities, moveable and immovable properties of respondent who was Enforcement Officer - Petitioner not able to show that the information sought was for larger public interest - Held disclosure of such information would cause unwarranted invasion of privacy of the respondent under S.8(1)(j) of the Act and was rightly refused.  		(Paras 13-16)

heading: Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Information regarding functioning of Private School - Sought from Education Officer who is a public authority - Said authority ordered the school to supply necessary information directly to applicant - Permissibility - Public authority has to secure information from private school itself and then supply it to applicant - Ordering direct supply of information, not permissible.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: "Public authority"
Word "substantial assistance"
Interpretation
HeadNote.description: "Public authority" - NGO receiving amount of Rs.75 lakhs from Government - Word "substantial assistance" - Interpretation - Though word "substantial assistance" is not defined in the Act amount of Rs.75 lakhs cannot be said to be trivial - Request sought for by respondent is to provide a copy of a day book pertaining to a sum of Rs.3 lakhs received by NGO and the said information was not exempt under S.3 of Tamil Nadu Right to Information Act, 2007 or under the Central Act - Held as long as information sought for was not prohibited by a statute or rules framed thereunder, the petitioner was bound to furnish the same to a citizen including non member of the NGO.			(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Upheld.			(Paras 10, 11)
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of confidential information - Information regarding names of members of Interview Board for selection of lecturers and professors - Refusal to disclose as to would violate confidentiality - Upheld.			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Order of penalty
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Order of penalty - Challenge to - Failure to supply information - Application for information not forwarded to Public Officer - Order of penalty - Order based on assumption that Public Officer is "supposed to have known" - Held, order of penalty is liable to be set aside.

The order of penalty for failure is akin to action under Criminal Law. It is necessary to ensure that the failure to supply the information is either intentional or deliberate. Unless and until it is borne on record that any officer against whom order of penalty for failure is sought to be levied and had occasion to comply with the order, and has no explanation or excuse available worth satisfying the forum, possess the knowledge of the order to supply information, an order of penalty cannot be levied. In the present case the order of penalty is based on assumption that the petitioner is 'supposed to have known'. No such fiction is created by law nor on facts it is held that the defence is fake. In this premise, the order of penalty is unjust and deserves to be set aside being unsupported by law.  [Para 11,14]

heading: Public authority
Scope of definition
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Scope of definition - State Information Commissioner (S.I.C.) ordered petitioner-bank to supply information and documents sought by respondent within a period of 30 days - Held, petitioner bank is not a "public authority" within the meaning of S.2(h) - Hence respondent cannot seek information from bank under Right to Information Act - Order passed by S.I.C. set aside.	(Paras 2, 4)

heading: Right to information
HeadNote.description: Right to information - Information regarding income tax return of Member of Parliament was sought - Said information is a personal information - Information sought has no relationship to any public activity or interest - Information cannot be supplied. 			(Paras 8, 10, 15, 16, 22)

heading: Seeking of information
HeadNote.description: Seeking of information - Regarding assets of Judges of Bombay High Court - Information sought on basis of Full Bench judgment of Delhi High Court - Said Judgment had only persuasive value and subjudice before Supreme Court of India - Refusal to provide information by Public Information Officer, cannot be termed as perverse or vitiated by error of law apparent on face of record. 			(Paras 26, 27, 28)

heading: Application for furnishing information
HeadNote.description: Application for furnishing information - Information sought regarding number of members in Rail Coach Factory Employees Co-operative Consumer Store Ltd., and procedure to enroll new members and to expel the membership of a member and remedy against it - Refusal on ground that society was not a public authority and hence not bound to furnish information - State Commission in second appeal-cum-complaint however directed to furnish all the information without deciding whether the society is covered under the Act or not - Same being the issue of jurisdiction goes to the root of the matter - Held, it is for State Commission to firstly decide whether said society is public authority u/S.2(h), which it failed to do - Hence, matter remanded back to be decided afresh. 2014(1) ALL MR 451 (S.C.) Ref.to.			(Paras 4, 8)

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Applicant seeking information in respect of GR pertaining to release of lands from Urban Development Dept. - Applicant informed file not traceable - Second Appeal before State Information Commission - Commission directing that if file is not traced out action be initiated against all concerned by registering offence u/s.9 of Maharashtra Public Records Act - Govt. Officers not taking any action - Writ petition by applicant - Held, direction given by State Information Commission to file FIR was mandatory - High Court directed to file FIR.	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Public Authority
HeadNote.description:
Public Authority - Co-operative banks registered under Co-operative Societies Act and its authorities like Registrar are public authorities - Co-operative institutions are bound to supply information under RTI Act.

The provisions of the Maharashtra Cooperative Societies Act if read with the definition of information given in section 2(f) of the Right to Information Act, it can be said that everything which is mentioned in the definition of information needs to be supplied by the co-operative institution to the authority created under the Co-operative Societies Act. The definition of 'Public Authority' given in section 2(h) shows that such public authority can be created by any law made by the State Legislature.  [Para 10]

The petitioner (Association of co-operative banks) and its members, cooperative institutions, are registered under the Maharashtra Cooperative Societies Act, 1960. They are bodies created by the statute. But right from the registration till the liquidation there is control over these institutions of the authority created under the same Act. The authority steps in to take decision on the rights of the members. The authority has control over the manner in which the funds are invested or the distribution of the funds is made for different purpose. Such institutions cannot act independently and the apex bodies are created for such institutions.	  [Para 8]

The provisions of the Maharashtra Cooperative Societies Act show that the authority under the Act can do the audit and inquiry into irregularities. If loss is caused to the institution, the Directors, Promoters etc. the authority can assess the damage, and the loss caused to the institution can be recovered from those persons. There is the power of suspension of managing committee and removal of members with the authority created under the Act. For all the aforesaid purposes and other purposes mentioned in the Cooperative Societies Act, the co-operative institution is bound to supply the record to the authority. 2010(6) ALL MR 869 Held Not Good Law in view of 2016 ALL SCR 1090.    [Para 9]

heading: Delay in forwarding
Effect
HeadNote.description: Application for supply of information - Delay in forwarding - Effect - Application received by Tahasildar on 30.11.2010, forwarded to Talathi and B.D.O. on 13.12.2010 - As per S.6 transfer of application shall be made as soon as practicable but in no case later than five days from date of receipt of application - Tahasildar is responsible for delay in forwarding application - Also Naib Tahasildar could have furnished information as sought by applicant, he tried to avoid to furnish information - Penalty of Rs.25,000/- fastened on Naib Tahasildar. (Paras 10, 14, 15)

heading: Application to furnish information
HeadNote.description: Application to furnish information - Refusal to grant on ground of bar u/S.8(1)(d) - Petitioner appeared in the written test for the post of clerk - Information sought was for certified copy of the merit list in reference to the selection of the clerks - S.8(1)(d) pertains to information including commercial confidence, trade secrets or intellectual property etc. - Same is not case in said circumstances - Therefore, refusal to furnish information held, not proper. 2011 ALL SCR 2239, 2016(2) ALL MR 962 (S.C.) Ref. to.	(Para 6)

heading: Application u/S.18 before State Commission
HeadNote.description: Application u/S.18 before State Commission - Whether a complaint or an appeal - Body of application including prayer clause showing that it is a complaint against decision of first appellate authority - There cannot be any complain against appellate authority for simple reason that petitioner's appeal came to be decided rather promptly - Thus, body of appeal including prayer clause make it to be an appeal - Held, mere word 'Complaint' or 'Section 18' would not make application to be a complaint - 'State Information Commission' held right in treating the same as an appeal.	(Para 4)

heading: Imposition of penalty
HeadNote.description: Delay in furnishing information - Imposition of penalty - Application seeking information filed on 16-11-2015 - Information furnished in May, 2016 that too on direction of Commissioner - No satisfactory reason given regarding non-supply of information - Nor the delay explained in any manner - Finding that there was mala fide denial of information, held proper - Penalty of Rs.25000/- imposed by State Commission, sustained.(Para 6)

heading: PSC exams
Permissibility
HeadNote.description:
PSC exams - Disclosure of identity of examiners - Permissibility - Held, PSC and examiners stand in a principal-agent relationship - Examiners are bound to evaluate answer papers as per instructions given by PSC - Thus, fiduciary relationship established between PSC and examiners - Therefore, information shared between them, not liable to be disclosed.

In the present case the request of the information seeker about the information of his answer sheets and details of the interview marks can be and should be provided to him. It is not something which a public authority keeps it under a fiduciary capacity. Even disclosing the marks and the answer sheets to the candidates will ensure that the candidates have been given marks according to their performance in the exam. This practice will ensure a fair play in this competitive environment, where candidate puts his time in preparing for the competitive exams, but, the request of the information seeker about the details of the person who had examined/checked the paper cannot and shall not be provided to the information seeker as the relationship between the public authority i.e. Service Commission and the Examiners is totally within fiduciary relationship. The Commission has reposed trust on the examiners that they will check the exam papers with utmost care, honesty and impartially and, similarly, the Examiners have faith that they will not be facing any unfortunate consequences for doing their job properly. If disclosure of name of the examiners is allowed in every exam, the unsuccessful candidates may try to take revenge from the examiners for doing their job properly. This may, further, create a situation where the potential candidates in the next similar exam, especially in the same state or in the same level will try to contact the disclosed examiners for any potential gain by illegal means in the potential exam.   [Para 9,10]

heading: 'Public authority'
HeadNote.description: 'Public authority' - Co-operative Societies registered under Tamil Nadu Co-operative Societies Act, will not fall within definition of "public authority" u/S.2(h) of RTI Act.(Para 8)

heading: Public authorities
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Public authorities - Whether, Co-operative society is "Public authority" - Information sought from Registrar of Co-operative Societies with regard to petitioner-co-operative society - Since said information was not in possession of Registrar, direction issued to Registrar to access same from petitioner society - Petitioner refused to furnish such information on ground that it is private authority - Commissioner held that Government through Registrar of Cooperative Societies has absolute control over petitioner society and therefore petitioner society is "public authority" - Not proper - No findings by any authorities that information sought could be accessed by Registrar of Co-operative Societies, under MCS Act or any other law for time being in force - Impugned direction based on finding that petitioner is a public authority, is wrong and therefore, liable to be quashed. 2011(5) ALL MR 69, 2014(1) ALL MR 451 (S.C.), (2014) SCC OnLine Del 6435 Ref. to. 	(Paras 10, 11, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Sought by husband
HeadNote.description: Information about salary/PF of wife - Sought by husband - Whether, covered u/S.8(1)(e) and S.8(1)(g) as no public interest is involved - Information sought to be placed before District Court before whom matrimonial dispute is going between parties - In case of matrimonial disputes, there should not be any embargo on divulging PF accumulations of wife to husband - Husband cannot be said to be stranger or third party or the information sought by him also not confidential - He could have acquired such information by making application before District Court - Case not covered under 8(1)(e), 8(1)(g). AIR 2010 Delhi 7, 2013(1) ALL MR 444 (S.C.), 2013(3) ALL MR 932 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 18, 20)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Application under RTI Act - Failure to give reply to - Challenge - Petitioners had appeared in exam for post of Probationary Officers but not selected despite clearing pre-exam, whereas candidates scoring zero in one of subjects got selected - Petitioners sought certain information relating to criteria followed for selection, minimum marks fixed for interview, marks of main exam of all shortlisted candidates and also the marksheet on which panel has given marks at the time of interview - Held, unless the information sought by petitioner is divulged, they will not be in position to effectively lay challenge to selection process - Hence, direction issued to furnish information sought by petitioner. 		(Paras 3, 4, 8)

heading: Disclosure of information
Exemption from
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - Exemption from - Respondent sought information of individual employees working in Bank relating to their date of joining, designation, promotions etc. - Said information was personal in nature and was exempted u/S.8(j) - Further, no public interest involved in seeking such information of individual employees - Order directing disclosure of information of individual employees, liable to be set aside. 2012(6) ALL MR 442 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Application under RTI Act - Prayer for supply of scanned copies of answer sheet of Board exams - Grant of - In view of Apex Court judgment in Civil Appeal Nos.823-854/2016 information of answer sheets should be provided to applicant so as to ensure a fair play in this competitive environment - Therefore, petitioner held entitled to relief sought for. 2016(2) ALL MR 962 (S.C.) Foll.			(Paras 5, 6, 7)

heading: RTI application
HeadNote.description: Rules of Procedure and Conduct of Business in Haryana Legislative Assembly, R.118 - RTI application - Seeking information as to attendance of each MLA during each session period - In view of Rule 118 of Assembly Rules, documents and information within Assembly cannot be made public without permission of Speaker - Hon'ble Speaker reconsidered matter and decided not to supply information on ground of Rule 118 r/w S.8(1)(c) of RTI Act - Said decision cannot be interfered with. 	(Para 6)

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Society registered under Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960 - Is not public authority within meaning of S.2(h) of RTI Act - As it does not fall within any of category mentioned in S.2(h) - Order imposing penalty on society for not giving information, improper. 	(Paras 10, 12)

heading: Interpretation of Statute
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statute - Definition of "information" under S.2(f) - Definition cannot include within its fold answers to the question "why" which would be the same thing as asking the reason for a justification for a particular thing - Held, justifications are matter within the domain of adjudicating authorities and cannot properly be classified as information.

The definition of information cannot include within its fold answers to the question "why" which would be the same thing as asking the reason for a justification for a particular thing. The Public Information Authorities cannot expect to communicate to the citizen the reason why a certain thing was done or not done in the sense of a justification because the citizen makes a requisition about information. Justifications are matter within the domain of adjudicating authorities and cannot properly be classified as information.  [Para 8]

heading: Denial of information
HeadNote.description:
Denial of information - Inspection of documents relating to Annual Confidential Report of the member of CESTAT, inter alia, relating to adverse entries and follow up action taken on question of integrity sought - High Court taking the view that information sought is the third party information wherein third party may plead privacy as defence and proper question would be whether such divulging is in public interest or not and as such matter was remitted to Chief Information Commissioner - Held, view taken was proper and no interference was required.

Section 8 deals with exemption from disclosure of information. Under clause (j) of Section 8(1), there shall be no obligation to give any citizen information which relates to personal information the disclosure of which has no relationship to any public activity or interest, or which would cause unwarranted invasion of the privacy of the individual unless the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority is satisfied that the larger public interest justifies the disclosure of such information. On the other hand Section 11 deals with third party information and the circumstances when such information can be disclosed and the manner in which it is to be disclosed, if so decided by the Competent Authority. Under Section 11(1), if the information relates to or has been supplied by a third party and has been treated as confidential by the third party, and if the Central Public Information Officer or a State Public Information Officer intends to disclose any such information or record on a request made under the Act, in such case after written notice to the third party of the request, the Officer may disclose the information, if the third party agrees to such request or if the public interest in disclosure outweighs in importance any possible harm or injury to the interests of such third party.

2012(6) ALL MR 442 (S.C.) Foll. 						    [Para 12,13,17]

heading: Public authority
Definition of
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Definition of - Is illustrative and not exhaustive - Includes non-governmental educational institution receiving substantial grants from Government - Is obliged to furnish information asked for.	(Paras 6, 7, 10)

heading: Education institution
Validity
HeadNote.description: Education institution - Refusal to provide information as sought - Validity - Petitioner sought information regarding steps taken by institution regarding implementation of free ship scheme of Government and also scholarship given by Government to SC/ST students - Though respondent institution cannot be called as Public Authority, when such institution or college is collecting money for SC/ST students, it needs to maintain entire record and account of that amount - Supply of such information cannot be avoided by anybody, including respondent institution as it is public money and it needs to be utilized only for beneficiaries of scheme - Institution is bound to supply information to petitioner - Refusal to provide information, not proper. 			(Para 7)

heading: Information regarding corruption
Disclosure of
HeadNote.description: Information regarding corruption - Disclosure of - Petitioner seeking general detail of corruption cases pending against serving and retired public servants - And information as to whether inspite of registration of such cases, service benefits to such officers given or not and which officer passed such orders - No personal information being sought for against any of officers - Keeping in view principle laid down in 2011 AIR (Punjab) 168 that allegation of corruption shall not be excluded u/S.24(4), order denying to furnish said information held, not sustainable - Matter remitted to be decided afresh. 2011 AIR (Punjab) 168 Rel. on. 2012(6) ALL MR 442 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 11, 13, 14, 15)

heading: RTI application
HeadNote.description: RTI application - Seeking information as to in-house probe initiated by CJ of High Court - Upon alleged scam and manipulations in Registry, reported in newspaper - Not permissible to be disclosed - In-house probe is a "confidential inquiry" under the charge of Chief Justice - Its affairs are to be kept out of public domain - Said information not only relates to third party but its disclosure is also prohibited under law. 1995 ALLMR ONLINE 1421 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Rules (1961), R.65
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Rules (1961), R.65 - Information regarding returns, accounts and books of society - Liability of Assistant Registrar to provide - U/S.79 of MCS Act as well as R.65 of MCS Rules, Co-operative society is required to maintain returns, accounts and books - Said material can be accessed statutorily by Registrar under MCS Act - Information as contemplated by S.2(f) as well as such information which is accessible to Registrar under MCS Act including that which is required to be maintained u/S.79 and R.65 of MCS Rules would be liable to be supplied to applicant under RTI Act - Information u/S.2(f) is required to be provided by Assistant Registrar to applicant under RTI Act. (Paras 5, 7, 8, 10)

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Complaint against Punjab Cricket Association (PCA) for not furnishing information sought u/s.6 (1) of RTI - Rejection on ground that PCA-a Society registered under Societies Registration Act is not "public authority" - Appellate court remanded the matter to State Information Commission to consider afresh in view of the guidelines laid down in Thalappalam Ser. Coop. Bank Ltd.'s case declaring an institute or society a "public authority". 
2014(1) ALL MR 451 (S.C.) Rel. on.(Para 7)

heading: Application under RTI Act
HeadNote.description: Application under RTI Act - Copy of vigilance manual of Directorate of Vigilance and Anti-Corruption (DVAC) sought to be furnished - Denial on ground that as per G.O.Ms. dt.26/8/2008 DVAC has been exempted from furnishing information under RTI Act - Held, the manual cannot be kept as a secret document - It is not exempted from dis-closure as per S.8 of RTI Act - Cumulative reading of Ss.2(f), 4(1)(b)(v), 8 and provisos to S.24(4), make applicant entitled to manual of DVAC. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Transfer of State Information Commissioners (SIC)
HeadNote.description: Transfer of State Information Commissioners (SIC) - By State Chief Information Commissioner (SCIC) - PIL filed challenging authority of SCIC by contending that only Governor and Committee constituted u/S.15(1) has power to do so - S.15 empowers Committee specially constituted to make recommendation and forward same to Governor who accepts same and then issues notification to appoint SIC - S.15 does not empower Committee to designate place at which these Commissioners are to be appointed - Function of Committee is over as soon as it selects SCIC and SIC - For purpose of internal management of said Commission, power is vested in SCIC to decide general administration, management and superintendence of Commission - Therefore, SCIC has power to transfer SIC from one region to another for purpose of ensuring that Commission functions in smooth manner. 2009(5) ALL MR 50 Ref. to. 	(Para 11)

heading: Cognizance by Information Commission
HeadNote.description:
Cognizance by Information Commission - Not permissible unless remedy of appeal u/s.19 has already been exhausted - S.18 presupposes completion of procedures prescribed u/Ss.6, 7, 19.

Section 18 confers power on the State Information Commission to receive and inquire into a complaint from any person in the nature of supervisory in the circumstances referred to in that Section. Thus the State Information Commission may entertain a complaint from any person who has been unable to submit a request to the PIO because no such officer has been appointed or if the PIO has refused to accept his application for information or an appeal under the Act; or whether the person has been refused access to any information requested under the Act or whose request has not been responded within the time specified under the Act etc.

The opening words of Sec. 18 clearly have the effect of requiring a party seeking of information to make the request in accordance with Section 6; the disposal of the request in accordance with Section 7 and filing of an appeal in accordance with Section 19 where a person is aggrieved by a decision of the Central Public Information Officer or the State Public Information Officer.

It is not the intention of the parliament to permit parties who seek information, to by pass the appeals provided under the Act by directly taking recourse to Sec.18.      [Para 8]

heading: Third party information
Requirement of notice
HeadNote.description: Third party information - Requirement of notice - Inspection reports prepared by RBI, was sought from Registrar of Co-operative Societies - Information relates to third party i.e. RBI - Direction to disclose said reports without issuing notice to RBI, would be arbitrary & illegal - Banking Regulation Act, (1949) S.35. 	(Paras 10 to 13)

heading: Recourse to court
HeadNote.description: Central Civil Services (Conduct) Rules, R.19 - Failure to furnish information by public servant - Order to initiate disciplinary action - Recourse to court - Sanction of Govt. whether necessary - Held, R.19 of the Conduct Rules does not put blanket prohibition on Govt. servant from taking recourse to the court - Recourse to court is prohibited only for vindication of any official act, which has been the subject matter of adverse criticism or an attack of defamatory character - Rule is not meant to leave the Govt. servant remediless. (Para 15)

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Information already suo motu available by public authority in discharge of obligations u/S.4 cannot be requested for u/S.6 - Nor is the CIPO required to reject said request giving reason of information having been so made available on internet. (Para 21)

heading: Imposition of penalty
HeadNote.description: Failure to furnish information - Imposition of penalty - It is incumbent on CIC to hold whether information requested for, was required to be furnished or not and without deciding so, penalty could not have been imposed. (Para 29)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Performance of adjudicatory function by Central/State Commission - Must reflect application of mind - Reasoned order must be passed.(Para 13)

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Access to information u/s.3 is the rule and exemption u/S.8 is the exception - S.8 being restriction on the fundamental right, must therefore, be strictly construed.(Para 16)

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - If the information seeker has sought copies thereof - Public authority cannot say that it will furnish such information by offering their inspection only - The only ground on which public authority can say so is, either where information so furnished would entail diversion of resources or where furnishing of copies would be detrimental to safety or preservation of information/document.(Para 25)

heading: Application under RTI Act
HeadNote.description: Application under RTI Act - Applicant on being dissatisfied with marks awarded to him, seeking copies of question papers, answer key and OMR answer sheet of his MBBS entrance exam - Refusal on ground of same in turn revealing contents of question paper and that stock of multiple choice question is limited - Same cannot be ground of preservation of OMR sheet or answer key - However, matter being academic in nature, impugned order not quashed - Respondent-University directed to review its policy/Rules/Regulations in the light of observations made by the court and take appropriate decision on the issue. (Paras 25, 27, 29)

heading: Appointment of Chief Information Commissioners and Information Commissioners
HeadNote.description:
Appointment of Chief Information Commissioners and Information Commissioners - Directions issued by Apex Court in 2013 ALL SCR 3177 at Para 39.5, has to be read as mandatory and inbuilt requirement under Ss.12(3),  15(3) r.w. Ss.12(5), 15(5) of the Act.
