From a perusal of the above, it is evident that the exemption gets attracted under two circumstances namely, (a) if the information is personal in nature and has no relationship to any public activity or interest, and (b) furnishing of the same would cause unwarranted invasion of privacy of an individual. These exemptions are, however, subject to the opinion that may be formed by the Central or State Public Information Officer or the appellate authority that the larger public interest justifies the disclosure of such information.   [Para 8]

The right to information is treated as a facet of the fundamental rights guaranteed under Articles 19 and 21 of the Constitution of India. That, however, would be in respect of the information which relates to the functioning of the Government and public activity. The information which relates to an individual cannot be compared with, or equated to, the one of public activity. On the other hand, disclosure of the information in relation to an individual, even where it is available with the Government, may amount to invasion of his privacy or right to life which in turn is also referable to Article 21 of the Constitution of India. It is also possible to treat the privilege of an individual not to be compelled to part with any information available with him, as an essential part of the Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution of India. Even while exercising his right of freedom of speech and expression, an individual can insist that any information relating to him cannot be furnished to others unless it is in the realm of public activity or is required to be furnished under any law, for the time being in force. The 2nd petitioner is not able to state as to how the copies of qualification certificates of the selected candidates have any characteristics of public activity or partake public interest. [Para 10,11]

It may appear to be enterprising or tempting for any one to have access to every possible information for an individual whether it relates to an individual or not. The freedom of an individual to have access to the information cannot be projected to such an extent as to invade the rights of others. Further, Section 6(2) of the Act cannot be read in isolation, nor can be interpreted to mean that an applicant can seek every information relating to any one. Just as he cannot be compelled to divulge the purpose for which he needs the information, he must respect the right of the other man to keep the facts relating to him, close to his chest, unless compelled by law to disclose the same. It is relevant to mention that even where an individual is placed under obligation to speak, the law can only draw adverse inference from his failure or refusal to speak but cannot go further to invade his privacy or private life.  						 [Para 11]

Section 8 of the Act, on one hand, and the Section 6 of the Act, on the other hand, operate in different and distinct fields. Though Section 6(2) of the Act enables every individual to seek information without disclosing the purpose, the information that can be furnished to him is subject to the restrictions placed under Section 8 of the Act. Therefore, no exception can be taken to the impugned orders.  [Para 12]

heading: Sections operate in different and distinct fields
HeadNote.description: Sections operate in different and distinct fields - Section 6(2) though enables every individual to seek information without disclosing the purpose information that can be furnished to him is subject to restrictions placed under S.8.	(Para 12)

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Motive which impels a person to move an application under the Act, cannot be a ground to refuse furnishing of information. (Para 5)

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Right of audi alteram partem - Held, once the information is actually in public realm whether it affects any person prejudicially or not would hardly be germane - No right of audi alteram partem, ensures to such person against whom information is being sought.(Para 6)

heading: Exemption from disclosure of information
HeadNote.description: Exemption from disclosure of information - Information sought regarding results of objective testing of the samples submitted by petitioner to see whether it conforms to prescribed standards - No trade secrets or intellectual property in the matter - Information cannot be exempted from disclosure.(Para 7)

heading: Public Authority
HeadNote.description: Public Authority - Political parties, whether State u/Art.12 - Held, merely because political parties have been declared "Public Authority" under RTI Act - Would not per se make it 'State' for the purpose of Article 12 of the Constitution so as to make it amenable to jurisdiction of High Court. 	(Para 8)

heading: Access to information
HeadNote.description: Access to information - No reasons need to be given for seeking information - However, this restriction on disclosure of reasons, cannot be misconstrued to mean that any information pertaining to a public authority or its employees, is public information. (Para 15)

heading: Access to information
HeadNote.description: Access to information - Departmental promotion committee proceedings and minutes of such proceedings - Cannot be disclosed except for in public interest. (Para 22)

heading: Public authority
Scope of definition
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Scope of definition - Deemed university established under Notification for Govt. of India - Would fall within definition of public authority even if it does not receive any grant in aid from appropriate Govt. - Bound to provide information sought by employee.	(Para 9)

heading:
Object of the Act.

The preamble of the Act would make it clear that the object of the Act is to bring about a regime of securing to the citizens access to information under the control of public authorities in order to promote transparency and accountability in the working of every public authority as a democracy requires an informed citizenry and transparency of information which are vital to its functioning and also to contain corruption and to hold Governments and their instrumentalities accountable to the governed.	 [Para 14]
HeadNote.description:
Object of the Act.

The preamble of the Act would make it clear that the object of the Act is to bring about a regime of securing to the citizens access to information under the control of public authorities in order to promote transparency and accountability in the working of every public authority as a democracy requires an informed citizenry and transparency of information which are vital to its functioning and also to contain corruption and to hold Governments and their instrumentalities accountable to the governed.	 [Para 14]

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description:
Furnishing of information - Application for copies of document in relation to development plans and approvals from Municipal Corporation - Denial would amount to rendering provisions of the Act, nugatory.

A perusal of the application filed by the respondent seeking information under the Act made it quite clear that the copies of the documents as sought were the documents which were submitted by the petitioners in relation to the development to be undertaken in respect of the lands in question. The documents as sought thus include, copies of plans, layouts sub divisions and amendments made therein from time to time, copies of development plans and amendments made therein from time to time and copies of all the reports submitted to the municipal Commissioner and his approvals on the same. The documents are admittedly under the control of the Municipal Corporation which is a public authority. The development proposals and plans are required to be submitted for the purpose of any development to be undertaken by any person/citizen so as to enable the Municipal authorities to examine whether the development can be permitted and whether the same is in accordance with the rules and regulations and requirements under law. The municipal authorities undoubtedly are required to consider these proposals and pass orders to approve the same as the law would require. The denial of such information would amount to rendering provisions of the Act nugatory, This would result in total lack of transparency and accountability in such authorities discharging their obligations under the relevant laws under which they are supposed to function.				 [Para 16]

heading: Furnishing of information
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Copies of development plans or drawings submitted to Municipal Corporation - Furnishing of, would not ipso facto amount to infringement of copyright.	(Para 17)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Building proposals approved and sanction granted by Municipal Corporation - After sanction of plans information sought about plans and apparels cannot be denied.

Once building proposals are considered and plans are sanctioned, by the Municipal authorities, such permission, plans and documents pertaining to the same form part of public record. Once the approvals are granted such information as in the present case is not of the nature of any trade secret or of a commercial confidence or of a nature which would harm the competitive position of the petitioner. If the contention as urged on behalf of the petitioners is accepted to be the position in law, then in that event, plans submitted for development to any authority would always remain a secret, sacrificing public interest, transparency and accountability in public offices. The information as sought by the respondent was also not in the nature which would endanger life or physical safety of any person so as to attract section 8 (1) (d) and (g) of the Act. The petitioners cannot stretch the meaning of subsection (g) to this extent. As regards the submission of violation of section 8 (1) (g) that the information as sought by the respondent is personal information also cannot be countenanced as the same pertains to sanctions/approvals granted by the Municipal Corporation on plans and proposals of the petitioners. The order of a permission or approval cannot be separated from its essential ingredients namely proposals and plans submitted in that regard which form the basis of the decisions and any citizen subject to requirement being fulfilled under the Act would be entitled to such information. 			 [Para 18]

heading: Application for information
HeadNote.description: Application for information - Applicant making request for information is not required to give any reason for requesting the information or any other personal details, except that may be necessary for contacting him. 	(Para 19)

heading: Exemption from disclosure
HeadNote.description:
Exemption from disclosure - Tests.

There may be a situation where inter se rights between two private parties and the rights under the RTI Act may appear to overlap. In such a case, the approach of the authorities would be to consider whether the requirements which are laid down under the Act for furnishing such information to an applicant are satisfied. The tests are that the documents are in the custody and in control of the public authority and that none of the provisions under the Act would prohibit dissemination of such information. In doing so, the authorities under the Act are required to take into consideration that public interest and transparency are not sacrificed by denial of such an information. In the present case, the information is admittedly in control of the public authorities namely the Municipal Corporation. The same pertains to the submission for development plans and/or proposals in that regard on which the Municipal authorities in exercise of its statutory powers have granted approvals/development permissions. If this is the nature of the documents when a public element as also larger public interest is involved at the hands of the Municipal Corporation then certainly irrespective of any private dispute inter se between the petitioner and respondent, these documents could not be withheld and/or not furnished to the respondent. In matters which fall within the purview of the Act are required to be tested only on the parameters as provided under the Act and a inter se lis between the parties in such an event becomes secondary and cannot override what the legislature would intend by providing the legislation. 	 [Para 20]

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description: Shri Sanwaliyaji Temple Act (1992) - Public authority - Shri Sanwaliyaji Mandir Trust, is a body constituted under law made by State legislature i.e. Act of 1992 - Same therefore held as 'Public Authority' in meaning of S.2(h) of RTI Act. 	(Para 6)

heading: Exemption from disclosure
Availability
HeadNote.description: Exemption from disclosure - Availability - Information sought from a religious trust as to copy of agenda of Board meeting, copy of resolution passed by Board in said meeting and copy of proceedings registered of that day - None of said information covered by any exemption clause to S.8 - Same therefore do not deserve exemption from disclosure.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Scope and extent of definition.

For any body, authority or any institution of self Government, to be called 'Public Authority' for the purpose of the Act, it has to fall or to be covered within the definition of 'Public Authority' under Section 2(h) of the Act. Definition of Public Authority not only defines to mean a body, an authority or any institution of the self Government established or constituted as provided therein to be a public authority but has exhausted itself by including all those bodies which are owned, controlled and substantially financed by the funds of the Government and also non-Governmental organizations which are substantially financed by the funds of the Government. It is nowhere found from the definition that any body, authority or an institution is to be taken as a public authority under Section 2(h) of the Act simply because it is called or taken to be a self Government or a local authority. Definition of Public Authority clearly stipulates that to be called a Public Authority under Section 2(h) of the Act, any body, authority, or an institution of the self Government has to fall within the categories mentioned therein or to meet with the criteria provided therein. If all institutes of self Government or all local bodies were to be taken as Public Authority within the meaning of Section 2(h) of the Act, the legislature would have so provided. When the legislature in its wisdom has not so provided and when definition of Public Authority exhausts the categories, an institution of self Government or a local authority cannot be held to be a public authority unless it falls within the definition of public authority. 				 [Para 13,15]

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Market committee, whether falls within definition u/S.2(h) of RTI Act - Held, establishment and constitution of market committee is by the law of Market Act enacted by legislature - Therefore, it is a public authority as defined u/S.2(h) of RTI Act.

From the entire scheme of the Gujarat Agriculture Produce Markets Act (1963), it clearly appears that establishment and constitution of the Market Committee is by the law of Market Act enacted by the legislature. It is thus a public authority as defined under Section 2(h) of the Act. Having thus come to such conclusion, the Court is not required to examine whether such Market Committee could be said to be owned, controlled or substantially financed by the funds of the Government so as to be covered by Section 2(h) of the Act. However, even on such aspect, considering the provisions of the Market Act, it clearly appears that it is neither owned by the Government nor could it be said that it is controlled by the State Government or substantially financed by the Government. Chapter of Control in the Market Act is to ensure that the Market Committee functions in accordance with the provisions of the Act and to achieve the object and purpose of the Act. Thus, regulatory measures are provided to ensure that Market Committee conducts its affairs as required by the Market Act. The Market Committee has to generate its fund, called as 'Market Fund' by levying and collection of market fees and like the State Government, Market Committee is under statutory obligation to provide proportionate funds, as required by the provisions of the Act, to the statutory Board constituted for good object relating to up-liftment of the farmers and for achieving the object and purpose as regards regulating of buying and selling of the agricultural produce. Therefore, it cannot be said that the Market Committee is either controlled by the State Government or in any way, could be said to be substantially financed by the State Government. 	 [Para 34]

heading: Information regarding third party
HeadNote.description: Information regarding third party - Information sought was concerning Memorandum of Understanding to which Government of Maharashtra was party - It cannot be said that information was exclusively related to third party - Information can be provided to applicant.	(Paras 11, 13, 14)

heading: Information regarding third party
HeadNote.description: Information regarding third party - Applicant does not specify documents in respect of which information is sought - Direction to provide information on such vague request may prejudice third party - Direction to provide information not proper. 	(Paras 11, 13, 14)

heading: Notice of hearing
HeadNote.description: Information regarding third party - Notice of hearing - Is not required to be issued in each and every case. 	(Para 10)

heading: Delay of 45 days in supply of information
HeadNote.description: Delay of 45 days in supply of information - Imposition of penalty on PIO - Excuse that he was not aware of intricacies of RTI Act, not acceptable - Ignorance of law is no excuse - Explanation given by PIO clearly reflects his lackadaisical attitude - Only reasonable explanation for cause of delay can be accepted and not lame excuses - No interference with penalty so imposed. 	(Para 10)

heading: Decision of Chief Information Commissioner
HeadNote.description: Decision of Chief Information Commissioner - Limited scope for interference - Power of judicial review has to be exercised with great care and circumspection - Unless impugned order suffers from manifest error, procedural or legal, Court cannot interfere. 	(Para 16)

heading: Furnishing of information
Refusal to
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Refusal to - Challenge - Information sought by petitioner pertaining to transfer of registration of vehicles of all categories from other districts and other States in last 6 yrs. - He also requires copies of all documents attached to applications for registration of vehicles - Information sought for is apparently voluminous requiring involvement of staff to search entire record of 6 years - Information also pertains to third parties who have not even been mentioned - Further, no public purpose shown to be served by disclosure of such information - Information is in shape of fishing inquiry - Cannot be furnished.	(Paras 5, 8)

heading: Furnishing of information
Whether relevant
HeadNote.description: Furnishing of information - Reasons or purpose for seeking information - Whether relevant - Held, there is no provision in RTI Act for disclosing reason or purpose for seeking particular information - However, purpose becomes relevant in order to determine facts whether information sought for pertains to public purpose or falls under exception u/S.8 of RTI Act.	(Para 7)

heading: Public Interest Litigation
Not maintainable
HeadNote.description: Implementation of S.20 of RTI Act in the State - Public Interest Litigation - Not maintainable - Firstly because, it is for Central or State Commission to form opinion and not for Courts to issue omnibus directions in this regard - Secondly, there is no specific lis or material indicating that either State or Central Commission has improperly exercised its jurisdiction while imposing penalties in some cases and not in others - No aggrieved person approaching the Court - Thirdly and more importantly, S.20 is a penal provision in respect of which PIL is not permissible in law. JT 1991 (3) SC 497 Rel.on. (Paras 4, 5, 6)

heading: Right to Information
Application under Act
HeadNote.description: Right to Information - Application under Act - By candidate who was unsuccessful in Ward Officer (Assistant Municipal Commissioner) examination - Seeking details of marks for written examination and oral interviews - Also seeking information as to how merit list is prepared and where, in order of merit, her name appears in list - Such information is not personal to examiners or interview panelists - Information can be provided to candidate. 	(Para 42)

heading: Order to supply
HeadNote.description: Information of third party - Order to supply - Opportunity of being heard should be given to third party.			(Para 6)

heading: Supply of information
HeadNote.description: Supply of information - Order as to, passed against petitioner/company, a third party - No opportunity of hearing given to petitioner as per S.19(4) before passing impugned order - No finding returned that information sought was such information as can be assessed by a public authority under any other law for the time being in force - In fact, reply filed by respondent no.2 reflects that documents available with ROC are already in public domain being available for inspection and certified copies, therefore RTI Act would not apply - Thus, impugned order passed not only in violation of statutory provisions but also in excess of jurisdiction vested in the authority concerned - Therefore, quashed and set aside.			(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9, 10)

heading: Appeal to Information Commission
HeadNote.description: Appeal to Information Commission - Scope of exercise of power - Order of information Officer to disclose any information which relates to or has been supplied by a third party - Is appealable u/S.19 of RTI Act before Information Commission - While deciding such appeal Information Commission does not decide rights of a third party but only decides whether or not the information should be furnished to citizen in view of objection of third party. 	(Para 27)

heading: Information
HeadNote.description:
Information - Meaning of, as per clarification given by Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievance & Pension under office memorandum dt.10th July, 2008.

	As per Section 2 (f) 'information' means 'any material in any form' and under the Act citizen has a right to get material from a public authority, which is held by or under the control of that public authority, which includes inspection of work, documents, records, taking notes, extracts or certified copies of documents or records, taking certified samples of material, taking information in the form of diskettes, floppies, tapes, video cassettes or in any other electronic mode or through printouts where such information is stored in a computer or in any other device.

	Careful reading of these provisions of law as well as Office Memorandum reproduced here-in-above nowhere suggests that PIO is required to supply such material and it does not require the Public Information Officer to deduce some conclusion from the material and supply the conclusion so deduced to the applicant. 	 [Para 9,10]

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Scope of the Act - Aided private colleges, on basis of facts regarding its control and funding by State Govt. - Fall within definition of term 'public authority' - Notwithstanding whether it may or not be 'State' within Art.12 of the Constitution.

Adverting to the preamble to the RTI Act, held, it is abundantly clear that the scope of the Act is much wider in its applicability than getting confined to Governments and their instrumentalities and that the Act is intended to harmonise the conflict between the right of the citizens to secure access to information and the necessity to preserve confidentiality of sensitive information. Noticing that even the preamble states that the Act is intended to provide the practical regime of right to information in order to promote transparency and accountability in the working of every public authority, it has been held that in terms of Sections 3 and 4, the public authorities are obliged to supply information. Considering the definition of 'public authority' in Section 2(h), it has been laid down that on the basis of the undisputed facts regarding the control and funding of the aided private colleges after the introduction of the Direct Payment Scheme, such an institution falls within the definition of the term 'public authority' notwithstanding whether it may, or not, be 'State' within Article 12 of the Constitution. It was specifically held that the Act is not confined to bodies answering the definition of 'State' under Article 12, which definition primarily governs enforcement of fundamental rights. Holding that the Act is intended at achieving the object of providing an effective framework for effectuating the right to information recognised under Article 19 of the Constitution, it has been held that aided private colleges in the State of Kerala fall within the term 'public authority' in the RTI Act.

In the instant case, in the backdrop of the facts an aided private college is a body substantially financed by funds provided, directly or indirectly, by the State Government. It is also a body controlled by the State Government in relation to various aspects, predominantly the financial aspect. The huge funding that is extended by the State Government and by the University Grants Commission through the State Government and the Universities are regulated and controlled by the State Government. The Government controls the utility of the huge funds provided by it. Therefore, the finding that an aided private college is a body controlled and substantially financed, directly or indirectly, by funds provided by the Government of Kerala is only to be upheld.

2009 (2) KLT 507, 2009 (3) KLT 1001 Ref. to.             [Para 2,15]

heading: Overriding effect
HeadNote.description: Overriding effect - Over provisions of other statutes - Other statutory provisions inconsistent with RTI Act, would not operate within campus, ambit and sphere where RTI Act operates - Provisions of RTI Act have precedence and hold field, viz-a-viz any inconsistency with any other statute - Disclosure of information thereunder is a norm and refusal an exception - Section 22 leads the way to making fundamental right to information, a reality. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10)

heading: Application for information
HeadNote.description: Application for information - Information also available under some other statute - No inconsistency between RTI Act and such other statute - In such case, held, option and prerogative is with citizen to select and choose Act under which he would exercise his right - Information under RTI Act cannot be denied on ground that alternative statutory mechanism is available. 			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - For delay in providing information - Penalty of Rs.250/- per day upto maximum of Rs.25,000/- - Is discretionary and not mandatory. ILR (2012) IV Delhi 657 Rel. on. 			(Para 9)

heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - For delay in providing information - No scope for interference by High Court u/Art.226 - Penalty proceedings are akin to contempt proceedings - Once facts brought to notice of court, it becomes matter between Court and contemnor - Contempt petitioner/Information seeker has no right of audience. 	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Information as to development plan
HeadNote.description: Information as to development plan - Objection that said information was also sought in civil proceedings - Perusal of earlier application shows that applicant therein had sought for communications between developer and authorities, approval letter, occupation certificate, revenue records, documents of stamp duty, agreement with prospective flat buyers etc. - Whereas information in instant application is different - Here, approved plans and their modifications are sought, which are part of sanction process - Even otherwise, prayer in earlier application was not at all considered by civil Court - Objection of other side, therefore, not tenable. 			(Para 12)

heading: Disclosure of information
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - As to private documents - Even private documents submitted to public authorities may, under certain situations, form part of public record. 			(Para 15)

heading: Tenability
HeadNote.description: Information as to development plan - Objection as to absence of 'public interest' - Tenability - There was provision in repealed MOFA and also in new RERA, for disclosure of full information to prospective buyers regarding sanctioned plan - Purchase and investment in land development is a matter of public knowledge and debate - There is no 'personal information' involved - Application in instant case made by person executing power of attorney in favour of developer - When information available to public at large, no reason why it should not be available to owner or administrator of land - Thus, even on test of public interest, information cannot be declined to applicant. 			(Paras 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 26, 34)

heading: Information as to development plan
HeadNote.description: Information as to development plan - Defence of commercial confidentiality - There is statutory obligation for disclosure of such information under repealed MOFA and also under new RERA, 2016 - Such matters can hardly be said to be of commercial confidentiality. 	(Para 24)

heading: Disclosure of information
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - As to development plan submitted to public authorities - Objection as to likelihood of copyright infringement - Held, preparation of plan and its designs may give rise to copyright but its disclosure would not amount to infringement in view of S.52(1)(f) of Copyright Act which permits reproduction of any work in a certified copy - In any case, such disclosure would have overriding effect in view of S.22 of RTI Act. 	(Paras 24, 25)

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description:
Public authority - Supreme Court is a public authority - And office of Chief Justice is not separate from Supreme Court - Hence, there will be only one CPIO - Equally true is about High Courts and their respective CJs.

	Sanjiv Khanna, J. (For himself, Deepak Gupta J. & CJI) :- Term 'public authority' under Section 2(h) of the RTI Act includes any authority or body or an institution of self-government established by the Constitution or under the Constitution.

	Article 124 of the Constitution, which relates to the establishment and constitution of the Supreme Court of India, states that there shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice and other judges. It is undebatable that the Supreme Court of India is a 'public authority', as defined vide clause (h) to Section 2 of the RTI Act as it has been established and constituted by or under the Constitution of India. The Chief Justice of India as per sub-clause (ii) in clause (e) to Section 2 is the competent authority in the case of the Supreme Court. Consequently, in terms of Section 28 of the RTI Act, the Chief Justice of India is empowered to frame rules, which have to be notified in the Official Gazette, to carry out the provisions of the RTI Act.

	The Supreme Court of India, which is a 'public authority', would necessarily include the office of the Chief Justice of India and the judges in view of Article 124 of the Constitution. The office of the Chief Justice or for that matter the judges is not separate from the Supreme Court, and is part and parcel of the Supreme Court as a body, authority and institution. The Chief Justice and the Supreme Court are not two distinct and separate 'public authorities', albeit the latter is a 'public authority' and the Chief Justice and the judges together form and constitute the 'public authority', that is, the Supreme Court of India. The interpretation to Section 2(h) cannot be made in derogation of the Constitution. To hold to the contrary would imply that the Chief Justice of India and the Supreme Court of India are two distinct and separate public authorities, and each would have their CPIOs and in terms of sub-section (3) to Section 6 of the RTI Act an application made to the CPIO of the Supreme Court or the Chief Justice would have to be transferred to the other when 'information' is held or the subject matter is more closely connected with the 'functions' of the other. This would lead to anomalies and difficulties as the institution, authority or body is one. The Chief Justice of India is the head of the institution and neither he nor his office is a separate public authority.

	This is equally true and would apply to the High Courts in the country as Article 214 states that there shall be a High Court for each State and Article 216 states that every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other judges as the President of India may from time to time deem it appropriate to appoint.

(2013) 16 SCC 82 Ref. to. 	 [Para 12,13,14,15]

	D. Y. Chandrachud, J. :- Section 2(e)(ii) expressly stipulates that the competent authority means the Chief Justice of India in the case of the Supreme Court and Section 2(e)(iii) stipulates that the competent authority in the case of a high Court is the Chief Justice of that Court. Significantly, Article 124 of the Constitution of India stipulates that there shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice of India and other judges. The office of the Chief Justice of India is not distinct from the Supreme Court of India. The Supreme Court is constituted by virtue of the Constitution and consists of judges, of which the Chief Justice is the head. This however, does not mean that the Supreme Court and the Chief Justice are two separate public authorities within the RTI Act. 	 [Para 148]

heading: Right to information
Scope
HeadNote.description: Right to information - Scope - Right available in respect of information 'held by or under control of public authority' - This reflects a limit on right to information - Information must be accessible to public authority. 2010 ALL SCR 387, (2013) 16 SCC 82, 2011 ALL SCR 2239 Ref. to. 	(Paras 18, 19, 22)

heading: Fiduciary relationship
HeadNote.description:
Fiduciary relationship - Relationship between Chief Justice and other judges, may or may not be of a fiduciary and beneficiary - Parameters for determination, enunciated.

	Sanjiv Khanna, J. (For himself, Deepak Gupta J. & CJI) :- Fiduciary relationships, regardless of whether they are formal, informal, voluntary or involuntary, must satisfy the four conditions [as enunciated in RBI Vs. Jayantilal N. Mistry, 2016 ALL SCR 1090] for a relationship to classify as a fiduciary relationship. In each of the four principles, the emphasis is on trust, reliance, the fiduciary's superior power or dominant position and corresponding dependence of the beneficiary on the fiduciary which imposes responsibility on the fiduciary to act in good faith and for the benefit of and to protect the beneficiary and not oneself. Section 8(1)(e) is a legal acceptance that there are ethical or moral relationships or duties in relationships that create rights and obligations, beyond contractual, routine or even special relationships with standard and typical rights and obligations. Contractual or non-fiduciary relationships could require that the party should protect and promote the interest of the other and not cause harm or damage, but the fiduciary relationship casts a positive obligation and demands that the fiduciary should protect the beneficiary and not promote personal self-interest. A fiduciary's loyalty, duties and obligations are stricter than the morals of the market place and it is not honesty alone, but the punctilio of an honour which is the most sensitive standard of behaviour which is applied. Thus, the level of judicial scrutiny in cases of fiduciary relationship is intense as the level of commitment and loyalty expected is higher than non-fiduciary relationships. Fiduciary relationship may arise because of the statute which requires a fiduciary to act selflessly with integrity and fidelity and the other party, that is the beneficiary, depends upon the wisdom and confidence reposed in the fiduciary. A contractual, statutory and possibly all relationships cover a broad field, but a fiduciary relationship could exist, confined to a limited area or an act, as relationships can have several facets. Thus, relationships can be partly fiduciary and partly non-fiduciary with the former being confined to a particular act or action which need not manifest itself in entirety in the interaction and relationship between two parties. What would distinguish non-fiduciary relationship from fiduciary relationship or an act is the requirement of trust reposed, higher standard of good faith and honesty required on the part of the fiduciary with reference to a particular transaction(s) due to moral, personal or statutory responsibility of the fiduciary as compared to the beneficiary, resulting in dependence of the beneficiary. This may arise due to superior knowledge and training of the fiduciary or the position he occupies.

	Ordinarily the relationship between the Chief Justice and judges would not be that of a fiduciary and a beneficiary. However, it is not an absolute rule/code for in certain situations and acts, fiduciary relationship may arise. Whether or not such a relationship arises in a particular situation would have to be dealt with on the tests and parameters enunciated above.

2016 ALL SCR 1090 Ref. to. 	 [Para 34,35]

heading: Privacy and confidentiality
HeadNote.description: Privacy and confidentiality - Includes right to protect one's identity and anonymity - Same is also subject to public interest test. 2017(5) ALL MR 686 (S.C.), 2014 SCC 43 Ref. to. 	(Paras 43, 46)

heading: Privacy and confidentiality
HeadNote.description: Privacy and confidentiality - Scope of 'information' u/S.11 of RTI Act is much broader than S.8(1)(j) - Apart from personal information, S.11 could include other information, such as, information concerning Govt. supplied by a third party and treated as confidential - Third-party may be individual, natural or juristic entity including a public authority. 	(Para 62)

heading: Confidentiality
HeadNote.description: Confidentiality - In Govt. related information - Absolute transparency in Govt. functioning is not feasible - Especially in matters of national security and diplomatic relations, confidentiality needs to be maintained - However, confidentiality is not an absolute bar - PIO has to undertake balancing exercise and weigh advantages and benefits of disclosure as against possible harm or injury. (1987) 10 NSWLR 86, (1980) 147 CLR 39, 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 1154 (S.C.) Ref. to. 		(Paras 69, 70)

heading: Public interest test
HeadNote.description:
Public interest test - In Ss.8 and 11 of RTI Act - Test prescribed by proviso to S.11(1) is broader and wider.

	Sanjiv Khanna, J. (For himself, Deepak Gupta J. & CJI) :- Comparison or balancing exercise of competing public interests has to be undertaken in both sections, albeit under Section 8(1)(j) the comparison is between public interest behind the exemption, that is personal information or invasion of privacy of the individual and public interest behind access to information, whereas the test prescribed by the proviso to Section 11(1) is somewhat broader and wider as it requires comparison between disclosure of information relating to a third person or information supplied and treated as confidential by the third party and possible harm or injury to the third party on disclosure, which would include all kinds of 'possible' harm and injury to the third party on disclosure. 	 [Para 73]

heading: Public interest test
Meaning and connotation
HeadNote.description:
Public interest test - Meaning and connotation - Discussed.

	Sanjiv Khanna, J. (For himself, Deepak Gupta J. & CJI) :- The public interest test in the context of the RTI Act would mean reflecting upon the object and purpose behind the right to information, the right to privacy and consequences of invasion, and breach of confidentiality and possible harm and injury that would be caused to the third party, with reference to a particular information and the person. 	 [Para 76]

	Public interest has no relationship and is not connected with the number of individuals adversely affected by the disclosure which may be small and insignificant in comparison to the substantial number of individuals wanting disclosure. It will vary according to the information sought and all circumstances of the case that bear upon the public interest in maintaining the exemptions and those in disclosing the information must be accounted for to judge the right balance. Public interest is not immutable and even time-gap may make a significant difference. The type and likelihood of harm to the public interest behind the exemption and public interest in disclosure would matter. The delicate balance requires identification of public interest behind each exemption and then cumulatively weighing the public interest in accepting or maintaining the exemption(s) to deny information in a particular case against the public interest in disclosure in that particular case. Further, under Section 11(1), reference is made to the 'possible' harm and injury to the third party which will also have to be factored in when determining disclosure of confidential information relating to the third parties. 	 [Para 78]

heading: Public interest
HeadNote.description: Public interest - Testing 'motive' of applicant - Though motive of applicant in seeking information is irrelevant as per S.6(2) of RTI Act, it may be relevant while testing public interest in cases of qualified exemptions. 	(Para 79)

heading: RTI Application
HeadNote.description:
RTI Application - Seeking information as to appointment and elevation of Judges - Whether public interest lies in disclosure or denial of such information, to be tested in each case - Independence of judiciary, is a relevant factor in said determination.

	Sanjiv Khanna, J. (For himself, Deepak Gupta J. & CJI) :- It cannot be doubted and debated that the independence of the judiciary is a matter of ennobled public concern and directly relates to public welfare and would be one of the factors to be taken into account in weighing and applying the public interest test. Thus, when the public interest demands the disclosure of information, judicial independence has to be kept in mind while deciding the question of exercise of discretion. However, we should not be understood to mean that the independence of the judiciary can be achieved only by denial of access to information. Independence in a given case may well demand openness and transparency by furnishing the information. Reference to the principle of judicial independence is not to undermine and avoid accountability which is an aspect we perceive and believe has to be taken into account while examining the public interest in favour of disclosure of information. Judicial independence and accountability go hand in hand as accountability ensures, and is a facet of judicial independence. Further, while applying the proportionality test, the type and nature of the information is a relevant factor. Distinction must be drawn between the final opinion or resolutions passed by the collegium with regard to appointment/elevation and transfer of judges with observations and indicative reasons and the inputs/data or details which the collegium had examined. The rigour of public interest in divulging the input details, data and particulars of the candidate would be different from that of divulging and furnishing details of the output, that is the decision. In the former, public interest test would have to be applied keeping in mind the fiduciary relationship (if it arises), and also the invasion of the right to privacy and breach of the duty of confidentiality owed to the candidate or the information provider, resulting from the furnishing of such details and particulars. The position represents a principled conflict between various factors in favour of disclosure and those in favour of withholding of information. Transparency and openness in judicial appointments juxtaposed with confidentiality of deliberations remain one of the most delicate and complex areas. Clearly, the position is progressive as well as evolving as steps have been taken to make the selection and appointment process more transparent and open. Notably, there has been a change after concerns were expressed on disclosure of the names and the reasons for those who had not been approved. The position will keep forging new paths by taking into consideration the experiences of the past and the aspirations of the future.

	It is not possible to answer these questions in absolute terms. In each case, the public interest test would be applied to weigh the scales and on balance determine whether information should be furnished or would be exempt. Therefore, a universal affirmative or negative answer is not possible. However, independence of judiciary is a matter of public interest.		 [Para 88]

heading: RTI application
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: RTI application - Seeking copy of correspondence between CJI and a Judge of High Court - Denial, on ground that said information is held by CJI and not by Registry of Supreme Court - Not tenable - CJI being administrative head of Supreme Court, information held by him cannot be said to be unavailable to Supreme Court. [Per N.V. Ramana, J.] 	(Paras 111, 112)

heading: RTI Application
HeadNote.description:
RTI Application - Seeking details of assets as submitted by Judges of SC and HC before CJI and CJ of concerned HC - Information whether exempted u/S.8(1)(j) being a private information - To be determined by applying two steps test.

	N.V. Ramana, J.:- The purport of the Section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act is to balance privacy with public interest. Under the provision a two steps test could be identified wherein the first step was: (i) whether there is a reasonable expectation of privacy, and (ii) whether on an ultimate balancing analysis, does privacy give way to freedom of expression? It is acknowledged that these two tests are very difficult to be kept separate analytically.

	FIRST STEP: There are certain factors which needs to be considered before concluding whether there was a reasonable expectation of privacy of the person concerned. These non-exhaustive factors are;

1.	The nature of information. 

2.	Impact on private life. 

3.	Improper conduct. 

4.	Criminality 

5.	Place where the activity occurred or the information was found.

6.	Attributes of claimants such as being a public figure, a minor etc and their reputation.

7.	Absence of consent.

8.	Circumstances and purposes for which the information came into the hands of the publishers.

9.	Effect on the claimant.

10.	Intrusion's nature and purpose.

These non-exhaustive factors are to be considered in order to come to a conclusion whether the information sought is private or does the persons has a reasonable expectations of privacy. In certain cases we may conclude that there could be certain information which are inherently private and are presumptively protected under the privacy rights. These information include gender, age and sexual preferences etc. These instances need to be kept in mind while assessing the first requirement under the aforesaid test.

	If the information is strictly covered under the aforesaid formulation, then the person is exempted from the right to information unless 'the public interest test' requires to trump the same.

	SECOND STEP: Having ascertained whether the information is private or not, a judge is required to adopt a balancing test to note whether the public interest justifies disclosure of such information under Section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act. The term 'larger public interest' needs to be understood in light of 'balancing test' which needs to be incorporated to see the appropriateness of disclosure. There are certain basic principles which we need to keep in mind while balancing the rights which are relevant herein. That the right to information and right to privacy are at an equal footing. There is no requirement to take an a priori view that one right trumps other.

	The contextual balancing involves 'proportionality test'. The test is to see whether the release of information would be necessary, depends on the information seeker showing the 'pressing social need' or 'compelling requirement for upholding the democratic values'. We can easily conclude that the exemption of public interest as occurring under Section 8(1)(j) requires a balancing test to be adopted. We need to distinguish two separate concepts i.e. "interest of the public" and "something in the public interest." Therefore, the material distinction between the aforesaid concepts concern those matters which affect political, moral and material welfare of the public need to be distinguished from those for public entertainment, curiosity or amusement. Under Section 8(1)(j) of the RTI Act, only the former is an exception to the exemption.

2017(5) ALL MR 686 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	 [Para 125,127,128,129,130,131]

heading: Fiduciary relationship
Existence
HeadNote.description:
Fiduciary relationship - Existence - Judges of Supreme Court declaring about their assets - Said information held by CJI in exercise of his official functions as mandated by Resolution of Judges dt. 7.5.1997 - Information not held in fiduciary relationship.

	Dr. D.Y. Chandrachud, J. :- The Chief Justice of India in exercising his official functions in accordance with the 1997 resolution while holding asset information of other judges does not act for and on behalf of other judges of the Supreme Court. There exists no fiduciary relationship between them. The Chief Justice of India is not entrusted with the power to protect and further the interests of individual judges who disclose their assets. The information is required by the mandate of the resolution dated 7 May 1997 passed by all the then sitting judges of the Supreme Court and it cannot be said that such information is being provided in any personal capacity. The Chief Justice of India merely holds the information in accordance with the official functions and not in any fiduciary capacity. The judges of the Supreme Court, including the Chief Justice of India occupy a constitutional office. There exists no set hierarchies between the judges and they enjoy the same judicial powers and immunities. The judges who disclose their assets cannot be said to be vulnerable to and dependent on the Chief Justice of India. In these circumstances, it cannot be held that asset information shared with the Chief Justice of India, by the judges of the Supreme Court, are held by him in a fiduciary capacity, which if revealed, would result in breach of fiduciary duty. Therefore, the argument that the information sought is held in a fiduciary capacity is inapplicable and cannot be used to prevent the information from being made public.	 [Para 204]

heading: RTI Application
HeadNote.description: RTI Application - Seeking a copy of declaration of assets by Judges and documents relating to appointment of Judges - Said information relates to and supplied by third parties - Procedure u/S.11 applicable. [Per Dr. D.Y. Chandrachud, J.] 	(Para 215)

heading: Disclosure of personal information
HeadNote.description:
Disclosure of personal information - Abridgment of right to privacy - RTI Act satisfies the test of legality and proportionality.

	Dr. D.Y. Chandrachud, J. :- The constitutional validity of the RTI Act as a measure abridging the right to privacy is not in question before this Court. But it is trite to say that the RTI Act satisfies the test of legality (by virtue of being a legislation) and also pursues a legitimate state aim of ensuring, transparency and accountability of government and an informed electorate. By requiring the Information Officer to balance the public interest in disclosure against the privacy harm caused, clause (j) creates a legislatively mandated measure of proportionality to ensure that the harm to the individual's right to privacy is not disproportionate to the aim of securing transparency and accountability. 	 [Para 222]

heading: Private information
HeadNote.description:
Private information - Balancing between right to privacy and public interest - Analytical approach to be applied by Information Officer, set out.

	Dr. D.Y. Chandrachud, J. :- The requirement to record reasons is a principle of natural justice and a check against the arbitrary exercise of power by judicial and quasi-judicial bodies. In making a determination under clause (j) of clause (1) of Section 8 in a given case, it would not be satisfactory if an Information Officer were merely to record that the privacy interest outweighed the public interest. Something more is required. By providing an analytical framework to address the two interests to be weighed and requiring the Information Officer record detailed reasons within this framework, the arbitrary exercise or discretion of the Information Officer is guarded against. 	 [Para 243]

	Once the information sought has been identified as "personal information" the Information Officer must identify the actual rights being claimed in the individual case. In setting out the substantive content of "public interest" and "privacy" various facets of these concepts have been set out. In any given case, the Information Officer must identify the precise interests weighing in favour of "public interest" disclosure, and those interests weighing in favour of "privacy" and non-disclosure. The Information Officer must then examine the justifications for restricting each right and whether they are countenanced under the scheme of RTI Act and in law generally. The ground of confidentiality simpliciter is not a ground to restrict the right to information under the RTI Act or Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution. Lastly, the Information Officer must employ the principle of proportionality. As observed by Baroness Hale, both the right to privacy and the right to information are legitimate aims. In applying the principle of proportionality, the Information Officer must ensure that the abridgement of a right is not disproportionate to the legitimate aim sought to be achieved by enforcing the countervailing right. 	 [Para 247]

heading: PIL
HeadNote.description: PIL - For effective implementation of RTI Act - Inaction of Central and State Govts. in appointing Information Commissioners in timely manner - Resulting in huge backlogs of appeals and complaints - General directions issued for making appointments in timely manner, ensuring transparency in selection process, regarding terms and conditions of appointment, selection of candidates not only from public service but also from other fields etc. 2013 ALL SCR 3177 Ref. to. 	(Para 67)

heading: Transparency of process
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Information Commissioners - Transparency of process - Information in respect of each candidate, members of Search Committee, agenda of their meeting, even minutes of Search Committee put on website - It cannot be said that there is no transparency in appointment process. 	(Para 36)

heading: Chief Information Commissioner
Eligibility conditions
Indicates official bias
HeadNote.description: Chief Information Commissioner - Eligibility conditions - Not restricted to Govt. employees alone - There is wide area of consideration - Eminent persons from fields of law or science & technology or social service or journalism or mass media etc. can be selected - Selection only from one category i.e. Govt. employees - Indicates official bias - Search Committee advised to make selections from other categories also. 	(Para 40)

heading: Salary and allowance
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Information Commissioner - Salary and allowance - No specific condition of service mentioned in advertisement - Though S.13(5) of RTI Act states that terms and conditions would be same as Election Commissioner, it would be appropriate if terms and conditions are specifically stipulated in advertisement and put on website as well. 		(Paras 42, 67)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of West Bengal - Functioning with only one Chief and 2 other Commissioners - Pendency of cases is about 7680 - Delay in disposal of cases would deter and discourage applicants from pursuing RTI applications - It therefore becomes duty of State Govt. to have adequate number of Commissioners for quick and speedy disposal of cases - Creation of at least three more such posts, recommended.	(Paras 45, 46, 47)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Andhra Pradesh - Virtually non-functional since May 2017 - Though 3 Information Commissioners have been recently appointed, that would not make SIC fully functional - State Govt. impressed upon to make appointments of State Chief and other Commissioners at earliest.	(Paras 50, 51)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Telangana - More than 10,000 cases pending - State Commission with only one Chief and one other Commissioner is too inadequate having regard to pendency of cases - If sufficient number of Commissioners is not appointed, pendency will keep on increasing - At least 4 more Commissioners need to be appointed.		(Para 54)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Maharashtra - About 40,000 cases pending - State Commission has 8 sanctioned posts, one Chief and 7 other Commissioners - Out of these, 2 posts of Commissioners are lying vacant - One of Commissioners has been given additional charge of State Chief - Vacancies directed to be filled in - Going by pendency, it would be appropriate if State Commission has total strength of one Chief and 10 other Commissioners. 	(Paras 55, 56, 57)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Gujarat - Two posts of Commissioners lying vacant - Directed to be filled up within one month as applications have already been received.	(Para 58)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Kerala - About 10,000 appeals and 4000 complaints pending - Process of appointment of Commissioners stalled due to filing of writ petitions - State Govt. expected to ensure timely appointment in future. 	(Para 60)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Karnataka - About 33000 cases pending - State Commission functioning with one Chief and 4 other Commissioners - Appointment of Chief and 2 other Commissioners is in process - Directed to be completed within 2 months - Going by alarming pendencies, it would be appropriate if strength of Commission is increased to one Chief and 10 other Commissioners - Recommended accordingly. 		(Paras 61, 62, 63)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Odisha - Present strength of Commission is one Chief and 3 other Commissioners - One post of Commissioner lying vacant - More than 10,000 cases pending - At least 3 more posts of Commissioners need to be created - Decision in this regard to be taken by State Govt. 	(Paras 64, 65)

heading: State Information Commission
HeadNote.description: State Information Commission - In State of Nagaland - Post of State Chief lying vacant - State Govt. directed to take immediate steps in this regard. 	(Para 66)

heading: Public authority
Definition
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Definition - Notification contemplated in clause (d) - Is a notification relating to establishment or constitution of authority, body or institution of self-government - It does not contemplate a notification declaring that such authority, body or institution is brought within ambit of RTI Act - No such declaration is necessary. 	(Para 15)

heading: Public authority
Definition
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Definition - Second part of definition starting with words 'and includes any' - Is in addition to and independent of first part - Two categories of public authority included in second part need not be established or constituted by any law or notification. 2014(1) ALL MR 451 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 16, 17, 18, 22)

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description: Public authority - NGOs substantially financed by Govt. - Substantial finance need not necessarily mean major portion or more than 50% of finance - It has to be determined in facts of each case - One relevant aspect is, whether functioning of concerned NGO is dependent on finances of Govt. 	(Paras 26, 27, 28)

heading: Disclosure of information
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - Disclosure of question papers, model answers and instructions given to examiners and moderators after examination and after evaluation of answer papers - Is not barred as it will not harm competitive position of any third party - Contention that if information is exempt at any given point of time it continues to the exempt for all time to come cannot be sustained.	(Para 12)

heading: State Institute of Chartered Accountants of India being a statutory body is "State"
HeadNote.description: State Institute of Chartered Accountants of India being a statutory body is "State" - Providing access to information in respect of which ICAI holds a copyright does not involve infringement of copyright subsisting in a person other than the state - ICAI is, therefore, not entitled to claim protection against disclosure of question papers, model answers and instructions given to examiners and moderators.	(Para 13)

heading: Infringement of copyright
HeadNote.description: Infringement of copyright - Combined reading of Ss.51 and 52(1)(a) of copyright Act shows that furnishing of information by an examining body in response to query under RTI Act may not be termed as infringement of copyright.	(Para 14)

heading: Connotation of
HeadNote.description: Words " information available to a person in his fiduciary relationship" - Connotation of - Word "Person" is of much wider import than the word "public authority" - Hence instructions and solutions communicated by examiners, head examiners and moderators are information available to them in their fiduciary relationship and, therefore, exempt from disclosure.	(Para 17)

heading: Disclosure of information
Exception
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - Exception - Denial of in public interest - Competent authority will have to record reasons for holding that exempted information should be disclosed in larger public interest.	(Para 19)

heading: Right to information
HeadNote.description: Right to information - Information sought not part of record of examining body - Authority is not bound to furnish the same.	(Para 24)

heading: Right to information
HeadNote.description:
Right to information - Public authorities should realize that in an era of transparency unwarranted secrecy has no place - They should atune themselves to new regime of maximum information.

Examining bodies like ICAI should change their old mindsets and tune them to the new regime of disclosure of maximum information. Public authorities should realize that in an era of transparency, previous practices of unwarranted secrecy have no longer a place. Accountability and prevention of corruption is possible only through transparency. As the examining bodies have not been exempted, and as the examination processes of examining bodies have not been exempted, the examining bodies will have to gear themselves to comply with the provisions of the RTI Act. Additional workload is not a defence. It is, however, necessary to make a distinction in regard to information intended to bring transparency, to improve accountability and to reduce corruption, falling under section 4(1)(b) and (c) and other information which may not have a bearing on accountability or reducing corruption. The competent authorities under the RTI Act will have to maintain a proper balance so that while achieving transparency, the demand for information does not reach unmanageable proportions affecting other public interests, which include efficient operation of public authorities and government, preservation of confidentiality of sensitive information and optimum use of limited fiscal resources.	 [Para 25,26]

heading: Expression "means" and "includes"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "means" and "includes" - S.2(h) exhausts categories mentioned therein.

Legislature, in its wisdom, while defining the expression "public authority" under Section 2(h), intended to embrace only those categories, which are specifically included, unless the context of the Act otherwise requires. Section 2(h) has used the expressions 'means' and includes'. When a word is defined to 'mean' something, the definition is prima facie restrictive and where the word is defined to 'include' some other thing, the definition is prima facie extensive. But when both the expressions "means" and "includes" are used, the categories mentioned there would exhaust themselves. When such expressions are used, they may afford an exhaustive explanation of the meaning which for the purpose of the Act, must invariably be attached to those words and expressions.Section 2(h) exhausts categories mentioned therein.	          [Para 27,28]

heading: Expression "controlled"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "controlled" - Control has to be substantial and not merely supervisory or regulatory.

When we test the meaning of expression "controlled" which figures in between the words "body owned" and "substantially financed", the control by the appropriate government must be a control of a substantial nature. The mere 'supervision' or 'regulation' as such by a statute or otherwise of a body would not make that body a "public authority" within the meaning of Section 2(h)(d)(i) of the RTI Act. In other words just like a body owned or body substantially financed by the appropriate government, the control of the body by the appropriate government would also be substantial and not merely supervisory or regulatory. Powers exercised by the Registrar of Cooperative Societies and others under the Cooperative Societies Act are only regulatory or supervisory in nature, which will not amount to dominating or interfering with the management or affairs of the society so as to be controlled.   [Para 34]

heading: Words "substantially financed"
HeadNote.description:
Words "substantially financed" - Meaning of.

The words "substantially financed" have been used in Sections 2(h)(d)(i) & (ii), while defining the expression public authority as well as in Section 2(a) of the Act, while defining the expression "appropriate Government". A body can be substantially financed, directly or indirectly by funds provided by the appropriate Government. The expression "substantially financed", as such, has not been defined under the Act. "Substantial" means "in a substantial manner so as to be substantial". 

The word "substantial" literally means solid, massive etc. Legislature has used the expression "substantially financed" in Sections 2(h)(d)(i) and (ii) indicating that the degree of financing must be actual, existing, positive and real to a substantial extent, not moderate, ordinary, tolerable etc. Therefore the word 'substantial' is not synonymous with 'dominant' or 'majority'. It is closer to 'material' or 'important' or 'of considerable value.' 'Substantially' is closer to 'essentially'. Both words can signify varying degrees depending on the context. 		          [Para 36,37]

heading: Public authorities
HeadNote.description:
Public authorities - Categorization in the Section is exhaustive - Language thereof cannot be given a liberal construction to include co-operative societies.

The categories mentioned in Section 2(h) of the Act exhaust themselves, hence, there is no question of adopting a liberal construction to the expression "public authority" to bring in other categories into its fold, which do not satisfy the tests laid down. Court cannot, when language is clear and unambiguous, adopt such a construction which, according to the Court, would only advance the objective of the Act. The opening part of the definition clause states "unless the context otherwise requires". No materials have been made available to show that the cooperative societies, in the context of the Act, would fall within the definition of Section 2(h) of the Act of the Kerela co-operative Societies Act, 1969. 		     [Para 43]

heading: Public authority
HeadNote.description: Public authority - Registrar of Co-operative Societies - Is public authority within meaning of S.2(h) - He can furnish information enumerated in S.2(f) subject to limitations provided under S.2(h) and S.8 - He cannot call for details of bank accounts maintained by citizens or members in co-operative bank.	(Paras 52, 53)

heading: Term "fiduciary relationship"
Meaning
HeadNote.description: Term "fiduciary relationship" - Meaning - Information shared under statutory obligation or duty, cannot be said to be shared under fiduciary relationship.

heading: Not justified
Fiduciary relationship lacking
HeadNote.description: Application seeking information from RBI - Regarding inspection reports of Banks and Financial Institutions - Denial, on ground that information was obtained by RBI in fiduciary relationship with Banks - Not justified - Information was obtained by RBI and provided by Banks & Financial Institutions not under pretext of 'trust' but under their respective statutory obligations - Fiduciary relationship lacking - RBI is supposed to uphold public interest and not interest of individual banks - RBI bound to disclose information so sought.

heading: Information
Definition
HeadNote.description: Information - Definition - Legislative intent appear to make available to general public not only information from public authorities but also from private body - Otherwise, Legislature would not have included the word "private body". 	(Para 67)

heading: Disclosure of information
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - To what extent, permissible - Disclosure of some information may cause more harm than good - Such as, information about currency exchange, foreign investment etc. - They can be exempt u/S.8 - However, lower level economic and financial information, like contracts and departmental budgets etc. should not be withheld under this exemption.

heading: Severability of information
HeadNote.description: Severability of information - Information sought from RBI regarding Advisory Notes and warning issued to some banks - Plea of concerned Bank that some information be severed from Advisory Note before it is provided to applicant - Held, severability of information is to be decided on case to case basis - In instant case, detail of matter has already been placed in Lok Sabha by Finance Minister - No question of applying S.10(1) and severing the contents. 	(Paras 77, 82)

heading: Information as to unauthorized constructions
HeadNote.description: Information as to unauthorized constructions - Available with Police Dept. as also with Municipal Corporation - That information is also available with another public authority, is no ground to reject application - Information sought from Police Authorities had to be allowed. 			(Para 19)

heading: Not justified
S.11 not applicable
HeadNote.description: Information as to unauthorized constructions - Information sought from Police Dept. as to total number of complaints sent to Municipal Corporation and other details of unauthorized constructions in city - Denial, on ground of bar u/S.11 of RTI Act that information relates to third parties - Not justified - S.11 does not prescribe furnishing of information - It only provides for certain safeguards i.e. giving notice and considering submissions of third parties - Above information neither provided by third party nor treated as confidential - S.11 not applicable - Information has to be provided. 	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Request for information
HeadNote.description: Request for information - Respondent applied for photocopy of final results of semester III and IV, MA Part I and II Political Science inclusive of all marks - Record showing that before First appellate authority respondent did not press for this information - Second appellate authority is not justified in directing University to grant same - Order directing University to provide photocopy of results liable to be set aside. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Request for information
HeadNote.description: Request for information - Respondent sought information relating to statements of students/faculty, report of sub-committee on ragging and minutes of sub-committee meeting on ragging - Respondent sought information when inquiry was pending against him  and if any information was sought to be used against respondent in course of inquiry, then respondent right in requiring such information to be furnished to him - Bot now inquiry is completed and penalty imposed on respondent is upheld by court and matter is pending before Supreme Court - Objection raised by University that disclosure of information will affect rights of privacy of third parties, proper - Order directing to furnish information, liable to be set aside. (Paras 9, 11, 12)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Appointment of Public Information Officer (PIO) by Information Commission - By removing existing PIO - Validity - As per S.19, though Information Commission may have superintendence power over actions of any PIO, same would not extend to removal of an already appointed PIO and/or appointment of any other person as PIO - Only a direction could be issued by Information Commission requiring Public Authority to appoint PIO, if no such person has already been appointed - Further order of removing existing PIO does not indicate any reason as to why he was removed - There was also no prayer before Information Commission for removal of existing PIO - Appointment of PIO by removing existing PIO, not proper. 	(Para 12)

heading: Disclosure of information
HeadNote.description: Disclosure of information - Duties and obligations of Governor - Decision or direction by Public Information Officer (PIO) or the appellate authority to disclose a particular information is binding upon Governor - No immunity would then be available to him under Art. 361 - Governor by virtue of his oath is bound to obey decision of PIO - Else, he would not be defending the law i.e. RTI Act.  (Paras 29, 30)

heading: Access to information
HeadNote.description:
Access to information - Annual Confidential Report (ACR) of an employee is confidential document - Disclosure of the same would cause unwarranted invasion of privacy of an individual - However, once the CPIO/SPIO reaches conclusion that disclosure of such information is in larger public interest, appropriate order can be passed in this regard.

It is a settled law that for seeking personal information regarding any employee of the public authority the applicant must disclose a 'sustainable public interest'. Section 8(1) (j) of the Act was enacted to ensure that all information furnished to public authorities including personal information is not given free access to. As per this Section unless the Central Public Information Officer ('CPIO' for short) or the State PIO or the appellate authority, as the case may be, is satisfied that the larger public interest justifies, the disclosure of any such information that invades the privacy of an individual is not permissible. Annual Confidential Reports are essentially performance appraisal by higher officials which along with other things constitute the basis for promotions and other service benefits. It is a settled law that the performance of an employee in an organization is primarily a matter between the employee and the employer and normally those aspects are governed by service rules which fall under the expression 'personal information', the disclosure of which has no relationship to any public activity or public interest. It is a normal rule that the disclosure of such information would cause an unwarranted invasion of privacy of an individual, however once the CPIO/SPIO reaches the conclusion that disclosure of such information is in larger public interest, appropriate order can be passed in this regard.          [Para 16,19]

heading: Right to Information
HeadNote.description:
Right to Information - Whether accessible to visually impaired persons - S.6(1) of RTI Act takes care of persons who are unable to write or have difficulty in writing - Several States provide information in Braille since year 2012 - Audio files are also being prepared - No further direction needs to be issued - Petitioner however granted liberty to submit representation to competent authority pointing out any other mode available for getting information under the Act.

	In instant case petitioner submitting that illiterate persons and visually impaired persons or persons affected by other kind of disabilities are not in position to get information. As per the proviso to S. 6(1) it is obligatory on the part of the Central Public Information Officer or State Public Information Officer to render all reasonable assistance to the persons making the request orally to reduce the same in writing. It will be the duty of the officer to listen to the persons and to reduce it in writing and process the same. S.6(3) of the RTI Act takes care of the apprehension of the persons for whose cause the petitioner espouses, by making the provision pertaining to appropriate competent public authority.Assistance has to be rendered under Section 6(1) of the Act to the persons who are unable to write or have difficulty in writing.Further, several States providing information in Braille since the year 2012. Every time the authority receives an RTI application seeking information in Braille, it prepares a reply in the printed format and forwards it to the National Institute for the Visually Handicapped where it is converted to Braille. The visually impaired citizens of Bihar were the first in the country to get copies under the Right to Information (RTI) Act and the Rules made by the State Government for its implementation in Braille script. Audio files are also being prepared.Therefore, no further direction needs to be issued except granting liberty to the petitioner to submit a representation to the competent authority pointing out any other mode(s) available for getting information under the Act.
