heading: Applicability of S.31
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of S.31 - Section applies not only to transfer of suit but also to transfer of proceeding like an execution application - Transfer is automatic because of the operation of law.

2000(1) ALL MR 331 (S.C.), (2000) 6 SCC 655 Rel. on. 	(Paras 13, 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Proceeding by DRT
HeadNote.description: Proceeding by DRT - Provision of Limitation Act are applicable in view of S.24 of Recovery of Debts Act.  (Para 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Word "debt"
HeadNote.description: Word "debt" - It includes relief for enforcement of mortgage.	(Para 47)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Order of recovery officer
HeadNote.description: Order of recovery officer - Dispute as to payment of security service charges to court commissioner - Property of defaulter auctioned by bank - Bank had decided to discharge Court commissioner w.e.f. 8/5/2007 - Recovery officer though considered that continuance of service of Court Commissioner is only at the instance of auction purchaser yet directed Bank to continue with payment of security service charges to Court Commissioner - In appeal DRT set aside order of recovery officer and directed auction purchaser to pay security service charges - No challenge by Court Commissioner to order of DRT but he filed application seeking direction to auction purchaser for payment of said charges - High court failed to consider the same and gave finding that DRT had no jurisdiction to entertain appeal against order of Recovery Officer - Findings of High Court not sustainable - Order of DRT upheld. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11, 13)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Recovery proceedings
HeadNote.description: Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act (2006) - Recovery proceedings - Dispute as to payment of security service charges to court Commissioner - Jurisdiction of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Facilitation Council (MSMEDF Council) - Held, when proceedings lawfully conducted before quasi-judicial authorities like DRT and DRAT having trappings of civil court - MSMEDF Council had no jurisdiction to entertain any application in this regard - Moreso, when order passed by DRT accepted by parties.  (Para 12)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
HeadNote.sub_clause: Ss.21, 30-A [As inserted by amendment Act 44 of 2016]
heading: Appeal
Is mandatory
HeadNote.description: Order issuing recovery certificate - Appeal - Pre-condition of deposit of 75 % of amount due (50% after amendment) - Is mandatory - Tribunal should not entertain appeal against ex-parte order of issuing recovery certificate before deposit of amount by borrower. 			(Para 17)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.9 R.13 - Appeal - Against ex-parte order issuing recovery certificate - Ground of defective service of notice - Borrower-company objecting that notice was deliberately not sent on its correct address to obtain ex-parte order - Address of borrower- company is Block No.714-725 - Whereas address mentioned in notice was 712-725 which includes Block No.714-725 - Notice of recovery proceedings returned with remark 'not claimed' - In terms of Regulation 19(6), when notice is returned with such remark, it can be presumed that there was proper service of notice - Receipt of notice, not disputed by Director of borrower company - It shows they have knowledge of recovery proceedings - Applying the principles under O.9 R.13, merely on account of defect in service, ex-parte decree cannot be set aside - Appeal dismissed.	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Jurisdiction of High Court in transferred cases
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of High Court in transferred cases - Application seeking direction to court receiver - Suit transferred to Debts Recovery Tribunal - Recovery certificate issued by Tribunal and such application made on directions of Tribunal - On transfer court receiver does not automatically stand discharged and continues till discharged - High Court does not continue to have power to issue directions to receiver - Such power to be exercised by Tribunal in transferred matters - However in peculiar facts and circumstances and extreme urgency directions issued by court - Court receiver to receive directions from Tribunal for further period of 1 yr - As view held by single judge in 2000(3) ALL MR 46 dissented from matter referred to be placed before the Chief Justice for issuing necessary directions with request to place it before a larger bench.

2000(3) ALL MR 46 - Dissented from.

2000(3) ALL MR 475 (S.C.) - Relied on.	 (Paras 4,13,14,15,18,20)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Transfer of pending cases
HeadNote.description:
Transfer of pending cases - No suit but appeal pending on crucial date - Appeal subsequently allowed and matter remanded - Remand order has effect of reviving suit from date it was originally filed - Suit is liable to be transferred.

It is true that under sub-clause (c) of Section 31, every suit or proceeding "pending before any Court immediately before the date of establishment of the Tribunal under the Act" shall stand transferred to the Tribunal. It is also true that under the proviso to Section 31(1), appeals pending on the date do not stand transferred. The suit of the Bank was in fact, pending in appeal on 27-4-94, and it is clear that this provision for transfer does not apply to an appeal pending as aforesaid before any Court. But, it is now well settled that an order of remand by the appellate Court to the trial Court which had disposed of the suit revives the suit in full except as to matters, if any decided finally by the appellate Court. Once the suit is revived, it must, in the eye of the law, be deemed to be pending - from the beginning when it was instituted. The judgment disposing of the suit passed by the single Judge which is set aside gets effaced altogether and the continuity of the suit in the trial Court is restored, as a matter of law. The suit cannot be treated as one freshly instituted on the date of the remand order. Otherwise serious questions as to limitation would arise. In fact, if any evidence was recorded before its earlier disposal, it would be evidence in the remanded suit and if any interlocutory orders were passed earlier, they would revive. In the case of a remand, it is as if the suit was never disposed of (subject to any adjudication which has become final, in the appellate judgment). The position could have been different if the appeal was disposed of once and for all and the suit was not remanded.  [Para 15,16]

Applying the above principle, the suit filed by the Bank in 1985, even though it was disposed of by judgment dated 29-3-94, it stood revived with continuity by the remand order passed by the Division Bench on 11-8-98, and cannot be treated as a freshly instituted on 11-8-98 before the single Judge but must, in the eye of the law, be treated as pending on the crucial day i.e. 27-4-94.

If while a suit is pending, a law like the 1993 Act that the Civil Court shall not decide the suit, is passed, the Civil Court is bound to take judicial notice of the statute and hold that the suit - even after its remand - cannot be disposed of by it.  [Para 20]

If it is not to be transferred to the Tribunal and if it is to be retained in the Civil Court, without disposal as contended, then there will be a stalemate. It has to be kept perpetually pending in the Civil Court and necessarily the file has to be consigned to the record room. Or the plaint will have to be returned for presentation before the proper Court or Tribunal. That was surely not the intendment of the Act of 1993. When this aspect was put to the learned senior counsel for the respondents, there was practically no answer. It was, no doubt, faintly suggested that the bar in Section 18 does not apply to remanded suits but we are unable to agree. As stated earlier, they stand revived in law with continuity and therefore the bar under Section 18 clearly applies.  [Para 23]

The remanded suit cannot remain in the Civil Court with no chance of disposal. Again, our decision that the restoration of the suit is with continuity from the date of original institution of the suit does not amount to legislation but is the result of the application of a fundamental principle of law applicable to the civil procedure. It cannot therefore be said that we have encroached upon the jurisdiction of the legislature.  [Para 29]

For the aforesaid reasons, the principle of purposive interpretation is to be applied to Sections 18 and 31 of the Act and that suit 410/1985 filed by the Bank in 1985 and which stood remanded by the appellate Court on 11-8-98 must in the eye of the law be deemed pending before the single Judge and that it would stand transferred to the Tribunal. The High Court was, therefore, in error in retaining the same on the original side.  [Para 33]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Counter claim in S.19
HeadNote.description:
Counter claim in S.19 - Includes claim in suit filed earlier - Earlier to suit filed by Bank debtor company had filed suit for specific performance and permanent injunction against Bank - Would amount to counter claim and set off raised in suit filed by Bank and both suits are liable to be transferred to Tribunal.

The word 'counter-claim' in Section 19 (8) to (11) which is equated to a cross-suit, includes a claim even if it is made in an independent suit filed earlier. An agreement not to charge interest, the specific performance of which is claimed is nothing but a plea that the Bank could not charge interest. A permanent injunction directing the Bank not to charge interest because of an alleged agreement in that behalf is likewise a plea that no interest is chargeable. So far as the plea for further financial assistance is concerned, it is also, broadly, in the nature of a 'counterclaim'. All these fall under Section 19(8) to (10). Again, the plea for deducting 'damages' though raised in the suit is indeed broadly a plea of "set off" falling under sub-clauses (6) and (7) of Section 19.  [Para 41]

Both the suits, the one by the Bank against the respondent (suit 410/85) and the other by the debtor-against the Bank (suit 272/85) which raises claims or pleas in the nature of set-off or counter-claim are interconnected. The respondent's suit falls under sub-clauses (6), (7) and (8) to (11) of Section 19, as stated above. Our decision in regard to the real nature of suit 272/85 has become necessary in the context of a plea by the debtor-company that the company's suit is liable to be retained in the civil Court and on account of the plea that the Connected suit, suit by the Bank 410/85, is also to be retained. Such a plea, as shown above.  [Para 42]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Rel on.	(Para 12,13,14,15)
HeadNote.description:
Cases transferred to Tribunal - Jurisdiction of High Court - Power to issue directions to Court Receiver, High Court - After applicability of Recovery Act, High Court ceased to have jurisdiction to issue directions to Court Receiver - Only Tribunals under the Recovery Act 1993 have jurisdiction to issue directions to Court Receiver - However as no separate machinery of Court Receiver available to Tribunal - Chief justice requested to provide services of Court Receiver for a period of one year.

JT 2000(4) SC 411, JT 2000(8) SC 239 - Rel on.	(Para 12,13,14,15)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Court receiver
HeadNote.description: Court receiver - Cases transferred to Tribunal under the Recovery Act 1993 - Court Receiver to act on directions issued by Tribunal or Appellate Tribunal - Such directions may be issued on report of Court Receiver or on application of any party to proceedings - Receiver can be discharged by the Tribunals acting suo motu on application of any of the parties and other receiver can be appointed - Court Receiver of High Court can apply for discharge either at expiry of one year or earlier if directed by the Chief Justice.			(Para 15)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Jurisdiction of Tribunal
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Tribunal - Is exclusive not only in the matter of adjudicating claims of banks and financial institutions but also in the execution of adjudication orders - No dual jurisdiction are contemplated.

The jurisdiction of the Tribunal in regard to adjudication is exclusive. The RDB Act requires the Tribunal alone to decide applications for recovery of debts due to Banks or financial institutions. Once the Tribunal passes an order that the debt is due, the Tribunal has to issue a certificate under Section 19(22) (formerly under section 19(7)) to the Recovery Officer for recovery of the debt specified in the certificate. The question arises as to the meaning of the word 'recovery' in Section 17 of the Act. Basically the Tribunal is to adjudicate the liability of the defendant and then it has to issue a certificate under Section 19(22). Under Section 18, the jurisdiction of any other Court or authority which would otherwise have had jurisdiction but for the provisions of the Act, is ousted and the power to adjudicate upon the liability is exclusively vested in the Tribunal. (This exclusion does not however apply to the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court or of a High Court exercising power under Article 226 or 227 of the Constitution). This is the effect of Sections 17 and 18 of the Act.  [Para 21]

Even in regard to 'execution', the jurisdiction of the Recovery Officer is exclusive. Now a procedure has been laid down in the Act for recovery of the debt as per the certificate issued by the Tribunal and this procedure is contained in Chapter V of the Act and is covered by Sections 25 to 30. It is not the intendment of the Act that while the basic liability of the defendant is to be decided by the Tribunal under Section 17, the Banks/Financial institutions should go to the Civil Court or the Company Court or some other authority outside the Act for the actual realisation of the amount. The certificates granted under Section 19(22) has to be executed only by the Recovery Officer. No dual jurisdictions at different stages are contemplated. Further, section 34 of the Act gives overriding effect to the provisions of the RDB Act.  [Para 23]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Word "proceedings" in S.31
HeadNote.description:
Word "proceedings" in S.31 - Includes execution proceedings pending before a civil Court before the commencement of the Act.

The definition of "debt" in S.2(g) includes "Claims" by Banks and financial institutions and includes the liability incurred and also liability under a decree or otherwise. In this context Section 31 of the Act is also relevant. That section deals with transfer of pending suits or proceedings to the Tribunal. In our view, the word 'proceedings' in Section 31 includes as 'execution proceedings' pending before a Civil Court before the commencement of the Act. The suits and proceedings so pending on the date of the Act stand transferred to the Tribunal and have to be disposed of "in the same manner" as applications under Section 19.  [Para 20]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Initiation of proceedings by Banks and financial institutions against companies
HeadNote.description: Initiation of proceedings by Banks and financial institutions against companies - Leave of Company Court under S.537 of Companies Act not necessary - Company Court cannot stay proceedings before Tribunal under S.422 of Companies Act. (Paras 29, 30)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Both the RDB and Companies Act can be regarded as special laws
HeadNote.description:
Both the RDB and Companies Act can be regarded as special laws - RDB Act being later law would prevail over the Companies Act.

1993 (2) SCC 144 Rel. on. (Para 39)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Impleadment of banks in main application under S.19(1)
HeadNote.description: Impleadment of banks in main application under S.19(1) - Order of adjudication as to whether the debt is due or not already passed - Banks cannot be impleaded at this stage. (Para 51)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Priority
HeadNote.description:
Execution proceedings initiated by a Bank - Claim by another company which has not obtained a decree - Priority - Has to be decided as per S.73 of Civil P.C. by the Tribunal.

Where the defendant company is a company against which no winding up order is passed, the Company, is like any other defendant and if in such a situation a question of priority arises before the Tribunal, in respect of any monies realised under the RDB Act, as between the Bank or financial institutions on the one hand and the other creditors on the other, it will, be necessary for the Tribunal to decide such questions of priority bearing in mind principles underlying Section 73 of the Code of Civil Procedure. Section 22 of the RDB Act, gives sufficiently wide powers to the Tribunal and the Appellate Tribunal to decide such questions of priorities, subject only to the principles of natural justice. The powers under Section 22 are wider than those of civil Courts and the only restriction on its power is that principles of natural justice have to be followed. But under S. 73 CPC, sharing in the sale proceeds (here, sale proceeds realised under the RDB Act) is permissible only if a person seeking such share has obtained a decree or an order of adjudication from the Tribunal and has not complied with other conditions laid down under Section 73. In the present case, the Canara Bank is not in a position to invoke the principles underlying Section 73 CPC because it has not yet obtained any decree or adjudication of its debt from the Tribunal. Nor has it complied with other provisions underlying Section 73 CPC. Hence no relief can be granted on the basis of the said priorities.  [Para 52,53]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Position of secured creditor standing outside winding up
HeadNote.description:
Position of secured creditor standing outside winding up - Company which does not belong to the class of secured creditors covered by S.529-A(1)(b) cannot claim any amount lying in the Tribunal towards its security or any priority against the Bank at whose instance the execution proceedings are initiated.

The secured creditor who stands outside the winding up and whose claims are restricted to Section 529-A read with the clause (c) of proviso to Section 529(1), does not in the ultimate analysis stand to lose any part of his security merely because the "workmen's portion" is taken away from his security. Whatever he loses towards "workmen's portion' out of his security, can be claimed by him as a secured amount with priority over such creditors out of other realisations made by other creditors whose monies are lying in the Tribunal. At the same time, his position would not impose from what it was originally and his priority would not extend to his entice unrealised sums which might be in excess of his security.

But the point here is that the occasion for such a claim by a secured creditor (here the Canara Bank) against realisations by other creditors (like the Allahabad Bank) under Section 529-A read with proviso (c) to Section 529(1) can arise before the Tribunal only if the Canara Bank has stood outside winding up and realised amounts and if it shows that out of the amounts privately realised by it, some portion has been rateably taken away by the liquidator under sub-clause (a) and (b) of the proviso to Section 529(1). It is only then that it can claim that it is to be re-imbursed at the same level as a secured creditor with priority over the realisations of other creditors lying in the Tribunal. None of these conditions is satisfied by Canara Bank. Thus, Canara Bank does not belong to the class of secured creditors covered by Section 529-A(1)(b).

Therefore, the Canara Bank cannot rely on the words in Section 19(19) viz, "to be distributed among its secured creditors" for claiming any amount lying in the Tribunal towards its security nor can it claim priority as against the Allahabad Bank.

If one of the conditions required for applying Section 19(19) and Section 529-A is, therefore, satisfied, then the claim of Canara Bank before the Tribunal can only be on the basis of principles underlying section 73 CPC. There being no decree in its favour from any Court or from any tribunal, and the other conditions of Section 73 not having been satisfied, no dividend can be claimed out of monies realised at the instance of the Allahabad Bank, even if the Allahabad Bank is an unsecured creditor.   [Para 68,71]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Recovery of debts
Suit for
HeadNote.description: Recovery of debts - Suit for - Respondent Bank sanctioning credit facilities to petitioners on certain terms and conditions - Petitioners committing breach of terms and conditions of said agreements - One-time settlement agreed upon between parties and part payment made by petitioner - Petitioners failing to make payment of balance amount under compromise - Order passed by DRAT directing petitioners to pay 50% of total amount - Said amount not being more than what petitioners agreed to pay as one-time settlement as on date with interest - Order passed by Debts Recovery Appellate Tribunal - Held, just and fair.	(Para 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Banking Company
Co-operative Bank
HeadNote.description:
Banking Company - Co-operative Bank - Banking Company shall have the meaning assigned to it in clause (c) of S.5 of Banking Regulation Act (1949) - Reference to the word "Banking Company" shall be construed as reference to Co-operative Bank throughout the Banking Regulation Act.

From the careful and, conjoint reading of the Banking Regulation Act, Act of 1993 and the respective preamble, objectives and reasons, it would be clear that the co-operative banks were not at all intended to be excluded from the benefits of machinery made available to the banks under Act of 1993 for recovery of outstanding debts.  The Act of 1993 was enacted to work out suitable mechanism through which the dues to the Banks and Financial Institutions could be recovered and realised without delay.  The Parliament felt the need to set up special Tribunals and fora for the speedy recovery of dues and loans to the banks and financial institutions as the significant portion of the funds was blocked and rendered unproductive.  The Parliament does not appear to have intended to discriminate between the co-operative banks and banking companies for the purposes of Act of 1993 and it was for this reason that in section 2(e) of the Act of 1993, it was provided that "banking company" shall have the meaning assigned to it in clause (c) of section 5 of the Banking Regulation Act, 1949 which by virtue of section 56(a)(i) included co-operative banks already.  [Para 15]

In view of discussion aforesaid we hold that Act of 1993 is applicable to co-operative banks for adjudication of recovery of debts due to them and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto.  AIR 1998 Raj. 100 - Not proper law.  [Para 19]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Adjudication of liability and execution of certificate by Recovery Officer
HeadNote.description: Adjudication of liability and execution of certificate by Recovery Officer - Jurisdiction of Debts Recovery Tribunal under S.17 and 18 is exclusive so far the question of adjudication of liability and execution of the certificate by the Recovery Officer is concerned - No other court or authority much less the civil court or the company court can go into the said question relating to the liability and recovery, except as provided in the Act. AIR 2000 SC 1535 - Ref.on 	(Para 29)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Scope and application of
HeadNote.description: Scope and application of - Jurisdiction of Debts Recovery Tribunal is exclusive and the company court cannot use its powers under S. 442 of Companies Act against the Tribunal or Recovery Officer - Provisions of Ss. 442, 446 and 537 of the said Act cannot be applied against the Debts Recovery Tribunal. (Para 30)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Jurisdiction of Company Court under S. 446 (2)
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Company Court under S. 446 (2) - Exercise of jurisdiction by Company Court under S. 446 (2) can only be at the instance of the Recovery Officer acting under S.28 (4) of the RDB Act - In view of this, any decision by the Company Court on the application of a secured creditors as per the certificate under S. 19 (22) of the RDB Act, held, would be without jurisdiction.

The question whether the secured creditors have lost their security or not, or whether the assets and properties transferred can be attached or not, can be gone into only in the execution proceedings by the Recovery Officer under the RDB Act and it is not proper for company Court to express any opinion on that question, so as to prejudice the contentions of either of the parties. Not only that, but the Recovery Officer has power under sub-section (2) of Section 28 of the RDB Act to require any person from whom an amount is due to the defendant in recovery certificate to deduct such amount and credit it to the account of the Recovery Officer. If the Recovery Officer, after dealing with all such relevant aspects, approaches this Court, as required by sub-section (4) of Section 28 of the RDB Act, then only company Court can exercise jurisdiction. In other words, the exercise of jurisdiction by the Company Court under Section 446(2) can only be at the instance of the Recovery Officer acting under Section 28(4) of the RDB Act. In view of this, any decision by the Company Court on the application of a secured creditor under Section 446 of the said Act, to disburse amount to the secured creditors as per the certificate under Section 19(22) of the RDB Act, would be without jurisdiction.  [Para 39]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Jurisdiction of company court
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of company court - Matter completely determined by the Debts Recovery Tribunal - Company court has no jurisdiction under S.446 to re-open the issues concluded by the judgment and order passed by the Debts Recovery Tribunal under S. 17 of the RDB Act. 	(Para 46)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Jurisdiction of Company Court
HeadNote.description: Jurisdiction of Company Court - Charges of secured creditors - Company Court has no jurisdiction under S.446 of the Companies Act to go into the question as to whether the charges of the secured creditors are registered or not, and whether the debts of the secured creditors should be treated as secured only to the extent of the amounts specified in the certificate issued under S.19 (22) of RDB Act. 			(Para 47)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Relinquishment or surrender of claims of secured creditors
HeadNote.description: Relinquishment or surrender of claims of secured creditors - Question whether the first charge holders have relinquished their claims over the assets and properties of the company in Liquidation - The question is a mixed question of law and fact which is required to be pleaded and proved. (Para 49)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: "Debt"
HeadNote.description: "Debt" - Security deposit given against licensed premises by Bank - Is not "debt" within meaning of S.2(g) of 1993 Act - Thus proceeding instituted u/S.17 by Bank for recovery of said amount - Not maintainable. (1995) 60 DLT 454 Dissented from.			(Paras 34, 37)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Enforcement of Security Interest and Recovery of Debts Laws (Amendment) Act (2012) - Transfer of pending suit to DRT - In case of recovery of debt due to Multi-State Co-operative bank which is covered under definition of "bank" by Amendment Act - Objection raised that prerequisite for such transfer is pendency of suit from 'date of establishment of Tribunal' under original Recovery of Debt Act and not from date when Amendment Act came into force - Not acceptable - If accepted, neither S.18 nor S.31 would make any sense insofar as Multi-State Co-operative banks are concerned - Expression 'date of establishment of Tribunal' cannot have different meanings for purposes of Ss.18, 31 - It must be reckoned as date of coming into force of Amending Act, when Tribunal can be said to be established for entertaining applications for recovery of debts of multi-State Co-operative banks - Proceedings of suit shall stand transferred to DRT. 	(Paras 7, 8)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Enforcement of Security Interest and Recovery of Debts Laws (Amendment) Act (2012)
HeadNote.description: Enforcement of Security Interest and Recovery of Debts Laws (Amendment) Act (2012) - Transfer of pending suit to DRT - Suit for recovery of debt due to Multi-State Co-operative bank which is covered under definition 'bank' by Amendment Act, 2012 - Objection raised that in view of Objects and Reasons of Amendment Act, any such recovery proceedings pending before any forum shall be continued, notwithstanding anything contained u/S.31 - Not acceptable, as it is contrary to Amendment Act and proviso introduced therein - No need to refer objects and reasons of Bill as external aid for interpretation in absence of ambiguity in provisions of S.31 as it stands after Amendment Act - Even if one were to refer same, object was to permit Multi-State Co-operative bank to opt to either initiate proceedings under Multi-State Co-operative Societies Act, 2002 or under Recovery of Debts and Bankruptcy Act, 1993 - In view of specific provision for pending proceedings, civil Courts cannot exercise jurisdiction and under specific transfer provision, such proceedings must be transferred to DRT. HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Financial Corporation
Recovery of dues
Interpretation of statutes
HeadNote.description:
State Financial Corporations Act (1951), S.32(G) - Financial Corporation - Recovery of dues - Financial Corporation may either proceed under Financial Corporations Act, 1951 or under Recovery of Debts Act, 1993 - It cannot proceed under U.P. Act, 1972 - Interpretation of statutes - Principle of casus omissus.

Section 34 of the Act consists of two parts. Sub-section (1) deals with the overriding effect of the Act notwithstanding anything inconsistent therewith contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any instrument having effect by virtue of any law other than the Act. Sub-section (1) itself makes an exception as regards matters covered by sub-section (2). The U.P. Act is not mentioned therein. The mode of recovery of debt under the U.P. Act is not saved under the said provision i.e. sub-section (2) which is of considerable importance. Even a bare reading therein makes it clear that it is intended to be in addition to and not in derogation of certain statutes; one of which is the Financial Act. In other words, a Bank or Financial Institution has the option or choice to proceed either under the Act or under the modes of recovery permissible under the Financial Act. To that extent, the High Court's conclusions quoted above were correct. Where the High Court went wrong is by holding that proceedings under the U.P. Act were permissible, U.P. Act deals with separate modes of recovery and such proceedings are not relatable to proceedings under the Financial Act.  [Para 9]

The plea that mode of recovery under U.P. Act has to be read into S.34 of Recovery Act by application of principles known as casus omissus and the deficiency, if any, can be reconciled by purposive interpretation by reading the said statute as a whole and finding out the true legislative intent is not tenable.  Two principles of construction - one relating to casus omissus and the other in regard to reading the statute as a whole appear to be well settled. Under the first principle a casus omissus cannot be supplied by the Court except in the case of clear necessity and when reason for it is found in the four corners of the statute itself but at the same time a casus omissus should not be readily inferred and for that purpose all the parts of a statute or section must be construed together and every clause of a section should be construed with reference to the context and other clauses thereof so that the construction to be put on a particular provision makes a consistent enactment of the whole statute. This would be moreso if literal construction of a particular clause leads to manifestly absurd or anomalous results which could not have been intended by the Legislature.  [Para 14]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: 'Specified Company', 'Administrator to the Specified Underking' under the UTI (TUR) Act must be deemed to be financial institutions specified in S.4-A(1) of the Companies Act
HeadNote.description:
'Specified Company', 'Administrator to the Specified Underking' under the UTI (TUR) Act must be deemed to be financial institutions specified in S.4-A(1) of the Companies Act - By deemed amendment they come within the definition of 'financial institutions' under S.2(h)(i) of DRT Act - Words 'as the case may be' in S.18 do not introduce any element of uncertainty.

Appellant prayed for dismissal of Original Application stating that respondents are not 'financial institutions' under the Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act, 1993 (DRT Act), DRT had no jurisdiction to entertain and decide Original Application filed for alleged recovery of debts due to respondents.  DRT dismissed application.  Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunal (DRAT) dismissed the appeal.  High Court upheld order of DRAT.  In further appeal Supreme Court considered whether respondents 1 and 2 are 'financial institutions' within the meaning of DRT Act.  Supreme Court observed that section 4-A of the Companies Act provides that each of the financial institutions specified in sub-section (1) shall be regarded for the purpose of that Act, as a public financial institution.  The financial institutions specified included the 'Unit Trust of India' established under Section 3 of the UTI Act, 1963.  By operation of Section 18 of the UTI Act, 2002, 'Unit Trust of India' is substituted by the 'Specified Company' or 'Administrator of the Specified Undertaking', as the case may be.  Thus, the 'Specified Company' and the 'Administrator of the Specified Undertaking' must be deemed to be financial institutions specified in sub-section (1) of Section 4-A of the Companies Act.  Section 2(h) of the DRT Act defines a 'financial institution' to mean a public financial institution within the meaning of Section 4-A of the Companies Act.  Consequently by reason of deemed amendment of Section 4-A of the Companies Act, the 'Specified Company' and the 'Administrator of the Specified Undertaking' come within the definition of financial institutions as defined under Section 2(h) of DRT Act.  Court did not find that the use of words 'as the case may be' introduces any element of uncertainty.  [Para 27,28,29]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Recovery of dues
Jurisdiction of DRT
HeadNote.description:
Recovery of dues - Control of Central Government - Jurisdiction of DRT - Application seeking recovery of dues in exercise of status and power conferred by statute - Nature of control of Central Government wholly irrelevant in considering question of jurisdiction of DRT.

DRT did not accept appellant's contention that DRT had no jurisdiction to entertain Original Application filed by the respondents for alleged recovery of debts due to respondents.  Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunal (DRAT) dismissed appeal.  High Court upheld order of DRAT.  In further appeal Supreme Court considered whether the action before DRT is for recovery of debts due to them from appellant herein, and not due to any other person on whose behalf aforesaid respondents are suing.  Supreme Court observed that in place of Unit Trust of India both the respondents stand substituted.  Both are entitled to sue as financial institutions and question whether they have an enforceable claim must be decided in the facts and circumstances of each case.  There is no uncertainty because the assets possessed by these two identities are clearly enumerated in Schedules I and II of the Unit Trust of India (Transfer of Undertaking and Repeal) Act, 2002.  The erstwhile Unit Trust of India ceased to exist and in its place a specified company and an Administrator of the specified undertaking of the Trust came into existence.  The transfer and vesting of assets, rights etc. in these two bodies is in the widest possible terms as per section 5 of the Unit Trust of India (Transfer of Undertaking and Repeal) Act, 2002.  The transfer and vesting is complete.  The fact that the management is carried on by the Administrator of the specified undertaking on behalf of Central Government which is authorized to issue directions to the Administrator does not detract from the fact that the 'specified undertaking' vests in the Administrator.  Section 5 of the Act leaves no doubt that vesting in the Administrator or in the Specified Company is complete.  The powers vested in the Administrator under Section 10 of the Act cover almost every power of management and administration.  Section 10(1)(b) in particular authorizes him on the advice of the Board of Advisors to invest, acquire, hold or dispose of securities and to exercise and enforce all powers and rights incidental thereto including protection or realization of such investment etc.  Thus, it is a part of the power of management vested in the Administrator to invest as well as to realize such investments.  Apparently therefore, if any amount is owing to the specified undertaking, the Administrator has the authority to take all necessary steps to realize any amount due to the specified undertaking.  The statute vests this power in him.  It cannot therefore be assumed that he does not possess power to make recoveries in course of management.  The mere fact that Central Government may give him directions or he may seek instructions from Central Government does not mean that the power exercised by the Administrator are not the powers vested in him by law.  Subject to such directions as may be given by Central Government, it is the Administrator who must exercise his power of management and administration.  Apparently therefore in recovering dues owing to the specified undertaking, the Administrator exercises the powers vested in him under the Act in his own right since the undertaking vests in him, and the Act vests in him wide powers of management and administration which include the power to recover dues owing to the specified undertaking.  It is, therefore, futile to contend that the Administrator acts as an agent of the Central Government.  He acts in exercise of the powers vested in him by the statute and in the manner prescribed by the statute.  Even assuming that the Administrator manages the specified undertaking on behalf of Central Government, that will not make any difference.  The amounts sought to be recovered are allegedly owing to the Specified Company and the Administrator, who are 'financial institutions' within the meaning of DRT Act, 1993.  Thus, they are not seeking to recover any dues owing to Central Government, and therefore, they cannot be held to be acting on behalf of Central Government.  In their own right they are seeking to recover amounts due to them in exercise of status and power conferred upon them by statute.  So viewed, nature of control of Central Government over them is wholly irrelevant in considering question of jurisdiction of DRT to entertain such a claim.  There is nothing in the Act which may justify the submission that the specified company acts as a trustee.  It manages and executes the schemes contained in Schedule I of the Act in accordance with the provisions of the Act.  The Administrator and the Specified Company were therefore, fully authorized in law to recover dues from appellants as 'financial institutions' and DRT had undoubted jurisdiction to entertain their claims.  Appeal dismissed.  [Para 30,37,39]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Grant of adjournment
HeadNote.description:
Proceeding before Debt Recovery Appellate Tribunal (DRAT) - Grant of adjournment - Should be an exception, not to be granted in routine and mechanical manner.

A tribunal dealing with an appeal should not allow adjournments for the asking. It should be kept uppermost in mind of the Presiding Officer of the tribunal that grant of an adjournment should be an exception and not to be granted in a routine and mechanical matter.

The legislature by its wisdom under Section 22 of the RDB Act has provided that the DRT and the appellate tribunal shall not be bound by the procedure laid down by the Code of Civil Procedure, but shall be guided by the principles of natural justice and subject to the rules framed. They have been conferred powers to regulate their own procedure as given to them. It is so, for the very purpose of their establishment is to expedite disposal of the applications and the appeals preferred before them. They have the character of specialized institutions with expertise and conferred jurisdiction to decide the lis in speedy manner so that the larger public interest, that is, the economy of the country does not suffer. 					          [Para 20,21]

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts Due to Banks and Financial Institutions Act (1993)
heading: Claim before DRT
Jurisdiction of Ombudsman
HeadNote.description:
Claim before DRT - Jurisdiction of Ombudsman - Subsequent filing of claim by Bank before Debts Recovery Tribunal ousts jurisdiction of Banking Ombudsman in a complaint earlier instituted before him.

In this case, on the day the complaint was filed no proceeding before any Tribunal on the subject matter was pending or in which a final order had been passed or decision rendered. At the stage of initiation, there was no impediment in the way of Ombudsman in entertaining complaint or in proceeding with it. The impediment, if any, was caused by Bank's subsequent filing of Original Application before Debts Recovery Tribunal (DRT). High Court has taken view that since by the time Ombudsman rendered his award, Bank had already approached DRT with its claim under RDDBFI Act, Banking Ombudsman did not have jurisdiction to render award, or has lost his jurisdiction to render award.	 [Para 9]

In appeal Supreme Court held, in the context of power conferred on Ombudsman by Scheme read in the light of Section 35-A of Banking Regulation Act, it would be appropriate to understand expression as having a foundation in law in the sense that claim must have a foundation in law. Ombudsman, though might have initially jurisdiction to entertain a complaint on basis that it has a legal foundation, here in terms of Scheme, he may be divested of that jurisdiction or foundation in law might be lost on either of parties approaching Court, Arbitrator or DRT in respect of same subject matter.	 [Para 10]

The complaint must continue to have a foundation in law at the time Ombudsman takes up claim for his consideration and renders his decision or award. The foundation would be lost when a Court, Arbitrator, Tribunal or any other competent forum is moved on the same subject matter. When the subject matter of the complaint is taken to any other competent forum, the complaint loses its foundation in law. In other words, the subject matter of the complaint should not be pending in any other Tribunal, or Court or before an Arbitrator not merely when it is filed but also when it is taken up for consideration and disposal. High Court was justified in interfering with Award of Ombudsman on ground that he could not have passed Award in view of divestiture of his jurisdiction.  Appeal dismissed.							 [Para 10,16,17]

HeadNote.description:

AIR 1981 SC 951 Rel. on.	 [Para 15]

heading: Electoral roll
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Electoral roll - Challenge to - Entries made in electoral roll can only be challenged in accordance with machinery provided by it and not before any other forum. 

Entries made in electoral roll can only be challenged in accordance with machinery provided by it and not before any other forum. Finality of electoral cannot be challenged in an election petition, even if certain irregularities had taken place in preparing Electoral roll. The voters were not disqualified under Section 16 of 1950 Act. In the light of this legal position, merely for alleged breach of Section 23(3) of 1950 Act, by virtue of amendment in 1956,  in 1951 Act, the petition would not be maintainable under Section 100 of 1951 Act. 
AIR 2003 SC 4603 - Ref. to.  [Para 23]

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Filing of Statutory affidavit - Proviso to S.83(1) is a mandatory requirement of filing a separate affidavit in the prescribed form in support of allegations of corrupt practices - Rules framed by High Court will not prevail over the provisions of the Representation of the People Act - An Election Petition must be accompanied with a separate affidavit. High Court of Judicature at Bombay (Appellate side) Rules (1960), Rr.7, 8.

The Proviso to Section 83(1) is a mandatory requirement of filing a separate affidavit in the prescribed form in support of allegations of corrupt practices. The Rules framed by the High Court will not prevail over the provisions of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.  It was for the petitioner to present the petition as per the statutory provisions i.e. an Election Petition must be accompanied with a separate affidavit. Objection raised or not by the office is of no consequence.  Acceptance of affidavit by the office within the time of three days prescribed under the High Court Appellate Side Rules will not save the period of limitation prescribed by the Statute.  As stated above, the Election Petition in the present case is filed without accompanying a separate affidavit as required under Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act.  Though the petition was verified and sworn in by the petitioner as required under the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, that verification does not amount to compliance of Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act.  The affidavit filed on 19-01-2005 and acceptance of the same by the High Court office on the same day will not save the period of limitation of forty-five days prescribed under Section 81 of the Act.  Hence, the affidavit filed by the petitioner found filed after the period of limitation.  Thus, the petition as presented by the petitioner is found to be a petition without accompanying by an affidavit as required under Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act.

The affidavit in support of allegations of corrupt practices forms a part of the Election Petition.  The Election Petition and the affidavit is held to be one document consisting of two parts, one is Election Petition proper and another is affidavit referred to in the Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act.  Thus, a separate affidavit required under Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act which needs to be filed along with the Election Petition forms a part of Election Petition itself.  Thus, a petition without an affidavit required under Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act can be said to be an incomplete petition.  (1974)4 SCC 237 -Ref. to. 							 [Para 13,14,16]

heading: Election Petition
Statutory affidavit
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Statutory affidavit - Non-filing of statutory affidavit along with election petition - It being an incomplete petition, can be rejected under Order 7, Rule 11 of Civil P.C.

No ground in the election petition can be allowed to be inserted after expiry of prescribed period of limitation of forty-five days, challenging the election.  In the present case also, election petition came to be filed on the last day of the prescribed period of limitation without filing an affidavit as required under Proviso to Section 83(1) of the Act.  Subsequent filing of affidavit on 19-01-2005 after expiry of the period of limitation is not permissible as it amounts to insertion of a ground after expiry of the period of limitation.  Hence, the election petition as it is filed on the last day of expiry of the period of limitation of forty-five days is a petition without an affidavit and is an incomplete petition, which is not a petition in the eye of law at all.  Hence such a petition is liable to be rejected under O.VII, R.11 of the Code of Civil Procedure.  AIR 1986 1253 and AIR 1987 SC 1577 Rel. on.	 [Para 22]

heading: Running allowance
HeadNote.description:
Railways Establishment Manual Vol.I (Revised Edition 1989) - Running allowance - Entitlement to .

Only a specific category of employees in the Railways like Drivers, Motormen, Firemen, Guards, Assistant Guards etc. who constitute the running staff and such staff who are directly connected with the movement of trains perform running duties. Running Allowance under the Rules is required to be paid only to the running staff who are engaged in the performance of duties directly connected with the movement of trains and such allowance includes kilometerage allowance or allowance in lieu of kilometerage (ALK). While kilometerage allowance is to be paid for performance of actual running duties, the allowance in lieu of kilometerage (ALK) is to be paid to such members of the running staff who are temporarily required to perform stationary duties. The rules also make it clear that 30% of the basic pay of the running staff is required to be treated as representing the pay element in the Running Allowance. Those members of the running staff who are employed on non-running duties are paid the aforesaid 30% of the basic pay if such nonrunning duties are performed at the headquarters whereas in case such non-running duties are performed by the running staff at outstations they are required to be paid ALK at the rates prescribed by Rule 907(b). It is thus clear that no Running Allowance i.e. either kilometerage allowance or allowance in lieu of kilometerage is contemplated for any staff, including erstwhile members of the running staff, permanently engaged in performance of stationary duties. Running Allowance of either description is required to be paid only to members of the running staff who are directly engaged in actual movement of trains or such staff who are temporarily assigned stationary duties but who are likely to go back and perform running duties. The respondent does not fall in either of the above two categories. Under Rule 903 of the Running Allowance Rules, as noticed above, 30% of the basic pay of the running staff represents the pay element in the Running Allowance. Therefore, in case of medically decategorised Driver, like the respondent, the said component being a part of the pay drawn by him as a running staff has to be protected. 	      [Para 9,11]

Employees.

HeadNote.act_name: Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Rules (2011)
heading: De-recognition of school
Validity
HeadNote.description: De-recognition of school - Validity - Permission was granted to management in 1983 to start primary school at place situated near railway station - Record showing that school was shifted at two different places without permission of competent authority - Material on record showing that record of school leaving certificate was not available with management - Also class for VIIIth standard was started without permission - Report of Committee constituted u/R.12 showing that school was not having record of strength of students and also of other particulars - Management has not maintained muster roll of teachers - School was run in shed like structure - There was no education material and no material for teaching staff - Even after 33 years of getting permission to school, management could not get building of its own for school - Further, management was interested in giving employment to its nears and dears and for that it wanted to remove previous employees - Order of de-recognition of school, proper. 			(Paras 18, 19, 20, 22)

HeadNote.act_name: Rajasthan Civil Services (Classification Control and Appeal) Rules (1958)
heading: Suspension of judicial officer accused in murder case
HeadNote.description:
Suspension of judicial officer accused in murder case - On acquittal by trial court suspension cannot immediately be revoked - He could have been given non-sensitive posting not involving judicial function when appeal filed by CBI was admitted by High Court - Hence continuance of suspension, was not wholly unjustified. 

In this Case The High Court, literally, had no option but to place and keep the petitioner under suspension. It was not as if the petitioner had unwittingly breached a traffic regulation, which may not invite, even a frown from the general public. It was also not where he may had a minor altercation with someone which may well be overlooked by a reasonable man, as it would not involve any moral turpitude. He was facing a trial for the offence of murder, a crime of highest moral turpitude. Since time immemorial, Judges have been placed on a very high pedestal in every civilized society. Such high status is accompanied by corresponding responsibility of a judge maintaining an unusually high standard of dignity, poise and integrity. There can be no two ways about it! Therefore, the decision of the High Court to continue the suspension of the petitioner can not be said to be wholly unjustified till his acquittal by the Delhi High Court. [Para 34,35]

HeadNote.act_name: Rajasthan Civil Services (Classification Control and Appeal) Rules (1958)
heading: Suspension of judicial officer
HeadNote.description: Suspension of judicial officer - Acquittal in murder case confirmed by High Court - Continuation of suspension on ground that High Court wanted to start departmental enquiry is on same set of facts and evidence is wholly unjustified - Power under R.54 is discretionary, but has to be exercised reasonably. (Para 40)

HeadNote.act_name: Rajasthan Civil Services (Classification Control and Appeal) Rules (1958)
heading: Departmental enquiry
HeadNote.description: Departmental enquiry - Judicial officer under suspension acquitted in criminal trial and also found not guilty in departmental proceedings - Full Court held, was not justified in holding that he was not entitled to promotion when his juniors were promoted pending proceedings - He was also entitled to full pay and allowances from the date of decision of High Court confirming his acquittal by trial court. (Paras 45, 46)

heading: Gratuity
HeadNote.description: Vidarbha Konkan Gramin Bank (Officers and Employees) Service Regulations (2013), Regs.72, 2(m), 2(o) - Gratuity - Calculation of amount under Regulations of 2013 - Claimants were Managers in Bank - As per 2nd proviso to Reg.72(3), amount of gratuity payable to officers is to be calculated only on basis of last pay drawn and it does not include dearness allowance. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18, 20)

heading: Pay scales Govt. taking concious decision not to grant computer increment to employees/officer of Rural Banks
HeadNote.description: Pay scales Govt. taking concious decision not to grant computer increment to employees/officer of Rural Banks - Directions issued by High Court requiring Rural bank to grant said benefit cannot be sustained.(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Procedure for promotion
HeadNote.description:
Circulars dt.30.11.2009 and 12.7.2010 - Procedure for promotion - Where a person is eligible to be considered for promotion, he cannot be excluded from consideration on ground that he was awarded censure entry or other minor punishment - Circulars issued by bank cannot override statutory rules.

The RRB Rules 1998 have introduced a detailed procedure for determining the minimum merit for promotion to the next higher post/grade. The RRB Rules, 1998 clearly provided that officers holding post in 8 years as an officer on regular basis in the RRB shall be considered for promotion to the next higher post. The aforesaid rule does not provide that any employee/officer, who has suffered a punishment or has received an adverse appraisal/Grade 'D' in the performance appraisal, shall not be eligible. However, the Circulars dated 30th November, 2009 and 12th July, 2010 enables the appellant banks to eliminate such employees, which is clearly contrary to the provisions contained in the statutory service rules. The procedure prescribed under the aforesaid two Circulars clearly has the effect of supplanting the provision of eligibility, which is not permissible.

Whilst assessing the eligibility of the candidates, determination of bare minimum merit is not envisaged. There is, in fact, a complete segregation of Rule 2(e) from Rule 2(f). Determining the eligibility of candidate is in the nature of a ministerial function. The management merely has to see that the candidate possesses the minimum length of service and that he/she is confirmed in the feeder cadre. The determination of bare minimum merit is on the basis of the performance in the written test/interview and performance appraisal. This is the function of the Selection Committee i.e. Departmental Promotion Committee.

There is no doubt that punishment and adverse service record are relevant to determine the minimum merit by the DPC. But to debar a candidate, to be considered for promotion, on the basis of punishment or unsatisfactory record would require the necessary provision in the statutory service Rules. There is no such provision under the 1998 Rules.

Different rules/regulations of the banks provide specific punishments such as "withholding of promotion, reduction in rank, lowering in ranks/pay scales". However, there is another range of penalty such as censure, reprimand, withholding of increments etc. which are also prescribed under various staff regulations. To debar such an employee from being considered for promotion would tantamount to also inflicting on such employee, the punishment of withholding of promotion. In such circumstances, a punishment of censure/ reprimand would, in fact, read as censure/reprimand + 5 years debarment from promotion. Thus the circulars issued by the bank debarring such employees from being considered would be clearly contrary to the statutory rules.	            [Para 31,35,36,40]

heading: Promotion to Area Managers or Senior Manager
HeadNote.description:
Promotion to Area Managers or Senior Manager - Prescription of 30% marks for oral interview as per cl.6 of circular Dt.22-4-1996 - Is not excessive or irrational.

The criteria for promotion as per the Regional Rural Banks (Appointments and Promotion of Officers and Other Employees) Rule, 1988 is seniority-Cum-Merit.  In absence of statutory Rules, it is open to the employer to formulate its own promotion policy and parameters of weightage to be given in respect of seniority and merit separately.  As the Rules are silent regarding the weightage to be given for seniority, performance and interview, the employer vide circular dated 22/02/1996 supplemented the same and laid down the weightage for seniority, merit and the interview. Allocation of 30% marks for interview while selecting the candidates through promotion is not excessive.  [Para 10,11]

Perusal of the circular will depict that the said circular is in-conformity with the Rules. The circular has specified the marks to be allocated under each head. The Rules, 1988 lay down the criteria i.e. while giving promotions the seniority, merit and interview will have to be considered but are silent regarding weightage of marks to be allocated under each head. The respondent-Bank has allotted the marks under each head after consultation with the unions of the officers. The respondent Bank vide said circular has not laid down any new criteria but has allocated marks under different heads which are specified in the Rules, 1988. The respondent-Bank has only supplemented and has not supplanted the rules, 1988. The same is perfectly permissible.  Further, in case of selection by interview test without written examination, allocation of 50% marks for viva voce tests is not excessive. In the present case, also there was no written test, as such fixing 30% marks for oral interview cannot be said to be excessive or irrational.	 [Para 13,14]

heading: Election petition
Rejection
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Rejection - On ground that it contains vague allegations and does not disclose any cause of action - First allegation is about discrepancy in number of votes cast and votes actually counted - Data that petitioner relied upon is drawn from newspaper report and not from official communication received from Receiving Officer or Election Commission - Newspaper reports do not have any evidentiary value unless supported by legally acceptable database - Second allegation that 'idol or picture of Buddha' was used for seeking vote on ground of religion - No pleading regarding religion of petitioner and of respondent and as to which religion or caste or community has been used as ground for promoting enmity between which different classes of voters registered in relevant Constituency - As regards allegation of tampering with EVMs and its malfunctioning, at which polling booths this happened and which of EVMs installed therein were tampered with and who were voters affected with, not stated - Allegations made in petition are general and vague - They lack in material facts which are necessary to disclose cause of action - Petition also does not comply with requirement of R.94A of Conduct Rules r/w S.83, as affidavit supporting allegations has not been sworn in prescribed format - Election petition stands rejected. 2010(6) ALL MR 305 Disting.1988 ALLMR ONLINE 242 (S.C.), (2004) 3 SCC 363, 2008 ALL SCR 1989, 2009 ALL SCR 2419 Ref.to.	(Paras 24, 25, 26, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 36, 37)

heading: Verification of pleadings
HeadNote.description: Verification of pleadings - Paragraphs in petition distinctly verified by giving source of information - Affidavit in support of petition also filed - O.6, R.15(2), (3), (4) have been complied with - Objective to bring authenticity to contents of pleadings by disclosing source is duly achieved - Petition not liable to be dismissed on ground of verification. 	(Para 24)

heading: Verification of annexure
HeadNote.description: Verification of annexure - Annexure to election petition not attested as 'true copy' - Annexure also not verified as per O.6, R.15(2),(3),(4) - Petition is liable to be dismissed. 	(Para 25)

heading: Striking out pleadings
Application for
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Striking out pleadings - Application for - Maintainability - Challenge, on ground that no averment in this regard found in written statement - Election petition filed challenging result of election on account of disqualification of respondent who won election - Specific averment made in written statement that respondent had entered into contract with Zilla Parishad, subsisting on date of filing of his nomination form, that would not incur any disqualification for respondent - Because Zilla Parishad is not "appropriate government" for purposes of S.9A of RP Act - Thus, objection now taken in application under O.6 R.16, CPC has its foundation in written statement - Application held maintainable. 2013(4) ALL MR 486 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Para 5)

heading: Election petition
Standard of proof
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Standard of proof - Standard of proof in election petition is expected as it is in a criminal trial. AIR 1996 SC 1113 - Ref. to.	(Para 20)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - To contest election of Gram Panchayat - On ground that contract of petitioner-candidate with Govt. was subsisting on date of filing of nomination - Petitioner contended that work under contract was completed before filing of nomination - However, on date of filing nomination, it was his responsibility to make good if any defect is found in work - As long as liability to make good loss or damage in work is in existence on date of nomination, contract cannot be said to be concluded - Disqualification of petitioner to contest election, proper. 	(Paras 17, 19, 20)

heading: Accident to requisitioned vehicle
HeadNote.description:
Accident to requisitioned vehicle - Liability of registered owner - Vehicle was requisitioned by Magistrate for election duty - Owner had no other alternative but to hand over the vehicle - He, thereafter, ceases to exercise any control over the vehicle - State and not the owner is liable to pay compensation in such a case.

A vehicle is requisitioned by a statutory authority, pursuant to the provisions contained in a statute. The owner of the vehicle cannot refuse to abide by the order of requisition of the vehicle by the Deputy Commissioner. While the vehicle remains under requisition, the owner does not exercise any control thereover. The driver may still be the employee of the owner of the vehicle but he has to drive it as per the direction of the officer of the State, who is put in-charge thereof. Save and except for legal ownership, for all intent and purport, the registered owner of the vehicle loses entire control thereover. He has no say as to whether the vehicle should be driven at a given point of time or not. He cannot ask the driver not to drive a vehicle on a bad road. He or the driver could not possibly say that the vehicle would not be driven in the night. The purpose of requisition is to use the vehicle. For the period the vehicle remains under the control of the State and/or its officers, the owner is only entitled to payment of compensation therefor in terms of the Act but he cannot exercise any control thereupon. In a situation of this nature, this Court must proceed on the presumption that the Parliament while enacting the 1988 Act did not envisage such a situation. If in a given situation, the statutory definitions contained in the 1988 Act cannot be given effect to in letter and spirit, the same should be understood from the common sense point of view. Hence, the State shall be liable to pay compensation to the claimants and not the registered owner of the vehicle.  [Para 10,18]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Representation of the People Act (1950), Ss.16, 17 - Election petition - Challenge to election of petitioner in election of members of village panchayat - On Ground that name of elected representative appears in voters list of two different village panchayats and he has exercised his right to vote, in one village panchayat - Respondent on basis of provisions of Act, 1950 and 1951 claimed that elected representative became disqualified to contest election of village panchayat on casting vote in election of one village panchayat - Held, election of members of village panchayat would be governed by provisions of Act, 1958 and provisions of Representation of the People Act are not applicable to it - Act 1958 does not prescribe for disqualification to contest election if name of person appears in voters list of two village panchayats and has exercised his right of vote in election of another village panchayat - Election petition liable to be dismissed. 			(Paras 14, 18, 20)

heading: Quashing of FIR
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.482 - Breach of official duty in connection with election - Quashing of FIR - Allegations that petitioner failed to attend training program organized before election at Zilla Parishad which amounts to dereliction of his duty - Petitioner was on medical leave from 1.11.2011 to 30.11.2011 and said training was held on 20.11.2011 - Block Development Officer himself admitted that at relevant time petitioner was on leave, therefore notice for said training was not served to him - Petitioner was not intentionally absent on said day - FIR liable to be quashed. (Para 7)

heading: Claim for
HeadNote.description: Disqualification of member of APMC - Claim for - On ground that he is convicted for offence of murder and sentenced imprisonment for life - As per R.41(1)(a) of 1967 Rules person who is convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for term exceeding 6 months incurs disqualification to contest election unless such disqualification is removed by State Govt. - Respondent contested election in 2007 i.e. after 17 years of completion of sentence and his disqualification was removed in 2013 - No particular period fixed in R.41 after which person who has undergone sentence comes out of disqualification - Unless there is some period mentioned in Rule, it cannot be ascertained as to whether and when State Govt. can exercise power u/R.41 - As there is possibility of violation of fundamental right u/Art.21 and also of Art.14, period of 6 years after completion of sentence as mentioned in Ss.8(1), 8(2) and 8(3) of Representation of Peoples Act (1951) can be read into R.41 for coming out of disqualification - Considering said period, respondent was not disqualified at time of filing of nomination paper for election of member of APMC. 	(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Second highest number of votes - Where an election of a returned candidate is set aside on the ground that such candidate was not qualified to contest, the candidate who had secured second highest number of votes cannot be declared as elected - Held, what is not there in S.27(5) of the Act of 1961 cannot be added by judicial interpretation, since words of the section are very clear and there is no ambiguity.	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Election dispute
HeadNote.description: Election dispute - Prayer that some person other than returned candidate be declared to be elected - Held, proposition under Representation of the People Act cannot be applied to election dispute under Village Panchayats Act.  (Para 10)

heading: Constitution of India, Art.243Q
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.243Q - Errors in voters list - Not a ground to be raised in election petition - Bar u/S.15A of Village Panchayats Act or u/Art.243Q of Constitution, not attracted. 1966 ALLMR ONLINE 207 Rel.on. 			(Para 22)

heading: Errors in voters list
HeadNote.description: Errors in voters list - Whether materially affected elections of Village Panchayat - Contention raised that number of bogus voters is more than number of votes by which election has been won by candidates - However, nothing produced on record to show that any of these bogus voters had cast vote - Relevant data/documents claimed to be received by petitioners under RTI Act, neither identified nor annexed specifically - Not even certified as "true copies" and its contents are not backed by solemn affirmation - Such documents cannot be relied upon to set aside election - Two petitioners cannot be said to have personal knowledge of bogus votes cast at different polling booths - In any case, no general or special order issued by Election Commission for correction in voters list - Election cannot be set aside, particularly when winning candidates have not been made parties to petition - In view of fact that respondent/authorities have accepted errors in voters list, direction issued for correction without waiting for any order from Election Commission of India.	(Paras 24, 26, 29, 31, 35, 37, 38, 39, 40)

heading: Suspension of order of conviction
HeadNote.description:
Suspension of order of conviction - Appellate Court can suspend or stay order of conviction - Person seeking stay should specifically draw attention to consequences if conviction not stayed - Stay can be resorted to in rare cases depending upon special facts of case.

Appellant acquitted by Sessions Judge, High Court in appeal convicted him.  Supreme Court suspended execution of sentence, considered request for suspending conviction.  Supreme Court held appellate Court can suspend or grant stay of order of conviction.  But person seeking stay of conviction should specifically draw attention of appellate Court to consequences that may arise if conviction is not stayed.  Unless attention of Court is drawn to specific consequences that would follow on account of conviction, person convicted cannot obtain an order of stay of conviction.  Further, grant of stay of conviction can be resorted to in rare cases depending upon special facts of case.  Though for purpose of decision of prayer for staying or suspending order of conviction, it is not necessary to minutely examine merits of case, nevertheless Court referred to medical evidence having bearing on nature of offense alleged to have been committed by appellant.  FIR did not specifically mention that appellant had given blow on head of deceased.  Incident happened all of a sudden without pre-meditation.  Deceased was wholly unknown to appellant.  There was no motive for commission of crime.  Accused alleged to have lost temper and started giving abuses on account of objection raised by occupants of Maruti car due to obstruction being caused by vehicle of appellant.  Blows by fist are alleged to have been given and no weapon of any kind used.  Medical evidence shows deceased had a diseased heart, and it not conclusively establishing that death occurred due to blow given on head.  No role in causing injury on head of deceased was attached to appellant, but in subsequent statements after several years specific role was assigned to appellant of hitting deceased on head by a fist and thereby making him responsible for causing death.  These features of case which touch upon culpability of appellant, prima facie appear to be in his favour.  Another feature which has a bearing is that findings on factual aspects of case recorded in favour of appellant by Sessions Judge resulting in acquittal have been reversed by High Court.  Incident taking place in 1988, has no co-relation with public life of appellant which he entered much later in 2004 when he was elected as a Member of Parliament.  It is not a case where he took advantage of his position as M.P. in commission of crime.  As already stated, it was not necessary for appellant to have resigned from membership of Parliament as he could in law continue as M.P. by merely filing an appeal and had he adopted such a course he could have easily avoided incurring any disqualification at least till decision of appeal.  However, he has chosen to adopt a moral path and has set high standards in public life by resigning from his seat and in seeking to get a fresh mandate from people.  If prayer made by appellant is not granted he would suffer irreparable injury as he would not be able to contest for seat which he held and has fallen vacant only on account of his voluntary resignation which he did on purely moral grounds.  Having regard to entire facts and circumstances mentioned above Court was of opinion that it was a fit case where order of conviction passed by High Court deserved to be suspended.   [Para 1,3,7,10,11]

heading: Prohibitory order
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Excise Rules (1964), R.99(3) - Prohibitory order - Restriction on sale or supply of liquor within a polling area after 11 p.m. - On ground of breach of public peace - Petitioner organised event "Goafest" in hotel of Respondent - Plea that liquor may be served to poor electors which may give rise to ugly scenes and disturbing public order - Petitioner has already taken steps much prior to announcement of elections - Registration fees proposed to be charged by petitioner in sum of approximately Rs.24,000/-, inclusive of GST, per head, would indicate that no poor person would attend this function and would consume liquor therein - Hotel has already been granted permissions under Rules, 1964 for sale and service of liquor for 24 hours - Therefore, no violation of public interest if this event is allowed and liquor is allowed to be served beyond 11 p.m. till 1.30 a.m. as proposed by petitioner. 			(Paras 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 32)

heading: Election for Councillor
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Part IX-A, Art.243V - Election for Councillor - Validity - Disqualifications for membership of a municipality - Essential criteria of minimum age of 21 years - On the date of filing nomination forms petitioner had not completed 21 years of age - Non compliance of Art.243V(1) - Documentary evidence i.e. birth certificate, school leaving certificate school admission forms and LIC policies reliable and trustworthy for finding of the real date of birth of petitioner - No discrepancy in the date of birth - Appraisal and appreciation of the evidence on record cannot be said to be vitiated by law - Minimum criteria of 21 years of age not fulfilled - Election would be void.

AIR 1954 SC 520, AIR 2004 SC 230, AIR 1988 SC 1796 Ref. to.	 	 [Para 26,31,32,34,42,45,49,50,52,53]

heading: Parties
HeadNote.description:
Election petition on ground of corrupt practice - Parties - Petitioner making serious allegations about conduct of election and collusion of Election Commissioner, Returning Officer and Superintendent of police - They cannot, however, he joined as necessary or proper parties.

Section 82 does not provide for making any other person except the contesting candidates as party to an election petition.  The argument of the petitioner that since he has made allegations against the Election Commissioner, the Returning officer and the Superintendent of police, they should be made as parties has no support from the provisions of the Act.
