This is not a suit under common law or in equity where all interested parties can be made as parties.  This is an election tribunal trying an election petition vide 1951 Act and is bound by the provisions of the Act.  The only two provisions which provide for impleading parties are Sections 82 and 99.  As far as Section 82 is concerned, it speaks of only a candidate who is returned being made as party.  Under Section 99 of the Act if the Court comes to the conclusion that some third person has indulged in corrupt practices, then alone he can be made as party after giving him a notice about alleged corrupt practices.

There is no other provision in the Act which enables the Court to make third parties or other parties as parties to the election petition.

No doubt, Section 87 of the Act provides that while trying an election petition, the Court can adopt procedure applicable under the Code of Civil Procedure for trial of suits, but the Section starts with a clause " subject to the provisions of this Act".  Therefore, we have to read the applicability of Code of Civil Procedure subject to the provisions of the Act.  The Act specifically provides as to who are to be made parties vide Section 82 of the Act.  Therefore, we cannot import the principles of Code of Civil Procedure to make proper parties as parties to an election petition.  AIR 1982 S.C.983 and 1991 Supp(2)SCC 624 followed.  [Para 4]

heading: Election Petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Pleadings - Mere allegations of corrupt practice and /or irregularity itself are not sufficient to set aside the election of elected candidate - Held, burden always lies upon the petitioner to bring the material to support the grounds on record. 
2010(6) ALL MR 741 - Ref. to  (Paras 15, 19)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - High Court directing to furnish particulars of corruption not stated in the petition - Such directions are erroneous because they afford an opportunity to respondents to fill in gaps in the petition which would gravely prejudice appellants at the trial. (Para 3)

heading: Election Petition
Corrupt practice
Vicarious liability
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Corrupt practice - Vicarious liability - Allegation that candidate elected was responsible for alleged speeches by other persons - No notice u/s. 99 given to any of such persons - Candidate is not vicariously liable - Allegations in pleadings as well as attempted proof found very vague - Petition is liable to be dismissed. (Paras 6, 9, 10)

heading: Allegation of large scale reception of void votes
HeadNote.description: Allegation of large scale reception of void votes - Allegation not raised during counting by any of the counting agents of petitioner - Petitioner also failing to substantiate allegation - Even if allegation was proved it would not have materially affected result of election - Held election could not be declared void within meaning of S.100 (1) (d) (iii).	(Para 11,12)

heading: Disqualification of being an "undischarged insolvent"
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification of being an "undischarged insolvent" - Definition of insolvent in Sale of Goods Act cannot be imported - To be disqualified as "undischarged insolvent" a person should have been adjudged insolvent and remain undischarged by a Court under Insolvency Act - Mere incapacity to pay debts does not make a person an undischarged insolvent.

Article 191(l)(c) of Constitution of India does not contemplate mere impecuniousity or incapacity of a person to repay one's debts but he should not only be adjudged insolvent but also remain undischarged. Such a contingency could only arise under insolvency law. Article 191(l)(c) refers to disqualifications  of a  person  from  getting elected to State Legislature. The conditions for disqualification cannot be enlarged by importing to it any meaning other than permissible on strict interpretation of expressions used therein for what we are dealing with is a case of disqualification. Whenever any disqualification is imposed naturally the right of a citizen is cut down and in that event a narrow interpretation is required.  Therefore, the liberal view taken by the learned Judge to the contrary does not appear to be correct.

Under the Sale of Goods Act, a special definition of the expression 'insolvent' had to be given to the effect that a person is said to be 'insolvent' who has ceased to pay his debts in the ordinary course of business, or cannot pay his debts as they become due, whether he has committed an act of insolvency or not, and the definition is declaratory in character.   Question of insolvency of a buyer is of considerable importance in the context of the seller's lien.   It is in special context a meaning is given to the expression 'insolvent' even though a person had not been adjudged an insolvent in the Insolvency Act to be insolvent for the purposes of the Act. That definition cannot be imported into the R.P. Act.

The learned Judge goes on to observe that an insolvent is a person who is unable to repay his debts and as long as he remains in that  position  he  is  an  undischarged insolvent, that is, as long as he has not discharged his debts he is an "undischarged insolvent".  Redundancy and tautology cannot be attributed to the Legislature. When the Legislature has  used the expression "undischarged insolvent" .that expression must be given its full meaning.  A person on being adjudged insolvent remains so unless discharged in terms of the provisions of Section 41 of the Insolvency Act, either absolutely or conditionally, or in the absence of annulment as contained in Section 35 of the Insolvency Act.  [Para 18,19,20]

The High Court was not justified in holding that the expression 'undischarged insolvent'  should be understood de hors the Insolvency Act in a general sense.  [Para 22]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Compliance with mandatory provisions - Document incorporated by reference without reproducing its contents in body of petition - It forms integral part of petition - Copy of document not supplied with true copy of election petition to returned candidate - Election petition is liable to be dismissed for non-compliance of provisions of Act.

In the instant case, the document 'F' was incorporated by reference in the election petition without reproducing its contents in the body of election petition.  The document 'F' is the integral part of election petition.  It is the imperative and mandatory duty of the petitioner to supply the true copy of the election petition to the respondent No.1.  The petitioner has failed to supply copy of document "F" to the respondent along with true copy of the election petition.  Because of failure to supply the copy of "F", the copy of election petition supplied to respondent can not be said to be a true and complete copy of the election petition.  There is a clear cut infraction of mandatory provisions of law.  The law mandates that there should be strict and substantial compliance of section 81(3) of the Act of 1951.  In the instant case, there is non-compliance of section 81(3) of the Act of 1951.  Under the circumstance, the election petition is liable to be dismissed at the threshold in response to the provisions of section 86 of the Act of 1951.  [Para 23,24]

heading: Interpretation of statutes
HeadNote.description:
Representation of the People Act (1950). S.16(2) Proviso - Disqualification of member on ground of corrupt practice - Member's name deleted from electoral roll as consequence - Disqualification expiring on 18-11-97 - His name has to be reinstated immediately in the existing electoral roll - Action of authority in reinstating his name in provisional roll effective on 1-1-98 is illegal - Interpretation of statutes - Proviso. 

Where a member of parliament was disqualified for 4 years on ground of corrupt practice and his name was deleted from electoral roll as a consequence, on expiry of the disqualification on 18-11-97 his name has to be reinstated immediately in the electoral roll in existence on that date. Order of authorities to include his name in provisional roll effective form 1-1-98 is illegal.  [Para 14]

To suggest that the petitioner must wait till the new voters, list is published for his name being included, is far-fetched and may defeat the very purpose behind Section 16(2) of the 1950 Act. In the proviso, the words "shall" forthwith be reinstated in that roll, if such disqualification is, during the period such roll is in force, removed under any law authorising such "removal." Must mean that the name of the petitioner or any person similarly placed as the petitioner must be reinstated forthwith in the electoral roll which is in force as on the date the disqualification period has expired. The emphasis, therefore, must be on the words "such roll in force". Viewed in that way, it has to be held that the name of the member ought to have been reinstated forthwith in the electoral roll which is valid and in force upto 31-12-1997.  [Para 15]

The controversy in the instant case is required to be decided by interpreting the proviso read with Section 11A(2) of the 1951 Act. No doubt, the difficulties some times arise in construing a proviso, but it is generally found that inconsistencies can be avoided by applying the general rule that the words of proviso are not to be taken absolutely in their strict literal sense but that a proviso as of a necessity is limited in its operation to the ambit of section which it qualifies. If, however, the language of the proviso makes it clear that it was intended to have operation more extensive than that of the provision which it immediately follows it must be given such wider effect. If the proviso can be reasonably construed, the proviso even if contradicting the main provision will prevail on the principle that it speaks the last intention of the maker.  [Para 12]

Further the instructions issued by the Election Commission of India are in the nature of administrative instructions so as to enable the authorities concerned to conduct free and fair elections and these instructions are mere guidelines. By no stretch of imagination, such instructions can be said to have over-riding effect on the provisions of law or nullify their object intended to be achieved by the Parliament. The instructions applicable to a first time voter or a voter, whose name is missing from the voters list for any other reason than an order of disqualification in a particular electoral roll and the said guidelines do not come to the rescue of the authorities in support of their contentions that their action to include the name of the petitioner in the electoral roll effective from 1-1-1998 is legal and proper. If contention of authorities is accepted the provisions of Section 11A(2) of the 1951 Act will be rendered redundant and by implication it shall mean that the period of disqualification is extended beyond the period of four years i.e. upto 31-12-1997.  [Para 14]

heading: Election Petition
Service on respondents
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Service on respondents - Non-compliance  with provisions - Copies different from original petition - Particulars of attestation not shown in copy - Amounts to improper service - Petition liable to be dismissed.

The copy of the election petition which is required to be served on the respondent has to be a true copy i.e. a copy which is substantially a reproduction of the original and if there is omission of vital nature in the copy as compared to the original election petition, it cannot be ignored and if there is such a omission, the copy of the petition served on the respondent cannot be a true copy of the original.  The omissions consist in respect  of signature, the name as well as seal and the date of the officer before whom the election petition is said to have been verified or affirmed and all these things are conspicuously absent in the copies of the petition served on the respondents.  The failure to mention anything in this respect in the copies of the petition has deprived the respondents to know whether as a matter of fact the petitioner had verified the contents and also to know as to whether the officer before whom the petition is purported to be  verified was authorized to administer the oath.  Prejudice  is clearly caused to the Respondents.  [Para 12,13]

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Affidavit copy accompanying notice of Petition did not indicate name, designation, seal or stamp of notary - Whether  results in non-compliance of S.81(3) - Whether rule laid in (1996)5 SCC 181 is applicable - Questions referred to larger Bench. (Paras 1, 2)

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.83(1) -When no allegation of corrupt practice is made, Section 83(1)(b) does not apply
heading: Rejection of election petition at the preliminary stage on the ground that it does not contain concise statement of material facts
HeadNote.description:
Rejection of election petition at the preliminary stage on the ground that it does not contain concise statement of material facts - Not valid.

The election petition of the appellant does not allege any corrupt practice.  Therefore, in the present case, the question of application of Section 83(1)(b) does not arise.  The only relevant provision, therefore, is Section 83(1)(a) which requires the petition to contain concise statement of material facts on which the petitioner relies.  The language of Section 83(1)(a) is similar to the language of Order VI Rule 2(1) which provides that "Every pleading shall contain, and contain only, a statement in a concise from of material facts on which the party pleading relies for his claim or defence, as the case may be, but not the evidence by which they are to be proved".  By contrast under Section 83(1)(b) not only is it necessary to set out full (as opposed to concise) particulars, but also a full statement of the names of parties who have allegedly committed a corrupt practice, and the date and place of its commission.

The election petition of the appellant, from paragraph 10onwards deals with the counting of ballot papers and why according to the appellant, such counting was unfair, improper or not in accordance with law.  He has alleged that the Returning Officer did not comply with Rule 56 of the conduct of Election Rules, 1961 and the instructions contained in the Hand-Book for Returning Officers.  He has given particulars of some of the irregularities.  In paragraph 15, for example, he has alleged that on counting table Nos.11 and 12, ballot papers marked on "Hand" symbol were mixed with those of other party candidates; and in the process ballot papers which were marked on "Hand" were not being counted in favour of the appellant.  The appellant has stated that his counting agents specifically stated to him when he visited the counting hall that hundreds of such ballot papers had already been mixed with the ballot papers in favour of an independent candidate, respondent No.9.  He has alleged that 3,530 votes which should have been counted in his favour were wrongly counted in favour of respondent No.9.  He has also referred to the contemporaneous written complaints lodged by him in this connection.  In paragraph 16, detailed tables are given showing the wrong counting of votes cast in favour of the appellant which were counted as the votes of respondent No.9.  The numbers of such votes so counted on each counting table have been separately set out in tabular form in detail.  The appellant has also sought leave to refer to and rely upon the various fax messages and complaints to the Returning Officer as well as to the General Observer made in this behalf by him.  Amongst the other objections, he has alleged that at the stage of the fourth round of counting onwards, ballot papers of two different colours were seen.  Despite the appellant complaining to the Returning Officer about the different colours of ballot papers on the counting tables, no proper attention was paid to his complaint.  He has also set out that his counting agents were not given a reasonable opportunity of inspecting ballot papers before they were rejected.  There are various other particulars set out in the election petition in support of the appellant's contention regarding irregularities and illegality in the counting of votes.

Whatever be the merit of such contentions, one thing at least is clear.  The election petition cannot be rejected at a preliminary stage on the ground that it does not contain a concise statement of material facts.

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice alleged
Requirement is mandatory
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Corrupt practice alleged - Service of true copy of election petition on returned candidate - Requirement is mandatory - Copy of affidavit supplied to returned candidate without attestation - It results in non-compliance of substantial provision of S. 81(3) - Election petition is liable to be rejected.

AIR 1996 SC 1691 foll. (Para 7)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Ought to be decided with extreme alertness and quick promptitude.

An election petition has to be decided in quite promptitude as there is an obligation cast upon the Court to dispose of the same within a period of six months. Engrafting a provision in the nature of Section 86(7) of the Act, the legislative intendment is clear that the Court has to endeavour to dispose of an election petition as expeditiously as possible and not to allow the parties to take resort to unnecessary adjournments or file vexatious applications.

In the present case the elected candidate has been taking time at his own pleasure and leisure and filing applications as he desired giving vent to his whim and fancy and the Court has granted adjournment in an extremely liberal manner. All the aspects can be taken exception to and they really run counter to the conception of expeditious disposal. A voter casts his vote as a responsible citizen to choose the masters for governing the country. That being the trust of the electorate in an elected candidate, when he faces an assail to his election, it should be his sanguine effort to become free from the assail in the election petition and work with attainment and not take shelter seeking adjournments with the elated hope that he can be triumphant in the contest by passage of time. This kind of attitude has to be curbed from all angles because law does not countenance it.      [Para 14,15,19]

heading: Requisitioning of vehicle
HeadNote.description:
Requisitioning of vehicle - Direction issued by Collector to District Deputy Registrar of Co-operative Societies to instruct all societies to handover their vehicles to him and he in turn would hand over the same to Tahasildar of respective Talukas - Order passed by District Deputy Registrar directing petitioner society to hand over its vehicle to Tahasildar - No mention made that vehicles are required for election purposes nor any provision for compensation made as required by S.161 - Order cannot be sustained under S.160 and must be quashed.

By the present petition, the petitioner impugnes a direction issued by the Collector of Raigad dated 21/3/1996 directing the District Deputy Registrar of Co-operative Societies to instruct all societies to deposit their vehicles belonging to societies with him and he in turn would hand over the same to the Tahsildar of the respective Talukas. Pursuant to the above directions, the District Deputy Registrar has issued an order dated 26/3/1996 directing the petitioner society to hand over its vehicle Maruti Omni to the Tahsildar.

Held, a perusal of the order impugned in the petition shows that it is nowhere mentioned that the vehicles are required for election purposes. No provision in respect of payment of compensation as provided under S.161 has been made. The order merely requires the deposit of vehicles with the Tahsildar. The said order is not order passed under S.160 and the same is passed beyond the powers conferred on the State and its authorities. The present order is passed by District Deputy Registrar, Cooperative Societies, and not by the State Government as required under S.160. The said order in the circumstances is liable to be quashed.  [Para 4]

heading: Rejection of election petition at preliminary stage
HeadNote.description: Rejection of election petition at preliminary stage - Preliminary objection should be considered by duly observing distinction between "full particulars" and "material facts" - Petition disclosed cause of action which if unrebutted could void election - Rejection of petition at threshold without trial - Not justified. (Paras 10, 15)

heading: Election petition filed alleging certain corrupt practices against the respondents
HeadNote.description:
Election petition filed alleging certain corrupt practices against the respondents - Affidavit filed duly attested - But in the xerox copy supplied to the respondents the endorsement of verification was not found - Before preliminary objection was heard, two copies containing the endorsement of verification supplied - Held, the defect is not fatal.

Even before arguments were heard on the preliminary objection by the High Court in this case the true copies of the affidavits had been served on the first respondent and his Counsel. In the facts and circumstances of this case, it is undoubted that there was sufficient compliance of the provisions of Section 81(3) read with Section 83(1)(c) of the Act even if it could be said that the copies served in the first instance on the first respondent were not in conformity with the provisions of the Act. Unfortunately, this aspect of the matter has been completely ignored by the High Court. Hence the order of the High Court dismissing the election petition in liminae is unsustainable.

heading: Holiday for voting
Non grant of
Issuance of process
HeadNote.description: Holiday for voting - Non grant of - Issuance of process - Against directors, officers of company - Offence u/S.135-B of RP Act (1951), of not giving paid holiday on day of polling - S.135-B does not create any vicarious liability - Therefore, it cannot be held that where company, as an employer commits offence, individual director and/or its employees can be tried for offence - Issuance of process, liable to be quashed. 	(Paras 14, 16, 18)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Dismissal on preliminary issues that petition lacked in material facts as required u/S.83 (1) (a) of 1951 Act and did not disclose cause of action - High Court ventured into elaborate enquiry in the light of pleadings in replies to find out whether a cause of action made out - Issues pertained to rejection of petition at the stage of institution itself hence relatable to O.7 R.11 - Under O.7 R.11 Court required to consider pleadings of plaintiffs only - Merely because it is a trial on preliminary issues at stage of O.14, the scope does not change or expand - Stage at which such enquiry is undertaken, makes no difference as an enquiry under O.7 R.11 (a) can be taken up at any stage - And for an enquiry under O.7 R.11 (a) only pleadings of plaintiff can be look into - Therefore, approach of High Court dealing with replies filed by respondents, held erroneous - Impugned order, set aside - Matter remanded back to be considered on merits.	(Paras 6, 7, 8, 9, 13)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Non joinder of five out of seven candidates - Petition is liable to be dismissed - Petition cannot be saved by  resorting to provisions of O.6, R.17 or O.23, R.1 of Civil P.C. 

In the present case besides the petitioner and the respondent there were 5 others in the fray. Section 82 mandates that all of them must be joined in the petition, at the time when it was instituted, and by virtue of Section 86 of the Act, the Court has no option but to dismiss a petition which does not comply with the requirements of section 82 of the Act. None of the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure could be invoked with a view to defeating the provisions of the Act.

heading: Constituency reserved for Scheduled caste candidate
HeadNote.description: Constituency reserved for Scheduled caste candidate - Election petition challenging election on ground that returned candidate was not eligible to contest for that seat - Service of true copy of election petition on returned candidate - Affirmation on form of affidavit before Add. Registrar indicating different date than date on which petition is filed - Discrepancy in original and copy substantial and cannot be considered as true copy under S.81(3) - Election petition is liable to be rejected. (Para 3)

heading: Election petition
Parties
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Parties - Allegation of corrupt practices against returned candidate and person who had withdrawn his candidature - Person continues as a candidate even after his withdrawal - He ought to be joined as respondent - Plea that he had become election agent of returned candidate and was alter ego of returned candidate cannot absolve him from his liability for illegal act or offence - Plea that he could be joined at later stage,if necessary, under S.99 could not be accepted - Acceptance of such a plea would render mandatory requirement of S.82 ineffective.	(Paras 11,12,15 to 17,19)

heading: Parties to Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Parties to Election petition - Returning officer, Electoral Registration Officers and Election Commission of India - Merely by reason of certain allegations against them in petition - They do not become necessary party to petition - Concept of proper party is alien to election petition.

AIR 1982 SC 983, 1991 Supp(2) SCC 624 - Rel.on. (Para 10)

heading: Rel. on.
HeadNote.description:
Parties to election petition - Impleadment of party who was not a necessary party to election petition - Petition is not liable to be dismissed.

Those who are mentioned in S.82 of the Act must be made parties to an election petition and, if they are not, the election petition is one which does not comply with the provisions of Section 82 and must, therefore, be dismissed by reason of the terms of Section 86(1).  It does not, however, follow that if to an election petition parties other than those who are necessary parties under Section 82 have been impleaded, the election petition is one that does not comply with the provisions of Section 82 and must be dismissed.  Such a petition can be amended by striking out from the array of parties those additionally impleaded.	(1964) 3 SCR 573, (1969) 1 SCR 630, (1962) 1 SCC 691 - Rel. on.

heading: Election Petition
Relied on.			(Paras 16,19,21)
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Requirement that Petitioner to deposit security for costs in cash at the time of presenting the Petition - Though deposit mandatory, requirement mode of making deposit is directory - Word 'shall' in R.25 to be read as 'may' - Mode of deposit in cash as U/R.25 is directory - As practice in High Court to collect deposit by Advocate's cheque or Demand Draft or cash - Deposit by cheque a substantial compliance of S.117(1) & R.25 - Upon encashment of cheque, payment relates back to date on which Petition was presented.

AIR 1954 S.C. 429, AIR 1952 BOM 306, AIR 1983 S.C. 558 - Relied on.			(Paras 16,19,21)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Delay of 336 days in filing election petition - Application for condonation of delay means acceptance of fact of delay - Ss.4 to 24 of Limitation Act are not applicable to filing of election petition - Equity does not find place in filing of said petitions - Ground for delay is that petitioner was pursuing with authorities and had also filed PIL is liable to be rejected - Petition was filed beyond period prescribed in S.81 - Petition liable to be dismissed under provisions of S.86.

1974 (2) SCC 113, 1993 (1) SCC 636, 1999 (8) SCC 532 Ref. to. (Paras 19, 20)

heading: Public Interest Litigation
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Election Commission's Order No.3/4/ID/2009/SDR, dated 6th April, 2009 - Public Interest Litigation - Order permitting ration card to be taken as proof of identity of a voter - Challenge to - Held, Court would not be in a position to sit in appeal over the order passed by Election Commission, as the Election Commission must have taken all the relevant factors into consideration before passing the impugned order - If the operation of this order stayed today, it will amount to either hampering the election process itself or it will amount to depriving the sizable number of voters from casting their votes - Public Interest Litigation, dismissed.	(Para 9)

heading: Presentation of election petition
HeadNote.description:
Presentation of election petition - Election petition presented by Advocate and not by election petitioner - He was not present at time of presentation - Petition is liable to be dismissed on ground of improper presentation.

The preamble of the Representation of the People Act makes it clear that for the conduct of elections of the Houses of Parliament or the Legislature of each State, the qualification and dis-qualification for membership of those Houses, the corrupt practice and other offences in connection with such allegations the Act was enacted by the Parliament. In spite of existence of adequate provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure relating to institution of a suit, the present Act contains elaborate provisions as to disputes regarding elections. It not only prescribes how election petitions are to be presented but it also mandates what are the materials to be accompanied with the election petition, details regarding parties, contents of the same, relief that may be claimed in the petition. How trial of election petitions are to be conducted has been specifically provided in Chapter III of Part VI. In such circumstances, the provisions have to be interpreted as mentioned by the Legislature. One can discern the reason why the petition is required to be presented by the petitioner personally. An election petition is a serious matter with a variety of consequences. Since such a petition may lead to the vitiation of a democratic process, any procedure provided by an election statute must be read strictly. Therefore, the Legislature has provided that the petition must be presented "by" the petitioner himself, so that at the time of presentation, the High Court may make preliminary verification which ensure that the petition is neither frivolous nor vexatious.  1969(1) SCC 408 Distinguished.  [Para 15,16]

Inspite of provisions in CPC and Evidence Act relating to institution of suit and recording of evidence etc. this Act provides all the details starting from the presentation of the election petition ending with the decision of the High Court. In such circumstances, it is but proper to interpret the language used by the Legislature and implement the same accordingly. The challenge to an election is a serious matter. The object of presenting an election petition by a candidate or elector is to ensure genuineness and to curtail vexatious litigations. If we consider sub-section (1) along with the other provisions in Chapter II and III, the object and intent of the Legislature is that this provision i.e. Section 81(1) is to be strictly adhered to and complied with.  As per sub-section (1) of Section 81, election petition is to be presented by any candidate or elector relating to the election personally to the authorized officer of the High Court and failure to adhere such course would be contrary to the said provision and in that event the election petition is liable to be dismissed on the ground of improper presentation.  AIR 1987 Raj 63 Overruled.	 [Para 19,20]

heading: Corrupt practice
Bribery
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Bribery - Allegations levelled unbelievable and impracticable - Allegations of bribery ought to be made in a concise manner with material particulars.	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Inspection of election papers by parties - Not as a matter of course - Parties cannot be allowed to make a roving enquiry in order to fish out supporting material - Laconic and unreasoned order permitting inspection of papers cannot be allowed especially when election petition is awaiting trial and disposal.	(Paras 10, 11, 13)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description:
Election to Post of Member of Parliament - Disqualification - Holding of office of profit under Govt. - Director of Maharashtra Seeds Corporation Ltd. does not hold office of profit - Is not disqualified to be Member of Parliament - His election as M.P. cannot be quashed.

A Director, Maharashtra Seeds Corpn. Ltd. does not hold office of profit under Govt. and hence he is not disqualified to be Member of Parliament consequently his election as Member of Parliament cannot be set aside.						 [Para 20]

Perusal of the Articles of Association and Memorandum of Association and various clauses therein does not reveal that the State Government has any direct control over the functioning of the Corporation. The Articles of Association and Memorandum of Association as well as the Maharashtra State Seeds Corporation Limited (Appointment of Directors) Rules, 1977 which are approved by the Company do not also empower the State Government or the Central Government to remove the Directors of the Corporation. The major income of the Corporation is by way of sale of seeds and the Government does not advance any finance to the Corporation. The Articles of Association and Memorandum of Association of the Corporation also do not discloses that the Government has any direct control over the duties and functions of the Directors of the Corporation. No doubt Exh. the State Government has 49% shares and Central Government through National Seeds Corporation has 35.44% shares in the Corporation. But, this fact by itself would not be sufficient to hold that the State Government or the Central Government has control over the duties and functions of the Directors of the Corporation.  [Para 15]

In the present case, neither the State Government has right to remove the Director (including respondent) of the Corporation nor the Government pays any remuneration to the respondent. The functions performed by the respondent as a Director of Corporation cannot be said to be carried on by him for the Government nor the Government has control over his duties and functions.  [Para 16]

The mere fact that the respondent is a Director of the Corporation would not make him an agent of the Corporation and as such there is no question of respondent being considered as managing agent of the Corporation.  [Para 19]

Hence, he is not disqualified to be a Member of Parliament u/s.10 of Representation of the People Act.  [Para 20]

heading: Election petition
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Burden of proof - Election petition based on the contention that the successful candidate was ineligible to contest the election on the ground that she does not belong to a tribe recognised as a Scheduled Tribe - In the circumstances, it must be held that the initial burden of proving that the Respondent does not belong to a tribe recognised as a Scheduled Tribe under the Constitution (Scheduled Tribe) Order, 1950 is on the petitioner.			(Paras 7 to 9)

heading: Petition for declaring election of respondent as null and void
HeadNote.description: Petition for declaring election of respondent as null and void - It amounts to claim of petitioner that he be declared elected - In that case it was obligatory upon him to join all the contested candidates as respondents - This not having been done petition was liable to be dismissed.(Para 10)

heading: Election petition
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Limitation - Petition challenging election to Legislative Assembly or House of People, where there is single member constituency - Limitation is of 45 days from date of election - Election to Legislative Assembly - Respondent, only candidate remaining in fray on date of scrutiny - As such declared elected - Limitation starts running from date of such declaration.

S.81 is in two parts. The first parts provides that an election petition calling in question any election could be filed by a candidate or an elector within forty-five days from the date of the election of the returned candidate. The second part of Section 81 cannot apply to any election to a Legislative Assembly, but it would apply only to Legislative Council of a State or Council of States.  [Para 18,20]

Section 53 of the Act provides that if the number of candidates is equal to number of seats to be filled, the Returning Officer is required to forthwith declare such candidates to be duly elected and only in the event of contest, poll would be held.  Section 66 covers those cases where poll is felt necessary and requires the Returning Officer to declare the result of the election forthwith after counting of votes.  Thus, where in the general election to the Legislative Assembly of a State on the date of scrutiny of nomination for a constituency only one candidate was in the field and was, therefore, declared as elected by the Returning Officer as per S.53, his election can be called in question only within 45 days of such declaration.  [Para 21,22]

The submission that the limitation for filing an election petition should be reckoned not with reference to the date on which the candidate whose election is challenged was declared elected, but with reference to the date on which the last candidate was declared elected at a general election would not only make the provisions cumbersome and countrary to the provisions of the Act, particularly against the scheme of amendments introduced in 1956 and 1961 but would also make the starting point of limitation uncertain, indefinite and fluctuating.  Such construction would require complete details of all returned candidates of Legislative Assembly of a State.  Moreover, where the challenge is to an election of a Member of House of People (Lok Sabha), full particulars in different constituencies throughout the country must be before the Election Tribunal (High Court).  The Tribunal also is bound to inquire into such particulars with a view to ascertaining whether the election petition filed by the petitioner is or is not within the period specified in Section 81 of the Act.  Again, in case of dispute or contest on the issue of limitation, the Election Tribunal is required to call for and inspect records of all constituencies.  Unless compelled, a Court of law would not interpret a provision in such a way which would frustrate legislative intent and make the provision unworkable and impracticable.  [Para 30]

heading: Election petition
Pleadings
Duly nominated candidate
HeadNote.description:
Duly nominated candidate - Nomination of person rejected as he was disqualified - He cannot claim to be duly nominated as a candidate. 

The expression "claims to have been duly nominated as a candidate" in S.79(6) would not take within its fold a person whose nomination has been rejected as being disqualified. Such person cannot claim to be duly nominated as a candidate when he is not qualified to contest election. 
(1969) 1 SCR 630 Disting.        [Para 8]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Respondents nomination paper was rejected as one of the proposer's name was found to have been deleted from electoral roll - Question was about right of Proposer to be subscriber of nomination paper - Held Election Tribunal did not commit any error in dismissing the applications filed by Appellant for rejection of Election Petition filed by respondent because question whether proposer was eligible to support nomination paper could only be decided on evidence. (Para 17)

heading: Qualification for membership of the House of the People or Legislative Assembly of State
HeadNote.description: Qualification for membership of the House of the People or Legislative Assembly of State - Person who has no right to vote by virtue of S.62(5) is not an elector and is therefore not qualified to contest election.	(Para 6)

heading: Format of affidavit
HeadNote.description:
Format of affidavit - Affidavit requiring disclosure of dues, if any, payable to financial institution or the government - Affidavit clearly stating that no such dues were recoverable - Mere departure from the format would not result in rejection of nomination papers by returning officer. 

2002(3) ALL MR 228 (S.C.) - Ref. to. (Paras 14 to 16)

heading: No evidence led
HeadNote.description: Ground for declaring election to be void - Non-disclosure of information about first wife and dependent children from her and their assets and liabilities - No issue framed as to whether non-disclosure has resulted in materially affecting result of election - No evidence led - No issue framed and no opinion formed by High Court on this aspect - Election petition dismissed with costs. Quantified at Rs.1,00,000/-.  (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Corrupt practices
Allegations of
Filing of affidavit
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practices - Allegations of - Filing of affidavit - Requirement of filing affidavit as per Rule 15(4) is a requirement independent of the requirement of a separate affidavit with respect to each corrupt practice alleged, as mandated by proviso to S.83(1)(c). (Paras 23, 25)

heading: Privilege against self-incrimination
HeadNote.description:
Privilege against self-incrimination - Secrecy of election process will not stand in the way of a voter being summoned as a witness in election petition - Witness would be free to claim privilege u/s.94 and can refuse to reveal for whom he has voted - At the same time he is entitled to disclose his preference if he so desires - Hence perceived threat of self-incrimination is misconceived.

Section 94 does not provide for a total embargo on a party to an election petition to cite a voter as a witness. What is prohibited is that he cannot be required to state for whom he had voted at an election. Secrecy of ballots indisputably goes to the root of democracy, but the same may not itself be a ground to refuse issue of summons to the witnesses, Section 94 of the Act merely confers a privilege upon a voter.  He may even waive his right. It is not in dispute that any person can be produced as a witness by the parties to an election petition. Witnesses so produced on behalf of the parties without any summons being issued would be at liberty to disclose in the court as to in whose favour he had exercised his right of franchise. It is, therefore, evident that the question as to whether a witness will exercise his right/privilege conferred in terms of Section 94 of the Act is a matter of volition. It is one thing to say that the civil court while issuing a summon must exercise its jurisdiction in terms of sub-rule (2) of Rule 1 of Order XVI of the Code of Civil Procedure but it is another thing to say that the court would refuse to summon the witness only because a question as regard exercise of the privilege of the witness may arise. The court may not refuse to exercise its jurisdiction only on the ground that by reason thereof the privilege of a voter may be violated.  					 [Para 12,13,14]

Sub-Rule 2 of Rule 1 of Order XVI of the Code of Civil Procedure indisputably requires the party to file an application for obtaining any summons for the attendance of any person stating therein the purpose therefor; but the same would not mean that the court would refuse to exercise its jurisdiction only because, one of the purposes disclosed may be that the witness may be asked a question as to in whose favour he had exercised his right of franchise. The purpose which is required to be disclosed in such an application for summoning a witness is only with a view to apprise the court as to whether the evidence which may be adduced, would be relevant for the purpose of determining the issues and not for any other purpose.   [Para 16]

The privilege against self-incrimination is to be claimed by the witness. The right becomes available, only after the witness has taken the stand and a question that offends the privilege is put to him. A prospective witness or some other person (as in the present case, cannot raise such an issue in anticipation of an apprehended breach of privilege against self-incrimination.   [Para 27]

heading: Election petition
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Burden of proof - Petitioner making allegation against Respondent of filing false affidavit - Held, it was incumbent upon petitioner to prove falsity of said Affidavit by giving material particulars which is the basic requirement in so far as an election petition is concerned. AIR 1986 SC 1253 - Ref. to.	(Para 17)

heading: Right to information
HeadNote.description:
Right to information - Security of nomination paper - Right to know about candidate is integral part of Art.19(1)(a) - Filing of affidavit with blank particulars will render affidavit nugatory - If candidate does not fill blanks even after reminding him, his nomination paper is fit to be rejected - If nomination paper itself is rejected candidate need not be prosecuted further under S.125A. 

The voter has the elementary right to know full particulars of a candidate who is to represent him in the Parliament/Assemblies and such right to get information is universally recognized. Thus, it is held that right to know about the candidate is a natural right flowing from the concept of democracy and is an integral part of Article 19(1) (a) of the Constitution. The ultimate purpose of filing of affidavit along with the nomination paper is to effectuate the fundamental right of the citizens under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution of India. The citizens are supposed to have the necessary information at the time of filing of nomination paper and for that purpose, the Returning Officer can very well compel a candidate to furnish the relevant information. Filing of affidavit with blank particulars will render the affidavit nugatory. It is the duty of the Returning Officer to check whether the information required is fully furnished at the time of filing of affidavit with the nomination paper since such information is very vital for giving effect to the 'right to know' of the citizens. If a candidate fails to fill the blanks even after the reminder by the Returning Officer, the nomination paper is fit to be rejected. The power of Returning Officer to reject the nomination paper must be exercised very sparingly but the bar should not be laid so high that the justice itself is prejudiced. The candidate must take the minimum effort to explicitly remark as 'NIL' or 'Not Applicable' or 'Not known' in the columns and not to leave the particulars blank. Filing of affidavit with blanks will be directly hit by Section 125A(i) of the RP Act However, as the nomination paper itself is rejected by the Returning Officer, there is no reason why the candidate must be again penalized for the same act by prosecuting him/her.
(2003) 4 SCC 399 Explained.      [Para 27]

heading: Election petition on ground that Returning Officer had wrongly rejected nomination paper
HeadNote.description:
Election petition on ground that Returning Officer had wrongly rejected nomination paper - Petition withdrawn by petitioner - Once petition was withdrawn, it could not have been continued by substituting any one in his place - Election petition filed was an action in personam and was, therefore, confined to his own situation. 

In the instant case, the complaint in the Election Petition was that the nomination paper of the Election Petitioner had been wrongly rejected by the Returning Officer. The Respondent herein, who had been substituted in his place, did not have the same interest and, accordingly, the High Court misconstrued the provisions of Section 110(3)(c) of the 1951 Act in applying the conditions literally, without even satisfying itself that the order fit in the facts of the case.  [Para 15,16]

heading: Election
Non-disclosure of information
HeadNote.description:
Election - Non-disclosure of information - Non-disclosure about Government dues, of bungalow in name of spouse and outstanding taxes of vehicle owned by wife, of property purchased in name of firm - Stage at which nomination paper can be rejected on ground of non-disclosure of information in affidavit. 

The citizens have fundamental right under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution of India to know about the candidates contesting the elections and this is the primary reason that casts a solemn obligation on these candidates to furnish information regarding the criminal antecedents, educational qualifications and assets held by the candidate, his spouse and dependent children. It is on that basis that not only Election Commission has issued guidelines, but also prepared formats in which the affidavits are to be filed. As a fortiorari, it follows that if the required information as per the said format in respect of the assets of the candidate, his wife and dependent children is not given, it would amount to suppression/non-disclosure.      

When the information is given by a candidate in the affidavit filed along with the nomination paper and objections are raised thereto questioning the correctness of the information or alleging that there is non-disclosure of certain important information, it may not be possible for the returning officer at that time to conduct a detailed examination. Summary enquiry may not suffice. Present case is itself an example which loudly demonstrates this. At the same time, it would not be possible for the Returning Officer to reject the nomination for want of verification about the allegations made by the objector. In such a case, when ultimately it is proved that it was a case of non-disclosure and either the affidavit was false or it did not contain complete information leading to suppression, it can be held at that stage that the nomination was improperly accepted. The grounds stated in Section 36(2) are those which can be examined there and then and on that basis the Returning Officer would be in a position to reject the nomination. Likewise, where the blanks are left in an affidavit, nomination can be rejected there and then. In other cases where detailed enquiry is needed, it would depend upon the outcome thereof, in an election petition, as to whether the nomination was properly accepted or it was a case of improper acceptance. Once it is found that it was a case of improper acceptance, as there was misinformation or suppression of material information, one can state that question of rejection in such a case was only deferred to a later date. When the Court gives such a finding, which would have resulted in rejection, the effect would be same, namely, such a candidate was not entitled to contest and the election is void. Otherwise, it would be an anomalous situation that even when criminal proceedings under Section 125A of the Act can be initiated and the selected candidate is criminally prosecuted and convicted, but the result of his election cannot be questioned. This cannot be countenanced.		     [Para 38]

Insofar as non-disclosure of the electricity dues is concerned, in the given facts of the case, it may not be a serious lapse. No doubt, the dues were outstanding, at the same time, there was a bona fide dispute about the outstanding dues in respect of the first electricity meter. When the appellant nurtured belief in a bona fide manner that because of the said dispute he is not to give the information about the outstanding amount, as it had not become 'payable', this should not be treated as a material lapse. Likewise, as far as the second electricity meter is concerned, it was in the premises which was rented out to the tenants and the dues were payable by the tenants in the first instance. Again, in such circumstances, one can bona fide believe that the tenants would pay the outstanding amount. No doubt, if the tenants do not pay the amount the liability would have been that of the owner, i.e. the appellant. However, at the time of filing the nomination, the appellant could not presume that the tenants would not pay the amount and, therefore, it had become his liability. Same is the position with regard to non-payment of a sum of Rs.1,783/- as outstanding municipal dues, where there was a genuine dispute as to revaluation and reassessment for the purpose of assessing the taxes was yet to be undertaken. It would depend in the facts and circumstances of each case as to whether such a non-disclosure would amount to material lapse or not. Even if it is so, in respect of the aforesaid aspects, on other nondisclosures, the case of the appellant has to fail. It is clear case of non-disclosure of bungalow in the name of the appellant's wife, which is a substantial lapse. So is the case about the nondisclosure of vehicle in the name of appellant's wife. Likewise, nondisclosure of the appellant's interest/share in the partnership firm is a very serious and major lapse. On all these aspects, the defence/explanation furnished by the appellant does not inspire any confidence. It is simply an afterthought attempt to wriggle out of the material lapse on the part of the appellant in not disclosing the required information, which was substantial. In the affidavits given by the appellant along with the nomination form, material information about the assets was not disclosed and, therefore, it is not possible to accept the argument of the appellant that information contained in the affidavits be treated as sufficient/substantial compliance.  [Para 34,35]

heading: Office of profit
HeadNote.description: Haj Committee Rules (2002), R.11 - Office of profit - Chairperson of State Haj Committee for Kerala - Receiving only compensatory allowances by way of TA and DA for attending meetings - Post did not carry any other benefit 'receivable' by chairperson - Held, chairperson of Kerala Haj Committee was not disqualified to contest election. (Paras 12, 20)

heading: Election petition
Expeditious disposal of
Is mandatory
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Expeditious disposal of - Is mandatory - Necessity of creating dedicated Benches in each High Court by Chief Justice to deal with election petitions, exclusively emphasized.

Membership of the Legislative bodies under the scheme of our constitution is a sacred responsibility. The continuance of any member in such bodies who secured his election to such a body by legally impermissible means even for a day is most undesirable. Such continuance affords an opportunity to such a member to take part in the law making process affecting the destinies of the people.

 Even from the point of view of the contesting candidates, unless the rights and the obligations are decided within a reasonable time, the adjudication and the consequences of the adjudication may eventually remain on paper without any tangible effect insofar as the participation of such parties in the legislative process. 			    [Para 12]

The stakes are very high for the parties. Nothing short of the membership of a constitutional body for a limited period. The power and glory that go with such membership is too high and valuable and the returned candidates naturally leave no stone unturned for protracting the litigation as long as possible.

The law of elections and election disputes is highly technical. Therefore, there is always scope for lot of objections and cross-objections regarding every step in the conduct of the election petition.

 The absence of dedicated Benches in the High Court for resolution of the election disputes is another factor which contributes enormously to the delay in the adjudicatory process. 

It is not possible for laying down any absolute rules in this regard. Essentially it is for a Chief Justice of the High Court to run the administration and devise ways and means for expeditiously disposing of the cases brought before the High Court. The kind of delay in the adjudication of election disputes exposes the High Court's unpleasant criticism damaging the credibility of the institution. A situation which is certainly required to be avoided at any cost. 				          [Para 13,14]

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Petition filed challenging election to Maharashtra Legislative Assembly Constituency - On ground that respondent-returned candidate is engaged in corrupt practice of spreading rumour about candidature of petitioner - Petitioner stated that it has affected results of election - But, petitioner failed to produce documents to prove alleged corrupt practice and made only vague allegations - Also, there is no compliance with provisions of Ss.81, 82 - Petition liable to be dismissed. (Paras 14, 15, 19)

heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Expression "result of election materially affected" - Meaning of - Improper acceptance of nomination of candidate - Petitioner unable to prove how far result of returned candidate had benefited by improper acceptance of nomination of candidate - Petition liable to be dismissed.

The law as regards the result of election having been materially affected in case of improper acceptance of nomination may be summed up as under :-

1. 	A case of result of the election, in so far as it concerns the returned candidate, having been materially affected by the improper acceptance of any nomination, within the meaning of Section 100(1) (d) (i) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 has to be made out by raising specific pleadings setting out all material facts and adducing cogent evidence so as to enable a clear finding being arrived  at on the distribution of wasted votes,that is the manner in which the votes would have been distributed if the candidate, whose nomination paper was improperly accepted, was not in the fray.

2. 	Merely because the wasted votes are more than the difference of votes secured by the returned candidate and the candidate securing the next highest number of votes, an inference as to the result of the election having been materially affected cannot necessarily be drawn. The issue is one of fact and the onus of proving it lies upon the petitioner.

3. 	The burden of proving such material effect has to be discharged by the election petitioner by adducing positive, satisfactory and cogent evidence. If the petitioner is unable to adduce such evidence the burden is not discharged and the election must stand. This rule may operate harshly upon the petitioner seeking to set aside the election on the ground of improper acceptance of a nomination paper, but the Court is not concerned with the inconvenience result ing from the operation of the law. Difficulty of proof cannot obviate the need of strict proof or relax the rigour of required proof.

4. 	The burden of proof placed on the election petitioner is very strict and so difficult to discharge as nearing almost an impossibility. There is no room for any-guesswork, speculation, surmises or conjectures i.e. acting on a mere possibility. It will not suffice merely to say that all or majority of wasted votes might have gone to the next highest candidate. The law requires proof. How far that proof should go or what it should contain is not provided by the legislature.

5. 	The casting of votes at an election depends upon a variety of factors and it is not possible for any one to predicate how many or which proportion of the votes will go to one or the other of the candidates. It is not permissible to accept the 'ipse dixit' of witness coming from one side or the other to say that all or some of the votes would have gone to one or the other on some supposed or imaginary ground.			 [Para 16]

heading: Election Petition
Amendment application
Amendment allowed
Rel.on. (Paras 8,11,12)
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Amendment application - Application seeking change of name of respondent in cause title - In body of petition correct name of respondent mentioned - Error of name in cause title a typographical error - Amendment allowed - Contention that petition not as per Form No.12 - Unsustainable.

Bombay High Court (Original Side) Rules (1980), R.126, Form No. 12.

1995 Supp. (3) SCC 407 - Rel.on. (Paras 8,11,12)

heading: Current electoral roll
HeadNote.description: Current electoral roll - Filing with nomination paper - On date of scrutiny latest electoral roll of 1998 not filed by respondent - One that was filed was of 1995 - Respondent was not present at time of scrutiny - Held, rejection of his nomination paper was not incorrect and election of appellant was valid and could not be set aside - Appellant was entitled to remuneration for entire period for which he was elected. (Paras 15, 16)

heading: Withdrawal of nomination
HeadNote.description:
Withdrawal of nomination - Neither made by candidate nor by his proposer or his election agent - Request of withdrawal made to Returning Officer by some other person on phone - Acceptance of withdrawal in total non-compliance with requirements of S.37 affected result of election materially - Specially when there were only two candidates, alert and careful exercise of powers u/S.37 gained more importance - Election of returned candidate validly set aside u/S.100(1)(d) - No interference.

	In the instant case, neither the candidate delivered the notice of withdrawal nor his proposer nor his election agent and there was no authorisation for the same to the proposer or election agent. To elucidate, if the candidate gives the notice himself ascribing to it, there can be no confusion. The only thing that the Returning Officer has to see is to verify the identity of the candidate and genuineness of the signature. The other two categories who can issue the notice has to satisfy certain conditions precedent. The notice has to be in writing, the proposer or the election agent must be in that capacity and they must have been authorised in this behalf in writing by such candidate. In the present case, there has been total non-compliance of Section 37 of the Act.	 [Para 22]

	As the provision would reflect, the legislature has provided number of safeguards before exercising the authority for acceptance of withdrawal of a candidate. The language employed in Section 37 of the Act is absolutely plain, unambiguous and unequivocal. It only admits of a singular interpretation. It is because the intention of the Parliament is that due care and caution has to be taken in letter and spirit so that no confusion is created. The issue of alert and careful exercise gains more significance when there are two candidates and that too from two National Parties.	 [Para 41]

	When in transgression of the statutory provision, a candidate's candidature is allowed to be withdrawn, it will tantamount to sacrilege of democracy. That is why, the mandate of Section 37 of the Act has been so carefully worded. The legislature has taken pains to provide safeguards since illegal acceptance of withdrawal has the potentiality to destroy the base of democracy and corrode its primary roots. The responsibility of a returning officer being statutorily significant, he has to keep himself alive to every facet and not act in a manner that will create a dent or hollowness in the election process.	 [Para 42]

	The High Court had opined that the election had been materially affected and accordingly declared the election result dated 15.03.2014 as void under Section 100(1)(d)(iv) of the Act. In view of the aforesaid, there is no merit in this appeal and the same stands dismissed. 

2002(3) ALL MR 228 (S.C.), 2002(1) ALL MR 650 (S.C.), 2016 ALL SCR 2230, AIR 1954 SC 510, AIR 1957 SC 242, AIR 1969 SC 604 Ref. to.	 [Para 15,43]

heading: Holding of bye-election
HeadNote.description: Holding of bye-election - On account of vacancy occurred due to resignation given by elected candidate - Justifiability in view of upcoming General elections in June 2019 - Resignation tendered on 8/12/2017 - Command of S.151A of RP Act is to hold election within period of 6 months from date of occurrence of vacancy - Vacancy occurred when resignation accepted by Loksabha Speaker i.e. on 14/12/2017 - Next General election to Lok Sabha is in June, 2019 - Thus, remainder of term for new incumbent is not less than 1 yr. - Ground raised that code of conduct would come into play before elections are held in June, 2019, is sans substance as RP Act does not contemplate so - It is period alone that should be governing factor subject to pendency of election petition - Therefore, rejection of petition challenging conduct of bye-election, held proper.  (2011) 1 SCC 370 Ref. to. 			(Paras 10, 16)

heading: Rejection of ballot papers
HeadNote.description: Rejection of ballot papers - Polling Officer stating that wrong seal was used for stamping ballot papers for the first one and half hours - On detection of mistake wrong seal was withdrawn and correct seal was provided - Only 90 ballot papers out of 440 papers were marked by wrong seal - Statement of Polling officer fully supported by circumstances and bald statement made by Returning officer that it was not due to fault that wrong seal was provided because other ballot papers were marked by correct seal without making any enquiry is vitiated - Wrongly rejected ballot-papers by the Returning Officer are required to be counted in favour of petitioners as per instructions of Election Commissioner.	(Paras 13,15,17)

heading: Opportunity of hearing
HeadNote.description: Registration of political party - Opportunity of hearing - Party formed on 23/12/2004 to the extent of State of Maharashtra - Proposal for registration of said party to expand its activities throughout nation made on 25.11.2008 - Rejection, on ground that application is time barred as date of formation of said party is 23.12.2004 - No opportunity of hearing given to petitioner while taking such decision - Election Commission u/S.29A of RP Act is required to act judicially and act of Commission has to be quasi-judicial - Impugned decision quashed with direction to reconsider representation of petitioner afresh. (2002) 5 SCC 685 Rel. on.	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Election petition
Provision is mandatory
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Furnishing true copy of election petition and affidavit - Provision is mandatory - Variance between description of affirming authority in original and its copy and omission to state in affidavit whether it has been affirmed or not - Is a serious and gravest lacuna - Petition is liable to be dismissed.

The expression appearing in S.81(3) viz "shall be accompanied" and "shall be attested" would show that the said requirements are mandatory. It mandates in the first instance furnishing as many copies of the petition as there are respondents mentioned in the petition. Further the copy to be furnished should be so true that nobody can by any possibility misunderstand it or get misled. A true copy means a copy which is wholly and substantially the same as original. When the copy served contains clerical or typing mistakes which are of no consequences, then the same cannot be regarded as lethal flaws warranting dismissal of the petition. But if the copy contains important omissions and substantial variance, then it would amount to non-compliance of the statutory provisions. It is also accepted principle in the context of dispute pertaining to the election under the provisions of the said Act that the concept of substantial compliance cannot be extended so far as to include serious or vital mistakes which shed the character of true copy.

1996(2) ALL MR 246  Relied on.  [Para 48]

In this case there is variance between the description of the affirming authority mentioned in the copy accompanying the petition and that which appears in the original. In that, in the original it is shown that the affirmation has been done before the Second Assistant Master, High Court Bombay, whereas the copy furnished to the 1st respondent shows that affirmation in fact has been done before the Associate High Court Bombay. This would clearly show that while furnishing the copy of the petition and the accompanying affidavit to the petition no care was taken for proper and due compliance of the statutory provisions. In any event such mistakes cannot be said and regarded as being trivial and inconsequential. The proper description of the authority before whom the affidavit or for that matter the petition are verified is must so that the opposite party to whom the copy thereof is served would know what is the real and true position. In any event the Statute makes it imperative that copy of the petition to be served upon the opposite party has to be true copy. The statute also requires the due and proper attestation of each copies and this is done to ensure that copy of the petition furnished and served to the opposite party is a real and true copy in a sense as is contemplated by the Statute.

AIR  1955  SC   610   Distinguished.  [Para 49]

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Charge of corrupt practice - Furnishing true copy of election petition to respondent - Copy of affidavit furnished not mentioning name and designation of authority before whom it was sworn and whether it has been affirmed or not - Held petition was liable to be dismissed.

Section 81(3) mandates furnishing of true copy of the election petition. True copy implies that the copy furnished must be the exact true copy of the original. The omission of conveying the authority before whom the affidavit has been affirmed in a copy of affidavit furnished is a most vital part of the affidavit and copy of affidavit with such omission cannot be said to be a true copy of the original affidavit.  [Para 36]

Therefore, in the instant case, the petitioner having failed to furnish to the respondent true copy of the affidavit filed in support of the allegation of corrupt practices the same amounts to clear non-compliance and non-observance of statutory provisions. The same is very crucial and fatal in the context. The result inevitable is that the petition suffers from serious and fatal lacuna and consequently same is required to be dismissed.

AIR 1978 SC 840, AIR 1984 SC 305, AIR 1992 Bom 227 Rel. on. AIR 1973 Bom 105, AIR 1973 P & H 431 Disting.  [Para 37]

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Death of independent candidate after publication of list of contesting candidates in S.38 - No cognizance can be taken by Returning Officer by invoking S.52 viz. postponement of election. 

The Representation of the People Act (1951) is complete and self-contained code within which the rights claimed in relation to an election or election dispute must be found. Section 52, after its substitution by Act 21 of 1996, takes cognizance of a death of a candidate of the recognized political party before poll and not the other two categories of the candidates classified in Section 38, namely (one) candidates of registered political parties other than the candidates of recognized political parties and (two) other candidates (which includes independent candidates). Thus, the electoral law as enacted in 1951 Act does not contemplate cognizance of the death of an independent candidate after publication of list of contesting candidates in Section 38. Section 52 enjoins that if a candidate set up by recognized political party dies before the poll, the poll must be adjourned; it does not provide any obligation on the returning officer if a candidate of a registered political party other than recognized political party or an independent candidate dies after the list of the contesting candidates as defined in Section 38 is published.  [Para 18,19,20,23]

Paras 4.14; 6.1, 8.1 and 8.2 of Handbook for Returning Officers (at elections where electronic voting machines are used) issued by the Election Commission of India in 2009 cannot be relied upon

2012 (1) SCC 762 Rel. on.  [Para 24,26]

heading: Recrimination petition
14 days limitation
Is mandatory
HeadNote.description: Recrimination petition - 14 days limitation - Is mandatory - S.5 of Limitation Act does not apply - Period of 14 days starts from date fixed for respondent to appear before High Court - Once party appeared and contested matter to say that it was not duty served for want of summons as contemplated under relevant rule is unacceptable. 			 (Paras 15, 19, 23, 26)

heading: Election petition
Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Rejection of - On ground that appellant has no locus to challenge election of respondent - As per S.81 of Representation of the People Act, election petition may be presented by any elector or any candidate at such election - Appellant was not elector as he is enrolled as elector from another constituency - He was also not candidate as his nomination paper was rejected on ground that it was not accompanied by certificate that his dismissal from service was not on ground of corruption or disloyalty to State as required by S.33(3) - Plea of candidate that he was not given time as required by proviso to S.36(5) to rectify nomination paper, not tenable - As candidate did not possess required certificate on date of filing of nomination, at time of scrutiny, on next day but one following date fixed for scrutiny or even at time of filing election petition - Appellant therefore has no locus to challenge election of respondent - Rejection of election petition, proper. 1983 ALLMR ONLINE 547 (S.C.) Foll. (Paras 12, 14, 15, 16, 19, 20, 22, 23, 24)

heading: Election petition
Application for rejection
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Application for rejection - Ground of failure to disclose cause of action - Election petition challenging election of Corporator of Bombay Municipal Corporation stating that he furnished false information regarding pending criminal cases against him - No allegation in petition that Corporator was accused of any offence punishable for imprisonment of 2 years or more in pending case at time of filing nomination - Nor any charge has been framed against him - Failure to plead these material facts amounts to failure to disclose cause of action - No other ground raised to challenge election - Election petition liable to be rejected.			(Paras 10, 12, 15, 16)

heading: Giving false evidence
Prosecution for
Election petition
HeadNote.description: Giving false evidence - Prosecution for - Election petition - Direction by High Court to initiate prosecution of appellant-Returning Officer for giving false evidence - High Court had not pointed out any deliberate or intentional falsehood arising from evidence of appellant - Mere reference to inconsistent statements by appellant and Election petitioner, not sufficient to take action unless definite finding is given that they are irreconcilable, one is opposed to other so as to make one of them deliberately false - Nothing on record to indicate that appellant uttered falsehood intentionally and deliberately before Court so as to initiate action u/S.193 - Moreover, appellant was not party respondent to election petition, but was examined as witness by election petitioner - No application filed by petitioner u/S.340 of Cr.P.C., seeking action - Appellant was not put on notice on allegation of committing perjury nor opportunity provided him or High Court came to conclusion that one of versions is deliberate or intentional falsehood and therefore, action is necessary to be taken against him - Only certain observations made while passing final order and Registrar General directed to file complaint - Held, in facts direction of High Court liable to be set aside. (Paras 11, 12, 16, 18, 19)

heading: Grampanchayat elections
HeadNote.description: Grampanchayat elections - Rejection of nomination form - On ground that petitioner had not completed age of 20 years therefore not qualified for contesting elections - Returning officer considered age of petitioner mentioned in voters list - Law does not independently require that age mentioned in voters list should be taken in to consideration for eligibility of candidate to participate in election on ground of age - Date of birth of petitioner going by transfer certificate produced by her was of year 1998 and she was 22 years and 7 months old - Order rejecting nomination form liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Grampanchayat elections
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Grampanchayat elections - Rejection of nomination form - On ground that petitioner had tendered passbook of bank account which was old one - Petitioner alleging that she had opened new account and was even ready with passbook to be tendered before returning officer - But there is no proof of it - Petitioner also alleged that returning officer refused to accept new passbook - It is disputed fact which cannot be gone into present matter - Order rejecting nomination form, proper. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Disqualification
To contest election
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - To contest election - For having more than two children - Cut off date for restraining birth of children beyond two is 12.09.2000 - Petitioner, elected representative has shown to have five children with gap of two years in 1994, 1996, 1998 and last twins born in 2000 - It is apparent that manipulations are done by husband of petitioner by issuing five birth certificates on single day - Birth date of last twin children with changed name are shown as 10.12.2000 though they are actually born on 24.06.2006 - Thereby their age increased by six years indicating them to be 19 years and 3 months today, when they are 13 years and 9 months old and are studying presently in 8th Standard - Petitioner and her husband have not only abused process of law but also shown scant respect to majesty of law and have manipulated Govt officials - Disqualification, proper. 	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description: Election - Challenge on ground that appellant-elected candidate being a Muslim, is not member of scheduled caste (SC) and not qualified to contest election from a constituency reserved for SC - Appellant was born to Muslim parents but he had embraced Sikhism - His family though followed Islam but he belonged to "Dhoom" community, a Scheduled caste in Punjab - Caste certificate obtained after his conversion to Sikhism, was not cancelled - Change of name, not necessary after change of religion - Moreover, appellants statement regarding conversion of religion, is fully corroborated by statements of witnesses - Therefore, election of appellant sustained. (1976) 3 SCC 411, (1984) 2 SCC 112, (1984) 2 SCC 91 Rel. on. 	(Paras 22, 24)

heading: Introduction of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs)
HeadNote.description: Introduction of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) - Making election system more transparent by appraising voter that his vote has been rightly registered and the same will be deposited in a box which can only be used by ECI in case of election disputes - Court directed introduction of a viable Voter Verifiable Paper Audit Trail (VVPAT) system as a part of presently used EVMs to make election system more transparent. 			(Paras 28, 29, 30, 31)

heading: Contents of petition
Section is mandatory
HeadNote.description:
