Contents of petition - Section is mandatory - Full particulars of alleged corrupt practice must be provided.

The corrupt practice must be pleaded as a material fact and all necessary particulars must be given in detail as provided in Section 83 of the Representation of the People Act, which has been held to be mandatory in nature.  It is also well settled that the right to challenge an election is neither a fundamental right nor a right in common law.  It is a statutory right provided by the Representation of the People Act, 1951.  When the law says that all necessary particulars of corrupt practice must be pleaded, then if there is no such pleading as provided in Section 83 of the Representation of the People Act, then election petition is liable to be rejected summarily. 

AIR 1986 SC 1253, AIR 1995 SC 2284, AIR 1969 SC 1201 Rel. on.  [Para 5]

heading: Corrupt Practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt Practice - Distribution of goggles and money - Amount involved, date, place and names of recipients not furnished - Held ground of corrupt practice was not made out. (Para 7)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Allegation that respondent indulged in terrorism - No  particulars furnished about type of terrorist activities and date and place where it was practiced - Complaints not made by any of the other 14 Candidates who contested election - Held such bald and vague allegation of terror spread in whole of the constituency could not be sustained. (Para 14)

heading: Corrupt practice
Threat to voters
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Threat to voters - Amounts to corrupt practice - It must, however, be substantiated by particulars of threat.

12 ELR 378, 20 ELR  443 Rel. on. (Para 14)

heading: Corrupt practice
Terrorist activities
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Terrorist activities - Nature of proof required.

There should be particulars to show as to in what village and on what date the terrorist activities took place. It has to be shown whether it is actually done by the respondent or his agents or friends, and if so, the names of agents and friends should be mentioned in the pleadings. Then the nature of the terrorist activities must be pleaded, whether it was in the form of a public speech holding out threats to the voters that voters will be punished if they do not vote for him. It could be in the form of a video cassette or audio cassette or it may be a case of threatening voters by going to the house of each voter.  [Para 12]

heading: Amendment of petition
HeadNote.description: Amendment of petition - Issues framed and trial commencing - Application made when case had reached stage of hearing - Amendment cannot be allowed. (Para 13)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Allegation of bogus voting on large scale - Details about names of bogus voters, of polling stations, of voters who were prevented from voting and of govt servants who facilitated bogus voting not furnished - Allegations in absence of relevant particulars must be summarily rejected. (Para 15)

heading: Details how was it done, are not given
HeadNote.description: Details how was it done, are not given - Information received is hearsay as no source is disclosed - Names of persons committing this corrupt practice are absent - Allegations in petition speak only about plan but do not state its execution - No facts disclosed to constitute cause of action - Petition liable to be rejected. AIR 1987 SC 1926, AIR 1986 SC 1253, AIR 1987 SC 1577, AIR 2000 SC 694, AIR 2000 SC 894, 2007 SCC 617, AIR 2001 SC 3689, 2009 (9) SCC 310 Referred. (Para 40 to 44)

heading: No pleadings as to how many and which booths were captured
HeadNote.description: No pleadings as to how many and which booths were captured - Names of persons who gave information are missing - Material facts, particulars not given - Petition liable to be rejected. AIR 1987 SC 1926, AIR 1986 SC 1253, AIR 1987 SC1577, AIR 2000 SC 694, AIR 2000 SC 894, 2007 SCC 617, AIR 2001 SC 3689, 2009 (9) SCC 310 Referred. 			(Para 45)

heading: Improper reception of votes
HeadNote.description: Improper reception of votes - No details as to how many voters were there and who polled without EPIC - No pleading that voters who possessed EPIC were only allowed to vote - No pleading as to how many votes were improperly accepted - There is huge gap of more than 74000 votes between respondent and petitioner - It cannot be construed that election of petitioners was materially affected - Material facts not disclosed and cause of action could not be made out - Petition is liable to be rejected. AIR 1987 SC 1926, AIR 1986 SC 1253, AIR 1987 SC 1577, AIR 2000 SC 694, AIR 2000 SC 894, 2007 SCC 617, AIR 2001 SC 3689, 2009 (9) SCC 310 Referred. 	(Para 46, 47)

heading: Procedure
Non compliance of
HeadNote.description: Procedure - Non compliance of - Verification of pleadings is not as per Rule 94 A - Schedule annexed to petition are not in Form no. 25 - Affidavit in respect of corrupt practices and particular is not in prescribed form - Apparent non compliance of procedure under S. 83 - Petition liable to be dismissed. (Para 48)

heading: Election petition
Withdrawal of
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Withdrawal of - Scope and applicability of S.23 - S.23 of Civil P.C. would be inapplicable as far as withdrawal of election petition is concerned in view of special provision having been made by S.109 of the Act.

Although the procedure to be followed in an election petition, is set out by Section 87 of the Act, Section 23, C.P.C. would be inapplicable as far as withdrawal is concerned in view of special provision having been made by Section 109 of the Act. In other words, Order 23, Rule 1, C.P.C. would have applied to an election petition but for the provision of Section 109 contained in Chapter IV of the Act. Order 23, Rule 1, gives absolute right to the plaintiff to withdraw. Section 109 of the Act, does not, and that is because an election petition is seen as a matter not only between candidates who contested the election against each other but also the voters of the constituency who also have a substantial interest in an election petition as an election is an essential part of democratic process. That is why the right to withdraw is circumscribed. Citizens at large have also an interest in seeing that all elections are fair and free and not vitiated by corrupt practices and that is why provision is also made for substitution of one Petitioner by another. Section 98 and Section 109 of the Act are entirely different provisions, applicable to different situations, and placed by the legislature in different Chapters. One is not controlled by the other. The purposes to be served by the said provisions are distinct and different, both can stand together as there is no disharmony between them.  AIR 1984 SC 135 - Ref. to.						 [Para 11]

heading: Costs
HeadNote.description:
Costs - Administration of justice is the sovereign function of the State but State does incur lot of expenditure of public money for maintenance of Courts, by way of salary to Judges, staff, buildings, stationery, electricity, water, etc. - Every citizen has right to use Court's time but not to waste or misuse it - Those who waste or misuse must pay for it - This is one of the causes which delays the disposal of cases.

Section 35 Civil P.C. deals with costs. Sub-Section (1) provides that subject to such conditions and limitations as may be prescribed, and to the provisions of any law for the time being in force, the costs of and incident to all suits shall be in the discretion of the Court, and the Court shall have full power to determine by whom or out of what property and to what extent such costs are to be paid, and to give all necessary directions for the purposes aforesaid. The fact that the Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit shall be no bar to the exercise of such powers. Sub-Section (2) provides that where the Court directs that any costs shall not follow the event, the Court shall state its reasons in writing.

Section 119 of the Act also deals with costs. That again is another special provision made in the Act. It states that the costs shall be in the discretion of the High Court:

Provided that where a petition is dismissed under clause (a) of section 98, the returned candidate shall be entitled to the costs incurred by him in contesting the petition and accordingly the High Court shall make an order for costs in favour of the returned candidate.

No doubt, the administration of justice is the sovereign function of the State but the State does incur lot of expenditure of public money for maintenance of Courts, by way of salary of Judges, staff, buildings, stationery, electricity, water, etc. State is run by taxes paid by the citizens. Court time is precious. Use of Court time by one has the effect on the availability of it for use of others. Time taken in this petition could have been utilized to dispose off other cases. True, every citizen has right to use Court's time but not to waste or misuse it. Those who waste or misuse must pay for it. This is one of the causes which delays the disposal of cases.  2009(4) ALL MR 370 - Rel. on. 					 [Para 13]

heading: Followed.			(Paras 14, 15)
HeadNote.description: Corrupt Practice of 'bribery' - Political party workers found distributing money to voters - Secretary of petitioner's party witnessed distribution of cash - 3 Persons along with cash and vehicle were arrested on spot - FIR registered and investigation going on - Arrest and cash distribution was reported in news paper - This amounts to disclosure of material facts relating to corrupt practices as per S.83 - Particulars as consent of respondent no.1 to distribute cash, who were voters etc requires evidence to be led in trial - Concise statement of material facts produced - Petition is not liable to be dismissed. 2009(10) SCC 541 - Followed.			(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Undue influence
Followed.			(Paras 21, 22)
HeadNote.description: Undue influence - Allegations that pamphlets showing that petitioner's party leaders appealing to vote for respondent no.1 rival party candidate were circulated - Names of persons influenced by pamphlets, consent of respondent no.1 - These are all particulars required to establish material facts by leading evidence - Allegations are not bereft of material facts - Petition not liable to be dismissed. 2009(10) SCC 541 - Followed.			(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Submission of false expenditure account
HeadNote.description:
Submission of false expenditure account - Allegations that pamphlets, voter's slip and other expenses in election incurred exceeded Rs.25 lac - Claims that respondent had printed 12 lac pamphlets and more than 15 lac voter's slips and spent more that 20 lac on printing based on conjectures - Cost of printing pamphlet or voter's slip is presumed by petitioner - Vague assertions based on presumptions cannot be said to be of material facts - Allegations are liable to be rejected. AIR 2002 SC 599 - Followed.

The pleadings in the petition must establish that errors are of such magnitude that they materially affect the election.  The allegation that the counting of votes was done very fast is a totally vague allegation.  Also allegation that the central observer had failed to recount 2 EVM machines is equally vague as such complaint was expressly rejected by the returning officer even before declaration of results.  Moreover no case is made out to show as to how such error committed has affected the election.  Allegations made that reasons for not recounting votes only communicated orally and not recorded by returning officer.  How it has affected election is not pleaded.  It is also alleged that there is discrepancy in votes in the working sheets lying with the petitioner and official counting sheets.  Such discrepancy if at all was there would have been noticed at the time of counting.  Apart from that in such case total number of votes polled in constituency in question would not have tallied at all.  There are also allegations that there is difference of 329 votes in votes polled and votes counted.  There was no bogus voting, allegations not made before declaring result, said difference did not reflect in final result and further more respondent no.1 won by margin of 2933 votes hence this did not affect his election.  Reasons seeking recounting of votes are vague, frivolous and are intended to delay trial.  These allegations in paragraph 11 are liable to be deleted.					 [Para 24,25,28,29]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Proof of corrupt practice - Onus of establishing rests heavily on person who alleges the same - Standard of proof is akin to that of proving a criminal or a quasi criminal charge - Hence clear cut evidence wholly credible and reliable is needed to prove beyond doubt charge of corrupt practice. (2000)1 SCC 481 - Rel.on.(Para 31)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Material facts and material particulars - Material facts are facts on which plaintiff's cause of action or defendant's defence depends - No rule of universal application can be laid down as to what particulars would be material facts - Material particulars ensure conduct of fair trial which would not take opposite party by surprise. 2004(7) SCC 181 - Rel.on.(Para 38)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Respondent categorically stated date, time and place of occurrence of alleged corrupt practice - Names of witnesses also given - Held what would be the worth of evidence produced will have to be examined during the trial but petition cannot be rejected out right for want of particulars.(Para 40)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Corrupt practice - Proof - Returned candidate was Social Security Minister - Alleged instances of bribery by granting pension to old age/widow/handicapped persons took place after he resigned as Minister and before he filed his nomination paper - Held allegations relating to period anterior to commencement of candidature cannot be relied upto to establish corrupt practice proprio vigore.

Sanction and approval for grant of pension as a Social Security Minister clearly would be within the ambit of the authority of the Minister to get it distributed as not distributing pension while discharging the functions of a Minister would on the contrary amount to non-performance on the part of the Minister in the State which could also include his constituency and to hold that even though the Minister had the authority to sanction and approve old age/widow/handicapped pension the same was done in order to lure the persons of his constituency so as to vote for him in any future election which he might contest and the same would amount to offer or promise of any gratification, would be wholly unrealistic and a far fetched allegation. In fact it has not even been contended and rightly so, that the appellant herein who was then a Minister, had no authority to sanction and approve the distribution of pension although he was a Minister.   [Para 45]

Where the appellant in discharge of his official duty distributed, sanctioned, approved or permitted the grant of old age/widow/handicapped pension prior to the filing of his nomination which was 23rd January, 2002 in the case at hand, it cannot be construed as indulgence in corrupt practice and hence, the appellant cannot be held to have committed corrupt practice if he had distributed pension amount even in his constituency upto 12th January, 2002 which was clearly within his legal and official domain as he was not a candidate in the election.   [Para 46]

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
Bribery
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Bribery - Pension to old age/widow/handicapped persons alleged to lure voters by returned candidate who had resigned as Minister before filing nomination paper - Witnesses who were competent to depose as to how pension applications were sanctioned not supporting case of election petitioner - Depositions of other interested witnesses stood contradicted by these non-partisan witnesses - Held evidence relied on by High Court could not be said to be of such probative value as to interfere with election result by which appellant was elected.(Paras 66, 67)

heading: Election petition
Necessary parties
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Necessary parties - Government servants acting in their official capacities as Returning Officer etc.- Not necessary parties - Ordered that their names as respondents be struck off from array of parties. (Para 27)

heading: Election petition
verification found defective
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - verification found defective - Copies supplied to respondents not "true copies" - Allegations of corrupt practice vague and bereft of details or particulars - Petition liable to be dismissed.

In the election petition in instant case it was alleged that the poll slips supplied to voters by the returned candidate contained photograph of the candidate and the symbol of his party. However, original poll slip was not annexed with the petition. The Marathi copy of the poll slip and its English translation were not identical. The verification of the petition was defective inasmuch as the source from which information was received was not given and was left blank. The copies of the election petition supplied to the respondents did not contain information as to before whom the affidavit was sworn. The column of date was left blank. Because of the various discrepancies the copies supplied could not be called to be "true copies" of the election petition. The petition was liable to be dismissed because of the incurable defects and defective verification below the documents which were the integral part of the election petition. The allegations as to corrupt practice against the returned candidate were vague and no particulars and details were given. The petition was therefore liable to be dismissed under s.86 of the Act.  [Para 38,39,40,44,47,49,58]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Allegation that names of large number of voters, not included in voters list - Cannot be entertained in view of provisions of Registration of Election Rules (1960). (Para 51)

heading: Corrupt practice
Setting aside election
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Setting aside election - Material particulars of corrupt practice - Must be stated in the petition - Party cannot be allowed to lead evidence in absence of facts stated - Failure to state even a single fact will entail dismissal of petition.		(Para 62)

heading: Corrupt practice
Material facts of
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Material facts of - Words "Material facts" mean entire bundle of facts which would constitute a complete cause of action - Digging of 13 bore holes in the constituency and purchase of five ambulances after election was notified - Particulars about expenses incurred, number of beneficiaries and about consent of candidate not stated - Held election petition was liable to be dismissed. (2005)13 SCC 511, (2008)7 SCC 604, (2000)2 SCC 294 - Rel. on.	(Paras 62, 63, 65, 67, 68)

heading: Legislative Assembly Election
Disqualification
HeadNote.description:
Legislative Assembly Election - Disqualification - Entry of name in electoral roll of two constituencies does not automatically entail disqualification.

There is nothing to suggest in Section 16 of the 1950 Act that if a person's name finds a place in more than one constituency that would automatically entail disqualification from contesting in any one of the constituencies. It is relevant to note that Section 2(1)(e) of 1951 Act refers disqualification under Section 16 of 1950 Act alone while interpreting the word 'Elector' and has not mentioned any contravention of Section 17 as disqualification. No doubt Section 17 of 1950 Act expressly states that no person shall be entitled to be registered in the electoral roll for more than one constituency. But if a person's name finds a place in more than one constituency does it automatically entail the disqualification under Section 16 ? We do not think so. Objection under Section 17 could have been successfully raised to prevent person's name from being included in other Constituency.  [Para 15]

The contention based on Section 33(5) of the 1951 Act is misconceived, as the respondent No.1 did not file his nomination to the 211 Nilanga Constituency on the basis of his name finding a place in 206 Latur Constituency. On the other hand he filed the nomination to 211 Nilanga Constituency only on the basis of his name finding a place in that Constituency. That being the position, the contention based on Section 33(5) cannot be accepted. Likewise, after reading Section 100 of the 1951 Act we are unable to decide the election of the first respondent void under any one of the grounds set out therein.  [Para 16]

Disqualification

Legislative Assembly Election - Disqualification - Entry of name in electoral roll of two constituencies does not automatically entail disqualification.

Likewise, after reading Section 100 of the 1951 Act we are unable to decide the election of the first respondent void under any one of the grounds set out therein.  [Para 16]

heading:
Sections are mandatory.

Sections 16 and 17 are mandatory for purposes of 1950 Act. For example, to object to the inclusion of the name in the electoral roll.

1997 (4) ALL MR 298 (Bom) Reversed only regarding this point.  [Para 14]
HeadNote.description:
Sections are mandatory.

Sections 16 and 17 are mandatory for purposes of 1950 Act. For example, to object to the inclusion of the name in the electoral roll.

1997 (4) ALL MR 298 (Bom) Reversed only regarding this point.  [Para 14]

heading: Election Petition
Allegation that respondent
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Allegation that respondent - returned candidate made speeches and indulged in character assassination of petitioner - Transcript of those speeches both in Marathi and their English trnaslations filed on record - Audio tapes also deposited in court - Non-supply of audio tapes to respondent - Inference could be drawn that respondent would be well aware about contents of those speeches and hence there was no substantial prejudice. (Para 11)

heading: Election petition
Verification
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Verification - Procedure.

Under O.6, R.15(2) the person verifying has to specify, by reference to the numbered paragraphs of his pleadings, what he verifies of his own knowledge and what he verifies upon the information received and believed to be true. It is not necessary for the election petition to state as to how he obtained the audio tapes in question from the person who recorded them and who prepared the transcripts.  [Para 12]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Conduct of Election Rules 1961, R. 94-A and Form 25 - Election petition - Sworning of affidavit in form 25 - Procedure.

In paras 2 and 3 of affidavit only reference was given to statement made in paras 3, 4, 5 and 6 about the commission of corrupt practices as alleged in election petition

Held, that affidavit filed by petitioner was not according to law. It was necesary for the petitioner to make statement in the affidavit as regards his allegations of corrupt practices committed by the respondent and his associates. As such, the affidavit filed was not in a proper form. In the copies of the election petition received by the respondent, there was no affirmation below this affidavit, much less the authority before whom it was sworn.  [Para 15]

heading: Election petitin
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petitin - Corrupt practice - Allegation that respondent made speeches levelling corruption charges against petitioner - Petitioner alleged to have diverted construction material of godown for construction of his flat - these allegations do not fall within purview of corrupt practice - Respondent securing 35, 544 votes whereas election petitioner securing 20, 952 votes - Lowering down of number of votes could not be attributed to such speeches - No cause of action arose for challenging election of respondent. (Para 18)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Member posing as Deputy Chief Minister - Public knowing that he has no power of Chief Minister - He cannot be said to have made any false statement.

For the member is recognised by people at large and by the Chief Minister and members of the Council of Ministers, as Deputy Chief Minister. However, there is no doubt in anybody's mind, that the member is not having any powers of the Chief Minister as invested in Chief Minister under the Constitution of India. So, it cannot be said that if the member poses himself as Deputy Chief Minister and if the leaders and members of BJP describe him as Deputy Chief Minister, either privately or publicly, any false statement is made. No misrepresentation or no offence is committed by describing the member as Deputy Chief Minister. Therefore, he cannot be said to have made false statements and has thereby committed breach of code of conduct or has indulged in corrupt practices, as described under Section 123 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.  [Para 18]

heading: Contents of petition
Material facts
HeadNote.description: Contents of petition - Material facts - Distinction between "material facts" and "particulars" - Material facts are primary facts disclosing cause of action and failure to plead such facts would result in rejection of petition - Defect in material particulars can be cured at a later stage by amendment - Question whether candidate held office of profit on date of scrutiny - Candidate ought to have stated whether he requested for waiver of three months notice for voluntary retirement, whether his request was granted and he stood retired on date of scrutiny - Held High Court was right in dismissing election petition for want of these material facts.	(Paras 5, 7, 9)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Requirement of serving true copy of petition on respondent - Omission of signature or name of Associate of High Court before whom verification and affirmation is made - Omission is fatal and petition is liable to be dismissed.

AIR 1978 SC 840 Ref. AIR 1996 SC 1691 and AIR 1992 Bom 227 Relied on. (Paras 26, 27)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Petitioner filing affidavit though no corrupt practice was alleged - Affidavit purported to be under R.94A, Form 25 - Having filed the affidavit it becomes an integral part of petition and a copy to be served on the respondent has to be a true copy thereof.

1996(3) ALL MR 475 Rel. on. (Para 31)

heading: Election petition
Verification
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Verification - Concise statement of material facts is an integral part of the petition - In absence of proper verification election petition is liable to be dismissed at the threshold itself. (Para 33)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Grant of adjournment for filing written statement - Availability of such power in the High Court - Is spelled out in the provisions of the Act itself and in the rules - Resort to provisions of CPC is not called for.

The trial of an election petition commences from the date of the receipt of the election petition by the Court and continues till the date of its decision. The filing of pleadings is one stage in the trial of an election petition. The power vesting in the High Court to adjourn the trial from time to time (as far as practicable and without sacrificing the expediency and interests of justice) includes power to adjourn the hearing in an election petition affording opportunity to the defendant to file written statement. The availability of such power in the High Court is spelled out by the provisions of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 itself and Rules made for purposes of that Act and a resort to the provisions of the CPC is not called for.   [Para 45]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Applicability of rules of procedure contained in CPC - Apply only by way of guidelines.

On the language of Section 87(1) of the Act, it is clear that the applicability of the procedure provided for the trial of suits to the trial of election petitions is not attracted with all its rigidity and technicality. The rules of procedure contained in the CPC apply to the trial of election petitions under the Act with flexibility and only as guidelines. [Para 45]

heading: Election petition
Trial
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Trial - Conflict between provision of Act and rules or rules framed by High Court and rules in CPC, former shall prevail over latter.

In case of conflict between the provisions of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 and the Rules framed thereunder or the Rules framed by the High Court in exercise of the power conferred by Article 225 of the Constitution on the one hand, and the Rules of Procedure contained in the CPC on the other hand, the former shall prevail over the latter.   [Para 45]

heading: Election petition
Written statement
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Written statement - High Court may in its discretion extend time for filing even beyond period of 90 days permitted by O.8 R.1. CPC.

Sub-section (6) of Section 86 of the Act would empower the High Court trying an election petition to adjourn the trial beyond the following day if necessary and for reasons to be recorded. The filing of a written statement being a stage in the trial of an election petition, this provision would empower the High Court to grant a reasonable time for filing of a written statement though for reasons to be recorded. The availability of this power finds support from Rules 5 and 12 of the High Court Rules. Under Rule 5, the High Court has power to fix a date for filing the written statement which power would include the power to fix such date not merely once but again and again depending on the discretion of the High Court. Power to extend time for filing the written statement being a matter of practice and procedure the High Court would be within its power to give such directions in that regard as it shall consider just and expedient within the meaning of Rule 12. This discretion vested in the Court by Rules made Under Article 225 for purposes of any special Act would not be controlled by the proviso to sub-rule (1) of Order VIII of the CPC.   [Para 16]

heading: Election petition
Trial
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), S.129 - Election petition - Trial - High Court's power to frame rules.

There is no provision in the Act which empowers the High Court to frame the rules governing the procedure of trials before the High Court. However, the High Court is not entirely powerless in the matter of framing the rules of procedure. Article 225 of the Constitution of India confers powers on the High Court, inter alia, to make rules of court for the purpose of hearing, trying and deciding any matter lying within the jurisdiction of the High Court. The High Court can thus frame rules of procedure regarding the trial of election petitions under Article 225 of the Constitution. This source of power emanates from the Constitution and, is therefore, very potent. Section 129 of CPC is another source of power of High Court to make rules to regulate its own procedure in the exercise of its original civil jurisdiction. This will include election petitions also as they are tried in the original civil jurisdiction of the High Court.   [Para 9]

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Corrupt practice - Appeal on ground of religion - Must be an appeal with reference to religion of the candidate - That is implication of the words "his religion".

The religion forming the basis of the appeal to vote or refrain from voting for any person, must be of that candidate for whom the appeal to vote or refrain from voting is made. This is clear from the plain language of sub-section (3) and this is the only manner in which the word 'his' used therein can be construed. When the appeal is to vote on the ground of 'his' religion for the furtherance of the prospects of the election of that candidate, that appeal is made on the basis of the religion of the candidate for whom votes are solicited. On the other hand, when the appeal is to refrain from voting for any person on the ground of 'his' religion for prejudicially affecting the election of any candidate, that appeal is based on the religion of the candidate whose election is sought to be prejudicially affected. Thus, for soliciting votes for a candidate, the appeal prohibited is that which is made on the ground of religion of the candidate for whom the votes are sought; and when the appeal is to refrain from voting for any candidate, the prohibition is against an appeal on the ground of the religion of that other candidate. The first is a positive appeal and the second a negative appeal. Sub-section (3) clearly indicates the particular religion on the basis of which an appeal to vote or refrain from voting for any person is prohibited under sub-section (3).   [Para 10]

heading: Striking out pleadings
HeadNote.description:
Striking out pleadings - In appropriate case Election Tribunal may invoke power under O.6, R.16 and strike out pleadings.

O.6, R.16 of Civil P.C. empowers the Court to strike out any pleading if it is unnecessary, scandalous, frivolous or vexatious or tends to prejudice, embarrass or delay fair trial of the suit or is otherwise an abuse of the process of the Court. The underlying object of the rule is to ensure that every party to a suit should present his pleading in an intelligible form without causing embarrassment to his adversary. Since the general principles as to pleadings in civil suits apply to election petitions as well, the pleadings which are required to be struck off under Rule 16 of Order VI in a suit can also be ordered to be struck off in an election petition. In appropriate cases, therefore, an election tribunal (High Court) may invoke the power under Order VI, Rule 16 of the Code. 					  [Para 22,23]

At the same time, however, it cannot be overlooked that normally a Court cannot direct parties as to how they should prepare their pleadings. If the parties have not offended the rules of pleadings by making averments or raising arguable issues, the Court would not order striking out pleadings. The power to strike out pleadings is extraordinary in nature and must be exercised by the Court sparingly and with extreme care, caution and circumspection. 						 [Para 25]

heading: Striking out pleadings
HeadNote.description: Striking out pleadings - Election petitioner complained that names of 568 electors were deleted wrongly - Entire list of deleted electors placed on record - He had applied for copies of orders and inspection of records which was denied - He further alleged that with the assistance of a Electoral Registration Officer in order to justify deletion of names orders were passed subsequent to declaration of results and orders were ante dated - Said action was alleged to have been taken in furtherance of prospects of election of respondent - Held, material facts and full particulars were set out in election petition and action of High Court in deleting impugned para from petition was not justified.			(Paras 31, 36, 37)

heading: Striking out pleadings
HeadNote.description: Striking out pleadings - Election petitioner complaining about wrongful acceptance of nomination papers of two independent candidates and contending that majority of their votes were likely to be polled in his favour - Held, allegations in this respect could not be said to be vague and deficient because question of burden of proof would arise only at the stage of trial and not at stage of pleadings, and as such para containing these allegations could not have been deleted by High Court.	(Paras 38-40)

heading: Striking out pleadings
HeadNote.description: Striking out pleadings - Election petitioner stating that out of 22 postal ballots 20 were not accompanied by requisite declaration - He further added that majority of them were of those electors who had been posted outside the constituency and were fully conversant with voting procedure - Held, this was wholly immaterial and irrelevant once it was found that action of rejecting ballot papers was in conconance with relevant rules and hence High Court was justified in striking out the allegations.			(Para 41)

heading: "Duly nominated candidate"
HeadNote.description: "Duly nominated candidate" - Nomination paper of main approved candidate of recognised political party accepted - Nomination paper of "substitute" candidate of the said party is liable to be rejected - Non-joinder of such candidate in election petition was of no consequence.			(Paras 48, 57)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Not setting forth all "material facts" necessary to disclose cause of action - Entails dismissal of petition in limine.

If the Election Petition lacks material facts on which the Petitioner relies, the same ought to be dismissed in exercise of powers under Section 86(1) of the Act read with provisions of Order VII, Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (hereinafter referred to as 'the Code'). That is so because Section 81 refers to "an election petition". Section 83 provides for the contents of an Election Petition. If the Petition does not conform to the requirements of Section 83, in particular, sub-section (1)(a) namely, lacks material facts, in that event, the Petition as filed cannot be allowed to proceed for want of cause of action; for it is not open to the election petitioner to improve upon that deficiency after the expiry of the period of limitation specified in sub-section (1) of Section 81 of the Act. In other words, even though Section 86(1) makes no reference to Section 83(1)(a) as such, even so, the Election Petition, if it fails to set forth "all the material facts" on which the Petitioner relies so as to disclose the cause of action, such Petition will have to be thrown out at the threshold. That power is not only to be exercised with reference to Section 86(1) of the Act, but also flows from provisions of Order VII, Rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (hereinafter referred to as 'the Code'), which obligates the Court to throw out the Petition at the threshold if the same does not disclose cause of action.   [Para 5]

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Petition for declaration of as void - Ground of corrupt practices like filing false or incorrect affidavit before Returning Officer - No plea in petition that respondent was disqualified for said seat or that he was convicted of any offence - None of the averments disclosing relevant material facts to constitute cause of action for invoking ground of corrupt practices - Petition hence liable to be dismissed - Pleadings regarding alleged ground of corrupt practices struck off the records.

Section 100(1)(d) refers to four situations. The first is of improper acceptance of any nomination. Even on construing allegations in the Petition liberally, it is not possible to assume that the ground under clause (i) has been invoked in the context of allegation of filing of false affidavit by the Respondent before the Returning Officer. The fourth clause provided in Section 100(1)(d) refers to non-compliance of the provisions of the Constitution or of the Act of 1951 or of any rules or orders made under that Act. To invoke this ground, however, what is required to be alleged is that the result of the election insofar as it concerns the returned candidate has been materially affected by such act-whether referable to clause (i) or clause (iv) in Section 100(1)(d). The ground provided in Section 100(1) (a) provides that on the date of election of the returned candidate, he was not qualified or was disqualified to be chosen to fill the seat under the Constitution or the Act of 1951 or the Government of Union Territories Act, 1963. The qualification to be elected as member of the Legislative Assembly of the State is provided by the Constitution under Article 173. It is not the case of the Election Petitioner that the Respondent was a person not qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in the Legislature of a State, having failed to fulfil any of the qualifications referred to in Article 173 of the Constitution. Insofar as Act of 1951 is concerned, Section 5 provides for qualifications of membership of a Legislative Assembly.  In the instant case nowhere in the Petition, it is even remotely suggested that the Respondent was not qualified within the meaning of the said provision. Similarly, in the entire Petition, it is nowhere the case of the Petitioner that the Respondent was disqualified to be chosen to fill the seat under any of the provisions of the Constitution or the Act of 1951. It is not the case of the Petitioner that the Respondent has been convicted for any of the specified offences under that provision. The Petitioner asserts that criminal case for offence punishable under Section 125-A of the Act has been registered against the Respondent. That, however, is not sufficient to disqualify Respondent on the date of his election on which he was declared a returned candidate. The disqualification, if at all, will be incurred after the criminal case ends in conviction. Besides, Section 125-A of the Act is not part of the several specified offences under Section 8.  In other words, Section 125-A which deals with penalty for filing false affidavit has not been specified as offence for the purpose of disqualification. In none of the paragraphs in the petition, all the relevant material facts have been disclosed to constitute cause of action for invoking ground under Section 100(1)(d), clause (i) or clause (iv). The consequence is that, the Petition as filed is not a complete Election Petition within the meaning of Section 83(1)(a) of the Act, for which reason, will have to be dismissed under Section 86(1) of the Act read with provisions of Order VII, Rule 11 of the Code, as it fails to disclose cause of action.   [Para 9,11,25]

Section 100(1)(b) provides that if the High Court is of the opinion that any corrupt practice has been committed by a returned candidate or his election agent or by any other person with the consent of the returned candidate or his election agent, may declare the election of the returned candidate to be void. Insofar as Section 100(1)(d)(ii) is concerned, that is a ground available for declaring the election of the returned candidate to be void if the High Court is of the opinion that the result of the election insofar as it concerns the returned candidate has been materially affected by any corrupt practice committed in the interests of the returned candidate by an agent other than his election agent.   [Para 27]

The Petition as a whole, the alleged corrupt practice stated by the Petitioner in these Paragraphs, all relevant material facts to disclose cause of action therefor are not mentioned in the Petition. The averments are short of statement of all relevant material facts to disclose cause of action to pursue the ground in question for declaring the election of Respondent as void. Accordingly, the Petition should fail and will have to be dismissed at threshold in exercise of powers under Section 86(1) read with Order VII, Rule 11 of the Code. In any case, this Court will have to strike off these pleadings regarding the ground pressed into service by the Petitioner in question being unnecessary, frivolous and vexatious, which may tend to prejudice, embarrass or delay the fair trial. In the circumstances, it will have to be held that the Petition lacks complete material facts to disclose cause of action with regard to the alleged corrupt practice. As a consequence, the Petition deserves to be thrown out at the threshold in exercise of Section 86(1) read with Order VII, Rule 11 of the Code. In any case, the pleadings in respect of stated corrupt practice will have to be struck out from the pleadings being unnecessary, frivolous and vexatious, which may tend to prejudice, embarrass or delay the fair trial.   [Para 38,46]

heading: Election Petition
Proof
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Ground of corrupt practice - Proof - Allegation that respondent carried out false campaign and played fraud on voters - Complaint also as to defamation of party candidate - Said plea based on newspaper reports and some leaflets without details or material facts - Nor any copies of said newspapers or leaflets attached to petition - Petition liable to be dismissed as not being a true copy - Said petition thus being unnecessary, frivolous and vexatious, petitioner ordered to pay cost of Rs.7,500/-.	(Paras 68, 69, 71 to 77)

heading: Limitation
Computation of
HeadNote.description: Filing of election petition - Limitation - Computation of - Applicability of S.10 of General Clauses Act is not excluded. (Paras 13, 14)

heading: Distinction
HeadNote.description: Compliance with S.81 and S.83 - Distinction - Checking compliance with S.81(1) and 81(3) is a ministerial act but checking compliance with S.83 is judicial act - Hence non-compliance of S.83 is not a ground for dismissal of election petition under S.86. (Paras 18, 19)

heading: Non-compliance of S.81(3)
HeadNote.description: Non-compliance of S.81(3) - Question is to be answered with reference to kind of use made of document annexed to petition - Whether as an integral part or merely as evidence of pleadings contained in the body of election petition. (Para 25)

heading: Distinction between clause (1)(b) and (d)(ii)
HeadNote.description: Distinction between clause (1)(b) and (d)(ii) - In view of provision in Cl.(d)(ii) consent of candidate is not required to be implied for any act done by a leader of his party in the candidate's interest. (Para 36, 37, 38 & 39)

heading: Corrupt practice
Word 'Hindutva'
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Word 'Hindutva' - Does not invariably mean Hindu religion, context in which it is used is to be examined - Plank of political party may at best be relevant for knowing context and nothing more. (Para 41)

heading: Words 'at the conclusion of the trial of an election petition in S.98
HeadNote.description: Words 'at the conclusion of the trial of an election petition in S.98 - Words' at the time of making an order under S.98 in S.99 - Proceedings under S.99 for naming person who is alleged to be guilty of corrupt practice must precede trial under S.98 and court cannot conclude S.98 proceedings first and then proceed under S.99. (Paras 54, 55 & 57)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Expression of a hope that first Hindu State will be established in Maharashtra is not by itself an appeal for votes on ground of religion - However, despicable be such a statement, it cannot constitute a corrupt practice. (Para 59)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Furnishing True copy to respondent - Copy simply stating 'before me' without giving name, signature, date and designation of the officer before whom verification was made - Held petition was not maintainable and liable to be rejected summarily for not furnishing true copy of the petition.

Decision in E.P. No. 7 of 1995 dt.23-12-1996 by R.G. Vaidyanatha J. (Bom) foll. (Para 4)

heading: Failure to furnish true copy of election petition
HeadNote.description:
Failure to furnish true copy of election petition - Objection relates to violation of mandatory statutory provision - As such it can be raised even after evidence is partly recorded.

AIR 1987 SC 1926 Rel. on. (Para 6)

heading: Mandatory provision about
HeadNote.description: Objection to maintaining of election petition - Mandatory provision about - Furnishing true copy not complied with - Objection can be raised by a simple application without there being a formal chamber summons. (Para 7)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Election challenged on ground that returned candidate was convicted under Penal Code and other Acts - Petition can be dismissed if it fails to disclose cause of action - It can be dismissed even after framing of issues.

1987 (Supp) SCC 663 Foll.	(Para 5)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Election of returned candidate challenged because he was convicted under Penal Code and other Acts - Single Judge suspending conviction and sentence of returned candidate in exercise of power under S.389 Cri.P.C. - It is discretion of Single Judge - Discretion exercised by Single Judge taking view that otherwise irreparable damage would be caused to elected candidate - Order cannot be interfered with by High Court - It is not for High Court to consider whether discretion was rightly exercised or not.			(Paras 5,12)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Single Judge while deciding petition is Election Tribunal - It cannot be said that it is not a court - Decision of Apex Court on relevant point is binding on Tribunal.

Precedents - Judicial Precedents. (Para 12)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Election challenged on ground that returned candidate was convicted under Penal Code and other Acts - His conviction and sentence suspended before filing of nomination papers - It cannot be said that candidate was not qualified or was disqualified to contest election.	(Para 12,13)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Election challenged on ground of conviction of returned candidate - Distinction between conviction prior to election and subsequent to election stated.

From S.8(4) it becomes apparent that parliament has treated the two cases differently. In so far as the case of a candidate seeking to contest the election, if such candidate has been convicted, no provision has been made  whereby a candidate who has been convicted even if he is granted Bail, can contest the election. This seems to be because the right to contest the election is a statutory right. By statute, Parliament has conferred the right to contest to a determinate class of citizens. That class of citizens is a class which has not incurred any disqualification on the date of filing the nomination or till the date of election. Long back, it seems to have been the intent of Parliament to keep certain felons from entering Parliament or the Legislatures. On the other hand in the case where a person has been convicted during his term of office, the conviction per se does not disqualify such a person form holding an office as the Act itself provides that the disqualification will not come into effect until three months have elapsed from the date of conviction or if appeal or application or revision is filed in respect of the conviction and sentence until that appeal or application is disposed of by the Court. The case of returned candidate therefore has been treated differently. Mere filing of an appeal by itself suspends the incurring of the disqualification, if any, till the appeal or application is disposed of. It is therefore, clear that parliament itself has made a clear distinction in respect of the two classes of cases. A perusal of offences which incur disqualification as set out in sub-section (1) of Section 8 or sub-section (2), it would be clear that they pertain to a class or category of offences which are offences relating to public order or morality or the interest of the State.					 [Para 11]

heading: Election petition
Verification
Defective verification
Defect curable
HeadNote.description: Bombay High Court (Original Side) Rules (1980), Rr.44 and 45 - Election petition - Verification - Defective verification - Does not go to root of jurisdiction - Defect curable - Petitioner can make necessary amendment.	(Para 14)

heading: Scope
Non-compliance of S.83
HeadNote.description:
Scope - S.86 being penal has to be strictly construed - Non-compliance of S.83 - Not a ground specified under S.86 for dismissal of election petition - Not filing affidavit in Form No.25 - Election petition not liable to be dismissed.
Election Rules (1961), Rr.21, 94-A and Form No.25.

Non-compliance of section 83 of the Act is not specified as a ground for the dismissal of the petition under Section 86 of the Act. Section 86 being in the nature of a penal provision it has to be construed strictly confined to its plain language. Thus an election petition is not liable to be dismissed under Section 86 of the Act for not filing the affidavit in Form No.25 as provided in rule 94-A of the Rules.  [Para 11,12]

heading: Corrupt practice
Affidavit by petitioner
Word "copy"
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Affidavit by petitioner - Copy served on returned candidate - Not containing endorsement of officer administering oath, his designation, name, signature and date - Petition not liable to be dismissed on that ground, when contents therein are identical with original affidavit - Word "copy" - Meaning of.

Where the contents of the copy of affidavit served on returned candidate are identical with the original copy, it is a "true copy" within the meaning of S.81(3) and the fact that the copy does not contain the stamped endorsement by the officer authorised to administer oath and also does not contain the designation, name and signature of such officer as also the date does not amount to contravention of Section 81(3) of the R.P.Act. The election petition is not liable to be dismissed in limine under Sec.86 on that ground.  [Para 27]

Where the copy of the election petition served on the returned candidate with the notice of the election petition is identical with the election petition as it was presented in the court, the requirements of plain language of section 81(3) of the R.P.Act are fully met. On the same line, it can very well be said that where the copy of the affidavit accompanying the election petition as a true copy served on the returned candidate is identical with the affidavit as it was presented in the court, the requirements of section 81(3) are fully met. It is true that had it been a case that there is variation in the contents of the affidavit from the copy of the affidavit served on the returned candidate and the affidavit presented in the court, that would have been a serious defect which might have resulted in dismissal of the petition under section 86.  [Para 27]

The word "copy" as appearing in Section 81(3) does not mean "an absolutely exact copy but means that the copy shall be so true that nobody misunderstands it." The principle governing section 81(3) of the R.P.Act is that "copy of the petition" should be attested with an endorsement as "true copy" and duly signed by the petitioner. No specific form of attestation is provided in the relevant rules and the signature below the endorsement "true copy" alone is enough.   [Para 24,25]

When the main petition is not liable to be dismissed under Section 86 for it does not contain the signature of the officer with all particulars of the stamped endorsement as appearing on the original election petition, the copy of the affidavit accompanying the main election petition merely containing the signature below the endorsement "true copy" of the petitioner would not be a defect to attract section 81(3).  [Para 26]

heading: Inclusion of name of elector in electoral roll, before date of nomination
HeadNote.description:
Inclusion of name of elector in electoral roll, before date of nomination - Submission of certified copy of relevant part of electoral roll - Held, inclusion of name and acceptance of nomination cannot be challenged.

It is now, established law that the names in the Electoral Roll if wrongly continued or inducted and if the same is not corrected till the last date of submission of the nomination paper then there hardly remains any scope to say that the participation of that person in the election would render the election itself illegal. Such an election may be challenged on any other ground, but acceptance of the nomination paper of such a person or receiving of the nomination paper of such a person cannot be said to be illegal AIR 1977 SC 1992 foll   [Para 31]

If S.62(1) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is read with S.36(7) of that Act, it would be clear that the name once having been entered into the electoral roll before the last date of submission of nomination paper virtually gets finality and the same would not be open for challenge. The electoral roll referred to in S.62(l) is strictly referable to an electoral roll that was in force on the last day of making the nomination at the election.	 [Para 33,36,37,39]

If the concerned candidate would not have submitted a certified copy of the relevant part of the electoral roll along with his nomination paper, the concerned officer would not have accepted the very nomination paper of that candidate and the same would have been objected to at the time of scrutiny either by the officer concerned or even by the other candidate. No such objection was ever raised at the time of scrutiny of the nomination paper either by the other candidate or anyone else.1963 SCR 479 foil; AIR 1976 SC 340, AIR 1976 SC 2573 and AIR 1970 SC 314 Disting.  [Para 38]

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Effect of acquiring disqualification - Seat occupied by such person becomes vacant immediately by operation of law - Cessation of disqualification will not put such a person back in the Legislature without his being elected once again. 

It is a settled proposition of law that the happening of any one of the disqualifying EVENTS has the effect of making the seat occupied by such a disqualified person vacant immediately by operation of law. The effect of the decision of the Governor under Article 192 is only to decide whether a legislator acquired the disqualification on a particular date on the happening of one of the disqualifying EVENTS contemplated under Section 191. The consequence is that the legislator who acquires the disqualification ceases to be a Member of the Legislature with effect from the date of the acquisition of the disqualification.

On the acquisition of the disqualification by a legislator, he ceases to be a legislator forthwith by operation of law. However, the cessation of the disqualifying factor cannot put such a person back in the legislature without his being elected once again, of course such person is entitled to contest any election under the R.P. Act, the moment the disqualifying factor ceases to exist as the disqualification is co-terminus with the disqualifying EVENT.         [Para 37,38]

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Effect of declaration of disqualification by Governor of the State - Whether it takes within its sweep both "pre-existing" and "supervening" contracts.

We cannot close our eyes to the reality of the unwholesome influence which money power exerts on the political system in this country. Any interpretation of Section 9A which goes to assist a legislator who directly enters into a contractual relationship with the State for deriving monetary benefits (in some cases of enormous proportions) should be avoided and be given a construction which as far as possible eliminates the possibility of creating such situation where the duty is certainly bound to conflict with personal interest.     [Para 56]

heading: Election petition
Effect
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Non-joinder of all contesting candidates - Effect - Petitioner seeking declaration that he be declared as returned candidate - However, failed to join all contesting candidates - Provisions of S.82 of Representation of the People Act mandates that all contesting candidates to election be joined as party respondents to petition - Non-compliance with the same results into dismissal of petition in view of provision of S.86 - Petition dismissed. 	(Paras 7, 12)

heading: Election petition
Parties to petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Parties to petition - Person who is not candidate at election cannot be joined as respondent to petition merely because allegations of corrupt practices have been made against such person in petition - Returning Officer cannot be impleaded as party to such petition on ground that he has been guilty of committing illegalities, etc. in conduct of election. AIR 1973 P&H 163 Rel.on.			(Paras 13, 15)

heading: Administration of oath to candidate
HeadNote.description: Administration of oath to candidate - Not improper merely because returning officer was sitting on chair while administering oath - Allegation of impropriety of the oath could not be sustained.  (Para 7)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Candidate posing himself as a devotee of Lord Shiva and covering his body with dhoti of orange (bhagwa) colour at the time of filing nomination paper - Not by itself a corrupt practice - Moreover allegation relating to period anterior to commencement of candidature could not be relied upon. (Para 8)

(c) Representation of the People Act (1951), S.100(i)(d)(vi) - Transfer of ballot boxes to the place of counting - Intimation not given to candidate - Held assuming such intimation was necessary it was a mere irregularity not affecting result of election.  (Para 9)

heading: Candidate being a Muslim alleged to have posed as devotee of Lord Shiva during election campaign and secured sympathy votes
HeadNote.description: Candidate being a Muslim alleged to have posed as devotee of Lord Shiva during election campaign and secured sympathy votes - Allegation not supported by material facts could not be sustained. (Para 10)

heading: Procuring or hiring vehicles
HeadNote.description:
Procuring or hiring vehicles - What must be proved.

In order to constitute corrupt practice under section 123(5) of the Act, hiring or procuring of a vehicle by a candidate or his agent or any other person with his consent is the first essential ingredient of the corrupt practice the second essential ingredient is that hiring or procuring of a vehicle must be for convenience of the voters to and from the polling station and the third necessary ingredient is the conveyance of elect rotates is free from any charge. All the three ingredients must be pleaded to make out a cause of corrupt practice under section 123(5) of the Act.   [Para 12]

heading: Verification
HeadNote.description:
Verification of election petition - Petitioner not verifying as to whether contents of each paragraph in petition were true and correct according to his own knowledge and which paragraphs were believed to be true and correct upon information received by him - Held, petition itself was not maintainable for non-compliance with provisions of O.6, R.15 of Civil PC. AIR 

1972 SC 515, AIR 1986 SC 1253 and AIR 1994 SC 2277 Rel.on.
Election petition - Verification - Applicability of provisions of Civil PC.
Civil PC (1908), O.6 R.15. (Para 26)

heading: True copy
Presentation
Effect. (Paras 28,39)
HeadNote.description:
True copy - Initials on top of pages of copy of election petition supplied to respondent not warranting inference that these were initials of petitioner - Words "attested by petitioner" absent below those initials - Verification without signature of petitioner or of his Advocate - Held, petition was liable to be dismissed for non-compliance of provisions of S.81(3) 1996(2) ALL MR 246, 1996(2) ALL MR 215 and AIR 1996 SC 1961 Rel.on.

Election petition - Presentation - Supply of true copy of petition to respondent - Material omissions in copy of petition - Effect. (Paras 28,39)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Allegation of corrupt practices - Petition must contain particulars of corrupt practice in detail - Making frivolous or baseless allegations is not warranted. 

A conspectus reading of Section 83(1)(a) along with its proviso of the Act, as well as, Rule 94A and Form No. 25 of the Rules make the legal position clear that in the filing of an Election Petition challenging the successful election of a candidate, the election petitioner should take extra care and leave no room for doubt while making any allegation of corrupt practice indulged in by the successful candidate and that he cannot be later on heard to state that the allegations were generally spoken to or as discussed sporadically and on that basis the petition came to be filed. In other words, unless and until the election petitioner comes forward with a definite plea of his case that the allegation of corrupt practice is supported by legally acceptable material evidence without an iota of doubt as to such allegation, the Election Petition cannot be entertained and will have to be rejected at the threshold. It will be relevant to state that since the successful candidate in an election has got the support of the majority of the voters who cast their votes in his favour, the success gained by a candidate in a public election cannot be allowed to be called in question by any unsuccessful candidate by making frivolous or baseless allegations and thereby unnecessarily drag the successful candidate to the Court proceedings and make waste of his precious time, which would have otherwise been devoted for the welfare of the members of his constituency.     [Para 20]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Details of corrupt practice alleged - Not specifically given in petition or in affidavit - Even after objection raised in written statement petitioner taking rigid stand that he wanted to go by whatever averments are made in petition and supporting affidavit - Defects were substantial in nature and not merely formal - Held, after taking such categoric stand before High Court petitioner appellant cannot now be given opportunity to set right the defects.			(Paras 39, 44)

heading: Furnishing information in nomination form
HeadNote.description: Furnishing information in nomination form - Conviction for less than a year - Not required to be disclosed in nomination form.	(Para 47)

heading: Power to enact  law relating to disqualification for membership of Parliament or State Legislature
HeadNote.description: Power to enact  law relating to disqualification for membership of Parliament or State Legislature - Is located only in Articles 102(1)(e) and 191(1)(e) of the Constitution and not in Arts.246(1) r.w. Entry 97 of List I of the VIIth Schedule and Art.248 of the Constitution. (Para 15)

heading: Validity of S.8(4)
HeadNote.description:
Validity of S.8(4) - Section deferring date from which disqualification will come into effect in case of sitting member of Parliament or State Legislature - Parliament has exceeded its powers in enacting such provision in S.8(4) - S.8(4) is ultra vires the Constitution.

Looking at the affirmative terms of Articles 102(1)(e) and 191(1)(e) of the Constitution, Parliament has been vested with the powers to make law laying down the same disqualifications for person to be chosen as a member of Parliament or a State Legislature and for a sitting member of a House of Parliament or a House of a State Legislature. The provisions of Article 101(3)(a) and 190(3)(a) of the Constitution expressly prohibit Parliament to defer the date from which the disqualification will come into effect in case of a sitting member of Parliament or a State Legislature. Parliament, therefore, has exceeded its powers conferred by the Constitution in enacting sub-section (4) of Section 8 of the Act and accordingly sub-section (4) of Section 8 of the Act is ultra vires the Constitution.      [Para 20]

The seat of a member who becomes subject to any of the disqualifications mentioned in clause (1) will fall vacant on the date on which the member incurs the disqualification and cannot await the decision of the President or the Governor, as the case may be, under Articles 103 and 192 respectively of the Constitution.     [Para 18]

heading: Effect of declaring S.8(4) as ultra vires the Constitution
HeadNote.description: Effect of declaring S.8(4) as ultra vires the Constitution - Should not adversely affect sitting members convicted for any of the offences mentioned in sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of S.8 if they have filed appeals or revisions which are pending - If, however, a member of Parliament or State Legislature who incurs disqualification under sub-sections (1), (2) or (3) after pronouncement of this judgment will not be saved by S.8(4) even if he files appeal or revision against conviction and/or sentence. (Para 23)

heading: Scheme of disqualification upon conviction
HeadNote.description:
Scheme of disqualification upon conviction - Is intended to preserve probity of representative government.

The scheme of disqualification upon conviction laid down by the 1951 Act clearly upholds the principle that a person who has been convicted for certain categories of criminal activities is unfit to be a representative of the people. Criminal activities that result in disqualification are related to various spheres pertaining to the interest of the nation, common citizenry interest, communal harmony, and prevalence of good governance. It is clear that the 1951 Act lays down that the commission of serious criminal offences renders a person ineligible to contest in elections or continue as a representative of the people. Such a restriction does provide the salutary deterrent necessary to prevent criminal elements from holding public office thereby preserving the probity of representative government.      [Para 21]

heading: Election Petition
Alleged corrupt practice
Affidavit defective
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Alleged corrupt practice - Filing of affidavit in support of allegation - Requirement to disclose source of information - Submission made that though source of information not disclosed in affidavit, in election petition, reference was made to CDs procured from Election Commission - However, averments in election petition already found vague - Even as regards CDs, only a reference was made to it - It was not clearly stated that allegations of corrupt practice are based on information received from said CDs - Affidavit defective - Election petition liable to be dismissed. (1999) 1 SCC 666, 2010 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 209 Ref. to. 	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Election petition
Dismissal of
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Dismissal of - On ground of non-filing of documents alongwith petition - Objection not raised at first instance or immediately - Belated raising of objection deprived petitioner of opportunity of curing defect, if any - Also respondent failed to point out that because of above defect, he was put to any prejudice or was not in a position to prepare and file written statement and defend himself - Election petition not liable to be dismissed. 1998(4) ALL MR 357 (S.C.) Rel. on. 	(Para 10)

heading: Election petition
Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Limitation for - It is to be filed within 45 days - Petition is filed on 44th day - Petition is within limitation. 	(Para 11)

heading: Election petition
MLA
Corrupt practice
Proof
Appreciation of evidence
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - MLA - Corrupt practice - Proof - Appreciation of evidence - Contention that in public meetings Respondent and his agents appealed to voters on ground of caste and also restrained voters from voting on ground of caste - Except oral testimony of witnesses no proof that alleged meetings were held - In absence of police record showing that public meeting held - Testimony of witnesses in respect of holding of such meeting cannot be believed - Also no complaint of any corrupt practice made by Petitioner to any authorities - Witnesses supporters of and belonging to Petitioner's political party - Political affiliation no ground to reject deposition as unreliable - But when deposition not substantiated in material particulars it cannot be accepted - Contradictions and inconsistencies in evidence of witnesses - In circumstances, Petitioner failed to prove corrupt practice of appealing to caste.

AIR 1975 SC 290 - Rel on.	(Para 17)

heading: Election petition
MLA
Corrupt practice
Proof
Appreciation of evidence
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - MLA - Corrupt practice - Proof - Appreciation of evidence - Corrupt practice of using force by obstructing, assaulting and intimidating active workers and campaigners of Petitioners alleged - No evidence led to prove incident as alleged in petition - Evidence in respect of some other incidents not admissible - Explanation by Petitioner that such other incidents not mentioned in petition as voters list and forms of polling agents were not snatched - Explanation incomprehensible and irrelevant - No documentary evidence produced of complaints allegedly made to Election Commission - Also no explanation for such non-production - Material contradiction in deposition of witnesses as to manner in which incident took place - In circumstances, Petitioner failed to prove corrupt practice beyond reasonable doubt.

AIR 1975 SC 290 - Rel on.	(Para 18)

heading: Election petition
MLA
Corrupt practice
Proof
Appreciation of evidence
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - MLA - Corrupt practice - Proof - Appreciation of evidence - Contention that Respondent distributed false 7/12 extracts in the constituency - Contradiction between oral and documentary evidence in respect of the date on which extracts distributed - No proper verification of averments in respect of distribution - Averments can be ignored by Court - No definite evidence as to when and by whom extracts distributed - Evidence of witnesses strange and unbelievable - Only one witness out of many witnesses before Magistrate examined in Election Petition - No explanation for such omission - In circumstances, Petitioner failed to prove corrupt practice beyond reasonable doubt.

AIR 1975 SC 290 - Rel on.	(Para 19)

heading: Election petition
MLA
Corrupt practice
Proof
Appreciation of evidence
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - MLA - Corrupt practice - Proof - Appreciation of evidence - Contention that in public meeting Respondent made false statements in respect of wealth of Petitioner - No evidence that meeting held before or after nomination papers were filed - No documentary evidence that meetings were held - Police records not showing that meeting was held as alleged in petition - Oral evidence contrary to documentary evidence - In his evidence Petitioner tried to conceal information in respect of his properties from Court and made contradictory statements - In circumstances, merely on basis of oral evidence corrupt practice cannot be considered as proved beyond reasonable doubt.

AIR 1975 SC 290 - Rel on.	(Para 20)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description: Election - False declaration relating to educational qualification while filing nomination, is a defect of substantial nature - Every candidate has to disclose his educational qualification to subserve right to information of the voter.	(Para 18)

heading: Election
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Election - Improper acceptance of nomination - Effect - Mere finding that there has been an improper acceptance of the nomination is not sufficient for a declaration that the election is void u/S.100(1)(d) - There has to be further pleading and proof that the result of the election of returned candidate was materially affected - But, there would be no necessity of any proof in the event of the nomination of a returned candidate being declared as having been improperly accepted, especially in a case where there are only two candidates in the fray.

There is a difference between the improper acceptance of a nomination of a returned candidate and the improper acceptance of nomination of any other candidate. There is also a difference between cases where there are only two candidates in the fray and a situation where there are more than two candidates contesting the election. If the nomination of a candidate other than the returned candidate is found to have been improperly accepted, it is essential that the election Petitioner has to plead and prove that the votes polled in favour of such candidate would have been polled in his favour. On the other hand, if the improper acceptance of nomination is of the returned candidate, there is no necessity of proof that the election has been materially affected as the returned candidate would not have been able to contest the election if his nomination was not accepted. It is not necessary for the Respondent to prove that result of the election in so far as it concerns the returned candidate has been materially affected by the improper acceptance of his nomination as there were only two candidates contesting the election and if the Appellant's nomination is declared to have been improperly accepted, his election would have to be set aside without any further enquiry and the only candidate left in the fray is entitled to be declared elected. 2012 ALL SCR 831, 2012 ALL SCR 1866, 1995 Supp (1) SCC 422, 2009 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 91 Ref. to.  [Para 22]

heading: Election
Disqualification
Criminalization of politics
HeadNote.description: Election - Disqualification - Criminalization of politics - Petitioner sought directions for debarring persons facing charges of serious nature from contesting elections - Such directions may be antidote to malignancy of criminalization of politics - But it is not Constitutionally permissible - Therefore, Supreme Court recommended to Parliament to bring out strong law whereby it is mandatory for political parties to revoke membership of persons against whom charges are framed in heinous and grievous offences and not to set up such persons in elections, both Parliament and State Assemblies. 	(Paras 107, 108, 118)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Voters to have informed choice - Disclosure of antecedents by candidate to make election fair one - Supreme Court issued direction to be implemented in true spirit.

	Disclosure of antecedents by the candidate makes the election a fair one the exercise of the right of voting by electorate also gets sanctified such a right is paramount for a democracy. A voter is entitled to have an informed choice. If his right to get proper information is scuttled, in the ultimate eventuate, it may lead to destruction of democracy because he will not be an informed voter having been kept in the dark about the candidates who are accused of heinous offences. Therefore Supreme Court issued following directions which ought to be implemented in true spirit right cornestmep in a bid to strengthen the democratic set up.

(i)	Each contesting candidate shall fill up the form as provided by the Election Commission and the form must contain all the particulars as required therein.

(ii)	It shall state, in bold letters, with regard to the criminal cases pending against the candidate.

(iii)	If a candidate is contesting an election on the ticket of a particular party, he/she is required to inform the party about the criminal cases pending against him/her.
