heading: "Material facts"
Rel.on.		 [Para 12]
HeadNote.description:
"Material facts" - Meaning of.

The phrase "material facts" has neither been defined in the Act nor in the Code and, therefore, it has been understood by the courts in general terms to mean the entire bundle of facts which would constitute a complete cause of action. In other words, "material facts" are facts upon which the plaintiff's cause of action or defendant's defence depends. Broadly speaking, all primary or basic facts which are necessary either to prove the cause of action by the plaintiff or defence by the defendant are "material facts". Material facts are facts which, if established, would give the petitioner the relief asked for. But again, what could be said to be material facts would depend upon the facts of each case and no rule of universal application can be laid down. 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 297 - Rel.on.		 [Para 12]

heading:
Distinction between "material facts" and "full particulars".

In order to appreciate the real object and purport of the phrase "material facts", particularly with reference to election law, it would be appropriate to notice distinction between the phrases "material facts" as appearing in clause (a) and "particulars" as appearing in clause (b) of sub-section (1) of Section 83. "Material facts" are primary or basic facts which have to be pleaded by the petitioner to prove his cause of action and by the defendant to prove his defence. "Particulars", on the other hand, are details in support of the material facts, pleaded by the parties. They amplify, refine and embellish material facts by giving distinctive touch to the basic contours of a picture already drawn so as to make it full, more clear and more informative. Unlike "material facts" which provide the basic foundation on which the entire edifice of the election petition is built, "particulars" are to be stated to ensure that opposite party is not taken by surprise.  2007(1) ALL MR 450 (S.C.)

heading: Rejection of election petition at threshold
HeadNote.description:
Rejection of election petition at threshold - Propriety.

Undoubtedly, by virtue of Section 87 of the Act, the provisions of the Code apply to the trial of an election petition and, therefore, in the absence of anything to the contrary in the Act, the court trying an election petition can act in exercise of its power under the Code, including Order 6, Rule 16 and Order 7, Rule 11 of the Code. The object of both the provisions is to ensure that meaningless litigation, which is otherwise bound to prove abortive, should not be permitted to occupy the judicial time of the courts. If that is so in matters pertaining to ordinary civil litigation, it must apply with greater vigour in election matters where the pendency of an election petition is likely to inhibit the elected representative of the people in the discharge of his public duties for which the Electorate have reposed confidence in him.  	  [Para 17]

heading: Material facts
HeadNote.description: Dismissal of election petition at the threshold - Material facts - Omission on part of Returning Officer to circulate signatures of election agent to polling stations - How it affected result of election not stated - Held petition was liable to be rejected at the threshold on this ground.			(Para 21)

heading: Secrecy of ballot paper
HeadNote.description: Secrecy of ballot paper - Has always been the hall mark of fair and free elections - At the same time it cannot be pressed into service to suppress a wrong coming to light and to protect a fraud on the election process.	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Inspection of election papers
HeadNote.description: Inspection of election papers - Allegation in election petition that elected candidate was beneficiary of a large number of void votes in her favour by impersonation - Details of votes cast by impersonation on behalf of persons who were not in the constituency on date of election, on behalf of persons already dead, on behalf of persons who were in jail or abroad given - Court must exercise its power of inspection under R.93(1).			(Paras 13, 15, 16)

heading: Grounds
HeadNote.description: Rejection of nomination paper - Grounds - Printing mistake in voters' list as to correct name of candidate - Details as to father's name, his age as appearing in voters' list and nomination paper tallying - Nomination paper cannot be rejected - It was not necessary for candidate to produce a certified copy of relevant entries in electoral roll or to produce the same at time of scrutiny - Mere false description does not vitiate, if there is sufficient certainty as to the object.	(Paras 12, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Election petition
Onus of proof
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Onus of proof - Lies on the one who challenges the election to raise necessary pleadings and adduce evidence to prove such averments as would enable the result of the election being set aside on grounds available in law - Success of a winning candidate is not to be lightly interfered with.	(Para 20)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Defectiveness and untrustworthiness of Electronic Voting Machines - No allegations of malice by employee of election machinery - No averments that deficiencies in EVM has materially affected result of election - Pleadings are without any cause of action - Petition liable to be dismissed on this ground. 	(Paras 18 to 20)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Copy of petition served upon returned candidate did not bear words 'Attested True Copy' - Failure to attest was in totality - Mandatory provisions under S.81(3) are not complied with - Defect goes to root of case - Petition liable to be dismissed. 	(Para 23)

heading: Election Petition
Corrupt practices
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Corrupt practices - Disclosure of material facts - Particulars of expenditure on helicopter was factually adequate and sufficiently pleaded - Particulars of expenses on buses to transport voters to public meeting narrated by giving names of persons doing that act - Speech of Minister for Food and Civil Supplies to ration shop and kerosene licence holders uttering threat to vote for respondent - Particulars of same sufficiently pleaded - Objection that allegations of corrupt practices do not give description of material facts is liable to be rejected. 2009 ALL SCR 2419 - Rel. on. 			(Para 26)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practices
Giving material particulars
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practices - Giving material particulars - Contents of affidavit do not give detailed narration of events with full particulars - Failure to give material particulars of corrupt practices - Failure to give affidavit in support of allegations - Defect goes to root of case - Petition liable to be dismissed. 2009 ALL SCR 2419 - Rel. on. 	(Paras 27, 30, 31)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Petition not containing statement and particulars about how result of election of returned candidate has been materially affected - Petition liable to be dismissed. 2009 ALL SCR 2419 - Rel. on. 	(Paras 28, 30)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practices
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practices - Speech of State Minister for Food and Civil Supplies to ration shop and kerosene licence holders uttering threat to vote for respondent - Video cassette of said meeting is matter of evidence - Failure to produce video cassette is not fatal to petition - Petition not liable to be dismissed on this ground. 2010(1) ALL MR 469, 2007(6) ALL MR 176, 2006(3) ALL MR 606 - Ref. to.			 (Para 29)

heading: Right u/s.8(4)
Suspension of conviction
HeadNote.description:
Right u/s.8(4) - Suspension of conviction - Person convicted of offence in S.8(1), (2) and (3) continues to remain a Member of Parliament or State Legislature on basis of protection in Sub-section (4) - Person resigning from Parliament or Assembly and seeking re-election, if elected, will have greater moral authority to represent constituency and his is a fit case for suspending conviction.

Submission by State that appellant having given up rights under section 8(4) of Representation of People Act and having himself resigned from Parliament, cannot again come back to Parliament until appeal is decided in his favour has no substance.  After discussing broad features of case which impelled granting order favouring appellant, Supreme Court held that argument that appellant having given up his right under section 8(4) should not be permitted to offer himself as a candidate is wholly misconceived.  If a person convicted of any offence enumerated in section 8(1), (2) and (3) files an appeal within 3 months he continues to remain a Member of Parliament or Legislature of a Sate on basis of protection afforded by Sub-section (4), but not on any moral authority because electorate had exercised their franchise prior to order of conviction and not when he had become a convict.  But a person who resigns from Parliament or Assembly and seeks a re-election, if elected, will have greater moral authority to represent constituency.  Therefore, it is not possible to accept contentions raised.  Application by appellant deserves to be allowed.  Order of conviction and sentence awarded against appellant suspended, conviction shall not be operative till decision of appeal.   [Para 12,16]

heading: Suspension of conviction
Interpretation of statute
Distinguished. [Para 13]
HeadNote.description:
Suspension of conviction - Interpretation of statute - Question of continuation of disqualification for contesting election, is alien while considering suspension or stay of conviction - Question can arise only when validity of election is in question in election petition - Courts have to interpret law as it stands, not on consideration which may be perceived to be morally more correct or ethical.

Contention that in order to maintain purity and probity in public bodies, criminalisation of politics has to be stopped and persons who have been convicted of any offence should not be allowed to enter Parliament was elaborated by submitting that irrespective of quantum of sentence if a person is convicted for an offence referred to in section 8(1) where punishment imposed may be only a fine, a person will incur disqualification from date of conviction which will remain for a period of 6 years and this evinces intention of Legislature that a convict should not enter precincts of Parliament or a State Legislature.  Supreme Court did not accept contention.  It observed that Representation of People Act, 1951 is a complete Code.  Preamble of Act says it is 'to provide for conduct of elections to Houses of Parliament and to House or Houses of Legislature of each State, qualifications and disqualifications for membership of those Houses, corrupt practices, other offences at or in connection with such elections, decision of doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with such elections.  Act provides not only eligibility and qualification for membership of House of People and Legislative Assembly but also for disqualification on conviction and other matters.  Parliament in its wisdom having made a specific provision for disqualification on conviction by enacting Section 8, it is not for Court to abridge or expand same.  Supreme Court in Rama Narang's case having recognized power possessed by Court of appeal to suspend or stay an order of conviction and having also laid down parameters for exercise of such power, it is not possible to hold, as a matter of rule, or, to lay down, that in order to prevent any person who has committed an offence from entering Parliament or Legislative Assembly order of conviction should not be suspended.  Courts have to interpret law as it stands and not on considerations which may be perceived to be morally more correct or ethical.  Contention that appellant would not be absolved of disqualification even if an order of suspension or stay of conviction is passed by Supreme Court was considered.  It was observed that Court was dealing with limited question viz. 'prayer made by appellant for suspending or staying order of conviction'.  Court was not required to adjudicate upon question as to what will be effect of order and further whether he will continue to be disqualified for purpose of contesting election even if prayer made by appellant is granted as such an issue is wholly alien to present controversy which can arise only in an election petition where validity of election may be called in question.  (1996)5 SCC 329 and 2001 ALL MR (Cri) 2160 (S.C.) - Distinguished. [Para 13]

heading: Election petition
Contents
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Contents - Deficiency in particulars cannot be a ground for dismissing the petition.

If the Court feels that the particulars as given in the petition are deficient in any manner the petitioner can be directed to supply the particulars and make the deficiency good. In any case, deficiency in particulars could not have been a ground for dismissing the petition at the threshold. It is only the non-supply of particulars though ordered by the Court which could have led to either striking-off the pleadings or refusal to try the related instances of alleged corrupt practice.   [Para 13]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Affidavit filed in support of allegations of corrupt practice - Defect in verification and affidavit is a curable defect - Election petitioner should be given an opportunity to remove defect by filing a proper affidavit.

The proviso enacted to sub-section (1) of Section 83 of the Act is couched in a mandatory form inasmuch as it provides that a petition alleging corrupt practice shall be accompanied by an affidavit in the prescribed form in support of the allegations of such corrupt practice and the particulars thereof. The form is prescribed by Rule 94-A. But at the same time, it cannot be lost sight of that failure to comply with the requirement as to filing of an affidavit cannot be a ground for dismissal of an election petition in liminae under sub-section (1) of Section 86 of the Act. The defect in the verification and the affidavit is a curable defect. What other consequences, if any, may follow from an allegedly "defective" affidavit, is required to be judged at the trial of an election petition but Section 86(1) of the Act in terms cannot be attracted to such a case. (2001)4 SCC 428 and (2001)2 SCC 247 Rel. on. 			 [Para 14]

heading: Presentation of election petition
HeadNote.description: Presentation of election petition - Can be presented by any candidate at such election - "Candidate" would not mean only such person where nomination form has been accepted or whose name appears in the list of validly nominated candidate.			(Para 13)

heading: Nomination paper
HeadNote.description: Nomination paper - Question of rejection can arise only when defects pointed out are not removed - Nomination paper cannot be rejected at the threshold.			(Para 13)

heading: First proviso
Election petition
HeadNote.description: First proviso - Election petition - Clear averment that nomination paper was subscribed by 10 proposers - Whether averment is true or not can only be decided during trial - Election petition cannot be rejected on this ground. 1993 Supp (4) SCC 386 Disting.	(Para 14)

heading: Payment of deposit
HeadNote.description: Payment of deposit - Can be made after acceptance of nomination paper for scrutiny but before presentation of nomination paper.	(Para 18)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Statement of "material facts" - Meaning of.

The phrase 'material fact' as used in Section 83(1)(a) of the Act or Order VI Rule 2 of the Code of Civil Procedure has not been defined in the Act or the Code of Civil Procedure. In our opinion all specific and primary facts which are required to be proved by a party for the relief claimed are material facts. It is settled legal position that all material facts must be pleaded by the party on which the relief is founded. Its object and purpose is to enable the contesting party to know the case which it has to meet. An election petition can be summarily dismissed if it does not furnish the material facts to give rise to a cause of action. However, what are the material facts always depend upon the facts of each case and no rule of universal application is possible to be laid down in this regard. 		 [Para 21]

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Affidavit in support of - Verification to be on lines of O.19, CPC.

The non-disclosure of grounds or sources of information in an election petition which is to be filed within 45 days from the date of election of the returned candidate, will have to be scrutinised from two points of view. The non-disclosure of the grounds will indicate that the election petitioner did not come forward with the sources of information at the first opportunity. The real importance of setting out the sources of information at the time of the presentation of the petition is to give the other side notice of the contemporaneous evidence on which the election petition is based. That will give an opportunity to the other side to test the genuineness and veracity of the sources of information. The other point of view is that the election petitioner will not be able to make any departure from the sources or grounds. If there is any embellishment of the case it will be discovered.  [Para 14]

Form No.25 of the Conduct of Election Rules requires the deponent of an affidavit to set out which statements are true to the knowledge of the deponent and which statements are true to his information. The source of information is required to be given under the provisions in accordance with Rule 7 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court Rules. In so far as form No.25 of the Conduct of Election Rules requires the deponent to state which statements are true to knowledge there is no specific mention of the sources of information in the form. The forms of the affidavit and the High Court Rules are not inconsistent. The High Court Rules give effect to provisions of Order 19 of the Code of Civil Procedure.  [Para 11]

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Appeal to voters on ground of religion and threatening them with divine displeasure - However all witnesses produced were prepared on the same pattern of evidence, each witness spoke in identical words and in the same sequence about speeches of appellant - Their version was similar to reading cyclostyled copies of the speech - They cannot be relied on.			(Paras 25, 29, 52)

heading: Requisition of vehicles for the election work of Assembly
HeadNote.description: Requisition of vehicles for the election work of Assembly - State Government alone can requisition the vehicle.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Order of requisition
HeadNote.description: Requisition of vehicles for the election work - Order of requisition - It is obligatory for Government to mention compensation to be paid to person whose vehicle has been requisitioned. 1997(1) ALL MR 73 - Rel. on.	(Para 5)

heading: Improper nomination
HeadNote.description: Improper nomination - Whether returned candidate was a member of two registered political parties - Candidate contested election as a member of DMK - Tamil Nadu Indian Union Muslim League not being a registered political party candidate's continuing as a member of that party on date of filing of nomination paper cannot disqualify him for contesting election - Hence acceptance of his nomination paper was not invalid - Moreover TNIUML had aligned with DMK before polls.			(Paras 15, 17)

heading: Whether election is materially affected
HeadNote.description: Whether election is materially affected - Entire electioneering was done by two major pre-poll formations and there was no confusion that TNIUML was aligned with DMK - Moreover margin between returned candidate of DMK and defeated candidate was of 1,78,610 votes - Hence it cannot be said that result of election was materially affected.	(Para 30)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Standard of proof is as in criminal trial - To say that it is higher than one applicable in civil cases and lower than one applicable in criminal cases is contrary to settled principles of law. (1964)6 SCR 750 - Ref.	(Para 8)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - In election trial it is not permissible to the High Court to discard substantive oral evidence on account of defect in the pleadings. AIR 1966 SC 773 - Rel.on.	(Para 10)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Charge cannot be proved merely on basis of oral evidence because it is very easy to get help of interested witnesses. (1975)4 SCC 533 - Rel.on.	(Para 12)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Hearsay evidence in articles published in newspapers - Reporters of the paper denying personal knowledge of events published in newspaper - Cannot be relied on. 1994 Supp (3) SCC 5, (1988)3 SCC 319 - Rel.on.	(Para 12)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Attributing corrupt practice by a third person to the candidate - It must be proved that candidate had consented to the commission of such act.	(Para 21)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Distribution of offending pamphlets - Order under S.98 against returned candidate for vicarious liability - Notice to distributors of pamphlets and to name them as persons guilty of corrupt practice with requisite contumacious mind is necessary - If party workers who allegedly distributed pamphlets had no contumacious mind, appellant can hardly be fastened with any vicarious liability.			(Para 22)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Publication of offending pamphlets - Reproduction and distribution of information within a short period of few months cannot be regarded as publication of statements of facts relating to personal character and/or conduct of returned candidate - It is wrong to say that republication as in defamation law amounts to publication so far as Section 123(4) of the Act is concerned.	(Para 25)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
[Para 27]
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Corrupt practice - Distribution of offending pamphlets - It must be proved that returned candidate believed statement that was published to be an untrue statement.

One of the important ingredients in proving the offence of corrupt practice under Section 123(4) of the Act is that it has to be established that the returned candidate believed the statement that was published, to be an untrue statement. It is significant that unlike the law of defamation, where truth is a defence, Section 123(4) of the Act not only recognizes truth as a defence by using the words "publication of any statement of fact ..... which is false....." but additionally protects the maker of the statement by stipulating that the maker must believe the statement to be false. The onus of proving that the maker believed the statement to be false rests with the election petitioner.  AIR 1966 SC 773 - [Para 27]

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Publication of offending pamphlets - Reproduction of material from "crime" magazine - Whether "crime" magazine is yellow journal is a matter of opinion and not of fact - Opinion in this respect cannot be taken judicial notice of for purposes of Ss.56 or 57 of Evidence Act.	(Para27)

heading: Corrupt practice
What constitutes
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - False statement should relate to personal character or conduct of defeated candidate - If it is about some one other than candidate it would not be a corrupt practice. (1970)1 SCC 392 - Rel.on.	(Para 24)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Pamphlet published addressed certain questions to a rival candidate requiring him to give an answer to ordinary congressmen about a member of his personal staff who attempted to murder a Congress Mandalam President and two others and was absconding - Held it was not possible to read an implied false statement that rival candidate harboured a member of his personal staff who was accused to have murdered three persons and was absconder.	(Para 27)

heading: Corrupt practice
Rel.on.	(Paras 28-30)
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Statement that candidate should give an answer about a member of his personal staff alleged to have murdered three persons and was absconding - No clear pleading that this statement was an innuendo and it really meant that the candidate harboured his personal staff member - Innuendo is required to be clearly pleaded and extrinsic facts must be proved to spell out innuendo meaning of words complained of. (1990)3 SCC 396 - Rel.on.	(Paras 28-30)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Use of interrogative form in pamphlet - It is often employed as an assertion - Facts of each case must be examined and not go by any rule of thumb.	(Paras 33, 34)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Statement not about personal character and conduct of defeated candidate but about his public and political character - This does not attract S.123(4) of the Act - Unless all the ingredients of corrupt practice are made out election cannot be set aside straightaway on the basis of incorrect allegation.			(Paras 37, 38)

heading: Submission of return of election expenses
HeadNote.description:
Submission of return of election expenses - It cannot be said that responsibility of Election Commission is only to ensure form and not substance.

Under Section 10A when the Election Commission, on being satisfied that a person failed to lodge an account of election expenses within the time specified and in the manner required by or under this Act, can pass an order of disqualification of such person for a period of three years from the date of its order, it is needless to state that such an exercise should be carried out by the Election Commission with utmost care and caution and not by merely finding that there is a statement of account claimed to be a true copy of the election expenses maintained by the candidate and that it was lodged with the DEO in the appropriate format. In such an event, the concerned candidate can go scot- free even in a case where it can be brought to the notice of Election Commission that apart from the expenses disclosed in the statement of expenses lodged with the Election Commission, the candidate concerned had incurred various other expenses in a clandestine manner by adopting various manipulations and thereby, violating the requirement of law in particular Section 77(1) and (3) of the Act and thereby in effect not only cheat the electorate concerned, but even a constitutional authority in whom a very heavy responsibility has been invested under Article 324(1) of the Constitution. In fact, the requirement of an enquiry to be made by the Election Commission at the instance of the President of the country under Article 103 and in the case of Members of Parliament under Article 192 by the Governor of the State in the case of Member of Legislative Assembly of the State, fortifies above conclusion that even the President of the country and the Governor of a State can rely upon the report of the Election Commission based on an enquiry before taking a decision under Article 103(2) and under Article 192(2) of the Constitution. Therefore, to call the Election Commission's responsibility before passing an order under Section 10A only to see the form and not substance as canvassed by the Appellant is a proposition too difficult to accept.      [Para 46]

The maintenance of expenses, as mandated under Section 77(1), should not only be correct, but also be bona fide expenses. Therefore, even the explanation to sub-section (1) to Section 123 makes it clear that incurring of election expenses and the maintenance of account of those expenses are not an empty formality but the very purpose of stipulating such restrictions and directions under Section 77(1) and (3) read along with Section 78 explains the mandate to maintain absolute purity in elections by the contesting candidates. This is required in order to ensure that the process of the election is not sullied by resorting to unethical means while incurring election expenses.      [Para 47]

Court cannot turn a Nelson's eye and state that Section 77(1) and (3), as well as 78 would be relevant only for the purpose of ascertaining the corrupt practices under Section 123(6) of the Act and that such requirement of incurring bona fide and correct expenditure need not be a requirement for ascertainment for the Election Commission while exercising its powers under Section 10A of the Act. In fact, ascertainment of the requirement under Section 77(3) viz the expenses incurred, do not exceed the limit prescribed and can be made both for the purpose of an enquiry under Section 10A, as well as in the event of a candidate exceeding the limit as a corrupt practice for the purpose of invalidating the election. Therefore, the requirement under Section 77(3) has got twin objectives to be fulfilled.      [Para 48]

heading: Powers of Election Commission
HeadNote.description:
Powers of Election Commission - It can only pass order of disqualification for not lodging account of election expenses - It cannot set aside election of successful candidate. 

While exercising power under Section 10A, the Election Commission cannot set aside the election of a successful candidate. Section 10A talks of only an order of disqualification that can be passed by an Election Commission. Further, such disqualification order can be passed for failure to lodge an account of election expenses and such failure was within the time and in the manner required by or under the Act. Therefore, the scope of an Election Petition to be tried by an Election Tribunal (High Court) and the scope of an order of disqualification to be passed under Section 10A are entirely different and it must be stated that one does not conflict with the other.

It cannot therefore, be contended that once the Election Petition having been rejected for want of particulars, which order has become final, a complaint under Section 10A cannot be pursued.

1999 (1) SCC 666 Foll. to.      [Para 59]

heading: Locus standi
HeadNote.description:
Locus standi - Complaint against illegality in submission of account of election expenses - Any citizen whether a voter or not who seeks inspection of accounts and gets a copy of accounts can move appropriate authorities to point out illegalities committed in submission of accounts.

Reading Section 10A along with Rules 87 to 90, in particular, the right conferred on any person to seek for inspection of the accounts submitted, it will have to be held that such a right is not conferred merely to look into the details of the account. If based on the inspection, made by a person under Rule 88 and the attested copies of such accounts disclose that the candidate concerned committed a very serious illegality in the matter of submission of the account of election expenses, it must be stated that such a person will have every right to bring it to the notice of the Election Commission for taking appropriate legal recourse available to that person under the Act. It may be stated that once any such misfeasance in the submission of the account of the election expenses is brought to the notice of the Election Commission, thereafter it would be for the Election Commission to set the process in motion for deciding the issue as contemplated in Section 10A of the Act. It cannot be said that no person can by way of a complaint approach the Election Commission.

1999 (1) SCC 666 Foll.      [Para 69]

heading: Election petition
Contents
Material facts
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Contents - Material facts - Allegations about tampering of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) - Mere imaginary allegations about possibility of mal-functioning, irregularity or tampering with EVMs - Not sufficient to constitute corrupt practice in absence of proper pleadings and evidence.

In this case all the allegations relating to tampering of EVMs are based on possibility imagined by the petitioner. Mere imaginary allegation of such possibility of occurrence of malfunctioning or irregularity is no ground to challenge the election. All the allegations in this behalf are described in the petition as, "could be", "apprehension of manipulation", "scope for manipulation", "huge scope for doubts", "possible to rig", "could contain several flaws". Such "ifs" and "buts" are suspicions, howsoever strong, cannot take place of material facts constituting cause of action. The pleadings must disclose complete cause of action. There are no pleadings of material facts :-

(a) 	which can afford basis of allegations made in it.

(b) 	which are necessary to constitute complete cause of action.

(c) 	to constitute any "corrupt practice", specific description of one of the corrupt practices enumerated in Section 123.

Thus, there is no issue of fact amounting to corrupt practice which would be framed. There is no triable issue which can call for any further investigation and even if evidence is allowed to be led, it cannot be taken into consideration in the absence of pleadings. The petition, which does not comply with the requirements of Section 83(1)(a) and (b) can be dismissed at the threshold. 			    [Para 17]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Fact that S.83 does not find place in S.86 does not mean that powers under CPC cannot be exercised - Absence of material facts and insufficiency of cause of action would result in dismissal of election petition.

Since the Code of Civil Procedure applies to the trial of an election petition by virtue of Section 87 of the Act, the Court trying the election petition, can exercise powers of the Code including Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11(a) of the Code of Civil Procedure. The fact that Section 83 does not find place in Section 86 of the Act does not mean that powers under the Code of Civil Procedure cannot be exercised.

An election petition shall disclose all material facts on which the petitioner relies to establish existence of cause of action. Material facts essentially refer to all the relevant facts on which the petitioner relies for purposes of drawing inferences in his favour during the course of trial. The absence of material facts and insufficient cause of action would inevitably lead to dismissal of election petition.

The actual mischief or intentional tampering or consequential malfunctioning of EVMS is a question of fact, which is required to be pleaded with material particulars. Instant petition does not disclose material fact of tampering of EVMs by respondent or at the instance of respondent so as to draw an inference that the elections have been materially affected because of such tampering or manipulation of EVMs.	    [Para 18,23,24]

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Excess expenditure on paid news in newpapers and other publications - No evidence about whether alleged publications were prior to presentation of nomination paper by respondent or thereafter - It will provide no cause of action to plead corrupt practice. 		(Para 30)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Absence of proper affidavit - If petition raises triable issues absence of affidavit in proper format can be cared by filing a proper affidavit but if petition does not disclose material facts same is required to be dismissed.			(Para 34)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Approach in deciding.

 Election dispute is not an action at law or a suit in equity, but is a purely statutory proceeding unknown to the common law and that the Court possesses no common law power. It is also well settled that the success of a candidate who has won at an election should not be lightly interfered with and any petition seeking such interference must strictly conform to the requirements of law. It is not a private Civil dispute between two parties. A conscientious approach is required to be taken. Neither turning a blind eye to the controversies, which has arisen nor assuming a role of overenthusiastic activist would do. The two extremes have to be avoided in dealing with election disputes. 

The election petition shall have to be decided on the touch stone of the aforesaid principle.  [Para 1]

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Neither an action at common law nor in equity - It is a statutory proceeding - Must strictly conform to statutory provisions.

Right to elect, though it is fundamental to democracy, is neither a fundamental right nor a common law right. It is purely a statutory right. So is the right to be elected. So is the right to dispute an election. Dehors the statute, there is no right to elect, no right to be elected and no right to dispute an election. They are statutory creations and therefore, subject to statutory limitation. A election petition is not an action at common law nor in equity. It is a statutory proceeding to which neither the common law nor the principles of equity apply but only those rules which the statute makes and applies. It is a special jurisdiction and a special jurisdiction has always to be exercised in accordance with the statute creating it. Concepts familiar to common law and equity always remain strangers to election law. In the trial of election dispute, Court is put in a straight jacket. The entire election process commencing from the issuance of the notification calling upon a constituency to elect a member or members and right up-to the final resolution of the dispute, if any, concerning the election, is regulated by the Representation of People of Act Act, 1951. The election law being statutory in character must be strictly adhered. The Election Petition must conform to the requirements of election law. Unless grounds U/s 100 of the R.P. Act of 1951, are proved, no election of a successful candidate can be set aside.   [Para 8]

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Nomination paper not properly filled in - Defect of substantial character which could not have been rectified after last date for filing of nomination paper or on date of scrutiny of nomination paper - Petitioner cannot be said to have cause of action to maintain election petition - It can be rejected at the threshold. (Paras 24, 26)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Whether returned candidate belonged to Scheduled Caste - Appellant on five earlier elections was elected from a constituency reserved for Scheduled Caste - Father of appellant was originally a member of Scheduled Caste before his conversion to Christianity - Appellant reconverted himself to Hinduism in 1978 and was admitted into Scheduled Caste by local people and he also married a Scheduled Caste girl and marriage was performed according to Scheduled Caste form - Certificate that he belonged to Scheduled Caste was also issued by Tahasildar - Held appellant was qualified under S.4(a) to be chosen to fill the seat reserved for Scheduled Caste and his nomination was validly accepted and hence his election was not void.	(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Corrupt practice
Charge of
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Charge of - Should be proved almost like the criminal charge - Charge should be clear and precise and must be proved to the hilt as in a criminal trial by cogent and credible evidence.	(Paras 24, 26)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Election of returned candidate should not be lightly interfered with - At the same time purity of election process has to be maintained.			(Paras 25, 29)

heading: Corrupt practice
Charge of
Proof
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Charge of - Proof - Allegation that winner was moving from village to village asking for vote and in this process he took help of two gazetted officers for canvassing votes in his favour - Apex Court after re-assessing and re-evaluating entire evidence concurred with High Court that appellant had failed to prove ingredients of S.123(7).			(Paras 32, 35, 36)

heading: Ground of subsisting contract with appropriate Government
HeadNote.description: Ground of subsisting contract with appropriate Government - "Appropriate Government" refers to State Government alone, and not to any instrumentality of State Government - Godawari Marathwada Irrigation Development Corporation and Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran though may fall within scope of "State" they are not "State Government" for purpose of S.9-A - Returned candidate though having subsisting contracts with them is not disqualified to contest election. 2005(2) ALL MR 539 (Bom) Reversed.	(Paras 11, 17, 19, 20)

heading: Disqualification under
Subsisting contract
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification under - Subsisting contract - Meaning of.

What is relevant under section 9-A of the Act is that the contractor should have some obligations to perform towards the State Government on the relevant date. In fact, the explanation to section 9-A makes it clear that where a contractor has performed all his obligations, but the government is yet to perform its obligations (for example, where the work assigned under a work order is completed by the contractor and that is duly certified, but payment therefor is not yet made by the Government) then there is no contract 'subsisting' within the meaning of section 9-A of the Act.   [Para 23]

heading: Material facts
HeadNote.description:
Material facts - Are those facts on which a party relies for his claim or defence.

The expression 'material facts' has neither been defined in the Act nor in the Code.  According to the dictionary meaning, 'material' means 'fundamental', 'vital', 'basic', 'cardinal', 'central', 'crucial', 'decisive', 'essential', 'pivotal', indispensable', 'elementary' or 'primary'. [Burton's Legal Thesaurus, (Third edn.); p.349]. The phrase 'material facts', therefore, may be said to be those facts upon which a party relies for his claim or defence.  In other words, 'material facts' are facts upon which the plaintiff's cause of action or the defendant's defence depends.  What particulars could be said to be 'material facts' would depend upon the facts of each case and no rule of universal application can be laid down.  It is, however, absolutely essential that all basic and primary facts which must be proved at the trial by the party to establish the existence of a cause of action or defence are material facts and must be stated in the pleading by the party.  [Para 23]

heading: "Material facts" and "particulars"
HeadNote.description:
"Material facts" and "particulars" - Distinction between.

A distinction between 'material facts' and 'particulars', must not be overlooked. 'Material facts' are primary or basic facts which must be pleaded by the plaintiff or by the defendant in support of the case set up by him either to prove his cause of action or defence.  'Particulars', on the other hand, are details in support of material facts pleaded by the party.  They amplify, refine and embellish material facts by giving distinctive touch to the basic contours of a picture already drawn so as to make it full, more clear and more informative.  'Particulars' thus ensure conduct of fair trial and would not take the opposite party by surprise. All 'material facts' must be pleaded by the party in support of the case set up by him.  Since the object and purpose is to enable the opposite party to know the case he has to meet with, in the absence of pleading, a party cannot be allowed to lead evidence.  Failure to state even a single material fact, hence, will entail dismissal of the suit or petition.  Particulars, on the other hand, are the details of the case which is in the nature of evidence a party would be leading at the time of trial.  [Para 25]

There is distinction between facta probanda (the facts required to be proved, i.e. material facts) and facta probantia (the facts by means of which they are proved, i.e. particulars or evidence).  It is settled law that pleadings must contain only facta probanda and not facta probantia. The material facts on which the party relies for his claim are called facta probanda and they must be stated in the pleadings.  But the facts or facts by means of which facta probanda (material facts) are proved and which are in the nature of facta probantia (particulars or evidence) need not be set out in the pleadings.  They are not facts in issue, but only relevant facts required to be proved at the trial in order to establish the fact in issue.  [Para 39]

heading: Material facts
Allegation is complete
HeadNote.description: Material facts - Allegation of double voting by 60 persons - Allegation is complete - Whether or not the election petitioner is able to prove the said allegation is a matter of evidence which can be considered only at the trial - Petition cannot be said to be defective for not stating material facts.	(Para 33)

heading: Material facts
HeadNote.description: Material facts - Petitioner stating that 19 persons voted in two constituencies and six persons whose names were given were issued postal ballot papers twice and they voted twice and as such all these votes should be treated as void - Held, material facts were stated by the petitioner and High Court stepped into prohibited area of considering correctness of allegations and evidence in support of averments by entering into the merits of the case which would be permissible only at the stage of trial of the Election Petition and not at the stage of consideration whether the Election Petition was maintainable and dismissed the petition.			(Paras 33-37, 41) (Paras 33-37,  41)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - On ground of improper and illegal reception and acceptance of votes and not on ground of corrupt practice - Petitioner was only required to state material facts under S.83(1)(a) and not full particulars as under S.83(1)(b) - Held, High Court went wrong in insisting on material particulars when deciding election petition under S.83(1)(a).

In this case allegations in Election Petition related to improper and illegal reception and acceptance of votes and the election-petitioner has challenged the election of the returned candidate on that ground and not on the ground of 'corrupt practice'.  He was, therefore, required to state material facts in the Election Petition under Section 83(1)(a) of the Act.  It was, however, not necessary to 'set forth full particulars', which is the requirement of Section 83(1)(b) of 'any corrupt practice'. The High Court dismissed the petition inter alia on the ground that paras 8(i) to (iv) lacked in material particulars.  Apart from the fact that the law does not require material particulars even in respect of allegations of corrupt practice but only full particulars and if they are lacking, the petition can be permitted to be amended or amplified under Section 86 of the Act, in the instant case, Clause (b) of Section 83(1) had no application and the petition has been dismissed by the High Court by applying wrong test.  On that ground also, the order passed by the High Court is unsustainable.  [Para 42]

heading: Election dispute
Recounting of votes
HeadNote.description:
Election dispute - Recounting of votes - Not to be resorted to in absence of genuine apprehension of mis-count or illegality.

A right to be elected is neither a fundamental right nor a common law right, though it may be very fundamental to a democratic set-up of governance. Therefore, answer to every question raised in election dispute is to be solved within the four corners of the statute. The result announced by the Returning Officer leads to formation of a government which requires the stability and continuity as an essential feature in election process and therefore, the counting of ballots is not to be interfered with frequently. More so, secrecy of ballot which is sacrosanct gets exposed if recounting of votes is made easy. The court has to be more careful when the margin between the contesting candidates is very narrow. "Looking for numerical good fortune or windfall of chance discovery of illegal rejection or reception of ballots must be avoided, as it may tend to a dangerous disorientation which invades the democratic order by providing scope for reopening of declared results". However, a genuine apprehension of mis-count or illegality and other compulsions of justice may require the recourse to a drastic step.      [Para 7]

heading: Recounting of votes
Election petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Pleadings - Court cannot pass an order beyond pleadings of parties - Order of recounting can be passed only if pleadings in this respect is supported by material facts.(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Secrecy of ballot paper
HeadNote.description:
Secrecy of ballot paper - Importance of.

The secrecy of a ballot is to be preserved in view of the statutory provision contained in Section 94 of the Act. Secrecy of ballot has always been treated as sacrosanct and indispensable adjunct of free and fair election. Such principle of secrecy is based on public policy aimed to ensure that voter may vote without fear or favour and is free from any apprehension of its disclosure against his will. Though secrecy of ballot is an inherent principle in conducting elections, however, the said principle has diminished to some extent in view of the rule of whip as prescribed in Tenth Schedule to the Constitution of India.          [Para 11,12]

heading: Composite election petition
HeadNote.description:
Composite election petition - Section allows returned candidate to recriminate and raise counter pleas in support of his case - But in doing so returned candidate is not allowed to lead any evidence because he is precluded from raising any pleas against the validity of claim of alternative candidate.

In a composite election petition wherein the petitioner claims not only that the election of the returned candidate is void but also that the petitioner or some other person be declared to have been duly elected, Section 97 of the Act comes into play and allows the returned candidate to recriminate and raise counter-pleas in support of his case, "but the pleas of the returned candidate under Section 97 have to be tried after a declaration has been made under Section 100 of the Act." The first part of the enquiry is in regard to the validity of the election of the returned candidate which is to be tried within the narrow limits prescribed by Section 100 (1) (d) (iii) while the latter part of the enquiry governed by Section 101 (a) will have to be tried on a broader basis permitting the returned candidate to lead evidence in support of the pleas taken by him in his recrimination petition. If the returned candidate does not recriminate as required by Section 97, then he cannot make any attack against the alternative claim made by the election petitioner. In such a case an enquiry would be held under Section 100 so far as the validity of the returned candidate's election is concerned, and if as a result of the said enquiry, declaration is made that the election of the returned candidate is void, then the Tribunal will proceed to deal with the alternative claim, but in doing so, the returned candidate will not be allowed to lead any evidence because he is precluded from raising any pleas against the validity of the claim of the alternative candidate.     [Para 18]

In the instant case, as explained hereinabove, there were 706 total votes, out of which 701 votes were polled. At the time of initial counting, both the candidates got equal votes as 336 and 29 votes were found invalid. On the request of the appellant, the Returning Officer permitted recounting of the votes and the appellant got 336 votes while the respondent no.1 got 335 votes and 30 votes were found to be invalid. In the election petition, the only grounds had been that 3 votes polled in favour of respondent no.1 which had wrongly been rejected and one vote which had been counted in favour of the appellant ought to have been declared invalid.

In view of the pleadings in the election petition, the case should have been restricted only to these four votes and even if the recrimination petition is taken into account, there could have been no occasion for the High Court to direct recounting of all the votes and in case certain discrepancies were found out in recounting of votes by the Registrar of the High Court as per the direction of the High Court, it was not permissible for the High Court to take into consideration all such discrepancies and decide the election petition or recrimination petition on the basis thereof. The course adopted by the High Court was impermissible and cannot be taken note of being in contravention with statutory requirements.        [Para 19,20]

heading: Election dispute
HeadNote.description:
Election dispute - Instructions in Hand Book for Returning Officers are binding on them in counting the ballots. 
2009 ALL SCR 1581 Rel.on.    (Para 25)

heading: Election dispute
HeadNote.description: Election dispute - Appellant and respondent receiving equal number of votes - Who will be the returned candidate is to be decided by draw of lots.(Paras 35, 36)

heading: Electoral roll
Publication of
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Registration of Electors Rules (1960), Rr.22, 24 - Electoral roll - Publication of - Effect - Once electoral roll is finally published, no Court can interfere with the said publication of electoral roll.

The Courts cannot decide any issue relating to issuance or revision of an electoral roll. The remedy lies in the procedure laid down in the prescribed rules. There is scope for challenging the contents of the electoral roll. However, once an electoral roll is finally published, it becomes final and then no court can interfere with the said publication of the electoral roll and it shall be the electoral roll of the constituency. The power of delimitation of constituencies vests in the Delimitation Commission and the preparation of electoral rolls vests in the Election Commission. In the absence of a fresh order of delimitation issued by the Delimitation Commission, the Election Commission had no power to change the electoral roll for the constituency.  AIR 1963 SC 479, (2000)8 SCC 46 - Rel.on.  [Para 19,24]

The power to carry out delimitation of the constituencies has been vested with the Delimitation Commission constituted under the Delimitation Act, 2002. The object of the Act is to provide for the re-adjustment of the allocation of seats in the House of People to the States, the total number of seats in the legislative assembly of each State, the division of each State and each Union Territory having a legislative assembly in to territorial constituencies for elections to the House of People and legislative assemblies of the States and Union Territories and for matters connected therewith. Section 8 of the Act provides for re-adjustment of number of seats, Section 9 of the Act provides for Delimitation of constituencies, Section 10 of the Act provides for publication of orders and their date of operation by Commission in the Gazette of India and in the official Gazettes of the State concerned and on such publication, every such order shall have the force of law and shall not be called in question in any court. Section 11 of the Act mandates that the Election Commission shall maintain delimitation orders up-to-date.  (1995)6 SCC 721 - Ref.   [Para 11]

heading: Material facts
HeadNote.description:
Material facts - Election petition must disclose all material facts and cause of action - In their absence petition is liable to be dismissed.

An election petition must clearly and unambiguously set out all the material facts which the appellant is to rely upon during the trial, and it must reveal a clear and complete picture of the circumstances and should disclose a definite cause of action. In the absence of the above, an election petition can be summarily dismissed. To see whether material facts have been duly disclosed or whether a cause of action arises, one must look at the averment and pleadings taken up by the party.  AIR 1969 SC 1201, (2007) SCC 617, (2004)7 SCC 181 - Rel.on.   [Para 35]

The averments of the appellants in the election petition did not disclose any definite cause of action. The appellant pleaded that the names of the 21 localities have been wrongfully included in the electoral roll of the relevant constituency. But there has been no order by the Election Commission for the alteration of the electoral rolls of the constituency. Furthermore the Election Commission does not have the power to amend the electoral roll as there has been no fresh delimitation carried out by the Delimitation Act. Delimitation is to be carried out by the Delimitation Commission and in furtherance of the delimitation carried out by the Commission, the Election Commission shall proceed to prepare electoral rolls for the constituency. Therefore, there has been no default on the part of any of the authorities, so as to render any votes void. There has been no violation of any of the provisions of the Act or the rules framed thereunder. The appellant primarily relies on the communication issued by the Election Commission but the same cannot be construed as any direction on the part of the Commission. The averments also do not disclose any material facts. As observed by the High Court, the main concern of the appellant in effect is the addition of the 21 colonies into the Meerut constituency and not in relation to addition or deletion of names in the electoral roll. But yet there has been no specific pleading in this regard in the election petition. The pleading should have been with respect to the said inclusion of the 21 colonies into the Meerut municipality constituency which was later incorporated into the 381 Meerut Municipality constituency. In the absence of such pleadings, it can safely be said that the election petition does not disclose any material facts and, therefore, High Court was right in summarily dismissing the election petition.   [Para 38]

heading: Concise statement of material facts
HeadNote.description: Concise statement of material facts - Concise means brief and comprehensive - Furnishing of facts in compendious manner is necessary and not material particulars. 	(Para 14)

heading: Annexures attached to election petition
HeadNote.description: Annexures attached to election petition - Signed and verified by petitioner - They form integral part of election petition. 	(Para 19)

heading: Election petition
Contents of
Disqualification for membership
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.7 R.11(a) - Election petition - Contents of - Disqualification for membership - Respondent holding post of chairperson of State Wakf Board - Receiving honorarium, allowances and facility of car with driver at State expense - These facts disclose a cause of action and whether respondent holds office of profit or not is an issue that will have to be tried in the petition - Petition disclosed cause of action and it should not have been thrown out at the threshold. 			(Paras 15, 24, 25, 34)

heading: Setting aside election petition
HeadNote.description:
Setting aside election petition - Court should not take unduly technical view as to nature of pleadings.

If the election petition sets out the requisite material facts that disclose a cause of action and gives rise to triable issues, which can not be given a short shrift by taking an unduly technical view as to the nature of the pleadings. There is no denying the fact that Courts are competent to dismiss petitions not only on the ground that the same do not comply with the provisions of Sections 81, 82 & 117 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 but also on the ground that the same do not disclose any cause of action. The expression "cause of action" has not been defined either in the Civil Procedure Code or elsewhere and is more easily understood than precisely defined. While examining whether a plaint or an election petition discloses a cause of action, the Court has a full and comprehensive view of the pleading, averments made in the plaint or petition cannot be read out of context or in isolation. They must be taken in totality for a true and proper understanding of the case set up by the plaintiff.

2006(6) ALL MR 18 (S.C.), (1977) 1 SCC 511, (2005) 10 SCC 760, 2005(4) ALL MR 17 - Rel. on.  [Para 3,4]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Can be dismissed for non-compliance of Ss.81, 82, 117 and can also be dismissed if matter falls within scope of O.6 R.16 or O.7 R.11.

(1999) 2 SCC 217 Rel. on. (Para 7)

heading: Prolongation of proceedings by prevarication
HeadNote.description: Prolongation of proceedings by prevarication - Not conducive to ends of justice - So also request for dismissal of petitions at the threshold - Caution to be exercised by courts. (Para 12)

heading: Filing of affidavit
HeadNote.description: Filing of affidavit - Affidavit not filed in prescribed format - Issue not raised before High Court and point not argued at the Bar - Deficiency, however, not causing any prejudice to successful candidate - It can be cured by election petitioner by filing a proper affidavit - Petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold for failure to file affidavit in proper format. (Para 23)

heading: Result of election whether materially affected
HeadNote.description: Result of election whether materially affected - Nothing to show that any incorrect information had been supplied or material information suppressed - Respondent trouncing nearest candidate by securing 2/3 rd of the votes polled and petitioner who is challenging his election had secured only 1% of votes polled the respondent - Held no question of declaring respondent's election as null and void arose. (Para 22)

heading: Election petition
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Returned candidate whether a Hindu belonging to Scheduled Caste - Burden of proof - Is on petitioner to prove that returned candidate is not a Hindu belonging to Scheduled Caste but a Christian.

In the instant case, merely because the appellant had stated in her counter affidavit that she got converted into Hindu faith in the year 1994 in Arya Samaj, Madurai, after following the required essential rituals, the learned Judge while deciding the lis between the parties has shifted the burden of proof on the appellant to disprove that she is not a Christian but a person practicing Hindu faith and the community has accepted her as a person belonging to Hindu Pallan Community. This reasoning of the learned Judge runs counter to the settled legal principles. In an election petition the burden of proof lies on the person who accuses that the elected person who had the support of the majority of the electorates still does not deserve to represent them in the State Assembly. In the present case, the appellant candidly accepts that her father is a Christian, but her mother who is separated from him never practiced Christian faith but continued to follow Hindu religion even after her marriage. The election petitioner has not produced any acceptable evidence to disprove the evidence adduced by the appellant and her witnesses. Therefore, issue of parentage which was sought to be projected as a factor which would prove that the appellant is a Christian and brought up as a Christian cannot be accepted.   [Para 47]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - False, incorrect statement about school where returned candidate studied - Explanation that declaration form was filled in by brother and candidate signed it - Sufficient to explain discrepancy - Moreover it cannot be a ground to hold that candidate was ineligible to contest from reserved constituency.	(Para 48)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Contents of.

An election petition must clearly and unambiguously set out all the material facts which the petitioner is to rely upon during the trial, and it must reveal a clear and complete picture of the circumstances and should disclose a definite cause of action. In the absence of the above, an election petition can be summarily dismissed. To see whether material facts have been duly disclosed or whether a cause of action arises, we need to look at the averment and pleadings taken up by the party.  		 [Para 52]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Cannot be based on frivolous grounds - Burden of proof about facts lie on the petitioner.

One cannot file an election petition based on frivolous grounds. The facts presented must be clear, concise and unambiguous. An election result, where the people elect their representatives cannot be taken lightly. For an election result to be annulled, there must be positive evidence to prove illegality of the election. The natural corollary is that the person who files an election petition, must have a clear and definite case, to prove that the election was illegal. Therefore the burden of proof shall lie on the petitioner filing the election petition. An election petition challenging the election of a returned candidate on the grounds of corrupt practices is not a criminal proceeding; but it is no less than a criminal proceeding with regard to the proof required to be furnished to the Court by the Petitioner. Though, in the present case, the charges are not those of corrupt practices, they are not any lesser in terms of seriousness; hence the burden of proof is on the election petitioner to prove the charges he has made beyond reasonable doubt. This is done so that the purity of the election process is maintained.   [Para 54,55]

heading: Distinction between
HeadNote.description:
Distinction between - Failure to sign and verify original copy filed in Court and failure to attest copy served on respondent - Failure to comply with S.81 is fatal to election petition but failure to comply with S.83 is not fatal.

Legally there is a distinction between failure to sign and verify the original copy of the election petition filed in the Court and failure to attest the copy served on the respondent to be a true copy of the election petition. While the latter failure falls within the scope of Section 81(3), the earlier failure falls under sub-Section (1)(c) and sub- Section(2) of Section 83. While the failure to comply with the requirements of Section 81 obligates the High Court to dismiss the election petition, the failure to comply with the requirements of Section 83 is not expressly declared to be fatal to the election petition.
1996(1) ALL MR 256 Rel. on.  [Para 10]

heading: Parties to election petition
HeadNote.description:
Parties to election petition - Who can be impleaded.

It can be seen from section 82 as to who should be made parties to an election petition depends upon two factors.

The first factor is the nature of the relief sought by the petitioner. Where a further declaration as contemplated under section 101 is sought, the petitioner is bound to make all the contesting candidates parties respondents to the election petition. Where no such declaration is sought, the section stipulates that it is enough to make all the returned candidates at the election, parties to the election petition. The employment of the expression "all the returned candidates" is obviously meant to cover disputes relating to elections to Rajya Sabha or Legislative Councils where more than one candidate is declared elected at the same election.  [Para 38]

If allegations pertain to commission of any corrupt practice by any one of the candidates at the election other than the returned candidate, such other candidates are also required to be made parties-respondents to the election petition.  [Para 21]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Section 82 speaks of candidates, Section 83(1)(b) speaks of 'parties'.

The question of proof of the commission of a corrupt practice arises only if there is an appropriate pleading in that regard in the election petition. Section 83 stipulates that an election petition, which contains allegations of corrupt practice, must contain full particulars of the "names of the parties" alleged to have committed a corrupt practice. The Legislature chose to use the expression 'PARTIES' for the reason that there are various categories of persons, who are capable of committing a corrupt practice in connection with the election of a returned candidate - (i) the returned candidate; or (ii) his election agent, or (iii) any other person with the consent of either the returned candidate or his election agent; or (iv) any other agent, as explained earlier. The difference in the language of Section 82 and 83(1)(b), is significant. While Section 82 speaks of candidates, Section 83(1)(b) speaks of parties.  [Para 45]

heading: Annexures
HeadNote.description:
Annexures - Are integral part of election petition where content of annexure is not fully described in main petition.

An annexure to an election petition, whose content is not described in the election petition, would not become the integral part of the election petition for all the purposes. It is only for a limited purpose of deciding the question whether a copy of the election petition, served on the respondent in the election petition, is a true copy of the original filed into the Court within the meaning of Section 81(3) of the Act, annexures are treated as integral part of the election petition, that too, only in the situation, where the content of the annexure is not fully described in the body of the main petition. [Para 56]

heading: Allegations in the petition
HeadNote.description:
Allegations in the petition - Allegations made not in the body of election petition but in a document annexed to election petition of which election petitioner is not the author - Allegations cannot be said to have been made in the petition.

Firstly, the document annexure is not authored by the election petitioner; secondly, in the entire body of the election petition there is no reference to any corrupt practice committed by other candidate. Making such an allegation against other candidate would in no way help the election petitioner to obtain the relief sought by him in the election petition in the election petition particularly when petition does not seek a further declaration under S.84 of the Act.  [Para 58,59]

heading: Election Petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Pleadings - Material facts must the pleaded at the outset - Failure to plead is fatal to election Petition - No amount of evidence can cure defect in the pleadings. 

2001 (8) SCC 233, 2000 (8) SCC 291 Rel. on. (Para 16)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Improper reception of votes and booth capturing - Ground neither pleaded nor issue framed - Respondent applying for calling voters register only to make fishing and roving inquiry to improve his case - Held Single Judge was clearly in error in allowing such application. (Para 19)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Candidate is required not only to prove his case of improper reception of votes but also to prove that such improper reception has materially affected his case. (Para 20)

heading: Production and inspection of election papers
HeadNote.description:
Production and inspection of election papers - Should be allowed very sparingly and only when absolutely essential to determine the issue. 

AIR 1964 SC 1249, AIR 1975 SC 2117 Rel. on. (Paras 23, 24)

heading: Election petition
Application for dismissal
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Application for dismissal - On ground that no triable issue disclosed to justify regular trial of allegations - Petitioner alleged corrupt practice with regard to incurring of expenditure in contravention of limit prescribed u/S.77(3) of RP Act - Petitioner mentioned dates on which advertisements had appeared, particulars of newspapers in which such advertisements were published and also cost incurred for each type of advertisement in each newspaper - It cannot be said that full particulars required u/S.83(1)(b) not furnished - Therefore, issue requires full-fledged trial - Petition cannot be dismissed on said ground. 1986 (supp) SCC 315, (1996) 1 SCC 399 Disting. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Alleged corrupt practice of submission of false return of election expenses - Petitioner alleging that expenses incurred in public meetings by respondent returned candidate is much more than what has been shown in return of election expenses - However, particulars as to source of information of petitioner with regard to details furnished, whether he has any personal knowledge of any of said meetings, names of persons who informed him of details of such meetings etc., are absent - In absence of said particulars said allegations do not disclose any triable issue - Trial of said allegations not justified. 	(Para 12)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Respondent returned candidate allegedly took assistance of a Gazetted Officer to further his election prospects - Petitioner pleaded that said person was Officer of Punjab State Electricity Board - Appellant had got him transferred to post of Addl. Superintending Engineer under State of Punjab - If that be so, said issue will have to go for full trial - Petition cannot be dismissed on ground that no triable issue disclosed to justify regular trial of allegations. 		(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
Bribery etc.
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Corrupt practice - Bribery etc. - Material facts and sufficient particulars must be stated - Deficiency can be made up at a later stage.

An election petition must contain a concise statement of the material facts on which the petitioner relies and set forth full particulars of any corrupt practice that the petitioner alleges, including as full a statement as possible of the names of the parties alleged to have committed such corrupt practices and the date and place of the commission of each such practice. It also requires that the petition be signed by the petitioner and verified in the manner laid down in the Code of Civil Procedure for the verification of the pleadings. While an election petition must necessarily contain a statement of material facts, deficiency if any, in providing the particulars of a corrupt practice could be made up by the petitioner at any later stage. The provision has been interpreted to mean that while a petition that does not disclose material facts can be dismissed as one that does not disclose a cause of action, dismissal on the ground of deficiency or non-disclosure of particulars of corrupt practice may be justified only if the election petitioner does not despite an opportunity given by the Court provide the particulars and thereby cure the defect.  (1969)3 SCC 238, (1972)3 SCC 850, 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 123 - Rel.on. 			 [Para 4,5]

heading: Election petition
Is curable
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Defect in verification of pleadings - Is curable - Petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold under S.86(1) for any such defect. (1991)3 SCC 375 - (Para 11)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
Material facts
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Material facts - Notice in newspaper alleging corrupt practice of bribery by elected candidate - Material facts about number of copies transported, number of vehicles used, names of drivers, names of persons who distributed published materials stated - Details of expenditure incurred also given - Matter remanded to High Court as it was not justified in dismissing petition at the threshold.	(Paras 22-24)

heading: Election
Applicability
HeadNote.description: Election - Filing of nomination paper - Requirement of submitting copy of voter list at the time of filing nomination paper - Applicability - Said requirement is applicable only when a person files his nomination paper for being elected from a place falling in a constituency in which his name does not find place in voter list and his name is registered in voters list of another constituency - When nomination filed on basis that candidate's name finds place in that constituency only, such requirement of law would have no relevance. 1999(3) ALL MR 339 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 2128 Rel. on.  (Paras 13, 14)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Charge of corrupt practice - Charge has to be proved beyond reasonable doubt and not merely by preponderance of probabilities. (1991)3 SCC 375 : AIR 1991 S.C. 1557 - Rel. on.			(Para 23)

heading: Election petition
Requirements of S.83
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Requirements of S.83 - An election petitioner can afford to overlook requirements of S.83 on pain of weakening the evidence that he may ultimately tender at the actual trial of the election petition.	(Para 23)

heading: Election petition
Absence of verification
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Absence of verification - In pleading itself, authenticity of all documents prima-facie sufficiently established - Essential facts to prove breaches of Rules with relevant legal provisions, sufficiently brought on record by him - Absence of verification in relation to each document therefore, cannot be held to be fatal and that defect can be allowed to be cured by making appropriate amendments in accordance with law.			(Para 27)

heading: Election petition
Dismissal of
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Dismissal of - Where an election petition is filed under S.83 r/w. S.100(1)(d)(iii) & (iv) of the 1951 Act and the pleadings in election petition reveal a clear complete picture of the circumstances and disclose a definite cause of action, election petition cannot be summarily dismissed. (2010)4 SCC 81 - Rel. on.			(Para 28)

heading: Election petition
Amendment of pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Amendment of pleadings - Election petition is a serious exercise and must be resorted to with all sincerity - Election petitioners avoiding to plead vital link between alleged breaches and the success of Returned candidate - This omission cannot be allowed to be cured by amendment as limitation for filing Election petition has long expired and "material facts" cannot be now permitted to be added.		(Para 32)

heading: Corrupt practice
Standard of proof
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Standard of proof - Charge has to be proved beyond doubt.
