The standard of proof required for establishing a charge of corrupt practice is the same as is applicable to a criminal charge. This implies that a charge of corrupt practice is taken as proved only if there is clear cut evidence which is entirely credible by the standards of appreciation applicable to such cases.  (1976)2 SCC 45, (1977)1 SCC 260 - Rel.on.   [Para 9]

heading: Corrupt practice
Standard of proof
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Standard of proof - It is unsafe to accept oral evidence at its face value unless the same is backed by unimpeachable and incontrovertible documentary evidence. (1977)1 SCC 771, (1978)1 SCC 504, (1990)2 SCC 173 - Rel.on.	(Para 10)

heading: Corrupt practice
Finding about
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Finding about - Ordinarily Court of first appeal would not disregard opinion by trial Judge more so when trial Judge happens to be a High Court Judge who has recorded evidence and who has had benefit of watching demeanour of witnesses in forming first-hand opinion regarding their credibility.	(Para 14)

heading: Corrupt practice
Proof
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Proof - Neither the candidate nor his election agent was witness to receiving bribes - Affidavits sworn by witnesses in this regard was carbon copy of the other - Parrot like story was contained in affidavits drawn by Advocate in his chamber - Witnesses were partisan in character - No documentary evidence about complaints lodged with election authorities was produced - Absence of a plausible explanation for non-production of documentary evidence would completely discredit version which oral evidence attempts to support - Allegations made against respondent about her attending a feast given to employees of a Tea Estate denied in examination-in-chief - Respondent was not cross-examined on this point by the appellant - Held, having regard to seriousness of charge of corrupt practice, and nature of evidence that has been adduced present is a fit case to give benefit of doubt to the respondent and leave her election untouched.	(Paras 17-22)

heading: Election petition
Disqualification u/S.9A
HeadNote.description: Vidarbha Irrigation Development Corporation Act (1997) - Election petition - Disqualification u/S.9A - On ground that contracts of candidate who was Govt. contractor with VIDC were subsisting on date of filing of nomination paper - However, said VIDC is not an 'Appropriate Govt' - It is distinct corporation and was established under Act of 1997 - Therefore, any contract with VIDC would not attract disqualification u/S.9A - Election petition stands dismissed. 2006(3) ALL MR 200 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Para 4)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Change of name of candidate in Election Voting Machine - Whether, violated provision of S.33(4) - Upon request of candidate, his name in ballot paper shown in manner by which he was commonly understood - No dispute with regard to identity of candidate nor case that voters were misled by use of such commonly understood name - In case person or place is described in manner as same is commonly understood, it shall not affect full operation of electoral roll - No breach of S.33(4) - In any event, election of candidate can be declared as void u/S.100 (1)(d)(iv) if by virtue of non-compliance of S.33(4), result of election has been materially affected - Such is not case sought to be made out - Election petition stands dismissed. (Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Proof required is of consent for the publication and not connivance.

Mere knowledge by itself will not imply consent, though, the vice-versa may be true. The requirement under Section 123(4) of the RP Act is not knowledge but consent. Connivance is different from 'consent'. According to the Concise Oxford English Dictionary, 'connive' means to secretly allow a wrong doing where as 'consent' is permission. The proof required is of consent for the publication and not connivance on publication.

(1984) 1 SCC 390 Rel. on.

No doubt, on charges relating to commission of corrupt practices, direct proof of consent is very difficult. Consent is to be inferred from the circumstances however, if an inference on consent from the circumstances is to be drawn, the circumstances put together should form a chain which should lead to a reasonable conclusion that the candidate or his agent has given the consent for publication of the objectionable material.    [Para 29,30,31]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Whether barred by limitation - Appellant claiming that petition earlier filed was returned by Registry for curing defects and when it was re-presented period of limitation was expired - Registry has not given permission for curing defects, it only directed to place petition before Court as unnumbered petition - Minor corrections which were not material were permitted to be made by Court, within one week's time - Only after defects were cured within stipulated time notices were issued to parties - Petition was not presented beyond time stipulated in S.81(1) - Not barred by limitation. (Paras 15, 16)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Presentation of petition whether in violation of S.81(3) of RP Act - Alleged corrupt practice by elected candidate in making false allegation against a candidate - Contention that chip of mobile phone in which conversation of parties was recorded, not submitted with election petition - Contents of chip of mobile phone has been reproduced in CD and provided to other party with transcription and translation - Whether translation correctly reflects what was said, is to be considered at time of trial - Presentation of petition is not in violation of S.81(3).  (Paras 17, 19)

heading: Assembly elections
Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Assembly elections - Election petition - Plea of improper acceptance of nomination paper of a candidate - Cannot be ground to set aside election of such candidate unless result of election has been materially affected.

In case of improper acceptance of nomination paper of a candidate other than the elected candidate, the election of the returned candidate can not be set aside on that ground, unless the election petitioner further establishes that as a consequence of such improper acceptance, the result of the election has been materially affected.  The scheme of section 100 of the Representation of People Act, especially clause (d) of sub-section (i) thereof clearly prescribes that inspite of availability of grounds contemplated by sub-clause (i) to (iv) of clause (d) the election of a returned candidate shall not be voided unless and until it is proved that the result of the election in so far as it concerns to a returned candidate was materially affected.  In the instant case, there is no evidence to show material effect on the election of respondent assuming that the nomination paper of respondent no.2 was improperly accepted.  It is true that the votes secured by respondent no.2 are almost three times more than difference of votes secured by respondent and petitioner, but then in the absence of any material on record, would be just by way of speculation to assume that entire votes secured by respondent no.2 could have been secured by the petitioner, in case the nomination of respondent no.2 were to be rejected.  The possibility of respondent no.1 having some more votes of the votes secured by respondent no.2 cannot be ruled out.  Therefore, it can not be concluded that the election of respondent no.1 would be materially affected as a result of improper acceptance of the nomination paper of respondent no.2.

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Plea of improper acceptance of nomination paper - Caste claim of respondent validated by Caste scrutiny committee and fortified by order of high court - Scrutiny of nomination paper being based on said validation - Acceptance of respondent's nomination paper cannot be said to be improper - More so as petitioners did not challenge his caste claim.	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Affirmation in Form 25
HeadNote.description: Affirmation in Form 25 - Nothing in election petition to personal knowledge of petitioner - Even then source of information not disclosed either with regard to particulars or facts - It can be held that affidavit is not in conformity with R.94 A and Form No.25. (Para 7,9)

heading: Amendment in petition
Court has discretion
HeadNote.description:
Amendment in petition - Court has discretion - It is for petitioner to seek amendment - No duty is cost on court to ask petitioner to amend.

Under Section 86(5) the High Court may allow the particulars of any corrupt practice alleged in the petition to be amended or amplified. The Court must form an opinion as to the amendment being necessary for the fair trial of the petition. It is not for the court to suo motu request or direct the petitioner to amend. Once the preliminary objection is raised it is the duty of the petitioner to take out the necessary application for amendment. It is only material particulars that can be amended.  [Para 10]

heading: Corrupt practice
Pleading in petition
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Pleading in petition - Plea that elected candidate distributed hand bills appealing on basis of community - No details as to who published and when consent of elected candidate was obtained for it - Petition is liable to be dismissed.

The failure to plead even a single material fact amounts to disobedience of the mandate of Section 83 (1) (a). Failure to prove material facts is fatal to the Petition. The Court has no option but to dismiss the Petition on the threshold. In the present case there are no details as to how and when the consent of the Respondent was obtained.  [Para 14]

In the present case the pleadings are sadly lacking in exactitude. The pleadings are not as required by law, as laid down by the Supreme Court, in a catena of judgments, to bind the Petitioner to the charge of the corrupt practice levelled by him and to prevent any fishing or roving enquiry and to prevent the returned candidate from being taken by surprise. In such circumstances the defects have to be fatal to maintainability of the petition. The material facts cannot be permitted to be pleaded by way of amendment.  [Para 14]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Service of copy on elected candidate - Essentials.

The copy served on the elected candidate is a photostat copy and is duly attested by the petitioner by putting his signature on each page with the endorsement "True copy". It is not the requirement of Section 81 (3) that the endorsement should read "Attested to be True copy". Section only requires that it must be under the signature of the Petitioner. This has been done. Therefore, this issue is decided in the negative.   [Para 12]

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - Precise statement of fact and particulars - Concise statement of all material facts of corrupt practice including names of person committing it, time and place of commission alleged in petition - Petition does not suffer from want of material facts. (Para 8)

heading: Not sustainable
HeadNote.description:
Affidavit accompanying election petition - In affidavit Petitioner not required to disclose his source of information - All such affidavits do not form integral part of petition - But when affidavit supplements material facts stated in petition it becomes an integral part - Since affidavit in accordance with Form 25 - Plea for rejection of plaint for defective affidavit - Not sustainable - Also as defect in verification curable - Time granted to petitioner to cure such defect.

AIR 1964 SC 1545, 1973(2) SCC 759, 1979(2) SCC 221, AIR 1991 SC 1557 - Rel. on.

AIR 1995 SC 2284, AIR 2000 SC 341, AIR 2000 SC 388 - Disting. (Paras 13, 18)

heading: Election Petition
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Burden of proof - Burden is upon the election petitioner to show affirmatively that the result of the election has been materially affected - Failure to state even a single material fact will entail dismissal of election petition - In election Petition, there cannot be roving and fishing inquiry at a trial without pleading. 

(a) Burden is upon the election petitioner to show affirmatively that the result of the election has been materially affected.

(b) The casting of votes at an election depends upon variety of factors and it is not possible for anyone to predicate how many or which proportion of votes will go to one or the other of the candidates. While it must be recognized that the petitioner in such a case is confronted with a difficult situation, it is not possible to relieve him of the duty imposed upon him by Section 100(1)(c) and hold without evidence that duty has been discharged.

(c) It is necessary for the petitioner to specifically plead that the election in so far it concern the returned candidate has been materially affected by non compliance with the provisions of the Act of 1951 or the Rules made thereunder. 

(d) Whether in an election petition, a particular fact is material or not and as such requires to be pleaded is dependent on the nature of the charge levelled and circumstances of the case. All the facts which are essential to clothe with complete cause of action must be pleaded.

(e) An election petition can be summarily dismissed if it does not furnish cause of action in exercise of power under Civil Procedure Code. Appropriate orders in exercise of powers under the Code can be passed if mandatory requirements enjoined by Section 83 of the Act to incorporate material facts in election petition are not complied with.

 Failure to state even a single material fact will entail dismissal of election petition. 

(f) It gives a mandate to the electoral registration officers not to amend, transpose or delete any entry in the electoral roll of a constituency after the last date for making nominations for election in that constituency and before the completion of that election. 

(g) The entire scheme of the Act of 1950 and the amplitude of its provisions show that the entries made in an Electoral Roll of a constituency can only be challenged in accordance with the machinery provided by it and not in any other manner or before any other forum unless some question of violation of the provisions of the Constitution is involved. 

In election petition there cannot be roving and fishing inquiry at a trial without pleading. Bridging up gaps at the trial for want of pleading are not permitted. Section 87 of 1951 Act takes care of applicability of Code of Civil Procedure, still, Section 83 refers to requisite contents of the petition to inform concise statement of material facts on which the petitioner alleges; allegations of corrupt practice will invite an affidavit in the prescribed form in support of allegations of such corrupt practice and particulars thereof.
2009 ALL SCR 2419, 1970(3) SCC 147, AIR 1969 SC 663 - Rel. on.   [Para 11,19]

heading: Election petition
Dismissal of
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Dismissal of - An election petition should not be summarily dismissed if the defects are minor or cosmetic in nature. 

An election petition should not be summarily dismissed if the defects are minor or cosmetic in nature. In order to maintain the sanctity of the election, the Court should not take such technical attitude and dismiss the election petition at the threshold. On the contrary, after finding the defects, the Courts should give proper opportunity to cure the defects and, in case of failure, to remove or cure the defects, it could result into dismissal.
2008(3) ALL MR 488 (S.C.) - Rel. on.   [Para 11]

heading: Interpretation of Statute
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statute - It is only where the provision of Statute are ambiguous that the Court can depart from literal or strict construction. 

It is only where the provisions of Statute are ambiguous that the Court can depart from literal or strict construction. Where the words of a statute are plain and unambiguous must be given effect to them. There should be judicial restraint and the temptation to do judicial legislation should be eschewed by the Courts. In fact, judicial legislation is an oxymoron.  [Para 11]

heading: Electoral roll
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Electoral roll - Challenge to - Entries made in electoral roll can only be challenged in accordance with machinery provided by it and not before any other forum. 

Entries made in electoral roll can only be challenged in accordance with machinery provided by it and not before any other forum. Finality of electoral cannot be challenged in an election petition, even if certain irregularities had taken place in preparing Electoral roll. The voters were not disqualified under Section 16 of 1950 Act. In the light of this legal position, merely for alleged breach of Section 23(3) of 1950 Act, by virtue of amendment in 1956,  in 1951 Act, the petition would not be maintainable under Section 100 of 1951 Act. 
AIR 2003 SC 4603 - Ref. to.  [Para 23]

heading: Election petition
Want of affidavit
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Want of affidavit - No allegations of corrupt practice made in petition in terms of S.123 of the 1951 Act - Petition would not fail for want of affidavit under R.94 of Election Rules, 1961, alleging corrupt practice. 

In the present case, the petitioner has clarified that he has not made allegations of corrupt practice in terms of Section 123 of 1951 Act. Whatever pleadings of unfair play or mala fides exists is owing to reference of deleted respondents. Since the respondents are deleted, the pleadings of unfairness or mala fides or ulteriorness of the election officers has become inconsequential. Hence, held the petition would not fail for want of affidavit under Rule 94 of Election Rules,1961, alleging corrupt practice.  [Para 24]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Application for dismissal of petition in limine - Petitioner had filed written statement raising various objections - However, no application filed for dismissal in limine immediately - Rather, applicant gave his consent in allowing amendment to election petition - Applicant even gave his consent to allow further amendment applied by petitioner orally - Petitioner thereafter filed 3 separate applications for various other reliefs - Gross delay on part of applicant in filing application for dismissal of petition in limine on ground of certain alleged defects pointed out across the bar and not raised in written statement - Therefore, application for dismissal of petition, dismissed.	(Para 71)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Application for dismissal of petition in limine - Election petition was filed on two grounds i.e. applicant had indulged in corrupt practice and on grounds mentioned in S.100(1)(d)(iii) - Objections raised in written statement pertain to allegation of corrupt practice and not in respect of any other pleadings - Subsequently allegations of corrupt practices withdrawn by petitioner by way of amendment for which applicant also gave his consent - Alleged defects pointed out by applicant for dismissing petition in limine, were not stated in written statement - Moreover, alleged defects are relating to verification of some of documents which do not go to the root of matter and are cosmetic in nature - It appears to have been raised to delay hearing of petition further - Therefore, application dismissed. 2008(3) ALL MR 488 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 2, 49, 50, 53, 64, 67, 68)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Bombay High Court (Original Side) Rules, R.7 - Election petition - Procedure before filing, explained.

Under Sub-Rule 4 of Rule 15 of Order 6 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, the persons verifying the pleadings is also required to furnish affidavit in support of his pleadings. It is not in dispute that at page 158 of the election petition, the petitioner has already filed an affidavit in support dated 2nd December, 2014 and has repeated, reiterated and confirmed the averments made in the accompanying election petition. It is averred that the same has been deemed to have been incorporated in the said affidavit. In my view there is thus no substance in the submission of the learned counsel for the applicant that the affidavit in support of the election petition was not in compliance with the Sub Rule 4 of Rule 15 of Order 6.   [Para 78]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Application for dismissal of petition in limine - Alleged defect in verification of pleadings - Is curable and can be rectified by giving an opportunity to petitioner to remove such defect - No requirement to incorporate what is incorporated in verification clause under O.6 R.15(2) in affidavit in support of pleadings - Petition cannot be dismissed in limine. 2004(5) ALL MR 322 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Paras 79, 80)

heading: Election petition
Approach of Court
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Approach of Court - Findings not to be recorded casually without actually looking into evidence and pleadings - Objection raised by respondent that requisite affidavits not filed by petitioner - Without looking into evidence of petitioner that such affidavits were actually filed, Court recorded a finding that non filing is a curable defect for which petition cannot be dismissed - Thus, decision was given in favour of petitioner but he was aggrieved of finding that affidavits were not filed by him - Held, it is wholly unsatisfactory way of dealing with any issue in a judicial proceeding and more so with election petitions - Election petitions deal with basic rights of citizenry - It is too serious a matter to be dealt with casually. 			(Para 20)

heading: Jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction - Clarification sought on interlocutory order passed in election petition - Contradiction between Section 80A(2) of Representation of People Act which prescribes hearing by Single Judge and High Court Rules which prescribe hearing by DB - Held, High Court Rules are subject to provisions of any law of the appropriate Legislature - It cannot curtail statutory provision under S.80A(2). 

	The adjudication of election petitions including the examination of all incidental questions in interlocutory proceedings arising during the course of the adjudication of the election petition is entrusted by Section 80A of the Representation of People Act, 1951 to the High Court within whose jurisdiction the election dispute arises. Section 80A(2) stipulates that the jurisdiction shall be exercised ordinarily by a Single Judge who is to be designated by the Chief Justice.

	Though the said Section indicates that the Chief Justice has a discretion to entrust trial of an election petition to a Bench consisting of more than one judges, such a discretion is to be exercised by the Chief Justice alone.

	The Rules of the High Court are framed by the High Court pursuant to the power vested in it under Article 225. The exercise of such power is subject to the provisions of the Constitution and the "provisions of any law of the appropriate legislature". Rule 13 mandates the listing of certain matters (nature of which is described therein) before a Division Bench. Such stipulation is contrary to the stipulation of Section 80A(2) that election petitions are to be tried by a single judge of the High Court leaving a discretion in the Chief Justice to decide whether in a given case, an election petition shall be heard by more than one Judge. Such a statutory discretion vested in the Chief Justice of the High Court cannot be curtailed by a rule made as the High Court in view of the clear declaration by the Constitution (in the opening clause of Article 225) that "any rule shall be subject to the law made by the appropriate legislature". 				 [Para 31]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.6 R.15 - High Court of Madhya Pradesh Rules (2008), R.6(4) - Election petition - Requirement to file affidavit alongwith petition - It is a question of fact to be proved by petitioner - Respondent pointed out absence of seal and signature of Registrar only on affidavit annexed to petition - It was contended that absence of such seal suggests that affidavit was inserted in subsequent time - However, it is a matter of record that from the beginning, petitioner took a clear stand of having filed requisite affidavits - Such a stand was never disputed by respondent by filing rejoinder - Respondent himself admitted that when he received summons, there was relevant affidavit annexed to it - Record shows that in the beginning, respondent objected only against format of affidavit - At subsequent stage, he objected to the very filing of affidavit - His changed contention now is that affidavit was inserted beyond period of limitation - Respondent cannot shift his case from stage to stage - Finding that petitioner had filed requisite affidavit, confirmed. 	(Paras 38, 39, 43)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Prayer for dismissal of, at threshold - On ground of non-removal of office objections raised by office/registry of High Court - However, no averment in application stating as to which office objection remained to be cured when matter was placed before the Court - Grievance made in application on mere conjectures and surmises, cannot be basis to dismiss election petition at threshold - Hence, rejection of application held, proper - Gujarat High Court Rules (1993), Rr.282, 283, 284, 285. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Prayer for dismissal of - Contention that copy of election petition served on appellant was not a true copy within meaning of S.81(3) of RP Act - High Court observed that appellant did not file original copy of election petition served on him but produced only a photocopy thereof and rejected contention of appellant - Fact that appellant undertook to produce original of actually served copy at time of hearing and that same was so produced, not recorded by High Court - Manifest error committed by High Court - Parties relegated before High Court for consideration of said grievance - Moreso because appellant has taken plea that he pointed out 20 discrepancies in copy of election petition served on him.	(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Affidavit filed under proviso to S.83(1) - Affidavit constitutes an integral part of the petition itself - It must strictly comply with requirements of the Act and Rules - Otherwise, Petition itself would be defective and therefore, it would be liable to be summarily dismissed.

The affidavit which is required to be filed under proviso to sub-section 1 of Section 83 forms a part of the petition.  It is further to be seen here that sub-section (1) of Section 83 requires that every petition shall be signed and verified in the manner laid down in the Code of Civil Procedure.  As observed above, the verification clause of the petition does not refer to the paragraphs of the petition, which relate to the corrupt practice under Section 123(4).  That defect in the verification clause is supplied by the affidavit which in terms refers to those paragraphs which are omitted from the verification clause of the petition and therefore, the learned Counsel appearing for the Respondent No.1 rightly submitted that it is for this reason that the petitioner himself states that this affidavit should be treated as a part and parcel of the election petition.  Therefore, it would be safe to say that in so far as the present case is concerned, the affidavit filed under proviso to sub-section 1 of Section 83 of the Act constitutes an integral part of the petition itself.  Therefore, it must strictly comply with the requirement of the Act and the Rules.  The affidavit filed in the present case does not either strictly or substantially comply with the requirement of the Act or the Rules.  Therefore, the petition as framed and filed can not be said to be petition filed under Section 81 of the Act.  Hence, the petition is liable to be summarily dismissed under Section 86 of the Act.AIR 1978 SC 840 and AIR 1968 SC 1079 - Referred to. [Para 14]

heading: Election Petition
Defect fatal
HeadNote.description:
Election Petition - Document merely referred to in election petition without reproducing the contents thereof - Document forms an integral part of the petition - Copy of the document, not filed - Defect fatal - Petition liable to be dismissed.

Where a document is incorporated in petition by reference without reproducing the contents of the document in the body of the petition, then a copy of that document has to be filed with the election petition as it forms an integral part of the election petition and if a copy is not so filed, the defect is fatal and the petition is liable to be dismissed under the provisions of Section 86 of the Act.  [Para 18]

In so far as the present case is concerned, it is clear that in the election petition, the cassettes have merely been referred to and contents thereof have not been reproduced.  Therefore, the cassettes which have been referred to in paragraph 38 form an integral part of the petition and as neither the cassettes have been filed in this Court nor the copies of the cassettes have been supplied to the Respondent No.1, there is a fatal defect, which calls for dismissal of the petition under Section 86.  [Para 19]

heading: Election petition
Period for filing
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Period for filing - Limitation - Date of election of returned candidate is not to be counted.

By Section 81(1), the legislation fixes the period for filing election petition and at the same time states that no elector or candidate shall file election petition before the date of election of the returned candidate and if there are more than one returned candidates at the election and dates of their election are different, the later of those two dates. The first day for the period of limitation is required to be excluded for the convenience of the parties and if the declaration of the result is delayed or is done late in the night, the candidate or elector would hardly get any time for presentation of the election petition. Law comes to the rescue of such parties to give full forty-five days' period for filing the election petition. Nevertheless, any petition presented on the date of election of the returned candidate would be certainly within the period of limitation as it is a presentation on the date of election of the returned candidate.  [Para 14]

heading: Computation of limitation of 45 days
HeadNote.description:
Computation of limitation of 45 days - Words "within forty-five days from" - Word "from" is used indicating the beginning - First day of the period is to be excluded.

Section 9 of the General Clauses Act says that in any Central Act or Regulation made after the commencement of the General Clauses Act, 1897, it shall be sufficient for the purpose of excluding the first in a series of days or any other period of time, to use the word "from", and, for the purpose of including the last in a series of days or any period of time, to use the word "to". The principle is that when a period is delimited by statute or rule, which has both a beginning and an end and the word "from" is used indicating the beginning, the opening day is to be excluded and if the last day is to be excluded the word "to" is to be used. In order to exclude the first day of the period, the crucial thing to be noted is whether the period of limitation is delimited by a series of days or by any fixed period. This is intended to obviate the difficulties or inconvenience that may be caused to some parties. For instance, if a policy of insurance has to be good for one day from the 1st January, it might be valid only for a few hours after its execution and the party or the beneficiary in the insurance policy would not get reasonable time to lay claim, unless the 1st January is excluded from the period of computation.  [Para 12]

In order to apply Sec. 9, the first condition to be fulfilled is whether a prescribed period is fixed "from" a particular point. When the period is marked by terminus a quo and terminus ad quern, the canon of interpretation envisaged and Sec. 9 of the General Clauses Act, 1897 require to exclude the first day. The words "from" and "within" used in Sec. 81 (1) of the R. P. Act, 1951 do not express any contrary intention.  [Para 13]

heading: Election petition filed by defeated candidate
HeadNote.description:
Election petition filed by defeated candidate - Copy of petition supplied to elected candidate not attested as true copy by petitioner but by his advocate - Provisions of S.81(3) vitiated.

An Election Petition is liable to be thrown out at the threshold without the trial under section 86 of the Representation of People Act if the Election Petition violates the mandatory provisions contained in section 81. Mandatory provision contained in sub section 3 of section 81 says that every election petition shall be accompanied by as many copies thereof, as there are respondents mentioned in the petition and every such copy shall be attested by the petitioner under his own signature to be true copy of the petition. Where each page or each annexure is signed by the petitioner in the election petition but copy thereof was attested as true copy by his advocate it cannot be said that there is substantial compliance of S.81(3).  [Para 8,9,19,20]

heading: Election petition
Compliance of provisions
It creates confusion
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Compliance of provisions - Omission to write name of attesting officer - It creates confusion - Defect is fatal.

Where the name of the attesting officer and verification is missing in the copy of election petition supplied to returned candidate doubt may arise and confusion may creep in as to whether it was signed by a proper officer and as to what objection has to be raised in the Election Petition. Therefore, absence of the name of the officer before whom the petitioner put signature can not be said to be one that can be substantially complied with. It is really a fatal defect.  [Para 19,20,21]

heading: Election petition
Non
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Strict compliance of provisions - Supply of copy of petition to opposite party - Non - supply of material particulars - Not curable by amendment.

In the copy of the Election Petition absence of verification of concise statement and affidavit can be treated as not only a defect under section 83(2), but also a non compliance of the section 81(3) of the Act as the true copy of the Election Petition cannot be said to be served on the respondent.  [Para 22,23]

heading: Recount of votes
HeadNote.description:
Recount of votes - When granted.

In election petitions which are filed with prayer for re-count of votes, the Court has always insisted upon a high standard of proof of grounds as would impel the Court to direct re-count of votes and re-check the election results. It is only after the election petitioner is able to demonstrate before the Court by leading satisfactory evidence that there was serious flaw in the counting procedure which had materially affected the result of election that the prayer for recount is generally allowed. In such a state of election law, the Court legitimately expects the parties to approach it with genuine grievances on truthful facts. Where false facts are pleaded and false evidence is produced to mislead the Court into interfering with the people's verdict of election, the misconduct of the parties to the election has to be viewed seriously. The Court allows an election petition only on strict proof of the grounds prescribed in Section 100 of the Act. If the parties to the election petitions are allowed to take the Court lightly even though attempts are skilfully made by them by false pleas and evidence to mislead the Court, the whole judicial process would be misused by clever parties to their advantage and to the detriment of the interest of the electorate who are vitally interested in the result of election.  [Para 20,21]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Ground for grant of recount - False statement made that application for recount was made prior to election results - Election petition dismissed and costs of Rupees twenty five thousand imposed.

In Election petition, if the parties are found to have made incorrect statements in their pleadings, affidavits or depositions and there is thereby an intention on their part to mislead the Court, appropriate deterrent action like dismissal of their cases with costs, prosecution for perjury or initiation of contempt proceedings should be taken by the Court lest the judicial process would continue to be polluted and misused by undeserving parties who have no real grievance or cause for seeking aid of judicial forums. Such false cases not only contribute to the work-load of the Court and kill its precious time but create hurdles in the ways of genuine litigants who sincerely need assistance of the Court for obtaining justice.					  [Para 23]

heading: Election petition
Verification of pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Verification of pleadings - Variation from language used in model form - Words "I believe the same to be true" and "no part thereof is false and nothing which is relevant is concealed" - Both expressions convey the same meaning and defect, if any, is not such as would entail dismissal of election petition.	(Para 5)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Affidavit with defective certification - After the signature of the deponent the only words occurring before the signature of Notary is, 'before me'. The words, 'solemnly affirmed by ....... at .......on this ......day of ...... 2006'. occurred above the signature of the deponent - Held this defect was of a very minor nature and could not entail dismissal of election petition - Court should have given opportunity to the party to rectify the same instead of resorting to dismissal at the out set.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Election petition
Defective petition
Non-compliance of S.83
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Defective petition - Non-compliance of S.83 - Consequences of S.86 does not follow - Petition cannot be rejected.

Whenever defects which do not go to the root of the matter are noticed, the proper course for the Court is not to dismiss the petition at the threshold. In order to maintain the sanctity of the election the Court should not take such a technical attitude and dismiss the election petition at the threshold. On the contrary after finding the defects, the Court should give proper opportunity to cure the defects and in case of failure to remove/cure the defects, it could result into dismissal on account of Order 6, Rule 17 or Order 7, Rule 11, CPC. Though technically it cannot be dismissed under Section 86 of the Act of 1951 but it can be rejected when the election petition is not properly constituted as required under the provisions of the CPC but in the present case the defects which have been pointed out in this election petition were purely cosmetic and it does not go to the root of the matter and secondly even if the Court found them of serious nature then at least the court should have given an opportunity to the petitioner to rectify such defects.   [Para 14]

heading: Secrecy of casting vote
HeadNote.description:
Secrecy of casting vote - In the direct elections to Lok Sabha or State Legislatures, maintenance of secrecy is a must. 
(2006) 7 SCC 1 Ref. to. (Paras 26, 27)

heading: Election petition
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Rejection of nomination on ground of non-compliance of S.33(1) - Challenge to - Election petition should contain averments that candidate was set up by a recognized political party by issue of a valid "B" form and that his nomination was signed by an elector of the constituency as a proposer, and that rejection was improper as there was no need for ten proposers - In absence of such averments, it cannot be said that election petition contains material facts to make out a cause of action.	(Para 6)

heading: Rejection of nomination
HeadNote.description: Rejection of nomination - Double entry of name of a citizen in electoral roll of a constituency - Not a ground of disqualification for registration in an electoral roll, nor is it a ground for rejecting nomination under S.36(2) of the Act. 1999(3) ALL MR 339 (S.C.) - Rel. on.			(Para 7)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Qualification or disqualification of a returned candidate - Has to be determined by reference to the date of his election - Whether a nomination was improperly accepted shall be determined by reference to the date fixed for scrutiny of nomination - Factum of pendency of an appeal against conviction is irrelevant - Subsequent decision in appeal or revision setting aside conviction or reduction in sentence, would not have the effect of wiping out disqualification. 

The question of qualification or disqualification of a returned candidate within the meaning of Section 100(1)(a) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 (RPA, for short) has to be determined by reference to the date of his election which date, as defined in Section 67A of the Act, shall be the date on which the candidate is declared by the returning officer to be elected. Whether a nomination was improperly accepted shall have to be determined for the purpose of Section 100(1)(d)(i) by reference to the date fixed for the scrutiny of nomination, the expression, as occurring in Section 36(2)(a) of the Act. Such dates are the focal point for the purpose of determining whether the candidate is not qualified or is disqualified for being chosen to fill the seat in a House. It is by reference to such focal point dates that the question of disqualification under sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of Section 8 shall have to be determined. The factum of pendency of an appeal against conviction is irrelevant and inconsequential. So also a subsequent decision in appeal or revision setting aside the conviction or sentence or reduction in sentence would not have the effect of wiping out the disqualification which did exist on the focal point dates referred to hereinabove. The decisive dates are the date of election and the date of scrutiny of nomination and not the date of judgment in an election petition or in appeal thereagainst.

(1970) 2 SCC 462, (1981) 2 SCC 84 Overruled.

(1961) 2 SCR 133 Rel. on.     [Para 61]

heading: Election
Disqualification on conviction
HeadNote.description:
Election - Disqualification on conviction - Expression "a person convicted of any offence and sentenced to imprisonment for not less than 2 years" - Meaning and applicability of - "A person convicted of any offence" is construed as all offences of which a person is charged and held guilty at one trial - Further, applicability of expression "sentenced to imprisonment for not less than 2 years", would be decided by calculating total term of imprisonment for which person has been sentenced.

R.C. Lahoti, CJI. (For self and on behalf of Shivraj V. Patil, B.N. Srikrishna and G.P. Mathur, JJ. :-

The word 'any' may have one of the several meanings, according to the context and the circumstances. It may mean 'all'; 'each'; 'every'; 'some'; or 'one or many out of several'. The word 'any' may be used to indicate the quantity such as 'some', 'out of many', 'an infinite number'. It may also be used to indicate quality or nature of the noun which it qualifies as an adjective such as 'all' or 'every'. In Section 8(3) of the RPA, the word 'any' has been used as an adjective qualifying the word 'offence' to suggest not the number of offence but the nature of the offence. A bare reading of sub-section (3) shows that the nature of the offence included in sub-section (3) is 'any offence other than any offence referred to in sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) (of Section 8)'. The use of adjective 'any' qualifying the noun 'offence' cannot be pressed in service to countenance the submission that the sentence of imprisonment for not less than two years must be in respect of a single offence.         [Para 51,52]

It is clear from a bare reading of sub-section (3) of Section 8 of the RPA that the actual period of imprisonment is relevant. The provisions of Section 8 of the RPA have to be construed in harmony with the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 and in such manner as to give effect to the provisions contained in both the legislations. In the case of consecutive sentences the aggregate period of imprisonment awarded as punishment for the several offences and in the case of punishments consisting of several terms of the imprisonment made to run concurrently, the longest of the several terms of imprisonment would be relevant to be taken into consideration for the purpose of deciding whether the sentence of imprisonment is for less than 2 years or not.          [Para 45,47]

The purpose of enacting disqualification under Section 8(3) of the RPA is to prevent criminalization of politics. Those who break the law should not make the law. Generally speaking, the purpose sought to be achieved by enacting disqualification on conviction for certain offences is to prevent persons with criminal background from entering into politics, and the House - a powerful wing of governance. Persons with criminal background do pollute the process of election as they do not have many a holds barred and have no reservation from indulging into criminality to win success at an election. Thus, Section 8 seeks to promote freedom and fairness at elections, as also law and order being maintained while the elections are being held. The provision has to be so meaningfully construed as to effectively prevent the mischief sought to be prevented. The expression "a person convicted of any offence" has to be construed as all offences of which a person has been charged and held guilty at one trial. The applicability of the expression "sentenced to imprisonment for not less than 2 years" would be decided by calculating the total term of imprisonment for which the person has been sentenced.                             [Para 54]

K. G. Balkrishan, J. (Contra) :-

I am unable to subscribe to the contention that the word "any" used in Section 8(3) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 should be construed so as to mean "more than one" or "all" or in a sense of plurality. It is also difficult to construe the words "not less than two years" used in Section 8(3) of the RPA by giving emphasis to the total period of imprisonment that a convict may undergo if all the periods of imprisonment for various offences are put together, when it is ordered to run consecutively.      [Para 67]

It is the gravity of the offence that matters and not the conviction for various minor offences and the total period of two years or more to be calculated by putting together all sentences for various minor offences. "Any offence" used in Section 8(3) of the RPA is to be taken as "out of many offences".     [Para 72]

Further, the direction for the sentence to run concurrently or consecutively is a direction as to the mode in which the sentence is to be executed. That does not affect the nature of the sentence. It is also important to note that in the Code of Criminal Procedure, there are no guidelines or specific provisions to suggest under what circumstances the various sentences of imprisonment shall be directed to run concurrently or consecutively. There are no judicial decisions, to my knowledge, by superior courts laying down the guidelines as to what should be the criteria for directing the convict to undergo imprisonment on various counts concurrently or consecutively. In certain cases, if the person convicted is a habitual offender and he had been found guilty of offences on various counts and it is suspected that he would be a menace if he is let loose on the society, then the Court would direct that such person shall undergo the imprisonment consecutively. Merely because the Magistrate ordered that the sentence shall run consecutively, and the aggregate period exceeds two years or more, a person convicted would not incur the disqualification under Section 8(3) of the RPA. If that be so, a Magistrate may order the sentence on various counts to run concurrently in one case and for the same type of offences, if another Magistrate directs the sentence on various counts to run consecutively, the person in the latter case would incur the disqualification whereas the former will not have any such disqualification under Section 8(3) of the RPA. The disqualification under Section 8(3) of the RPA shall not be solely dependent on the direction as to the mode in which the sentence is to be executed, especially when there are no statutory or judicial guidelines in this regard.                 [Para 69]

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - Protection to Members of House from disqualification - Purpose and interpretation of the provision.

Sub-section (4) operates as an exception carved out from sub-sections (1), (2) and (3), of Section 8 of the RPA. Clearly the saving from the operation of sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) is founded on the factum of membership of a House. The purpose of carving out such an exception is not to confer an advantage on any person; the purpose is to protect the House. Therefore, sub-section (4) would cease to apply to sooner the House is dissolved or the person has ceased to be a member of that House. Any other interpretation would render sub-section (4) liable to be annulled as unconstitutional. Once a House has been dissolved and the person has ceased to be a member, on the date of filing nomination there is no difference between him and any other candidate who was not such a member. Treating such two persons differently would be arbitrary and discriminatory and incur the wrath of Article 14. A departure from the view so taken by the court would also result in anomalous consequences not intended by the Parliament.    [Para 60]

heading: Election
HeadNote.description:
Election - S.8 of RPA, whether a penal provision - Held, contesting an election is a statutory right and qualifications and disqualification for holding the office can be statutorily prescribed - Hence, provision for disqualification cannot be termed as penal provision - Same cannot be equated with a penal provision contained in a criminal law.
2003 ALL MR (Cri) 2056 (S.C.) Rel. on.(Para 55)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - Contract completion certificate issued to candidate/contractor, much prior to date of filing of nomination by candidate - Mere fact that refund of security was made after election - Not sufficient to conclude that there was subsistence of contract - Explanation to S.9A takes care of such situation - Candidate/contractor would not incur disqualification by virtue of it.			(Para 17)

heading: Attestation of copy
HeadNote.description:
Presentation of election petition - Attestation of copy - Requirements.

Under S.81(3) the copies of the election petition have to be attested by the petitioner under his own signature to be a true copy of the petition. Where the election petition contains the full signature of the petitioner on the top of the page, merely because a shorter version of the signature is appended below the endorsement "True copy" would not make it to be not attested to be a true copy.  [Para 7]

heading: Non-compliance of
HeadNote.description:
Non-compliance of - Petition has to be rejected.

Those sections and Rule 94A and form 25 are to be read conjointly as an integral scheme. When so read if the Court finds non-compliance it has to uphold the preliminary objection and has no option except to dismiss the petition. In the instant case, looking at the affirmation of the affidavit it becomes apparent that the same is not strictly in conformity with Form No. 25. The name of the petitioner is not mentioned in the affirmation at all. That being so, the affidavit would have to be rejected on this ground alone.  [Para 10]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Non-disclosure of grounds or source of information regarding corrupt practice - Petition is liable to be dismissed.

The non-disclosure of grounds or sources of information in an election petition will have to be scrutinised from two points of view. The non-disclosure of the grounds will indicate that the election petitioner did not come forward with the sources of information at the first opportunity. It is also held that the real importance of setting out the source of information at the time of the presentation of the petition is to give the other side notice of the contemporaneous evidence on which the election petition is based. This is required so that an opportunity is given to the other side to test the genuineness and veracity of the sources of information. The other point of view is that the election petitioner will not be able to make any departure from the sources or grounds, if there is any embellishment of the case it will be discovered. The whole of the petition in the present case proceeds on the basis that the Board appealing to the voters has been displayed with the consent of the petitioner. Yet, there is not a whisper throughout the petition or in the affidavit as to how this consent was obtained, when it was obtained, where was it obtained. A bald statement is made to the effect that the boards have been displayed with the consent of the first Respondent/his agents/his workers. Thus the first Respondent would not know at all as to whose consent is being pleaded. Since the pleadings play an important role in an election petition, the legislature has provided that the allegations of corrupt practice must be properly alleged and both the material facts and particulars provided in the petition itself so as to disclose a complete cause of action.  [Para 11]

heading: Election petition
Verification
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Verification - Sources of information have to be disclosed.

Verification, in the instant case, does not clearly indicate which fact or particular is to the knowledge of the Petitioner nor does it clearly state which fact or particular is based on information. Apart from this, the verification cannot possibly be in the format prescribed as in the body of the petition the sources of information have not been disclosed. It has, therefore, to be held that the verification is not in accordance with the requirements of Rule 94-A. Similarly the whole affidavit proceeds on the basis of the averments made in the petition. Therefore, the affirmation of the affidavit also cannot be held to be in conformity with Rule 94-A and Form 25. Further, in para 9 of the Petition, it is stated that the Petitioner has deposited a sum of Rs. 2,000/- as required by Section 117 of the Act read with Rule 25 of the Rules of the High Court. This paragraph is verified on the basis of legal submission. This renders the verification to be not in conformity with Section 83 read with Rule 94-A of the Rules.  [Para 12]

In the circumstances, the verification in the petition and the affidavit attached to the petition are not in conformity with Rule 94-A of the Rules and Form 25. Thus the Court has no option except to uphold the preliminary objection and to dismiss the petition.  [Para 13]

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Ingredients of offence.

The ingredients of S.123(4) would be satisfied if there is a publication by a candidate or his agent or any other person with the consent of a candidate or his election agent of any statement of fact which is false. The statement has to be false or believed to be false by the person making the statement. The statement must be in relation to the personal character or conduct of the candidate or in relation to the candidature of the person and this statement must be reasonably calculated to prejudice the prospects of the candidate's election. Reading even the accepted translation of the Board containing appeal to voters it cannot even remotely be held that it pertains to the character of the petitioner. In fact the Board is totally silent as to the candidate which is being referred to.  [Para 14]

heading: Amendment in petition
High Court's discretion
HeadNote.description:
Amendment in petition - High Court's discretion - May allow amendment of particulars of corrupt practice - High Court cannot suo motu request petitioner to amend - It is duty of petitioner.

The High Court has discretion to allow amendment of particulars to any corrupt practice. This direction has to be exercised keeping in view the provision contained in S.86(5). No duty is cast on the High Court to request the petitioner to amend. Once the preliminary objection is raised it is the duty of the Petitioner to take out the necessary application for amendment.  [Para 15]

heading: Contract Act (1872), S.42
HeadNote.description: Contract Act (1872), S.42 - Election to Legislative Assembly - Rejection of nomination paper - Ground of subsisting contracts between petitioner's registered firm and State Govt. for execution of certain works - Petitioner claimed to have resigned/retired and reconstituted firm where he was partner before filing nomination paper - However, he kept his capital with said firm carrying 12% interest - Contracts executed by said firm with Govt. still going on - Petitioner not entitled to unilaterally separate himself and absolve from liability in respect of said contracts by setting up document of retirement/resignation - Especially when no notice of change of such partnership firm and/or intimation of document given to Govt. or its department - In view of facts S.42 of contract Act 1872, attracted - Thus, petitioner was part of firm on date of filing of nomination paper - Therefore, rejection of his nomination, was proper. 			(Paras 84, 86, 87, 88, 91, 99)

heading: Election
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Election - Setting aside of - Ground of improper rejection of nomination paper - High Court has to form opinion as to whether nomination paper was improperly rejected by returning officer - Plea by petitioner that returning officer committed wrong and/or erroneously rejected his nomination paper by not recording certain finding - Not tenable.	(Para 73)

heading: Election petition
Appreciation of evidence
Newspaper reports
Admissibility in evidence
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Appreciation of evidence - Newspaper reports - Admissibility in evidence - Petitioner himself having filed press reports on record - He cannot run away from the same.	(Para 14)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Corrupt practice - Election of returned candidate can be declared to be void if corrupt practice is committed by elected candidate or his election agent or any other person with the consent of elected candidate/his election agent.

Publication of a statement concerning personal character of a candidate (defeated) which is not only false but maker either believes the same to be false or which is not believed the same to be true is 'corrupt practice' if the statement is reasonably calculated to prejudice the election prospects of that candidate. The election of returned candidate can be declared to be void if such corrupt practice is committed by elected candidate or his election agent or any other person with the 'consent' of candidate (elected)/his election agent. The election is also liable to be set aside if such 'corrupt practice' is committed by an agent other than election agent of the returned candidate and result of the election is materially affected by the same. 2004(2) SCC 217 - Ref. to.  [Para 16]

heading: Election petition
Appreciation of evidence
Newspaper reports
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Appreciation of evidence - Newspaper reports - Held, the reports in the newspaper cannot be sufficient proof of the facts contained in these reports - This is because newspaper report is secondary evidence of the events covered therein and can be proved only by examination of the reporter at whose instance news is reported in the news paper.

The reports in the newspaper cannot be sufficient proof of the facts contained in these reports. This is because newspaper reports is secondary evidence of the events covered therein and can be proved only by examination of the reporter at whose instance news is reported in the newspaper. The newspaper report may be primary evidence to a very limited extent that such news had appeared in the press and may be secondary evidence of event reported. Yet, Court has relied upon some portions from the news reports against the Petitioner who has produced those news paper reports. This is because although secondary evidence of the contents within the report, by production, Petitioner has indicated his willingness to accept the correctness of the reports. 1994 Suppl.3 SCC 5 - Ref. to.							 [Para 17]

heading: Election petition
Proof
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Proof - Election of returned candidate challenged on ground that his caste certificate was fabricated and false one - Petitioner has to prove the same beyond reasonable doubt. (1991)1 Bom.C.R. 488 - Ref. to.	(Paras 22, 27)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Evidence Act (1872), S.3 - Scope and applicability of - Election petition - Applicability of Civil P.C. or Evidence Act to proceedings of Election Petitions is not in supersession of the provisions of the Representation of the People Act.

Applicability of the Civil Procedure Code or Evidence Act to the proceedings of Election Petitions is not in supersession of the provisions of the R.P. Act. On reference to proviso to Rule 5, it can also be said that deemed admission for want of specific denial can certainly not be equated with final or conclusive proof, and that is why the Court is left with discretion to require any fact so admitted to be proved otherwise than by such admission. Thus, even if any fact is deemed admitted for want of specific denial, Court will have discretion to require the election petitioner to prove the same, otherwise than by such admission and it may not be incorrect to say that the presumption that may arise due to deemed admission, would be rebuttable. AIR 1994 S.C. 2277 and AIR 1967 SC 808 - Ref. to.  [Para 23]

heading: Election petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Pleadings - Proper verification analysing and authenticating the pleadings is a mandatory requirement under S.83(1)(c) of the Act. 			(Para 38)

heading: Election petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Pleadings - Failure to give and plead necessary and material facts - Claiming that relevant averments contained in the petition are based on 'Personal Knowledge' and failing to give the factual matter, held, is equal to failing to give and plead necessary and material facts as regards the grounds on which the declaration of result of election is challenged.

The petitioner claims that the tampering of EVMs narrated in paragraph no.19 is partly a matter of personal knowledge of the petitioner, and partly based on information received by her which are true to her belief.

Analysis of part thereof which is based on personal knowledge and part thereof based on belief is not segregated and affirmed distinctly.

Any narration which would constitute the description of the act of programming the EVMs for favouring the respondent, interference & access therein, theft or any other overt acts to or in the EVMs tantamounting to tampering has not been incorporated, any where in the entire body of election petition.

As the petitioner claims that the tampering is her personal knowledge, she ought to have given the specific acts or omissions constituting such facts which describe the tampering.

If at all the tampering was done, has to be a human act done by some individual. If it be so, and if it is within the knowledge of the petitioner, she has to plead those facts, so that those can be proved.

The petitioner may not know technical data or manner in which the tampering has been done or whether it has been done on somebody's behest and if she knows it, she ought to have disclosed said acts and source of knowledge.

Claiming that relevant averments contained in the petition are based on 'personal knowledge' and failing to give the factual matter is equal to failing to give & plead necessary and material facts as regards the grounds on which the declaration of result of election is challenged.

Proper verification analyzing and authenticating the pleadings is a mandatory requirement under Section 83(1)(c) of The Representation of the People Act, 1951. It is clear that the petitioner has failed to comply with this mandatory requirement. 							 [Para 33,38]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - True copy of petition - Copy supplied to respondent not containing signature or name of associate and date put by him - It is violation of mandatory requirement - Petitions liable to be dismissed.

There is no fundamental right or other right under the Constitution to challenge an election. The  challenge to an election is conferred by the statute namely Representation of People Act,1951. It is a statutory right. That right can be exercised within the parameters of law. That law namely Section 81(3) provides as to how an election petition should be filed and how copies to be furnished etc. Therefore, strictly speaking we cannot go to the realm of substantial compliance or prejudice to the returned candicate. If there is a statutory mandate that a particular thing should be done in a particular way, then it must be done in that way, failing which an action fails.  [Para 29]

In these cases, since the copy supplied to the respondent does not contain the signature or name of the associate and the date put by him, the copy supplied is not a true copy within the meaning of Section 81(3) of the Act. AIR1980  SC 303, AIR 1981 SC956, AIR 1996 SC 1691, 1996 SCW 2715, AIR 1994 NOC 377 (Raj) Rel.on.  [Para 31]

heading: Affidavit in support of allegations of corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Affidavit in support of allegations of corrupt practice - It has to be filed in the prescribed form only - Endorsement of associate above confirmation of oath on a particular day and at a particular place absent - Affidavit is no affidavit at all and Petition is not maintainable

An affidavit contains two parts, one is a statement made by the petitioner about certain facts, then an endorsement by the concerned officer that the statement was made on oath before him. In the present case, the endorsement of the concerned officer about confirmation on oath "before me" on a particular day and at a particular place as provided in the prescribed form is conspicuously absent. Hence, the affidavits filed in the present cases are no affidavits at all in the eye of law and when there is no such affidavit, then an election petition is not maintainable because in the case of Election Petition alleging corrupt practice filing an affidavit under proviso to Section 83(1) is mandatory. AIR 1996 SC 1691 Rel.on.  [Para 32]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Preliminary objection about maintainability of petition - Violation of mandatory provision of 81(3) and 83(1) alleged - Objection raised by taking out chamber summons at the stage of pleadings and before issues were framed - There could not be said to be any delay in raising the objections. (Para 36)

heading: True copy- Original petition containing para numbers but they were not shown in the copy supplied to respondent
HeadNote.description: True copy- Original petition containing para numbers but they were not shown in the copy supplied to respondent - Election petition is liable to be dismissed. (Para 39)

heading: Termination of subsisting contracts with Government
HeadNote.description: Termination of subsisting contracts with Government - Absence of statutory enactment as a guide in terminating contracts - Government can issue G.O. to fill up the gap. Constitution of India, Art.162.	(Para 19)

heading: Termination of subsisting contract with government
HeadNote.description: Termination of subsisting contract with government - Government order authorising Chief Engineer to terminate contract - Termination by Divisional Engineer which was ratified subsequently by Superintending Engineer cannot be treated as valid termination.			(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Subsisting government contract
HeadNote.description: Disqualification to contest election - Subsisting government contract - Contracts with government found to be subsisting on date of submission of nomination papers and on date of scrutiny - Election of candidate ought to be declared as illegal.	(Para 22)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - Standard of proof would not be preponderance of probabilities as in civil case but proof beyond reasonable doubt as in a criminal trial.

A charge of corrupt practice envisaged by the Act is to be equated with a criminal charge and the standard of proof thereof would not be preponderance of probabilities as in a civil action but proof beyond reasonable doubt as in a criminal trial. If this test is not applied, a very serious prejudice is likely to be caused to the successful candidate whose election would not only be set aside, he may also incur disqualification to contest an election for a certain period entailing even extinction of his political career. Undoubtedly, the onus lies heavily on the election petitioner to make out a strong case for setting aside an election.  1975(4)SCC 769, (1999)9 SCC 386 - Rel.on. [Para 10]

If after balancing the evidence adduced there still remains little doubt in proving the charge, its benefit must go to the returned candidate. However, it is equally well settled that while insisting upon the standard of proof beyond a reasonable doubt, the Courts are not required to extend or stretch the doctrine to such an extreme extent as to make it well nigh impossible to prove any allegation of corrupt practice. Such an approach would defeat and frustrate the very laudable and sacrosanct object of the Act in maintaining purity of the electoral process.  (1985)13 SCC 370 - Rel.on.   [Para 27]

heading: Appeal
Election petition
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Election petition - Finding of facts recorded by trial Court (High Court) - Apex Court will not interfere in absence of compelling reasons to do so. 1995(5) SCC 347 - Foll.	(Para 28)

heading: Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Corrupt practice - Returned candidate got printed and published notice and photo calender with his photo and that of Holy Pope taken on the occassion of beatification ceremony of Mother Teresa - Notice contained a message or an appeal on religious grounds to the Christians/Catholics to vote for him for the benefit of the larger interests of the Christians, particularly the Roman Catholics - His election agent got these printed, paid charges and circulated amongst voters - Held, High Cour was justified in holding that the said notice did constitute an appeal to the members of the Christian community, particularly, the Catholics to seek their votes for the appellant, being a Catholic, on the ground of religion, caste and community - Further the calender strengthened the appeal in notice and they together constituted a corrupt practice.			(Paras 17, 18, 26, 29)

heading: Jurisdiction of Election Court
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Election Court - Election Petition and recrimination petition - Scope of powers of Election Court.

 The law relating to scope of powers of Election court in dealing with election and recrimination petition can be summed up as under :-

(1)  In an election petition wherein the limited relief sought for is the declaration that the election of returned candidate is void on the ground under Section 100(l)(d)(iii) of the Act, the scope of enquiry shall remain confined to two questions : (a) finding out any votes having been improperly cast in favour of the returned candidate, and (b) any votes having been improperly refused or rejected in regard to any other candidate. In such a case an enquiry cannot be held into and the election petition decided on the finding (a) that any votes have been improperly cast in favour of a candidate other than the returned candidate, or (b) any votes were improperly refused or rejected in regard to the returned candidate. (2) A recrimination by the returned candidate or any other party can be filed under Section 97 (1) in a case where in an election petition an additional declaration is claimed that any candidate other than the returned candidate has been duly elected. (3)  For the purpose of enabling an enquiry that any votes have been improperly cast in favour of any candidate other than the returned candidate or any votes have been improperly refused or rejected in reward in the returned candidate the election Court shall acquire jurisdiction to do so only on the two conditions being satisfied : (i) the election petition seeks a declaration that any candidate other than returned candidate has been duly elected over and above the declaration that the election of the returned candidate is void; and (ii) the recrimination petition under Section 97 (1) is filed. (4)  A recrimination petition must satisfy the same requirements as that of an election petition in the matter of pleadings, signing and verification as an election petition is required to fulfil within the meaning of Section 83 of the Act and must be accompanied by the security or the further security referred to in Sections 117 and 118 of the Act. (5)  The bar on enquiry enacted by Section 97 read with Section 100 (1) (d)(iii) of the Act is attracted when the validity of the votes is to be gone into and adjudged or in other words the question of improper reception, refusal or rejection of any vote or reception of any vote which is void is to be gone into. The bar is not attracted to a case where it is merely a question of correct counting of the votes without entering into adjudication as to propriety, impropriety or validity of acceptance, rejection or reception of any vote. In other words, where on a recount the election Judge finds the result of recount to be different from the one arrived at by the returning officer or when the election Judge finds that there was an error of counting the bar is not attracted because the Court in a pure and simple counting carried out by it or under its directions is not adjudicating upon any issue as to improper reception, refusal or rejection of any vote or the reception of any vote which is void but is performing mechanical process of counting or recounting by placing the vote at the place where it ought to have been placed. A case of error in counting would fall within the purview of sub-clause (iv), and not sub-clause (iii) of Clause (d) of sub-section (1) of Section 100 of the Act. [Para 33]

heading: Election petition
Rules of pleadings
How far binding
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Rules of pleadings - How far binding - Prime object is to ensure purity of election process.

The task before an Election Judge is ticklish.  It is often urged and also held that the success of a winning candidate should not be lightly set aside and the secrecy of ballot must be zealously guarded. On account of a rigid following of these principles the election Courts are inclined to lean in favour of the returned candidates and place the onus of proof on the person challenging the result of election, insisting on strict compliance with the rules of pleadings and excluding such evidence from consideration as is in divergence with the pleadings. However, what has so developed as a rule of practice should not be unduly stretched; for the purity of the election process needs to be preserved unpolluted so as to achieve the predominant goal of democracy that only he should represent the constituency who has been chosen by the majority of the electors. This is the purpose and object of the election law.   [Para 26]

heading: Ballot paper
HeadNote.description:
Ballot paper - Inspection to be allowed sparingly in the interest of justice.

Though the inspection of ballot papers is to be allowed sparingly and the Court may refuse the prayer of the defeated candidate for inspection if, in the garb of seeking inspection, he was indulging into a roving enquiry in order to fish out materials to set aside the election, or the allegations made in support of such prayer were vague or too generalized to deserve any cognizance. Nevertheless, the power to direct inspection of ballot papers is there and ought to be exercised if, based on precise allegations of material facts, also substantiated, a case for permitting inspection is made out as is necessary to determine the issue arising for decision in the case and in the interest of justice. In a proper case where the interests of justice demand it, the Tribunal may call upon the returning officer to produce the ballot papers and may permit inspection by the parties before it of the ballot papers which power is clearly implicit in Ss. 100(l)(d)(iii), 101,102 and Rule 93 of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961. This power to order inspection of the ballot papers which is apart from Order XI Code of Civil Procedure may be exercised, subject to the statutory restrictions about the secrecy of the ballot paper prescribed by Ss. 94 and 128(1). However, by the mere production of the sealed boxes of ballot papers before the Election Tribunal pursuant to its order the ballot papers do not become part of the record and they are not liable, to be inspected unless the Tribunal is satisfied that such inspection is in the circumstances of the case necessary in the interests of justice.  [Para 27]

heading: Recount of ballot papers
HeadNote.description:
Recount of ballot papers - Can be ordered only if a clear case in that regard is made out.

A recount is not to be ordered merely for the asking or merely because the Court is inclined to hold a recount. In order to protect the secrecy of ballots the Court would permit a recount only upon a clear case in that regard having been made out. To permit or not to permit a recount is a question involving jurisdiction of the Court. Once a recount has been allowed the Court cannot shut its eyes on the result of recount on the ground that the result of recount as found is at variance with the pleadings. Once the Court has permitted recount within the well-settled parameters of exercising jurisdiction in this regard, it is the result of the recount which has to be given effect to. [Para 28]
