Once the Court exercises its jurisdiction to enter into the question of improper reception, refusal or rejection of any vote, or the reception of any vote which is void by reference to the election result of the returned candidate under Section 100 (1)(d)(iii), as also as to the result of the election of any other candidate by reference to Section 97 of the Act and enters into scrutiny of the votes polled, followed by recount, consistently with its findings on the validity or invalidity of the votes, it cannot refuse to give effect to the result of its findings as to the validity or invalidity of the votes for the purpose of finding out true result of recount though the actual finding as to validity or otherwise of the votes by reference to number may be at variance with the pleadings. In short, the pleadings and proof in the matter of recount have relevance for the purpose of determining the question of jurisdiction to permit or not to permit recount. Once the jurisdiction to order recount is found to have been rightly exercised, thereafter it is the truth as revealed by the result of recounting that has to be given effect to.  [Para 29]

heading: Corrupt practice
What amounts to
HeadNote.description:
Corrupt practice - What amounts to - An appeal to voters in name of their religion would not by itself and without anything more constitute a corrupt practice under S.123 (3) of the Act of 1951.

AIR 1996 SC 796 and 2011(1) Mh.L.J. 620 - Rel. on.	 [Para 18,20]

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Plea of over spending - Over spending with a view to influence the voters would not constitute a practice which can be said to be corrupt or which would vitiate or invalidate the election for any other cause simplicitor.			(Para 21)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.19(1) - Election Petition - Right to vote, right to contest, right to get elected and to dispute an election, are statutory rights and they are not fundamental rights - These rights are subject to limitation in the statutes.			(Para 22)

heading: Defect in verification of election petition
HeadNote.description:
Defect in verification of election petition - Not a ground for dismissal of election petition - Defect, if any, is curable.

AIR 1964 SC 1545 Foll. 	 [Para 30]

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Supply of true copy to respondent - Mere omission of indicating name of Oath Commissioner on endorsement in true copy that affidavit was attested by Oath Commissioner bearing his stamp and seal - Would not be material omission.

Any defect of whatever nature, in the true copy supplied to the respondent would not render the petition liable to be dismissed under Section 86 of the Act. Such defects in supply of true copies are not always incurable. The main consideration which would weigh is that the returned candidate must get a correct idea of the allegations of corrupt practices so that it may be possible to understand and meet the charges levelled against him. The true copy supplied should also reflect that the part of the petition containing the allegations of corrupt practices has been verified and sworn by the petitioner on oath. The fact that the name, stamp, seal and signature of the Notary are not indicated or missing in the true copy is not material nor the absence of stamp of attestation by the Notary.  [Para 13]

The purpose of the provision to furnish a true copy of the petition is not to frustrate the cause of the petitioner approaching the Court by adhering strictly to technicalities of little consequence. On the other hand the anxiety is that the respondent must have correct idea of the allegations of corrupt practices made against him with some responsibility and that he may not be misled in any material respect by furnishing of a copy of the affidavit which may not be a correct copy having vital variation from the original. It is true that in the matters relating to elections and election petitions strict compliance of the legal provisions is necessary and full care is to be taken to see that rights of an elected representative are not lightly disturbed and rightly so. But an election petition is not to be thrown at the threshold on the slightest pretext of one kind or the other which may or may not have any material bearing on the factors to be strictly adhered to in such matters. It is substance not form which would matter. If it is permitted otherwise, the returned candidate would only be in the look out microscopically for any kind of technical lacuna or defect to abort the endeavour of the petitioner to bring to trial the issues relating to corrupt practices in the elections. The purpose of the law on the point cannot be to allow the returned candidate to avoid the trial of the issues of corrupt practices raised against him on the basis of any little defect which may not result in any vital variation between the original and the true copy so as to have the effect of misleading the returned candidate.  [Para 17]

The only grievance is that the stamp and the name of the Oath Commissioner is not indicated in the true copy of the affidavit. If it was there it would have been better but absence of stamp and the name of Oath Commissioner will not be a vital or material deviation from the original nor it may in any manner mislead the returned candidate. Prima facie on perusal of the heading of the affidavit and detailed verification of the contents of the paragraphs, would normally lead one to believe that the averments have been made on affidavit. In paragraph one of the affidavit there is a specific mention that the petitioner was acquainted with the facts of the case for the purpose of swearing of the affidavit in support of contention of corrupt practices taken recourse to by respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 7. In the end the petitioner signs as 'deponent' and he is identified by Advocate's Clerk. That being the position, mere omission of indicating the name of the Oath Commissioner or an endorsement in the true copy that the affidavit was attested by an Oath Commissioner bearing his stamp and seal etc. would not be material. Once an averment is there that affidavit was being sworn in support of allegations of corrupt practices and that the petitioner had put his signature thereon, prima facie fulfilment of such a legal requirement is adequately reflected even in absence of name and seal etc. of Oath Commissioner in the true copy.  [Para 21]

heading: Parties to petition
HeadNote.description: Parties to petition - Error in the spelling of name of respondent candidate - Correct name available in the list of candidates who contested election - Fact that no application for correcting error was moved or no application was filed to indicate that it was typing error will not adversely affect the petition.	(Para 24)

heading: Election petition -Verification
HeadNote.description:
Election petition -Verification - No reference to paragraphs of petition as to which petitioner verified in his own knowledge and which he verified on information received by him - Verification made in most casual manner - Held, verification was improper, but that by itself would not be sufficient to dismiss petition.

AIR 1964 SC 1545 foll.

Civil P.C. (1908), O.6, R.15

Election petition - verification (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Election
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Election - Post of member of Legislative Assembly - Petition challenging election of returned candidate - Ground of non-disclosure of assets, improper acceptance of nomination paper and corrupt practices indulged by returned candidate - Maintainability - Furshining of incomplete information by candidate does not entail rejection of nomination paper - Petitioner failing to discharge onus of proving improper and excessive expenditure incurred by candidate - Allegation of corrupt practice thereby not proved - Petition hence not maintainable.

Section 100(1)(d)(i) of the Act provides that if the High Court is of opinion that the result of the election , in so far as it concerns a returned candidate, has been materially affected by the improper acceptance of any nomination, the High Court shall declare the election of the returned candidate to be void.  However, in the present case, R-1 submitted affidavit in the prescribed form along with the nomination paper. The only thing is that he did not give complete information about the immovable assets of himself and his spouse and suppressed information about one flat and liability to pay Municipal taxes. However, on that count the Returning Officer could not have rejected nomination paper. No fault can be found with the order of the Returning Officer accepting the nomination of the candidate.  [Para 50,51]

Chapter VIII of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 relates to election expenses. Sub-section 1 of Section 77 thereof mandates that every candidate at an election shall, either by himself or by his election Agent, keep a separate and correct account of all expenditure in connection with the election incurred or authorised by him or by his election Agent between the date on which he has been nominated and the date of declaration of the result thereof, both dates inclusive. Sub-section 2 of section 77 directs that the account shall contain such particulars, as may be prescribed. Sub-section 3 of section 77 mandates that the total of the said expenditure shall not exceed such amount as may be prescribed.  Part VIII of the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961 relates to election expenses. Rule 90 thereof provides that the total of the expenditure of which account is to be kept under Section 77 and which is incurred or authorized in connection with an election in a State shall not exceed Rs.10 Lacs in any one assembly constituency.

Section 78 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 directs that every contesting candidate at an election shall, within thirty days from the date of election of the returned candidate lodge with the District Election Officer an account of his election expenses which shall be a true copy of the account kept by him or by his election Agent under section 77.  Sub-section 6 of Section 123 provides that the incurring or authorizing of expenditure in contravention of section 77 shall be deemed to be corrupt practice for the purposes of this Act.  Section 100(1)(b) provides that if the High Court is of the opinion that any corrupt practice has been committed by a returned candidate or his election Agent or by any other person with the consent of a returned candidate or his election Agent, the High Court shall declare the election of the returned candidate to be void. Mere vague and general statement that the candidate and his workers with his consent spent money in election in excess of permissible limit would not be sufficient to constitute corrupt practice.

In the instant case, the petitioner has failed to prove that there was wrongful acceptance of the nomination paper of the candidate and that he indulged in corrupt practice by incurring expenditure more than the prescribed limit and by hosting free meals to the voters to solicit their votes in his favour. The petition, therefore, fails on all counts. [Para 61,65,90]

heading: Allegations of murring expenses in excess of permissible limits
HeadNote.description: Allegations of murring expenses in excess of permissible limits - Allegations of expenditure on account of advertisements - Agency through which advertisements were published not examined - Office copies of Receipts for payments to newspapers not called upon to be produced - Constitutes failure to prove petitioner's allegations.

heading: Expenses on pandols
HeadNote.description: Allegations of excess expenditure by elected candidate - Expenses on pandols - Failure to examine contractor erecting the pandols - Amounts to failure to discharge petitioner's burden.

heading: Allegations of corrupt practice of mass feeding
HeadNote.description: Allegations of corrupt practice of mass feeding - Caterer who supplied food not examined - Voters who took meals at the arrangement by elected candidate, not examined - Respondent's Agents who sought votes for Respondent for the same not proved - Consent of Respondent for the same not proved - Alleged meeting of Muslim voters and meals for them not proved - Held, petitioner failed to discharge his burden.

heading: Election petition
Want of prosecution
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Want of prosecution - Challenge to election of returned candidate - There is no bar to dismiss the Election Petition for want of prosecution and/or for default.

There is no bar to dismiss the Election Petition for want of prosecution and/or for default. Considering the scheme and purpose of the Act and as the Election Petition needs to be disposed of expeditiously, there is no point in adjourning the matter again as the petitioner is not taking interest in the matter, though ample opportunities have been given to him to take effective steps and to appear before the Court to support the case.  [Para 13]

The present Petition is defective. No effective steps were taken in time. There is no scope now for any rectification by invoking a discretionary power of the Court even if any, which, in the present facts and circumstances, now is not available to the Petitioner. There is no option but to dismiss the Election Petition at this stage itself. (2001)7 S.C.C. 98 - Rel. on. AIR 2003 Punjab and Haryana 268 - Ref. to. 						 [Para 27]

heading: Election petition
Scope of S.82
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Scope of S.82 - Election petition has to be arrayed of all the contesting candidates specially in case the petitioner makes a claim to be declared as a winning candidate - Held, the special provisions in the election statutes with regard to this are mandatory and cannot be waived - It should prevail.	(Para 19)

heading: Election petition
Adjournments
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Adjournments - Court should be loath in giving adjournments - However, adjournments sought by parties and their counsel for personal pre-occupation, granted by the Court time to time in instant case. 	(Para 2)

heading: Secret ballot
HeadNote.description: Secret ballot - Bar to compel person to disclose his choice of candidate or give evidence in that regard - Does not apply to voluntary disclosure. 		(Para 44)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description: Election - Challenge that EVM used were faulty and do not record vote correctly - Petitioner producing witnesses who deposed to have voted for him - On comparison of evidence of witnesses with sequential list and voters register some witnesses found to have lied - Held, petitioner failed to prove his case. 		(Para 59)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Failure to use VVPAT unit with EVM - Principally amounts to non-compliance with Rules - However, considering assurance given by Election Commission that there would be phase wise introduction of VVPAT that cannot be ground to declare election as void - Also it is not the case of petitioner that VVPAT was used all over except his constituency - Moreover, vote difference between petitioner and elected candidate is so huge that on ground of use of EVM without VVPAT or breach of certain Rules or because of inability of petitioner's representative to be present at mock polls it can be said that election stood materially affected - Petition liable to be dismissed.		(Paras 73, 74, 75, 76, 77, 78)

heading: Power of District Election Officer under S.26
HeadNote.description:
Power of District Election Officer under S.26 - Power under S.26 is only to appoint Presiding Officer for polling stations and polling officers - However, for making such appointment, from what source the District Election Officer should draw the officers has not been provided in the said section - Section 26 does not give power to requisition the staff.

Section 26 gives power to the District Election Officer to appoint a Presiding Officer for each polling station and such polling officers or officer as he thinks necessary, but he shall not appoint any person who has been employed by or on behalf of, or has been otherwise working for, a candidate in or about the election. Therefore this is only a power to appoint the Presiding Officer for polling stations and the polling officers. However, for making such appointment, from what source the District Election Officers should draw the officers has not been provided in the said section. Since no provision is made in the said section as to from which source, the District Election Officer can appoint the said officers, such power cannot be read into said section. If such power is read in section 26, assuming for the moment it is so, section 159 of the Act of 1951 becomes redundant. It is a basic principle of interpretation of the statutes that a provision in the statute should not be interpreted in such a manner which will render the other provision or provisions from the said statute as redundant. Therefore, held, that the submission of the counsel for the Election Commission that Section 26 of the Act of 1951 gives such power to requisition the staff, is without any merit.  [Para 15]

heading: Interpretation of Statutes
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statutes - One cannot read provisions of one Act into another Act unless the Legislature by specific provision made to that effect has stated that the provisions of one Act can be read into the other Act - Therefore, unless there is a separate provision, the provisions of one Act cannot be read into another Act - Such a provision is not found in the Act of 1951.

Section 13-AA deals with District Election Officers and sub-section (4) of the said section provides that the District Election Officers shall also perform such other functions as may be entrusted to him by the Election Commission, and the Chief Electoral Officer. Therefore reading sub-section (4), the District Election Officer may perform any other duties and functions other than that which are provided under Section 13-AA provided the Election Commission and the Chief Electoral Officer of the State has entrusted those functions to him. However, what is important to note is that this provision of delegation of powers from the Act of 1950 cannot be read into the Act of 1951. The purpose and object of the Act of 1950 is to provide for the allocation of seats in, and the delimitation of constituencies for the purpose of elections to the House of the People and the Legislatures of State, the qualifications of voters at such elections, the preparations of electoral rolls [the manner of filling seats in the Council of States to be filled by representatives of Union territories, and matters connected therewith. Therefore, the delegation of powers from the Election Commissioner or the Chief Electoral Officer has to be considered in the light of the object of the Act of 1950, for which the provisions have been made by Parliament. The object of sub-section (4) of Section 13-AA of the Act of 1950 is not to provide for the delegation of powers in respect of the acts to be done under the Act of 1951. One cannot read provisions of one Act into another Act unless the Legislature by specific provision made to that effect has stated that the provisions of one Act can be read into the other Act. Therefore, unless there is a separate provision, the provisions of one Act cannot be read into another Act. Such a provision is not found in the Act of 1951. Therefore the assistance of sub-section (4) of section 13-AA of the Act of 1950 cannot be taken by the respondents in order to justify the orders which according to them have been passed under Section 26 and not under Section 159. Apart from that, assuming for a moment that sub-section (4) of Section 13-AA of the Act of 1950 permits the Respondents to pass such orders, still the Election Commission and the Chief Electoral Officer have not passed any order entrusting or delegating the powers to the respondents. Therefore, viewed from any angle the argument advanced on behalf of the respondents is misfounded and would therefore have to be rejected.  [Para 16,17,18]

heading: Interpretation of Statutes
HeadNote.description:
Interpretation of Statutes - One cannot read provisions of one Act into another Act unless the Legislature by specific provision made to that effect has stated that the provisions of one Act can be read into the other Act - Therefore, unless there is a separate provision, the provisions of one Act cannot be read into another Act - Such a provision is not found in the Act of 1951.

Section 13-AA deals with District Election Officers and sub-section (4) of the said section provides that the District Election Officers shall also perform such other functions as may be entrusted to him by the Election Commission, and the Chief Electoral Officer. Therefore reading sub-section (4), the District Election Officer may perform any other duties and functions other than that which are provided under Section 13-AA provided the Election Commission and the Chief Electoral Officer of the State has entrusted those functions to him. However, what is important to note is that this provision of delegation of powers from the Act of 1950 cannot be read into the Act of 1951. The purpose and object of the Act of 1950 is to provide for the allocation of seats in, and the delimitation of constituencies for the purpose of elections to the House of the People and the Legislatures of State, the qualifications of voters at such elections, the preparations of electoral rolls [the manner of filling seats in the Council of States to be filled by representatives of Union territories, and matters connected therewith. Therefore, the delegation of powers from the Election Commissioner or the Chief Electoral Officer has to be considered in the light of the object of the Act of 1950, for which the provisions have been made by Parliament. The object of sub-section (4) of Section 13-AA of the Act of 1950 is not to provide for the delegation of powers in respect of the acts to be done under the Act of 1951. One cannot read provisions of one Act into another Act unless the Legislature by specific provision made to that effect has stated that the provisions of one Act can be read into the other Act. Therefore, unless there is a separate provision, the provisions of one Act cannot be read into another Act. Such a provision is not found in the Act of 1951. Therefore the assistance of sub-section (4) of section 13-AA of the Act of 1950 cannot be taken by the respondents in order to justify the orders which according to them have been passed under Section 26 and not under Section 159. Apart from that, assuming for a moment that sub-section (4) of Section 13-AA of the Act of 1950 permits the Respondents to pass such orders, still the Election Commission and the Chief Electoral Officer have not passed any order entrusting or delegating the powers to the respondents. Therefore, viewed from any angle the argument advanced on behalf of the respondents is misfounded and would therefore have to be rejected.  [Para 16,17,18]

heading: Power to requisition the staff
HeadNote.description: Power to requisition the staff - Power is with Regional Commissioner appointed under Art.324(6) or the Chief Electoral Officer of the State who are representatives of Election Commission in matter of conduct of elections. Constitution of India, Art.324(6).	(Paras 21, 23)

heading: Failure to complete or defect in completing declaration in Form 2A or Form 2B
HeadNote.description:
Failure to complete or defect in completing declaration in Form 2A or Form 2B - Is not a defect of substantial nature.

A plain reading of proviso that follows Rule 4 leaves no manner of doubt that a failure to complete or defect in completing, the declaration as to symbols in a nomination paper in Form 2A or Form 2B by a candidate set up by a recognised political party or a candidate set up by registered unrecognised political party or a candidate who seeks to contest the election as an independent candidate is not a defect of substantial nature. It is not possible to catalogue defects contemplated by the proviso. However, to illustrate the few; wrong description of symbol, omission to fill blank space given in proforma in respect of choice of symbols, selecting a symbol which is reserved, etc., fall in the category of defects not of a substantial character.

(2000) 1 SCC 145 Rel. on.  [Para 30]

heading: Election Symbols (Reservation and Allotment) Order (1968), Para 13 Clause (e)
HeadNote.description:
Election Symbols (Reservation and Allotment) Order (1968), Para 13 Clause (e) - Non-compliance of requirements of Para 13 - Is a defect of substantial character and nomination paper having such defect is liable to be rejected as it tantamounts to non-compliance with S.33.

The applicability of proviso that follows Rule 4, however, is limited to defect in the declaration as to symbol made by a candidate in Form 2-A or 2-B appended to 1961 Rules. Its operation does not extend to the defects in forms required to be filled or completed by a candidate set up by a recognised political party under 1968 Order or non-fulfilment of requirements set out in clauses (a) to (e) of para 13 of the 1968 Order.. Non-compliance of requirements of para 13 of the 1968 Order, in our view, is a defect of substantial character and the nomination paper of a candidate proposed by a single elector set up by a recognised political party having such defect is liable to be rejected under Section 36(2)(b) as it tantamounts to non-compliance of the provisions of Section 33, namely, the nomination paper having not been completed in the prescribed form.  [Para 31,37]

heading: Scrutiny of nomination papers
HeadNote.description: Scrutiny of nomination papers - Original Form A and B not found - Returning Officer acting in haste and without giving time and opportunity to proposed candidate rejecting his nomination paper even though request was also made to postpone scrutiny to the next day - Held election of returned candidate was liable to be set aside under S.100(1)(c). (Paras 57, 66)

heading: Election to local bodies
HeadNote.description: Election to local bodies - Is creature of statute - Relevant provision of local body including Rules and Circulars, if are required to be looked into while considering any challenge to election of such local bodies - Decision given by Courts based upon concerned Acts of local bodies play important role while deciding such election petitions.	(Para 21)

heading: Expression "the result of the election has been materially affected"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "the result of the election has been materially affected" - Meaning of.

The expression "the result of the election has been materially affected" seems to indicate that the result should not be judged by the mere increase or decrease in the total number of votes secured by the returned candidate but by proof of the fact that the wasted votes would have been distributed in such a manner between the contesting candidates as would have brought about the defeat of the returned candidate.  [Para 5]

heading: Whether result of the election is materially affected
HeadNote.description: Whether result of the election is materially affected - Burden of proof is on the objector.	(Para 5)

heading: Finding about
HeadNote.description: Improper acceptance of votes - Finding about - Definitive finding is necessary - Court will interfere if finding is only speculative and conjectural.   (Paras 11-13)

heading: Election Petition
Striking off pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Striking off pleadings - Entire paragraph in petition merely seeking to raise a question as to who constitutes the HUF, the name of father of returned candidate whether Jairam or Jairambapu - No material fact pleaded in said paragraph - Thus, averments therein being unnecessary, liable to be struck off. (Paras 9, 25)

heading: Election petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Pleadings - In 7/12 extract, name of returned candidate shown as sole owner of particular survey of land - However, said land shown to be owned by HUF in affidavit filed by returned candidate - Averment that information given by returned candidate was false - In view of said material fact, pleadings regarding it, cannot be struck off. (Paras 10, 25)

heading: Election petition
Defect not substantial
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Information in affidavit regarding land owned by returned candidate and its location - Not asserted by election petitioner to be false but given incomplete information which is misleading - Defect not substantial - Said averments not disclosing any material fact - Liable to be struck off. (Paras 12, 25)

heading: Election petition
Pleadings
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Pleadings - Returned candidate in affidavit along with nomination form stated that he individually does not own any agricultural land - However, his source of income was shown to be through agriculture - These averments disclose existence of material facts - Hence, cannot be struck off as being unnecessary or vexatious. (Paras 11, 25)

heading: Pleading not giving details
HeadNote.description: Pleading not giving details - Based merely on imagination and conjectures of election petitioner - Nothing can be gathered therefrom as to what election petitioner desires to urge - Allegations in said paragraph not disclosing material fact - Liable to be deleted. (Paras 14, 25)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Allegations as to violation and non compliance of Election Manual 2019 by returned candidate - No averment that election of returned candidate has been materially affected - Said averment in petition liable to be struck off being unnecessary and not giving cause of action. (Paras 18, 25)

heading: Election petition
Corrupt practice
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Corrupt practice - No pleadings by election petitioner that election expenses of returned candidate exceeded the limit - Averments only indicating that account of election expenses had been improperly maintained by returned candidate and nothing further - Therefore, said pleading not giving rise to any cause of action, liable to be deleted. (Paras 22, 25)

heading: Election Petition
Corrupt practice
Pleadings
HeadNote.description: Conduct of Election Rules (1961), R.90 - Election Petition - Corrupt practice - Pleadings - Allegations of violation of Model Code of Conduct - Publication of advertisement of opening ceremony of jewellers show room by returned candidate - Expenses incurred for that not averred to be part of election expenses - Said averments not disclosing any material fact - Liable to be struck off. (Paras 24, 25)

heading: Election
HeadNote.description: Election - Improper acceptance of nomination - Allegation that Returning officer accepted nomination form of returned candidate after stipulated period - Election declared void by High Court - High Court relied upon other evidence, apart from evidence in form of electronic record - Finding of High Court cannot be faulted. 		(Para 68)

heading: Election
Challenge as to
HeadNote.description: Election - Challenge as to - Ground of improper acceptance of nomination form of returned candidate - There is no necessity to plead and prove that election was “materially affected”. 2016 ALL SCR 2230 Overruled. 2009 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 91 Foll. 			(Paras 71, 120)

heading: Scope of election petition
HeadNote.description: Scope of election petition - Allegation that petitioner was arrested on ground of complaint lodged with police by returning officer charging him under S.77(1) of the Act and under Ss.171(G) and (H) of IPC - Such allegation made with a view to get it quashed and to claim damages for defamation - Held election petition is not a forum to get criminal complaint quashed and claim damages for defamation. (Para 10)

heading: Verification
HeadNote.description:
Verification - Verification made before Associate of the High Court having authority to administer oath - Verification cannot be found fault with.

Election Petition No. 3 of 1992 dt. 10-2-1992 (Bom) Foll. (Para 29)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description:
Election petition - Petitioner filing affidavit though no corrupt practice was alleged - Affidavit purported to be under R.94A, Form 25 - Having filed the affidavit it becomes an integral part of petition and a copy to be served on the respondent has to be a true copy thereof.

1996(3) ALL MR 475 Rel. on. (Para 31)

heading: Election Petition
HeadNote.description: Election Petition - Complaint as to corrupt practice - Rs.6 lacs allegedly recovered from election agent of respondent - Said amount stated to be probably used for inducing voters - No definite assertion that said amount was in fact used for bribing voters - Recovery by itself does not amount to corrupt practice - Further, allegations made as to two incidents wherein election agents of respondent were caught while distributing cash in a Beedi factory and sweet factory - However, no further details given regarding names of persons receiving cash or who had caught them while doing so - Allegations lacking in material facts and particulars, vague and speculative - Do not make out cause of action - Election Petition liable to be dismissed u/O.7 R.11(a) of CPC. (1999) 1 SCC 666, 2010 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 209, (1995) 5 SCC 511, (1991) 3 SCC 375 Ref. to. 	(Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Disqualification under S.8(3)
Conviction and sentence
Effect of
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification under S.8(3) - Conviction and sentence - Stood suspended by Appellate court on date of nomination paper - Effect of - What was suspended was not conviction or sentence but only execution thereof - Disqualification continued notwithstanding suspension of sentence - Rejection of nomination paper was proper.

The purpose for introducing section 8(3) in the said Act was to ensure that the persons who are convicted and sentenced to suffer imprisonment for a period of not less than two years are not allowed to contest the elections and thus prevent criminalisation of politics. The salutary purpose of introducing the said section 8(3) is to ensure that the persons who are elected to the assembly and the parliament are completely above-board and are the persons having high moral character and integrity irrespective of their political leanings. The legislature introduced the said provision after it observed the general decadence and falling standards of persons who contest the elections for the assembly and the parliament and, therefore, the legislature felt that this trend was not in the best interest of the sovereignty, unity and integrity of this country. If persons having tainted moral character and who are declared by the competent court to be the law breakers, the legislature felt that such people were disqualified for the purpose of being elected as the law makers. It would be an ironical situation if such persons whose nominations are rejected on account of their conviction and sentence by the trial court are allowed to challenge the election of a returned candidate and on some technical ground the election of such a returned candidate is allowed to be set aside. This, surely, cannot be the intention of the provisions of section 100 (1)(C) of the said Act. The Returning Officer has correctly rejected the nomination papers of the petitioner as he had incurred disqualification under section 8(3) of the said Act merely because the order of conviction and sentence is stayed that would not obliterate the order of conviction and sentence which is imposed by the trial court.   [Para 14,16]

heading: Hearing before Election Tribunal
HeadNote.description:
Hearing before Election Tribunal - Defendant appeared through Counsel at the first hearing on 11-12-52 and filed written statement - Issues were framed and case was adjourned till 17-3-1953 - Defendant or his Counsel not present on 17-3-1953 and hearing proceeded ex-parte - Petitioner examining all his witnesses on 17th, 18th, 19th and 20th - Defendant had entered appearance on 20th through Counsel and claimed right to plead - Held, no good cause was shown and so the defendant had no right to be relegated to the position that he would have occupied if he had appeared on 17-3-1953, but he had a right to appear through counsel on 20-3-1953 and take part in the proceedings from the stage at which they had then reached, subject to such terms and conditions as the Tribunal might think fit to impose.

In this case, before the Election Tribunal defendant appeared at the first hearing on 11-12-1952. He filed his written statement and issues were framed. The case was then adjourned to 17th March for the petitioners' evidence only and he examined all his witnesses on 17th to 20th March. On 20th defendant had entered appearance through counsel and claimed the right to plead. The Election Tribunal did not exercise its discretion because it considered that it had none and thought that until the 'ex parte' order was set aside the defendant could not appear either personally or through counsel. No good cause was shown and so the defendant had no right to be relegated to the position that he would have occupied if he had appeared on 17-3-1953, but he had a right to appear through counsel on 20-3-1953 and take part in the proceedings from the stage at which they had then reached, subject to such terms and conditions as the Tribunal might think fit to impose. Whether he should have been allowed to cross-examine the three witnesses who were examined after the appearance of his counsel, or whether he should have been allowed to adduce evidence, was a matter that had to depend on whatever views the Tribunal in a sound exercise of judicial discretion would choose to take of the circumstances of this particular case, but there was no justification for not at least allowing counsel to argue. AIR 1949 Oudh 59 (FB) - Overruled.	 [Para 36,38,40]

When the defendant has been served and has been afforded an opportunity of appearing then if he does not appear the Court may proceed in his absence. But the Court is not directed to make an 'ex parte' order. Of course the fact that it is, proceeding 'ex parte' will be recorded in the minutes of its proceedings but that is merely a statement of the fact and is not an order made against the defendant in the sense of an 'ex parte' decree or other 'ex parte' order which the Court is authorised to make. All that R.6(1)(a) does is to remove a bar and no more. It merely authorises the Court to do that which it could not have done without this authority namely to proceed in the absence of one of the parties. The contrast in language between R.7 and R.13 emphasises this. Rule 7 provides that if at an adjourned hearing the defendant appears and shows good cause for his "previous non-appearance" he can be heard in answer to the suit "as if he had appeared on the day fixed for his appearance". This cannot be read to mean that he cannot be allowed to appear at all if he does not show good cause. All it means is that he cannot be relegated to the position he would have occupied if he had appeared. If a party does appear on "the day to which the hearing of the suit is adjourned", he cannot be stopped from participating in the proceedings simply because he did not appear on the first or some other hearing. If the defendant does not appear at the first hearing, the Court can proceed ex parte, which means that it can proceed without a written statement; and O.9, R.7 makes it clear that unless good cause is shown the defendant cannot be relegated to the position that he would have occupied if he had appeared. That means that he cannot put in a written statement unless he is allowed to do so and if the case is one in which the Court considers a written statement should have been put in, the consequences entitled by O.8, R.l0 must be suffered. What those consequences should be in a given case is for the Court, in the exercise of its judicial discretion, to determine to meet the ends of justice. When we speak of the ends of justice, we mean justice not only to the defendant and to the other side but also to witnesses and others who may be inconvenienced.	 [Para 26,28,30,33,34]

If the defendant does not appear at the adjourned hearing (irrespective of whether or not he appeared at the first hearing) O.17, R.2 applies and the Court is given the widest possible discretion either to dispose of the suit in one of the modes directed in that behalf by O.9 or make such other order as it thinks fit. The Court has a discretion which it must exercise. Its hands are not tied by the socalled 'ex parte' order; and if it thinks they are tied by O.9, R.7 then it is not exercising the discretion which the law says it should and, in a given case interference may be called for.	 [Para 37]

heading: Mention of offences for which petitioner was convicted
HeadNote.description:
Mention of offences for which petitioner was convicted - Not stated in form 3(C) but endorsement stating that list was attached - But no such list was annexed - Held nomination paper suffered from defect of substantial character - Returning officer was justified in rejecting nomination paper.

Section 33 mandates the candidate to deliver to the Returning Officer at the place specified in the notice issued U/s 31, "Nomination paper completed in the prescribed form and signed by the candidate and by an electrol of the constituency as proposer". As such the candidate is duty bound to deliver a nomination paper completed in the prescribed form. Section 36(2)(b), lays down that the Returning Officer shall reject any nomination if there has been failure to comply with any of the provisions of Section 33 or Section 34 of the. If the nomination paper was not complete as is required U/s 33(1) of the R.P.Act, the Returning Officer had no option but to reject the same. The nomination form was incomplete as can be seen as no information on a separate sheet or list was filled in though it was specifically represented in the nomination paper i.e. form 3-C. No question would arise of completing the nomination paper on the next date or the date of scrutiny of the nomination paper. As such the question of giving opportunity to the petitioner also would be redundant. Section 36 is mandatory and enjoins the Returning Officer to refuse any nomination when there has been any failure to comply with any of the provisions of Section 33, the Returning Officer at that stage can not remedy essential defect or permit to be remedied that defect. He must leave it as it is. If it is technical and non-substantial, it will not matter, if it is not, it can not be set right.

The defect in the present case is certainly of a substantial character. It is mandatory for the petitioner to give the information in form 3-C regarding the offences as enumerated in Section 8, so also the offences enumerated in Section 33-A. It is a fact that the petitioner had represented that he has been convicted for the offences U/s 8 by making an endorsement that a list has been annexed in respect of the same along with the form and no such list was annexed. The said defect is a defect of a substantial character. 


(2003) 2 SCC 176, AIR 1954 SC 510 Rel.on.  [Para 18,19]

heading: Disqualification under
HeadNote.description:
Disqualification under - Ground of subsisting contract with State Government - Contract with State Government subsequently transferred to statutory corporation - It will cease to be a subsisting contract with State Government.

A contract subsists till the rights and obligations thereunder are finally performed. The general rule is that though an employer may assign the benefits and obligations of a contract to an assignee, he will not be relieved of his obligations towards the contractor, unless the contractor is also a party to the assignment, in which event there is an assignment coupled with novation, (a new contract between the assignee and the contractor). But the exception to this general rule is where a statute vests certain assets of the State in a statutory corporation (or Government Company or other specified person) and provides that as a consequence, the rights and obligations of the State relating to such assets shall stand transferred to such statutory corporation (or Government Company or specified person). In that event, the statute engrafts itself into the existing contract and as a consequence, the statutory corporation stands substituted in place of the original employer, and the existing contracts become contracts between the statutory corporation and the contractor. In case of such statutory vesting/transfer, the consent of the contractor for the substitution of the contracting party and the assignment/transfer of the contract is not necessary. The contract, on such statutory transfer and vesting, though originally entered with the State Government ceased to be a subsisting contract with the State Government from the date of such transfer and vesting and will be considered as a subsisting contract with the statutory corporation (GMIDC). Therefore, the contract though subsisting on the date of filing of nominations and scrutiny of nomination, was not a contract with the appropriate Government, but with GMIDC.   [Para 24,26]

heading: Constitution of India Art.19(1)(a)
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India Art.19(1)(a) - Rules 41(2) & (3) and R.49-O are ultra vires S.128 and Art.19(1)(a) - Election Commission directed to provide another button called NOTA (None of the Above) in EVMS.

No doubt, the right to vote is a statutory right but it is equally vital to recollect that this statutory right is the essence of democracy. Without this, democracy will fail to thrive. Therefore, even if the right to vote is statutory, the significance attached with the right is massive. Free and fair election is a basic structure of the Constitution and necessarily includes within its ambit the right of an elector to cast his vote without fear of reprisal, duress or coercion. Protection of elector's identity and affording secrecy is therefore integral to free and fair elections and an arbitrary distinction between the voter who casts his vote and the voter who does not cast his vote is violative of Article 14. Thus, secrecy is required to be maintained for both categories of persons. Giving right to a voter not to vote for any candidate while protecting his right of secrecy is extremely important in a democracy. Such an option gives the voter the right to express his disapproval with the kind of candidates that are being put up by the political parties.

In the light of the above Rules 41(2) & (3) and 49-O of the Rules are ultra vires Section 128 of the RP Act and Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution to the extent they violate secrecy of voting. Hence the Election Commission ought to provide necessary provision in the ballot papers/EVMs and another button called "None of the Above" (NOTA) may be provided in EVMs so that the voters, who come to the polling booth and decide not to vote for any of the candidates in the fray, are able to exercise their right not to vote while maintaining their right of secrecy. 

The direction can also be supported by the fact that in the existing system a dissatisfied voter ordinarily does not turn up for voting which in turn provides a chance to unscrupulous elements to impersonate the dissatisfied voter and cast a vote, be it a negative one. Furthermore, a provision of negative voting would be in the interest of promoting democracy as it would send clear signals to political parties and their candidates as to what the electorate think about them.     [Para 52,54,55,56,61]

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - Registration of contractor/candidate cancelled after last date of filing of nominations - Contracts in favour of candidate were subsisting by virtue of clause regarding liability for damage done or for imperfection in works - Thus, disqualification u/S.9A would operate against candidate - His election would thus be rendered void.		 	(Paras 17, 18, 21, 22, 23)

heading: Proviso (a)
HeadNote.description:
Proviso (a) - Bailability of offences under the Act - All offences under the Act are not bailable.

Under the proviso to S.8(2) of the Act if the officer of the Force is of the opinion that there is sufficient evidence or reasonable ground of suspicion against the accused persons he shall (a) either admit him to bail to appear before a Magistrate having jurisdiction in the case or (b) forward him in custody to such Magistrate.  The jurisdiction to exercise the discretion is statutorily provided.  The exercise of such discretion is also controlled by the prescription regarding forming of opinion as regards sufficiency of material or otherwise.  [Para 5,6]

There are two options given to the officer to form opinion i.e. whether there is sufficient evidence or reasonable ground of suspicion against the accused persons.  It nowhere deals with the right of the accused to get bail.  The third category is contemplated by clause (b) of the proviso.  It inter alia, provides that when it appears to the officer that there is no sufficient evidence or reasonable suspicion, he shall release the accused person on his executing a bond with or without surety as the officer of the Force may direct to appear if and when so required before the Magistrate having jurisdiction and shall make a full report of all the particulars of the case to his superior officer.  This category deals with a case where there is absence of sufficient evidence or reasonable ground of suspicion.  In such case concerned officer has the power to release accused person on his executing bonds.  Therefore, the High Court was not justified in holding that all the offences under the Act are bailable.  Such view is contrary to the provisions contained in Section 8 of the Act. [Para 8]

heading: Manual of Railway Laws, Rr.14, 15
HeadNote.description: Manual of Railway Laws, Rr.14, 15 - Confessional statement of accused - Confession allegedly made to R.P.F. authorities - R.P.F. authorities though not Police Officers, the confessional statement made by accused to them, held, not sufficient to form basis of the conviction of the accused when it is no case of prosecution that the accused were produced before Magistrate of competent jurisdiction and their confessions were recorded by the said Magistrate. Penal Code (1860), S.379. Evidence Act (1872), Ss.24, 25. 2007 ALL SCR 961 - Ref. to.			(Para 8)

heading: Theft of railway property
HeadNote.description: Theft of railway property - Truck found to be loaded with cast iron - Accused who was described as contractor was present near the truck and when asked to unload stolen iron he got it unloaded through his labourers - Hence finding that he was in unlawful possession does not warrant interference - For offence committed for the first time, minimum of sentence of one year was rightly imposed - No interference called for.	(Paras 7, 10, 11)

heading: Punishment
Discretion
Accused pleaded guilty
HeadNote.description:
Unlawful possession of railway property - Punishment - Discretion - Appeal for enhancement in sentence.

Accused in unlawful possession of axles guard plates, failed to explain - Accused pleaded guilty - Accused requested leniency as he was blind, having wife, three children and very poor economic condition - Accused indicated that by mistake he lifted the property of railways and stated that he was repenting. Punishment of imprisonment of one day till rising of court and fine of Rs.20/- and in case of default four days rigorous imprisonment awarded by Magistrate. Appeal for enhancement in sentence. Held, Magistrate had not committed error in awarding above sentence.	 [Para 1,2,3]

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Unlawful possession of railway property - Appeal against acquittal - Accused found carrying brake block belonging to railway - On being inquired he answered that he took it from railway line with intent to sale it - Confessional statement recorded by inquiry officer - However, said confessional statement was not recorded in presence of two independent witnesses - Non fulfillment of clauses 14, 14(1) by enquiry authority - As regards seizure of property, no evidence on record to show that charge of brake block taken from accused - Even panchas did not support prosecution case - Neither inquiry officer received memo about property nor he inquired as to from which railway department it was stolen - Nothing on record to show that property belonged to railway department - No perversity in acquittal of accused. (Paras 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16)

heading: Punishment for
HeadNote.description: Theft of railway property - Punishment for - Offenders liable to be punished with imprisonment for a term not less than one year which may extend to five years - However, trial Judge has powers to impose minimum sentence less than one year for adequate reasons to be recorded by him.(Para 8)

heading: Unlawful possession of railway property
HeadNote.description: Unlawful possession of railway property - Accused alleged to have stolen 77 pieces of rail described as R 90-64 and 52 k.g. rails 13 pieces - Evidence on record showing that it was scrap and sold by Railway Yard - Also R.P.F. officers have given vital admissions that there were no identification marks to say that pieces belong to Railway - Prosecution failed to prove that property seized was belonging to railway - Offence not proved against accused - Acquittal of accused, proper.  			(Paras 11, 13, 14, 18)

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Unlawful possession of railway property - Appeal against acquittal - Respondents were found loading railway structures in a truck - On being inquired, they answered that loading instructions were given by original accused no.4 - Accused no.4 already convicted for deriving pecuniary advantage from supply of these structures - However, nothing on record to show that respondents were aware of illegalities committed by accused no.4 or that they received any consideration from him - Though cheques in name of wives of respondents were issued by accused no.4, its connection with alleged illegal act not established - Benefit of doubt given to respondents - Acquittal upheld. 			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Conviction u/S.3(a)
HeadNote.description: Conviction u/S.3(a) - Sentence of less than minimum prescribed period of 1 Yr. - Necessity to record special and adequate reasons - No such reason assigned by trial Court for imposing punishment of 6 months - Considering lapse of 23 years from date of incident and that accused has not filed appeal against conviction - Enhancement of punishment would not be proper. 			(Para 15)

heading: Application for discharge
HeadNote.description: Unlawful possession of railway property - Application for discharge - Applicant was in lawful possession of large volume of railway property and could not account for only an extremely small piece of property found alongwith property duly accounted for - None of the seized articles bore any mark of railway - Witnesses who are Engineers in Railways stating that seized articles are not used as railways but for miscellaneous work like stand of water tank etc. - That apart, no theft or missing report lodged in respect of any of the seized articles - Evidence lacking on the most vital aspects, even evidence  on basic ingredients of offence is absent - Hence, prosecution cannot be continued, accused discharged.  (Paras 13, 16, 17, 19)

heading: Application for discharge
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), Ss.227, 482 - Unlawful possession of railway property - Application for discharge - Rejection on ground that expert witnesses opined the property to be railway property - Said witnesses were two engineers working in railways - Nothing to show that they had acquired any special skill, knowledge or training in identifying railway property - Said witnesses could not be termed as experts and their opinion would not be covered by provision of S.45 Evidence Act - Rejection of discharge application on said ground held, illegal.	(Para 17)

heading: Appeal against acquittal
HeadNote.description: Theft of railway property - Appeal against acquittal - Respondents were charged either of being in unlawful possession of railway property or assisting in committing theft of railway property - Confessional statements were not trustworthy in absence of any independent witness and it could not be proved that possession of property was conscious being unlawful possession of railway property - Panch witness turned hostile and did not support prosecution case at all - Acquittal of respondents after taking into consideration all materials on record is proper - No interference. (Paras 22, 25, 28, 33, 38, 43, 49)

heading: Accident claim
HeadNote.description: Accident claim - Collision between truck and car - Claimants claiming that accident occurred due to rash and negligent driving of truck driver as he suddenly applied breaks due to which car coming from behind collided with truck - No evidence on record to show that driver of truck suddenly applied breaks in middle of road - Material on record showing that driver of car failed to keep sufficient distance between two vehicles - Driver of car and not truck was guilty of rash and negligent driving - Even then owner and driver of truck were jointly and severally liable to pay compensation of Rs. 50,000/- to claimants u/S.140 of Act with 9% interest. 	(Paras 10, 11, 14, 15)

heading: Contributory negligence
Determination
HeadNote.description: Contributory negligence - Determination - Collision between truck and car - Question of contributory negligence arise when both parties are involved in accident due to rash and negligent driving - Accident occurred when car was following truck and collided with truck from back side - Evidence on record shows that driver of car was driving vehicle in rash and negligent manner - Truck driver not found negligent - Question of contributory negligence on his part does not arise. 	 (Para 12)

heading: Composite negligence
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Composite negligence - Determination of - Car was running in east-west direction through southern side - Motorcycle coming from link/pocket road on southern side and had almost crossed the road - Damage to car was on right side, which indicates driver of car must have seen rider of motorcycle into main road - Driver of car had duty to slow down vehicle to avoid accident - But in view of Reg.9 it can be said that rider of motorcycle ought to have given way to vehicles proceeding along main road - Hence, degree of negligence apportioned among driver of car and rider of motorcycle in ratio 70:30. 	(Para 9)

HeadNote.act_name: Regional Rural Banks (Appointment and Promotion of Officers and Other Employees) Rules (1988)
heading: Promotion
Seniority-cum-merit
HeadNote.description:
Promotion - Seniority-cum-merit - Prescribing minimum qualifying marks to ascertain minimum merit necessary for discharging functions of higher post - Is not violative of concept of promotion by seniority-cum-merit.

Prescribing minimum qualifying marks to ascertain the minimum merit necessary for discharging the functions of the higher post, is not violative of the concept of promotion by seniority-cum-merit. It is clear that a process whereby eligible candidates possessing the minimum necessary merit in the feeder posts is first ascertained and thereafter, promotions are made strictly in accordance with seniority, from among those who possess the minimum necessary merit is recognised and accepted as complying with the principle of 'seniority-cum-merit'. What would offend the rule of seniority-cum-merit is a process where after assessing the minimum necessary merit, promotions are made on the basis of merit (instead of seniority) from among the candidates possessing the minimum necessary merit. If the criteria adopted for assessment of minimum necessary merit is bona fide and not unreasonable, it is not open to challenge, as being opposed to the principle of seniority-cum-merit.   [Para 10]

HeadNote.act_name: Regional Rural Banks (Appointment and Promotion of Officers and Other Employees) Rules (1988)
heading: Promotion
Seniority-cum-merit
HeadNote.description:
Promotion - Seniority-cum-merit - Fixing 78% as minimum qualifying marks for determining merit is not unreasonable or arbitrary.

In the instant case fixing of 78% as minimum qualifying marks i.e. as the minimum necessary merit is not unreasonable or arbitrary. The Rules in this case provide that the mode of selection is by interview and assessment of performance reports for the preceding three years as officer Scale I. The seniority list of officers in Scale I was published on 4.12.1996. Thereafter, the promotion process was held by earmarking 60 marks for assessment of performance Reports (at the rate of 20 marks per year) and 40 marks were allotted for interview. The officers possessing the minimum qualifying marks of 78%, were then promoted on the basis of seniority. What should be the minimum necessary merit for promotion, is a matter that is decided by the management, having in mind the requirements of the post to which promotions are to be made. The employer has the discretion to fix different minimum merit, for different categories of posts, subject to the relevant Rules. For example, for promotions at lower levels, it may fix a lesser minimum qualifying marks and fix a comparatively higher minimum qualifying marks for higher posts. In the first respondent Bank, the post of officer-Grade II (Area Managers and Senior Managers) is a very senior position, next only to the top post of General Manager. As the officers promoted to Scale II were required to head larger branches or departments in the Head Office, shouldering higher responsibilities and virtually competing with commercial banks, it cannot be said that the fixing the minimum qualifying marks at 78% is excessive, unreasonable or arbitrary. Another aspect requires to be noticed. Where the assessment of minimum merit is with reference to previous performance record (Annual Confidential Records) and/or by interview, as contrasted from a written examination, prescription of 78% as minimum, will not be considered as unreasonably high.   [Para 11,12]

Whether the guidelines/rules adopted for assessing the minimum necessary merit by prescribing marks under several heads or by prescribing a specific minimum mark, is reasonable or arbitrary, would depend upon the facts of each case. If it is demonstrated that the minimum marks were fixed with the intention of favouring someone or to specifically exclude someone, the courts may interfere. Similarly, where the minimum marks are shown to have been fixed to defeat or nullify the mode of seniority-cum-merit for promotion, there may be a cause for interference. In other cases, there is very little scope to interfere with the procedure adopted to ascertain the minimum required merit.   [Para 13,15]

HeadNote.act_name: Regional Rural Banks (Appointment and Promotion of Officers and Other Employees) Rules (1988)
heading: Procedure for promotion
HeadNote.description:
Circulars dt.30.11.2009 and 12.7.2010 - Procedure for promotion - Where a person is eligible to be considered for promotion, he cannot be excluded from consideration on ground that he was awarded censure entry or other minor punishment - Circulars issued by bank cannot override statutory rules.

The RRB Rules 1998 have introduced a detailed procedure for determining the minimum merit for promotion to the next higher post/grade. The RRB Rules, 1998 clearly provided that officers holding post in 8 years as an officer on regular basis in the RRB shall be considered for promotion to the next higher post. The aforesaid rule does not provide that any employee/officer, who has suffered a punishment or has received an adverse appraisal/Grade 'D' in the performance appraisal, shall not be eligible. However, the Circulars dated 30th November, 2009 and 12th July, 2010 enables the appellant banks to eliminate such employees, which is clearly contrary to the provisions contained in the statutory service rules. The procedure prescribed under the aforesaid two Circulars clearly has the effect of supplanting the provision of eligibility, which is not permissible.

Whilst assessing the eligibility of the candidates, determination of bare minimum merit is not envisaged. There is, in fact, a complete segregation of Rule 2(e) from Rule 2(f). Determining the eligibility of candidate is in the nature of a ministerial function. The management merely has to see that the candidate possesses the minimum length of service and that he/she is confirmed in the feeder cadre. The determination of bare minimum merit is on the basis of the performance in the written test/interview and performance appraisal. This is the function of the Selection Committee i.e. Departmental Promotion Committee.

There is no doubt that punishment and adverse service record are relevant to determine the minimum merit by the DPC. But to debar a candidate, to be considered for promotion, on the basis of punishment or unsatisfactory record would require the necessary provision in the statutory service Rules. There is no such provision under the 1998 Rules.

Different rules/regulations of the banks provide specific punishments such as "withholding of promotion, reduction in rank, lowering in ranks/pay scales". However, there is another range of penalty such as censure, reprimand, withholding of increments etc. which are also prescribed under various staff regulations. To debar such an employee from being considered for promotion would tantamount to also inflicting on such employee, the punishment of withholding of promotion. In such circumstances, a punishment of censure/ reprimand would, in fact, read as censure/reprimand + 5 years debarment from promotion. Thus the circulars issued by the bank debarring such employees from being considered would be clearly contrary to the statutory rules.	            [Para 31,35,36,40]

HeadNote.act_name: Regional Rural Banks (Appointment and Promotion of Officers and Other Employees) Rules (1988)
heading: Promotion to the post of field Supervisors
HeadNote.description: Promotion to the post of field Supervisors - Seniority-cum-merit basis to be followed - Bank not subjecting eligible candidates to any process of assessment to ascertain any specified minimum merit for promoting them on basis of their seniority - Instead their inter-se merit was assessed with reference to marks allocated to different educational qualification - Held promotion was on merit-cum-seniority and not seniority-cum-merit basis and hence High Court was justified in setting it aside.	(Paras 6, 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Regional Rural Banks (Appointment and Promotion of Officers and Other Employees) Rules (1988)
heading: Promotion
Basis of seniority-cum-merit
HeadNote.description: Promotion - Basis of seniority-cum-merit - Whenever a person is promoted to a post without following rules prescribed he should be treated as a person not regularly promoted to that post - Consequently, in computing the length of service, in the post to which employee is promoted, it is not permissible to include period of service rendered in pursuance of illegal promotion which is subsequently set aside. (Para 10)

heading: Impleadment
Validity
HeadNote.description: Impleadment - Deletion of name of promoter - From array of parties - Validity - Appellant filed consumer complaint to restrain respondents from charging additional amounts for alleged increase in area of flats - As per S.2(zk) of Real State Act 'promoter' would include entity which is constructing building as well as selling apartments or plots - There was nothing to show that promoter is unconnected with project or has been impleaded as party without any reason or basis - Deletion of name of promoter, improper. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Against order of Real Estate Appellate Tribunal - Dispute between respondent-allotees of apartments and appellant-promoter as to payment of consideration and interest on account of non-completion of project within stipulated period - Grounds raised in second appeal state that Tribunal should have considered certain aspects or it should not have relied upon fact finding exercise undertaken or persons who undertook said exercise were not authorised to do so - Clauses in appeal memo state that Tribunal was not correct in passing impugned order considering scope and parameters of clauses of agreement between parties - At the most it is contended that appellate authority has not followed procedure laid down in S.53 of the Act - None of these contentions are in nature of substantial question of law - Grounds of appeal memo are only challenges to order passed by Tribunal and not even raising question of law - Hence, second appeal dismissed. 2019 ALL SCR 217 Rel. on. 	(Para 27)

heading: Appellate Tribunal
Without jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Appellate Tribunal - Application for condonation of delay heard by non-judicial member alone - Without jurisdiction - There has to be at least one judicial member and one administrative member - Order of sole member liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Dismissal of appeal
HeadNote.description: Dismissal of appeal - For non-compliance of pre-deposit order - Challenge by contending that agreement between parties was not agreement for sale, but agreement in lieu of allottee’s share in promoter firm - Allottee was erstwhile partner of promoter firm and agreement was executed with view to satisfy allottee’s claim towards his share in partnership upon his retirement - Primafacie this agreement is nothing, but agreement for sale between promoter and allottee - Dismissal of appeal, proper. (Para 5)

heading: Appeal by promoter
Not proper
Impugned order quashed
HeadNote.description: Appeal by promoter - Order to make predeposit - Challenge by claiming that appellant does not come under expression "promoter" used in proviso - This issue not considered by Appellate Tribunal - Not proper - It was imperative for Appellate Tribunal to at least take prima facie view on this issue and only then proceed to order pre-deposit - Impugned order quashed - Matter remanded back for fresh consideration. (Para 6)

heading: Tenability
HeadNote.description: Information as to development plan - Objection as to absence of 'public interest' - Tenability - There was provision in repealed MOFA and also in new RERA, for disclosure of full information to prospective buyers regarding sanctioned plan - Purchase and investment in land development is a matter of public knowledge and debate - There is no 'personal information' involved - Application in instant case made by person executing power of attorney in favour of developer - When information available to public at large, no reason why it should not be available to owner or administrator of land - Thus, even on test of public interest, information cannot be declined to applicant. 			(Paras 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 26, 34)

heading: Bar of jurisdiction
HeadNote.description:
Consumer Protection Act (2019), S.107 - Bar of jurisdiction - Initiation of proceedings under Consumer Protection Act 1986 after provisions of RERA came into force - Not barred.

	Insofar as cases where such proceedings under the Consumer Protection Act are initiated after the provisions of the RERA Act came into force, there is nothing in the RERA Act which bars such initiation. The absence of bar under Section 79 to the initiation of proceedings before a fora which cannot be called a Civil Court and express saving under Section 88 of the RERA Act, make the position quite clear. Further, Section 18 itself specifies that the remedy under said Section is “without prejudice to any other remedy available”. Thus, the parliamentary intent is clear that a choice or discretion is given to the allottee whether he wishes to initiate appropriate proceedings under the Consumer Protection Act or file an application under the RERA Act. (Para 28)

	It is true that some special authorities are created under the RERA Act for the regulation and promotion of the real estate sector and the issues concerning a registered project are specifically entrusted to functionaries under the RERA Act. Since S.18 gives a right “without prejudice to any other remedy available’, in effect, such other remedy is acknowledged and saved subject always to the applicability of Section 79. (Paras 18, 30) There is nothing in consistent in the Provisions of Consumer Prortection Act with that of RERA Act 2016. (Para 32)

	Further Section 100 of Consumer Protection Act 2019 Act is akin to Section 3 of the Consumer Protection Act 1986 and Section 107 saves all actions taken or purported to have been taken under the 1986 Act. It is significant that Section 100 is enacted with an intent to secure the remedies under 2019 Act dealing with protection of the interests of Consumers, even after the RERA Act was brought into force. (Para 34)

heading: Delay
HeadNote.description:
Action under RERA Act - Delay - Construction project to be completed in 42 months - Said period expired well before project was registered under RERA Act - Fact that said registration is valid upto 31-12-2020 - Does not mean that entitlement of concerned allottees to maintain action stands defeated - Entitlement of complainants must be considered in light of terms of Builder Buyer Agreements.

	In the present case the apartments were booked by the Complainants in 2011-2012 and the Builder Buyer Agreements were entered into in November, 2013. As promised, the construction should have been completed in 42 months. The period had expired well before the Project was registered under the provisions of the RERA Act. Merely because the registration under the RERA Act is valid till 31.12.2020 does not mean that the entitlement of the concerned allottees to maintain an action stands deferred. Even for the purposes of Section 18, the period has to be reckoned in terms of the agreement and not the registration. Condition no. (x) of the letter dated 17.11.2017 also entitles an allottee in same fashion. Therefore, the entitlement of the Complainants must be considered in the light of the terms of the Builder Buyer Agreements. (Para 33)

heading: Group Housing Construction Project
HeadNote.description: Group Housing Construction Project - Date of handing over possession by Developer - Determination of, Under Agreement - Developer proposed to offer possession of apartment to allottee within 42 months from date of approval of Building plans/or fulfillment of preconditions imposed thereunder, a "commitment period" - Developer further entitled to "Grace period" of 180 days after expiry of commitment period for unforeseen delays beyond its reasonable control - It works out to be total 48 months - On 27-11-2014, fire fighting scheme was approved - Thus, computation of period for handing over possession would be computed from this date - Thus, relevant date would be 27-11-2018. (Para 18)

heading: Primacy of law
HeadNote.description: Primacy of law - Remedy under Consumer Protection Act is additional remedy despite existence of remedies under special statutes - U/S.18 of RERA Act 2016, remedies are "without prejudice to any other remedy available" - Thus, allottee of apartment may elect or opt for one out of remedies provided by law for redressal of injury or grievance - Election of remedies arises when two concurrent remedies are available - Aggrieved party when chooses to exercise one - It loses right to simultaneously exercise the other for same cause of action. (Para 20)

heading: Railway Pension Rules (1950), Cl.323
HeadNote.description:
Railway Pension Rules (1950), Cl.323 - Recovery of Government dues - Recovery of O.D. Wages, water charges, rent are outside the purview of the Rules - Power conferred vide Rule 323 of 1950 rules does not include power to recover the amounts of these dues.

If the premises partake the character of public premises then the remedy provided by section 7 of this enactment coupled with the right of appeal provided thereunder would be the only remedy.  In case of a doubt about the nature of occupancy and the character of the premises, civil suit is the other remedy.  The moment authorities seek to recover penal damages in respect of official accommodation or its retention beyond the permissible period, then the aforesaid modes of recovery only are available.  It is not permissible for the authorities to fall back on the Rules pertaining to grant of Terminal benefits and effect recovery therefrom.   [Para 19]

Assuming that Rule 15 of the 1993 Rules would apply, even then, a bare perusal of the Rule indicates that the railway or Government dues should be (a) ascertained and assessed and (b) they should renain outstanding till the date of retirement or death of railway servant.  Only then, it is permissible to adjust the same against the amount of retirement gratuity or terminal gratuity and (c) recovery of all dues against railway servant shall be regulated in accordance with the provisions of sub-rule 4 of Rule 15.  Now, it is well settled that whenever the Legislature uses the words "ascertained and assessed" pertaining to the dues, they necessarily pre-suppose crystallisation of the dues after adjudication. That such an adjudication only will result in ascertainment and assessment of the dues is apparent.  Further, that such an adjudication should be prior goes without saying. 2003(3) Mh.L.J. 168 AIR 1998 SC 2885 and AIR 1999 SC 1381 - Followed.   [Para 21]

heading: Distinguished.	(Paras 20, 21)
HeadNote.description: Benefit under Payment of Gratuity Act - Scope and applicability of - Railway employees- Railway servants are excluded from applicability of benefits under the Act of 1972 - They are not governed by the Act of 1972. ILR 1981(1) Ker 164 - Distinguished.	(Paras 20, 21)

heading: Recovery of Government dues
HeadNote.description:
Recovery of Government dues - Principles of natural justice - Opportunity of being heard will have to be given to concerned employee before recoveries or adjustments are effected by the Railway or Government.

Principles of natural justice have to be adhered to and an opportunity will have to be given to the concerned employee before recoveries or adjustments are effected by the Railway or Government.  In the instant case, merely addressing the letters, would not by any stretch of imagination mean compliance with the principles of natural justice.  There is nothing in the order dated 31st October, 1996 which would indicate that prior opportunity was given to the petitioner before adjustments were made from the terminal dues/benefits admissible to him.  In this view of the matter, the conclusion of the Tribunal that opportunity was given or that there was no dispute about the dues is contrary to the material placed on record and wholly erroneous.  It is difficult to agree with the conclusion of Tribunal on this aspect.   [Para 22]

heading: Suit for recovery of damages
