heading: Adoption of sentence
Rejection, illegal
HeadNote.description: Indo-Mauritius Agreement on Transfer of Sentenced Persons, Art.8 - Offence on foreign land - Adoption of sentence - It cannot be said that S.13(6) of Repatriation of Prisoners Act or agreement intend to measure duration of penalty and it is not sole basis of it being compatible - Compatibility of sentence would not only require compatibility of duration but also nature of offence - Accused found in possession of drugs in Mauritius and sentenced to 26 years of imprisonment - Transferred to India under Agreement, to undergo sentence - Said offence if committed by accused in India, he would have been imposed penalty of 10 years imprisonment as prescribed u/S.21(b) of NDPS Act - Prayer by accused for benefit of adoption of said sentence in terms of S.13(6) - Rejection, illegal - Mere reason that if prayer of accused is granted it would amount to reduction of sentence by 16 years, cannot be valid justification - Accordingly date of release of accused directed to be revised. heading: Transfer
HeadNote.description: Transfer - Petitioner passed 1st year of MBBS, applied for transfer to another Medical College on Medical ground - Petitioner obtained NOC from his institution - MUHS also granted approval for transfer - Petitioner's name was not listed in transfer list - State Government admitted that it considered all applications for transfer on basis of marks obtained - Procedure is contrary to regulations framed by MCI - Government to set right deficiency by promulgating new guidelines for 2012-13 - Petitioner's application was rejected without considering grounds of transfer - Petitioner to get certificate of Government Medical Hospital as per new guidelines - Application of petitioner must be considered afresh. 	(Paras 16, 17, 18)

HeadNote.description: Rights of Persons with Disabilities Act (2016), S.2(r), Sch. Cl.1B - Reservation - In admission to MBBS course - Candidate suffering from 40% loss of vision i.e. benchmark disability of low vision within meaning of S.2(r) r/w. clause 1B of Schedule Persons with Disabilities Act (2016) - Cannot be denied benefit of reservation in admission to MBBS course if he qualifies as per merit in category of person with disability. 	(Para 27)

heading: Exercise of
HeadNote.description:
Right of private defence - Exercise of - Once the right of private defence came to end, further acts of aggression cannot be said to be in exercise of the right of private defence of person or property - Exception-2 to S.300 will therefore not apply.

The facts of the present case indicate that even if story of the defence relating to the acts of the accused having commenced in exercise of a right of private defence was accepted, yet, under Section 102 of the Indian Penal Code the said right would cease to exist as soon as the apprehension ended and such apprehension must be said to have ended after the first shot was fired through the body of the deceased.  Firing a second and third shot by rifle after the first shot penetrating a vital part of the body, damaging the internal organs of the body cannot be said to be acts in pursuance of any provisions of the Railway Protection Force Act, 1957 or the rules framed thereunder.  Pumping of bullet shots one after another cannot also be said to be acts in excess of the private defence because the right of private defence would cease after the deceased was shot through and through his chest.  A 303 rifle is not anautomatic weapon.  The bolt of this rifle has to be pushed back and again pushed forward and this can only be intentional act with an object of firing the rifle.  The facts of the case indicate that the accused in the defence tried to justify his acts.  As far as the second shot is concerned, accused contended that he did not know whether his first bullet had hit the deceased.  But as far as third bullet is concerned, his story that he shot the third bullet at the body who was running away is clearly falsified by the circumstances of three bullet injuries being found on the deceased.  Such an act after cessession of the right of private defence cannot be said to be something done or intended to be done under the powers conferred by or in pursuance of any provision of the Railway Protection Force Act, 1957 or the rules thereunder and therefore, the argument based upon the provision of Section 20(3) of the Railway Protection Force Act, 1957 must fail.	 [Para 11]

heading: Sanction
HeadNote.description: Sanction - Prosecution against member of Armed Forces of Union - However, accused not a person removable from his office "save by or with the sanction of the Government" - Held, S.197 of Criminal P.C. was not attracted to the prosecution of the accused - Sanction u/s.197(2), not necessary. 2005 AIR SCW 2985, 1994 Supp (3) SCC 615, AIR 1990 SC 1976 - Referred to.	(Para 10)

heading: Sanction
HeadNote.description: Sanction - Prosecution against "members of Armed Force" - Prosecution without obtaining sanction u/s.197(1) of Criminal P.C. - Need not be proceeded further, for want of permission. 2006 AIR SCW 1695 - Rel. on.	(Para 11)

heading: Probationer constable
HeadNote.description: Probationer constable - Incorrect filling of attestation form - Appointment was subject to verification of facts given in attestation form - Probationer withholding information about his involvement in two criminal cases while filling in attestation form - His subsequent discharge in criminal cases will not absolve him from his failure to fill attestation form correctly and accurately - Termination of his services on this count during probation period will not attract any stigma or penal consequence - No question of following principles of natural justice arises.	(Paras 5, 8)

heading: Illegal seizure of amount
HeadNote.description: Illegal seizure of amount - Railway Police seized amount from petitioner no.1 on ground that he failed to account money - However, evidence showing that petitioner no.1 stated that amount was belonging to petitioner no.2 and petitioner no.2 justified his ownership by producing documentary evidence - There was no accusation in complaint that petitioner no.1 gave impression or conducted himself in such manner that he posed threat to railway property, passenger area or passenger - Direction given to release amount to petitioner no.2. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Application for pensionary benefits - Rejection on ground of delay - Validity - Petitioner was Rakshak in railway - He met with accident on duty which made him medically unfit for post of Head Rakshak - He was terminated by respondent administration as they could not find alternate job for him - After 9 years petitioner was absorbed as peon in office of DIG, RPF - On retirement he made representation to respondent for consideration of said period of 9 yrs. for pensionary benefits, but there was no response from respondent - Sufficient reason to consider claim of petitioner to pensionary benefits on merits rather than dismissing on ground of delay - Cause of action for claiming pensionary benefits is continuous - Rejection of application, not proper.  (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Departmental enquiry
Right of representation
Reversed.	 [Para 10,11]
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Art.14 - Departmental enquiry - Right of representation - Rules giving restricted right by providing that the friend cannot address Inquiry Officer or cross-examine witnesses - Not invalid or unconstitutional.

There is no vested or absolute right in any charge-sheeted employee to representation either through a counsel or through any other person unless the statute or rules/standing orders provide for such a right. Moreover, the right to representation through some one, even if granted by the rules, can be granted as a restricted or controlled right. Refusal to grant representation through an agent does not violate the principles of natural justice.   [Para 10]

Rule 153(8) only provides for assistance to a charge-sheeted employee by an agent. Thus, a restricted right of representation has been granted by Rule 153(8). Even if no right of assistance had been granted by the rules, there would be no illegality or unconstitutionality. How then can it be said that when a restricted right is granted, the said restricted right is unconstitutional ?  2001(5) Andh L.T. 543 (FB) - Reversed.	 [Para 10,11]

heading: Departmental enquiry
Right of representation
Reversed.	 [Para 10,11]

heading: Protection of the acts of members of the force
HeadNote.description: Protection of the acts of members of the force - Complaint lodged by father of boy, who died accidentally - An initiation of such proceedings in no way can be disturbed or halted by taking a shelter of provisions of S.20 and/or R.256 - No question of waiting for a report of the enquiry - It is for the Court to direct an appropriate authority to start enquiry or to constitute a Court of Enquiry. 2000 Cri.L.J. 424 - Referred to.	(Para 6)

heading: Dismissal from service
Legality
HeadNote.description: Dismissal from service - Legality - Charge-sheet filed with delay of 15 days - Charge alleged against respondent-Senior Rakshak in RPF are that he was found underneath IInd class passenger coach at 2.00 hrs. stabled in western railway yard in suspicious circumstances and was apprehended by another Rakshak for suspected theft from adjacent wagon but escaped after assaulting said Rakshak - However, in the course of inquiry said Rakshak denied any such incident - Therefore, later part of charge not proved at all - First part of charge is quite vague as respondent being a member of RPF, nothing suspicious about his presence at said place - Though degree of proof required in course of departmental proceedings may be rather relaxed, no finding of guilt can be recorded on basis of such vague statement - Therefore, dismissal of employee on said charges not proper. 	(Paras 20, 21, 22)

heading: Dismissal from service
Whether necessary
HeadNote.description:
Dismissal from service - Compliance with safeguards prescribed in Art.311(2) of the Constitution - Whether necessary - Held, once it is admitted that an Officer is entitled to protection of Art.311 of the Constitution, there is no question of dismissal of such an officer without compliance with safeguards prescribed in Art.311(2).

In the context of "reasonable opportunity of being heard" as contemplated by Article 311(2) of Constitution of India, it has been held that the Disciplinary Authority, before it finally or firmly disagrees with the findings recorded by the Inquiring Authority, must afford charged officer, opportunity to show cause as to why such disagreement should not be recorded and the charges, of which, the charged officer may have been exonerated by the Inquiring Authority, not held as proved. Such requirement is to be read as a concomitant to "reasonable opportunity" as contemplated by Article 311 (2) of the Constitution of India. As noted earlier, Section 9 of RPF Act, 1957, which is source for action of dismissal, suspension or reduction in rank of an enrolled member of the RPF itself states that the same shall be "subject to the provisions of Article 311 of the Constitution". Even in the absence of such a provision, once it is admitted that an officer is entitled to protection of Article 311 of the Constitution, there is no question of dismissal of such an officer without compliance with the safeguards prescribed in Article 311 (2) of the Constitution. 2000(1) ALL MR 223 (S.C.), (2003) 2 SCC 449, (2004) 13 SCC 797 Ref.to.	 [Para 26]

heading: Age of retirement of Presiding Officers of DRT
HeadNote.description: Age of retirement of Presiding Officers of DRT - Applicability of amended S.6 of 1993 Act - Language used while inserting new S.6 showing that this Section is "substituted" with old Section - Effect of same would be that all incumbents who are holing post of Presiding Officer on 1st Sep., 2016 i.e. date of new S.6 being inserted, would be governed by amended provision - Moreover, purpose of amending S.6 was to reduce burden of pendency by enhancement of age of Judges concerned - To fulfil said objective "purposive interpretation" should be given and benefit of said provision should be extended even to those who are serving as Presiding Officer on date when amendment became enforceable. 	(Paras 14, 15, 18, 20, 21)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts and Bankruptcy Act (1993)
heading: Appeal before DRT
Condonation of delay
Powers of Tribunal
HeadNote.description: Appeal before DRT - Condonation of delay - Powers of Tribunal - Pre-requisite for applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act, is pendency of proceedings before a Court - Proceedings under RDB Act being before a statutory Tribunal, it cannot be placed at par with proceedings before a Court - Hence, Tribunal shall have no power to condone delay, unless expressly conferred by the statute creating it. 	(Para 11)

HeadNote.act_name: Recovery of Debts and Bankruptcy Act (1993)
heading: Appeal before DRT
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Appeal before DRT - Against order of Recovery Officer - Condonation of delay - S.5 of Limitation Act, whether applicable - Scheme of RDB Act manifestly provides that Legislature has provided for application of Limitation Act to original proceedings before Tribunal u/S.19 only - Therefore, delay in preferring appeal against order of Recovery Officer cannot be condoned by application of S.5 of Limitation Act.

	The RDB Act is a special law. The proceedings are before a statutory Tribunal. The scheme of the Act manifestly provides that the Legislature has provided for application of the Limitation Act to original proceedings before the Tribunal under Section 19 only. The appellate tribunal has been conferred the power to condone delay beyond 45 days under Section 20(3) of the Act. The proceedings before the Recovery officer are not before a Tribunal. Section 24 is limited in its application to proceedings before the Tribunal originating under Section 19 only. The exclusion of any provision for extension of time by the Tribunal in preferring an appeal under Section 30 of the Act makes it manifest that the legislative intent for exclusion was express. The application of Section 5 of the Limitation Act by resort to Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, 1963 therefore does not arise. The prescribed period of 30 days under Section 30(1) of the RDB Act for preferring an appeal against the order of the Recovery officer therefore cannot be condoned by application of Section 5 of the Limitation Act.	                                        [Para 14]

heading: Accident claim
Final award
Power of Tribunal
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), Ss.151, 153 - Accident claim - Final award - Application for change in name of claimant - Power of Tribunal - Held, provisions under Rajasthan Rules as well as provisions of CPC empower the Tribunal to allow correction in name of claimant, if such an application is filed during execution of award.

	Rule 10.27 of the Rajasthan Rules, makes provision that the power vested in the Civil Court under Sections 30, 32, 34, 35 (a), 75(a) and (c), 76, 77, 94, 95, 132, 133, 144, 147, 148, 149, 151, 152 & 153 may be exercised by the Claims Tribunal so far as they may be applicable, subject to the provisions of Section 174 of the Act of 1988. By virtue of Rule 10.28, the provisions of Order XXI CPC, are also made applicable to the proceedings before the Claims Tribunal. That apart, it has been specifically provided that in so far as the Act and the Rules make no provision or make insufficient provision, the relevant provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 shall so far as may be, apply to the proceedings before the Claims Tribunal. 

	Further, as per clause (4) of Rule 10.22, where an application is made to the Claims Tribunal in this behalf or otherwise, the Tribunal is satisfied that on account of the negligence of the children on the part of the parents or on account of variation of the circumstances of the dependent or for any other sufficient cause, an order of the Tribunal as to distribution of any sum paid as compensation or as to manner in which sum payable to any such dependent is to be invested, applied or otherwise dealt with ought to be varied, the Tribunal may make such order for variation of the former order as it thinks fit just in the circumstances of the case. 	 [Para 13,14]

	It is true that after passing the award, the Tribunal becomes functus officio and it cannot review the determination for entitlement of compensation under the award. But then, so far as the order directing disbursement of the amount of compensation already determined is concerned, it is open to be reconsidered and varied by the Tribunal where it is found just in the circumstances of the case in the interest of the claimants.

	It is the duty of the Tribunal to ensure that the compensation awarded by it is disbursed to the rightful claimant in the manner directed by it and therefore, during the execution of the award passed, if the petitioner had applied for the correction of her name in the award on the strength of the documentary evidence, there was absolutely no reason for the Tribunal to decline to entertain the application made. The Tribunal is empowered to grant such amendment invoking the power under the Rules 10.22(4) & 10.27 of the Rules as also the inherent power under Section 151 & 153 of Civil Procedure Code, 1908, while executing the award, which in no manner affects adversely the rights of the non-claimants. 	 [Para 15,16]

heading: Accident claim
Final award
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), Ss.151, 153 - Accident claim - Final award - Application for change in name - Nick name of petitioner mentioned in claim petition and not her real name - No dispute as to identity - Since application is only for alteration in name and not for change in identity of entitled person, same has to be allowed - Tribunal is duty bound to ensure that compensation is disbursed to rightful claimant - Rejection of application improper - Matter remitted back to Tribunal for decision on basis of documents produced by petitioner. 			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Disciplinary enquiry
HeadNote.description: Disciplinary enquiry - Rules and Act are not interdependent - Provisions of Act are applicable only when government sanction is prior condition - Provisions of Railway rules apply to all non-gazetted officers except Grade-A officers - If employee is covered under the Act, disciplinary authority shall have to appoint inquiry officer and proceed with inquiry under the Act, whereas if he is covered under the Rules, procedure prescribed under Rules will have to be followed.	(Para 20)

heading: Dismissal from service
HeadNote.description: Dismissal from service - Whether proportionate to the charges leveled - Appellant doctor employed with Railway, found guilty of illegally accepting Rs.26/- and Rs.18/- for issuing fitness certificate - Appellant had served for 23 years - Not a case that as a matter of habit or on wide scale, appellant had made illegal demands - Punishment of dismissal is disproportionate - Imposition of  compulsory retirement with retiral  benefits, would meet the ends of justice.  			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Disciplinary proceedings
Initiation of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Disciplinary proceedings - Initiation of - On basis of charge sheet issued by authority superior to employee but was neither appointing authority nor competent authority for imposing major penalty - Validity - Employee was Head Parcel Clerk in Railways - As per Rr.2(1)(c) and 8 of Railway Servants (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, only an authority competent to impose any of major penalties can initiate disciplinary proceedings for imposition of major penalty in relation to R.9 in respect of non-gazetted staff - Charge sheet issued by Divisional Commercial Manager who was superior to employee but was neither appointing authority nor competent authority for imposing any major penalty, illegal - Disciplinary proceedings initiated on basis of said charge sheet also become null and void. 	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Misappropriation of money
Determination of punishment
HeadNote.description:
Misappropriation of money - Determination of punishment - Quantum of amount misappropriated - Is not yardstick to be considered while awarding punishment in cases of misappropriation, theft, fraud etc. - Misappropriation of whatsoever nature, irrespective of whether it involves Rs.1/- or thousand, is a grave and serious misconduct. 
2008(4) ALL MR 789 Ref. to. 	(Para 16)

heading: Removal from service
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Removal from service - Challenge - Petitioner-Booking Clerk of Railway allegedly over charged Decoy passenger by Rs.2/- and also that Rs.122/- found short in railway cash - Petitioner contending that Disciplinary Authority was inclined to award punishment of reversion - But owing to undue influence and pressure exerted by Vigilance Dept., Authority was compelled to award a grave punishment - Held, as per R.10(5) Disciplinary Authority has liberty to seek an advice from Vigilance Dept. - That apart, correspondence between the Authority and Vigilance Dept. simply indicates that the latter had merely highlighted seriousness of the misconduct - Same cannot be considered as undue influence - Action taken by Disciplinary Authority held, proper.
(1997) 11 SCC 444, (1991) 3 SCC 219 Disting. 	(Paras 20, 25)

heading: Expression "other authority"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "other authority" - Meaning of the word 'authority' - Expression "other authority" cannot be restricted or limited to serving officers/officials - Principle of necessary implication requires that exclusion should be in conformity with purpose and object of the rule.

There is some unanimity as to what meaning can be given to the expression 'authority'. The authority, should be understood on its plain language and without necessarily curtailing its scope. It will be more appropriate to understand this expression and give it a meaning which should be in conformity with the context and purpose in which it has been used. The 'other authority' appearing in Rule 9(2) is intended to cover a vast field and there is no indication of the mind of the framers that the expression must be given a restricted or a narrow meaning. It is possible that where the authority is vested in a person or a body as a result of delegation, then delegatee of such authority has to work strictly within the field delegated. If it works beyond the scope of delegation, in that event it will be beyond the authority and may even, in given circumstances vitiate the action.   [Para 24]

The words of the rule, therefore, should be explicit or the intent should be irresistibly expressed for exclusion. If it was so intended, the framers of the rule could simply use the expression like 'public servant in office' or 'an authority in office'. Absence of such specific language exhibits the mind of the framers that they never intended to restrict the scope of 'other authority' by limiting it to the serving officers/officials. The principle of necessary implication further requires that the exclusion should be an irresistible conclusion and should also be in conformity with the purpose and object of the rule.   [Para 26]

The language of Rule 9(2) does not debar specifically or even by necessary implication appointment of a former employee of the Railways as Inquiry Officer. Even if, for the sake of argument, it is assumed otherwise, all the respondents have participated in the departmental inquiries without protest and it is only after the orders of the competent authority have been passed that they have raised this objection before the Courts. In the light of the peculiar facts and circumstances of the present case, it is obligatory upon the respondents to show that they have suffered some serious prejudice because of appointment of retired Railway Officers as Inquiry Officers. The respondents have no way satisfied this test of law. Thus, if their argument was to be accepted on the interpretation of Rule 9(2), which we have specifically objected, even then the inquiries conducted and the order passed thereupon would not be vitiated for this reason.   [Para 57]

heading: Expression "other authority"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "other authority" - Whether retired officers can be appointed to conduct inquiries - Rule of strict construction and of ejusdem generis cannot be applied.

The rule of ejusdem generis is applied where the words or language of which in a section is in continuation and where the general words are followed by specific words that relates to a specific class or category. The language of Rule 9(2), on its plain reading shows that the words are disjunctive and, therefore, this principle of interpretation would be hardly applicable to the facts of the present case. It is also incorrect to suggest, much less to argue, that under Rule 9 (2) a discreet choice is vested under the authority concerned. The Act is applicable to a special class of persons while Rules are applicable to other class of persons including Grade-A to Grade-D. Once the provisions of the Act are attracted, a public inquiry has to be held in accordance with the provisions of the Act. The Rules and the Act, as self-contained Codes within themselves, operate in a way without impinging upon the field of the other. There is hardly any discretion vested in the competent authority, it is only for the purposes of conducting an inquiry personally or through some other appointed authority that the discretion is vested. In the event of delegation by the competent authority, the delegatee authority has to function within the limit of the authority delegated to it. Neither in the Rules nor in the provisions of the Act which are independent in their application, there is any requirement or even suggestion that appointment of an authority or Board has to be essentially of a person in service, even a former employee could be so appointed. [Para 36,37]

heading: Contextual constitution
Rule as to
HeadNote.description:
Contextual constitution - Rule as to - Can be applied for construction of R.9(2) - Legislative background and object of both the Rules and Public Servants Enquiries Act is not indicative of any implied bar in appointment of former employees as Inquiry Officers.

It will be useful to apply the rule of contextual interpretation to the provisions of Rule 9. It would not be permissible to import any meaning or make additions to the plain and simple language of Rule 9(2) in relation to "other authority." The rule of contextual interpretation requires that the court should examine every word of statute in its context, while keeping in mind the preamble of the statute, other provisions thereof, pari materia statutes, if any, and the mischief intended to be remedied. Context often provides a key to the meaning of the word and the sense it carries. It is also a well established and cardinal principle of construction that when the rules and regulations have been framed dealing with different aspects of the service of the employees, the Courts would attempt to make a harmonious construction and try to save the provision, not strike it down rendering the provision ineffective. The Court would normally adopt an interpretation which is in line with the purpose of such regulations. The rule of contextual interpretation can be purposefully applied to the language of Rule 9(2), particularly to examine the merit in the contentions raised by respondent before us. The legislative background and the object of both the Rules and the Act is not indicative of any implied bar in appointment of former employees as Inquiry Officers.   [Para 38]

heading: Enquiries of public servants
HeadNote.description:
Enquiries of public servants - Practice of appointing former employees as Inquiry Officers - Not opposed to any statutory provision or public policy - No harm in applying it.

A practice adopted for a considerable time, which is not violative of the Constitution or otherwise bad in law or against public policy can be termed good in law as well. It is a settled principle of law, that practice adopted and followed in the past and within the knowledge of the public at large, can legitimately be treated as good practice acceptable in law. What has been part of the general functioning of the authority concerned can safely be adopted as good practice, particularly, when such practices are clarificatory in nature and have been consistently implemented by the concerned authority, unless it is in conflict with the statutory provisions or principal document. A practice which is uniformly applied and is in the larger public interest may introduce an element of fairness. A good practice of the past can even provide good guidance for future. This accepted principle can safely be applied to a case where the need so arises, keeping in view the facts of that case. There can be hardly any doubt that the practice of appointing former employees had been implemented for quite some time in the Department. We are unable to see how this practice is opposed to any statutory provision or even public policy. To bar such a practice, there has to be a specific prohibition under the statutory provisions, then alone the argument raised could have some merit.	 [Para 42,43]

heading: Expression "other authority" under R.9(2)
HeadNote.description: Expression "other authority" under R.9(2) - Person engaged for purpose of performing delegated functions - Would be "other authority" - Appointment of enquiry officer - No specific exclusion of retired employee of Govt. - Court cannot introduce that element by implication - Circular issued by Railway in 1998 permitting appointment of former employees to be inquiry officers - Is only supplementary R.9(2) and not in conflict with its language.			(Paras 29, 30, 37, 40)

heading: Expressions "public servant" and "other authority"
HeadNote.description:
Expressions "public servant" and "other authority" - Not interchangeable or synonymous.

The expression "public servant" cannot be equated to the term "other authority". Both these expressions cannot be treated as inter-changeable or synonymous. They have different connotations and meaning in law. "Public servant" is a term which is well defined and explained in the field of law, while "authority" is a generic term and is used in different places with different meanings and purposes. 'Authority' thus is an expression of wide magnitude and is frequently used not only in legal jurisprudence but also in administrative and executive field. Therefore, it is not permissible to permit restricted meaning of this term. [Para 33]

heading: Disciplinary enquiry
HeadNote.description: Disciplinary enquiry - Seeking advice of Central Vigilance Commission - Application for by delinquent officer - Record silent about what was the note of CVC and whether it was taken into consideration by disciplinary authority - Unless it is shown that delinquent was prejudiced by non-supply of report to him Court cannot interfere.			(Paras 50-52)

heading: Disciplinary enquiry
HeadNote.description: Disciplinary enquiry - Consulting Central Vigilance Commission not mandatory - Report is also not binding in the enquiry.	(Para 54)

heading: Disciplinary enquiry
No defacto prejudice
HeadNote.description: Disciplinary enquiry - No defacto prejudice - Cannot be based on a mere apprehension or even on a reasonable suspicion - It must exist as a matter of fact and fact must be pleaded and shown by cogent documentation to be true - In its absence enquiry or punishment cannot be set aside.	(Paras 61, 63)

heading: Misconduct
Disciplinary proceeding
Procedure
HeadNote.description:
Misconduct - Disciplinary proceeding - Procedure - Procedures laid down under Rules is required to be strictly followed.

The Service Card issued to the appellant, during verification for regularization as a casual labour, was reported to be a fake one.  The disciplinary authority not being satisfied with the report merely sent a demi-official letter to the Inquiry Officer without passing any order, the file was sent back to him for giving a clear remark on every point of charges framed.  Without any further inquiry or opportunity of hearing, the Inquiry Officer opined that the service card was fake.  Punishment of removal from service was imposed by the disciplinary authority and confirmed by the Appellate Authority.  At the instance of Appellant the Central Administrative Tribunal directed reinstatement holding that the disciplinary authority having differed with the Inquiry Officer was enjoined to record reasons and own findings on the charge.  Respondent's writ petition was allowed.  In appeal, the Supreme Court ruled that the disciplinary authority being a statutory authority was bound to act within the four corners of the statute.  Inquiry Officer could not have arrived at a different finding, when no further opportunity was given to Appellant and no reason was recorded therefor.  When an employee, by reason of an alleged act of misconduct, is sought to be deprived of his livelihood, the procedures laid down under sub-rules are required to be strictly followed.  Appeal allowed with costs.  [Para 8,9,15,16]

heading: Appreciation of evidence
HeadNote.description:
Appreciation of evidence - It is permissible to look to the evidence for the purpose of ascertaining as to whether the statutory requirement had been complied with or not.

The Tribunal was entitled to consider the question as to whether the evidence led by the department was sufficient to arrive at a conclusion of guilt or otherwise of the delinquent officer. While re-appreciation of evidence is not within the domain of the Tribunal, an absurd situation emanating from the statement of a witness can certainly be taken note of. The manner in which the trap was laid, witnessed by the Head Constable and the legality of enquiry proceeding were part of decision making process and, thus, the Tribunal was entitled to consider the same. It was only for the aforementioned purpose that paragraphs 704 and 705 of the Manual have been invoked. It may be that the said instructions were for compliance of the Vigilance Department, but substantial compliance thereof was necessary, even if the same were not imperative in character. A departmental instruction cannot totally be ignored. The Tribunal was entitled to take the same into consideration alongwith other materials brought on records for the purpose of arriving at a decision as to whether normal rules of natural justice had been complied with or not.  					 [Para 20,21]

heading: Rule is imperative
HeadNote.description:
Rule is imperative - Purpose for which it is framed is clear and unambiguous - Railway servant must get an opportunity to explain circumstances appearing against him.

Sub-rule (21) of Rule 9 of the Rules is imperative.  The purpose for which the sub-rule has been framed is clear and unambiguous. The railway servant must get an opportunity to explain the circumstances appearing against him. In this case he has been denied from the said opportunity. The cumulative effect of the illegalities/irregularities were required to be taken into consideration to judge as to whether the departmental proceeding stood vitiated or not. For the aforementioned purpose, the manner in which the enquiry proceeding was conducted was required to be taken into consideration by the High Court. The trap was not conduced in terms of the Manual; the Enquiry Officer acted as a Prosecutor and not as an independent quasi judicial authority ; he did not comply with Rule 9(21) of the Rules, evidently, therefore, it was not a case where the order of the Tribunal warranted interference at the hands of the High Court.  2006(3) ALL MR 9 - Overruled.   [Para 26,28]

heading: Jurisdiction of Tribunal
Reappreciation of evidence
Departmental enquiry
Followed.						 [Para 9,10]
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of Tribunal - Reappreciation of evidence - Respondent working as Booking Supervisor allegedly indulging in malpractice of overcharging passengers while issuing tickets - Departmental enquiry - Tribunal overstepping its jurisdiction while reappreciating the evidence pertaining to the Departmental Enquiry - Tribunal rejecting evidence of the witness who watched the transaction on spacious ground that he was standing at distance of about 30 feet from the booking window - Held, in absence of evidence to show that such a distance could cause loss of visibility and audibility, out right rejection of his evidence is improper - Tribunal had no jurisdiction to reappreciate the evidence and set aside the order of Disciplinary Authority.

In the present case, the Tribunal rejected evidence of the witness who watched the transaction on spacious ground that he was standing at distance of about thirty (30) feet from the booking window. In the absence of evidence to show that such a distance could cause loss of visibility and audibility, out right rejection of his evidence is improper. Moreover, the witness blurted out about such distance by his approximation without measurement thereof.

Not only that the Tribunal has reappreciated the evidence as if it is an appellate authority but appears to have applied incorrect standard of proof for substitution of its own conclusion/finding. In Departmental Enquiry the standard of proof required is only of "preponderance of probability". There cannot be a requirement of proof beyond doubt as appears to have been expected by the Tribunal. Even in the case of a criminal trial the requirement is of proof beyond a reasonable doubt but the Tribunal appears to have applied standard of proof reaching to the hilt i.e. reaching point "beyond doubt". Needless to say the Tribunal has committed jurisdictional error while reappreciating the whole facts and reaching its own conclusions on application of erroneous yardstick of required amount of proof in the Departmental Enquiry. It follows that the findings of the Tribunal are improper and incorrect due to such wrong approach.

The Tribunal had no jurisdiction to reappreciate the evidence and set aside the order of the Disciplinary Authority. The Respondent was not prejudiced, in any way, due to non-observance of Rule 9(21) in stricto-sensu since he was fully aware of the circumstances which appeared against him and could have offered himself for examination or might have explained the circumstances through his written statement. The impugned order is liable to be set aside.  (1998)2 SCC 394 and (1996)7 SCC 509 - Followed.						 [Para 9,10]

heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - Petitioner engaged 65 casual labourers after date given by Railway Board - Penalty imposed of withholding increments for 2 years - Charge sheet against petitioner was for minor penalty - Opportunity to lead evidence was rejected on this ground - Order of Tribunal, upheld. heading: Penalty
HeadNote.description: Penalty - Petitioner engaged 65 casual labourers after date given by Railway Board - Penalty imposed of withholding increments for 2 years - Punishment depends upon number of casual labourers engaged by officers - Contention regarding quantum of punishment of petitioner as compared to other delinquent officers is liable to be rejected - Order of Tribunal, upheld. heading: Manner and mode of holding enquiry
HeadNote.description: Manner and mode of holding enquiry - Must be strictly adhered to - Departure from manner and mode laid down would be improper.								(Para 4)

heading: Punishment
HeadNote.description: Punishment - Absence from duty for some days - Punishment of removal from service is shockingly disproportionate - Held Tribunal was justified in remitting matter for reconsideration of proper punishment.			(Para 5)

heading: Removal from service

heading: Removal from service
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Removal from service - Challenge - On ground that decision of Disciplinary Authorities is result of influence exercised by Vigilance Department - Respondent-Head Booking Clerk of Railway allegedly overcharged decoy passenger by Rs.10/- and Rs.175/- found short in railway cash - Circular dated 16th May 2001 mandates Disciplinary authorities to consult Vigilance Department before imposition of punishment - Such procedure of authorising Vigilance Department which assumes role of prosecutor to participate in decision making process is in breach of principles governing conduct of departmental inquiries - It would severely affect independence of Disciplinary Authorities and also restrict application of principles of natural justice and therefore, cannot be approved - Order of remand by Tribunal for reconsideration, proper. 	(Para 5)

heading: Sale and purchase of personal property of employee while in service
HeadNote.description:
Sale and purchase of personal property of employee while in service - Duty of railway employee - A duty is cast on railway employee to give intimation about disposal of property owned by him to the authorities and prior approval is to be obtained before the disposal of the property.

Every railway servant is under a legal obligation to give prior information to the Railway Authorities about the purchase or sale of any property. The Rule clearly indicates that this requirement is applicable in the case of property standing in the name of the employee or any member of his family. The contention of the petitioner that in case of property standing in the name of HUF, it is not necessary to inform the Railway Authorities, therefore, cannot be accepted. Railway employee has to disclose the information about his property at the time of joining service which is indicated in Rule 18(1). The petitioner has been exonerated of the charge which is levelled against him under Rule 18(1) by the CAT. So far as Rule 18(2) is concerned, it is in respect of property while the employee is in service. The underlying purpose of the rule is clearly to keep the Railway Authorities informed about any transaction of purchase and sale of property while the employee is in service so as to keep a track of assets acquired or sold by the employee and further to ensure transparency in such transactions. Admittedly, the petitioner did not give prior information about the sale of flats by him in respect of his HUF property which he developed and later on sold. The contention of the petitioner that the respondent already had prior knowledge about the said development and sale of the property is not borne out of the record and the petitioner could not point out a single document to substantiate his claim. The petitioner invited our attention to the charge which was framed against him and submitted that the charge itself indicated that the respondent was aware about the said transaction. This submission of the petitioner cannot be accepted as the requirement of Rule 18(2) is that before the said transaction takes place, prior information has to be given to the railway authorities which admittedly has not been done. There is no infirmity, therefore, in the finding recorded by the Enquiry Officer which is confirmed by the appellate authority as well as by the CAT. There is neither any error of jurisdiction nor any legal error committed by the CAT and as such, there is no reason to interfere with the finding recorded by the Tribunal.  (1997)9 SCC 31 - Ref. to.  [Para 14]

heading: Enquiry report by officer of R P F under S.8
HeadNote.description:
Enquiry report by officer of R P F under S.8 - It is merely a complaint within meaning of S.2(d) and not a report under S.173 of Code.

An officer conducting an inquiry under Section 8(1) of the Act has not been invested with all powers of an officer incharge of a police station making an investigation under Chapter XIV of the Code.  He has no power to file a charge sheet before the Magistrate concerned under Section 173 of the Code. The main purpose of the Act was to invest powers of investigation and prosecution of an offence relating to Railway property in the RPF in the same manner as in a case relating to the offences under the law dealing with excise and customs. The offences under the Act are non-cognizable which cannot be investigated by a police officer under the Code. The result is that initiation of inquiry for an offence inquired into under this Act can be only on the basis of a complaint by an officer of the Force, as was actually done in this case. 		 [Para 8]

HeadNote.description: Correction of date of birth - At fag end of service - Permissibility - Petitioner has given his birth date as 11/05/1957 at the time of appointment - In PAN Card/Aadhar Card his birth date mentioned as 11/05/1957 - At the fag end of his service petitioner seeking direction to take entry of his birth on 06/07/1960 - Provisions of S.13(3) of Registration of Births and Deaths Act are not for getting adjudication of disputed date of birth of the aggrieved party - Appropriate remedy for petitioner is to get declaration from Civil Court as to correct date of his birth - At the fag end of service the person is not entitled to seek his birth date to be corrected - Correction of date of birth, not permissible. 	(Para 7)

HeadNote.act_name: Registration of Births and Deaths Act (1969)
heading: Correction in birth certificate
HeadNote.description:
Correction in birth certificate - Entry of name of step-father replacing name of biological father - Permissibility.

A bare perusal of the provision of S.15 of Registration of Births and Deaths Act shows that the applicant has to prove to the satisfaction of the Registrar about the error in the entry of a birth or death in form or substance which may crept in fraudulently or improperly, which can be corrected or cancelled by the Registrar by making suitable entry in the margin but without any alteration of the original entry and he shall sign the marginal entry and add thereto the date of the correction or cancellation.

In the instant case the entry in the Birth Certificate of the petitioner, which was conveyed to the authorities on 23.10.1993 about birth of the petitioner on 05.10.1993 out of the wedlock of his biological parents is neither recorded fraudulently or improperly and is also not erroneous in form or substance. The mother of the petitioner has only divorced his biological father and after remarriage he has become the step-son of his step-father, who cannot replace the biological father but the things would have been different had it been a case of adoption because as per Section 12 of the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956.

Perusal of S.9 of 1956 Act it transpires that even if there is a divorce between biological parents of the petitioner, in the presence of the biological father, the step-father of the petitioner cannot give the petitioner in adoption with his biological mother. Even under Section 8 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, the step-son is neither Class-I nor Class-II heir.

Thus, from the aforesaid discussion, it transpires that correction in the Birth Certificate in the Register of Births and Deaths of the adoptive parents can be made if it is proved to the satisfaction of the Registrar, that too in accordance with the other terms and conditions mentioned in Section 15 of the Act but the entry of a step-father, replacing the name of the biological father in the Birth Certificate maintained under the Act, cannot be made. 	 [Para 8,9,13,14]

headline:
Railway Claims Tribunal Act 1987, S.23 –Untoward accident- Compensation- Entitlement -As per affidavit by claimant-Wife, deceased travelling in train w/ticket; died by falling down from running train
Burden of proof whether deceased bona fide passenger on Railways –Contradiction between testimony of Loco Pilot & Station Master-No evidence that deceased crossed railway track & runover- Entitled for compensation.

heading: Untoward accident
Compensation
Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Untoward accident - Compensation - Entitlement - Affidavit filed by claimant-wife of deceased shows that deceased was travelling in train with ticket and died due to untoward incident of falling down from running train - Burden of proof whether deceased was bona fide passenger was on Railways - Testimony of Loco Pilot that one unknown person was runover by the train - But the testimony of Station Master that Loco Pilot informed him that dead body of one unknown person was lying on the railway track - Such contradictory testimony cannot be relied on - No evidence on record that deceased was crossing the railway track and was runover by train - Claimants entitled for compensation. (Paras 15, 17, 18)

heading: Condonation
Same was dismissed
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing petition - Condonation - Claim petition filed with delay of 594 days - Explanation given as to severe head injuries and long-time continuing treatment - Same was dismissed - Claimant filed restoration application, with delay of 211 days - Same explanation was given and again application was rejected - Thereafter review application filed, again with delay of 365 days - Apart from similarity of reason, Tribunal also referred to injuries of claimant and observed that they are non-scheduled injuries, uncovered by Railways Act and Rules - Approach of Tribunal not sustainable - Whether injuries suffered by claimant are covered by Act and Rules, can be decided only on merits - Not in interlocutory application - Explanation as to long-time continuing treatment had to be considered in view of severe head injuries - Beneficial legislation not to be interpreted technically - Order of rejection set aside - Tribunal directed to decide claim on merits. 			(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Railway accident
Compensation
Denial
HeadNote.description:
Railway accident - Compensation - Denial - On ground that there is no eye witness to prove that deceased actually fell down from train - However, dead body of deceased found on track itself along with valid ticket - Nature of injuries mentioned in panchanama also shows that deceased died due to accidental fall from train - Denial of compensation, not justified. 
2008(5) ALL MR 917 (S.C.) Foll. (Para 12)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Compensation - Deceased while travelling from Nagpur to Chandur Railway station, was standing near door as the train was overcrowded - Due to sudden jerk, he fell down from running train and died on spot - No journey ticket found with him or on spot of incident - Finding of Tribunal that deceased was not bonafide passenger and he was ran over by train since body was found in pieces - Evidence of friend of deceased that in his presence, deceased entered in train having journey ticket - Ticket might have been lost in train and that itself is not ground to deny claim - No evidence to show that deceased was crossing railway track and therefore, he was ran over by coming train - Written statement and Investigation report submitted by Railway Authority shows that deceased was travelling in train standing in door of compartment and fell down from train due to his own negligence - This clearly reveals that deceased was travelling in train - Negligence cannot be ground to deny claim - Direction issued to pay compensation to claimants. 2010(5) ALL MR 986 (S.C.), 2018 ALL SCR 1750 Rel. on. 2018(7) ALL MR 311 Disting. (Paras 12, 15, 16, 18, 21, 22, 23, 24)

heading: Untoward incident
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Untoward incident - Compensation - Deceased died as he fell down while boarding passenger train - Railway authority claiming that deceased was not having valid ticket - Evidence of shopkeeper that he along with deceased came to railway counter for purchasing ticket and after getting card ticket, deceased kept it inside pocket - Widow of deceased also corroborated evidence of shopkeeper - Deceased was holding valid ticket - Merely because of non-production of ticket purchased by passenger, claim for compensation cannot be refused - Further, there was no evidence to prove that incident occurred while train was moving as alleged by railway authorities - Order granting compensation, proper. 			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Appeal u/S.23
HeadNote.description: Appeal u/S.23 - Payment of court fee - Said appeal arising out of application u/S.16(1) r/w S.13(1-A) of Railway Claims Tribunal Act - Appellant not challenging award but only seeking enhancement of compensation - Court fee would be payable as per Art.13 of Sch.II of Court Fees Act - Art.3 of Sch.I of said Act would not apply. 1991(1) Mh.L.J. 823 Disting.
